inputs.context:
In response to these adverse threats to the eco-region the Oromia Regional Government has attempted to
take concrete actions in recent years through policy and institutional development reforms. Establishment of
Oromia Forest and Wildlife Enterprise (OFWE) is one of these concrete actions taken. However, capacity
and resources are still major limiting factors for OFWE to achieve significant outcome in improved
management of the forests and associated natural resources in the eco-region. This BMERP is designed to
create a sustainable financing mechanism to help government and local communities build capacity and fill
critical resource gaps to bring meaningful changes in the management of natural resources and forests in
the eco-region.
The BMERP will build itself on works under implementation in the eco-region. From 2007 - 2012, Farm
Africa/ SOS Sahel Ethiopia in partnership with the Oromia Forest and Wildlife Enterprise implemented the
Bale Eco-Region Sustainable Management Programme (BERSMP), supported by the Netherlands,
Norwegian and Irish Embassies in Ethiopia. The programme aimed to contribute to the conservation and
sustainable development of the unique biodiversity and ecological functions of the greater Bale Mountains
Eco-region, whilst establishing and enhancing sustainable local livelihoods. The idea was to involve local
communities into a central role in the sustainable management of the area, and as the natural resource
management leaders, supported by government services, across the whole Bale Massif. The Bale
Mountains Eco-Region REDD+ initiative started as part of the bigger programme to address the financial
sustainability of the programme.
Figure 13. Agricultural frontiers expansion into moist forest of Harenna, Bale Eco-Region
There has been little active or effective management of natural resources in the area. Unsustainable
exploitation and degradation throughout the eco-region is increasingly threatening the natural resources
thereby the livelihoods of the local people that directly dependent on them as well as the very survival of a
unique biodiversity resources whose economic potential as a basis for tourism in particular remains
unfulfilled. Under business as usual, the3 eco-region will be on the verge of significant degradation
threatening not only the unique biodiversity of the area but livelihoods of millions of community that directly
and indirectly depend on goods and services from the eco-region. Action should be taken urgently to save
this globally important ecosystem.
1.4 Project Proponent G1.1
The BMERP proponent is the Oromia Forest and Wildlife Enterprise (OFWE), an autonomous fully
government-owned enterprise, established with regulation number 122/2009 issued in July 2009 by the
Oromia State Council under the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia. The Oromia Forest and Wildlife
Enterprise owns concession for all of the forests and regionally administered wildlife related conservation
area in Oromia State. The concession area of OFWE covers a total of 367,700 Km2.
OFWE’s mission is to undertake conservation, sustainable development and utilization of the forest and
wildlife resources in its concessions through community participation; ensure supply of forest products
markets and services to domestic and international markets by enhancing forest industry; and subsequently
contribute to the regional and national socio-economic development endeavours.
33

The project proponent, OFWE, is currently responsible for the management of all forests in Oromia regional
state of Ethiopia. The forests were given to OFWE by concession to administer and manage it. OFWE has 9
branch enterprises, where Bale Mountains REDD+ mountains REDD+ project fall in two of the forest
enterprises: Arsi and Bale branches. The two branch enterprises with the OFWE headquarter support will be
responsible for the implementation of the BMERP.
In line with this they will perform the following:
 developing work plans and budgets
 implementation of activities such as law enforcement, community nursery establishment and
management
 support community forest management groups in the implementation of participatory forest
management
 closely work with legal bodies to enforce law
 ensure participation of other government agencies such as the office of agriculture, energy, etc in
the project implementation
 coordination of involvement of non-governmental organizations
OFWE staff profile:
OFWE has a total of3543 staffs working in the different branch offices and districts, out of which 117 staffs
are directly related to the Bale Eco-Region. These are working in two of the branch offices in Bale and West
Arsi within which the Bale eco-region forests fall.
Besides their professional background and skill in forest and biodiversity management the Bale REDD+
project has also provided series of training to build the capacity of the OFWE in REDD+ project management
and implementation. The Bale and Arsi branch office OPFWE staff were the one that conducted the forest
inventory work for the development of this PDD as well.
The Bale REDD+ piloting project (2012-2015) has also developed and is implementing Government and
Community staff capacity building plan (Government and community capacity building plan supplementary
material 25).
Farm Africa and SOS Sahel-Ethiopia, who supported OFWE in the development of the Bale REDD+ pilot
project and this PDD are also supporting the proponent in implementing the project activities until 2015, and
beyond through their current projects such as Bale REDD+ pilot project and SHARE projects (additional
documents enclosed as references). This will also strengthen the proponent in developing additional
capacity.

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03  
 
CDM – Executive Board     Page 3  
 
 
Environment well being: 
• Reduction in the consumption of fossil fuels:  The installation of power plant generating 
electricity through utilization of renewable res ource such as wind power, would lead to reduction 
in usage of fossil fuels such as coal. 
• Reduction in emission of GHG: The reduction in usage of fossil fuels for electricity generation 
will result in reduction of the release of associated GHG  emissions (CO 2 and CH 4 emissions).  
• Improvement of Air Quality: The use of renewable energy for power generation will avoid the 
emission of air pollutants such as Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM), Sulphur Dioxide (SO 2) 
and Nitrogen Oxides (NO x) thereby improvising the surrounding air quality  
• Conservation of Natural Resources: Installation of wind power plant will result in conserving 
fast depleting natural resources such as coal, oil etc.  
 
Economic well being: 
• Rural Development:  The installation of wind power project will result in rural and 
infrastructural development in the surrounding rural areas 
• Economic Development:  The generation of wind power will result in improvising the reliability 
of the Southern Grid and thereby enha nce economic development in the region. 
 
Social well being: 
• Generating Local Employment: The installation of wind power project in rural areas will result 
in generating local employment opportunities and capacity building of the local employees. 
• Encouragement to entrepreneurs:  The project will provide encouragement to other 
entrepreneurs to invest into renewable energy sources. 
 
Technological well being: 
• The project activity involves the successful installa tion and operation of state-of-art wind turbine 
generators (WTGs) of Vestas make. The implem entation of these new technologies will help in 
increasing reliability on efficient technology and large capacity wind mills. 
 
Community Development:  
Powerica would use, at a minimum, 2% of the revenues accrued from the sale of Certified Emission 
Reductions (CERs) on an annual basis for commun ity related activities. These may include providing 
assistance for development of public amen ities in the surrounding areas such as water 
distribution/sanitation facilities/building of School a nd Hospital/ free distribution of educational books 
and school uniforms/annual eye camps/health check up centres for villagers etc.  If the activity undertaken involves capital expenditure  exceeding the minimum requirement of 2%, the 
additional expenditure made would be setoff against the requirements for the subsequent years. Such 
expenditure would be made within one year after th e realization of revenues from the sale of the CERs. 
Monitoring plan proposed for the expenditure is included in Annex 4 of the PDD.

Kaizhou District is located in the northeast of Chongqing, north of the Yangtze River, in the
combination of the southern slope of the Daba Mountains and the parallel ridge and valley of
Chongqing.Itliesbetween107°55′48′′to108°54′Eand30°49′30″to31°41′30″N,withatotal

to the north, Yunyang County and Wuxi County to the east and Wanzhou District to the south.

decreasingfromnortheasttosouthwest.

The project aims to increasethe carbon sequestration and to contribute to local sustainable development through plantingtrees on the degraded land or degraded mountain. The project proponent is National Forestry andGrassland Administration Northwest Investigation and Planning Institute (hereafter “the projectproponent”).\r\n3,407.34 ha of forest has been planted by direct planting on degraded land and degradedmountain in Kaizhou district, there are 6 main species selected as designated tree species, theyare Cunninghamia lanceolata, Phoebe zhennan, Cupressus funebris, Acer spp., Idesia polycarpa,Houpoea officinalis, the planted trees are all native species. The implementation of theafforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and improve the Kaizhou district’slocal environment, enhance the capabilities of local communities and residents by providing themwith relevant technical skills and training and increase local biodiversity as a result ofestablishing a forest of native trees.', 'project_state_province': 'Chongqing', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 31.31, 'project_longitude': 108.28}

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is based on the application of approved methodologies Version 19 of AMS-I.C titled "Thermal energy production with or without electricity" and Version 03 of AMS-III.R titled "Methane recovery in agricultural activities at household/small farm level". These methodologies provide guidelines and criteria for the implementation of projects that involve the production of thermal energy using renewable energy technologies and the recovery of methane in agricultural activities. The project applies these methodologies to assess the applicability of renewable energy technologies that supply users with thermal energy and displaces fossil fuel use. It also considers biomass-based co-generating systems that produce heat and electricity, excluding those that produce heat and power in separate processes. The project aims to achieve emission reductions through activities such as electricity supply to a grid.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector for this project is Agriculture, specifically Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land Management (ALM).
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Hulin within Jixi City, Heilongjiang Province of China, with a total
acreage of 20,206 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project,
which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded
method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded
method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition
can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the 4
intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase
and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 2.92 tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to
413,462 tCO e in the first 7 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 2
59,066tCO e. 2
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
Agricultural Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is
1 Dr. Reiner Wassmann (2016). Coordinator, Climate Change Research. International Rice Research
Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org
4

So, this\nproject can be categorized as eligible ALM\nactivity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within the 10 years period prior to\nthe project start date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.2'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems\nby increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil\nN O emissions, and/or reducing CH\n2 4\nemissions.', 'This project practices intermittent flooded\nmethod on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH emissions. methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice

The project activity follows all the legislation and it is not mandatory to take up wind project activity.
Contribution of the project activity to sustainable development
The project primarily assists the state of Karnataka and India as a whole in stimulating and accelerating the
commercialization of grid connected renewable energy technologies. In addition to this, wind power
projects like this demonstrates the viability of grid connected wind farms, which improve energy security,
air quality and local livelihoods, as well as assisting the development of a domestic sustainable renewable
energy industry. The specific goals of the project are:
(cid:127) Sustainable development through generation of eco-friendly power;
(cid:127) Increasing the share of renewable energy power generation in the regional and national grid;
(cid:127) To bridge India’s energy deficit in the business as usual scenario;
(cid:127) Providing national energy security, especially when global fossil fuel reserves threaten the long term
sustainability of the Indian economy;
(cid:127) Strengthening India’s rural electrification coverage;
· Essentially reducing GHG emissions compared to a business-as-usual scenario;
(cid:127) Reducing other pollutants (SO , NO , PM, etc.) resulting from power generation industry; x x
(cid:127) Contribute towards reducing power shortage especially in the state of Karnataka, India;
(cid:127) Demonstrate and help in stimulating the growth of the wind power industry in India;
(cid:127) Enhancing local employment in the vicinity of the project, which is a rural area;
(cid:127) Capacity building and empowerment of vulnerable sections of the rural communities dwelling in the
project area;
(cid:127) Power generation from Renewable Energy sources paves way for energy security of future
generations;
(cid:127) Conserving natural resources including land, forests, minerals, water and ecosystems;
The National strategy for sustainable development also aims at providing access to clean energy with the
objective that increased availability of power in the rural areas will lead to industrial activity aimed at
generating employment and reduce poverty. For these reasons, the wind power project of Savita group is
fully in line with the overall goals for sustainable development of the Government of India (GOI) and the
requirement of Karnataka state.
Ministry of Environment and Forests, Govt. of India has stipulated the social well being, economic well
being, environmental well being and technological well being as the four indicators for sustainable
development in the host country approval eligibility criteria for Clean Development Mechanism (CDM)
projects1, which is in accordance of VCS guidelines.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology used in this project is the approved consolidated baseline and monitoring methodology ACM0002 “Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources” (ACM 0002). This methodology is applicable to the project because it meets the applicability criteria of ACM0002 version 11.

The sources and gases included in the project boundary are CO2 emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel-fired power plants that are displaced due to the project. Minor emission sources such as CH4 and N2O are not included.

The monitoring plan includes the measurement of net electricity generation supplied by the project plant to the grid, which will be continuously measured and monthly recorded. The data will be archived electronically and kept during the crediting period and 2 years after. Quality assurance and quality control procedures will be applied to ensure the accuracy of the metering equipment and data management system.

Overall, the methodology and monitoring plan aim to accurately measure and verify the emission reductions achieved by the project.

B.3. Description of how the sources and gases included in the project boundary:
The proposed project is the installation of a new grid-connected renewable power plant,
and the baseline scenario is the following:
Electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been
generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new
generation sources, as reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in
the “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system”.
A project electricity system is defined by the spatial extent of the power plants that can be
dispatched without significant transmission constraints. The proposed project delivers its
electricity generated to Northeast China Power Grid. The spatial extent of the project boundary
includes the proposed project and all power plants connected physically to the Northeast China
Power Grid that the CDM project power plant is connected to. The grid boundaries definition was
1 used with DNA guidance . For the proposed project, the Northeast China Power Grid was as the
project’s system boundary. The Northeast China Power Grid is net electricity export grid.

boundary are shown in the following table:

1.11 Identification of risks that may substantially affect the project’s GHG emission
reductions or removal enhancements
The risks that may affect the project’s GHG emission reductions are given below:
A. Wind electricity generation is risky and unpredictable due to the variability involved in
wind resources as well as its forecasting. This variability is due to the variability in the
wind speed and wind pattern, which in turn depends on weather cycle, climatic
conditions, etc.
B. The project is dependent on the utility provider for grid availability. If there is a grid
failure, the project will be unable to supply the generated electricity to the grid.

emissions primarily for the purpose of its subsequent removal or destruction.

produce any GHG emissions. The project activity has not been implemented to create GHG
emissions for the purpose of the subsequent removal or destruction of GHG emissions.

Project Summary: The Tibet Ngari Improved Grassland Management Project aims to restore the degraded grassland ecosystem in Ngari Region, Tibet Autonomous Region, China. The project involves reseeding native grasses, implementing grazing management practices, and promoting local development. It covers a total area of 373,467.02 hectares and includes measures such as rest grazing, grazing prohibition, and black soil beach restoration.

Province: Tibet Autonomous Region

Country: China

Latitude: Not mentioned

Longitude: Not mentioned
inputs.context:
CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Tibet Ngari Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in
Ngari Region, Tibet Autonomous Region, China. Ngari is located in the southwest border of
China, the west of Tibet Autonomous Region and the north of Qinghai Tibet Plateau (Qiangtang
plateau). The objective of the project is to restore the "black soil beach14" and degraded
grassland ecosystem through reseeding native grasses and grazing management, such as rest
grazing and grazing prohibition, increase carbon sequestration, and promote local development.
The project proponent is National Forestry and Grassland Administration Northwest Investigation
and Planning Institute.
The project area is located in Ngari, covering Gar County, Burang County, Zanda County, Rutog
County, Gê'gyai County, Gêrzê County and Coqên County. According to the Participatory Rural
Appraisal (PRA) report. Before the implementation of the project, there were severely degradation
and desertification of the grasslands in this area due to the impact of climate change and human
activities, some grassland even degenerated into "black soil beach", the excellent forages in the
plant community almost disappeared, and the natural reproduction and renewal ability was very
low. According to the Parameters for Degradation, Desertification and Salinization of Rangeland
(GB19377-2003) in China15, moderately degraded grassland areas refer to the total grass yield
decreased by 21%-50% compared with that before degradation and the total grass yield
decreased by more than 50% compared with that before degradation is regarded as severely
degraded grasslands.
Totally, 373,467.02 ha of degraded grassland in Ngari have been managed sustainably including
rest grazing and grazing prohibition by fence building and seeding of local high-quality forage.
There are three main restoration measures as followed in the project:
(1) Rest grazing was implemented in moderately degraded grassland areas where grass yield
was 130-190kg/Mu 16 which decreased by 21-50% compared with the non-degraded
grassland. It is required that grazing shall not be allowed within 120 days when the grass
turns green every year (from 01-May to 31-August) through the construction of fence and
sustainable management. Through the implementation of rest grazing, 322,770.02 ha of
degraded grassland were managed sustainably.
(2) Grazing prohibition was implemented in seriously degraded grasslands where grass yield
less than 130 Kg/Mu which decreased by more than 50% compared with the non-degraded
grassland. Fence building shall be carried out in the grazing prohibition area. When the
construction is completed, grazing prohibition shall be implemented for 5 years. After that,
14 "Black soil beach" is an extreme type of grassland degradation caused by overgrazing, human factors, rat and
insect damage, climate warming and other factors.
15GB19377-2003 is a national standard document of the people's Republic of China which issued by The Ministry of
Agriculture and Rural Affairs to assess the level of degradation, desertification and salinization of natural grassland.
The original website of the standard is
http://c.gb688.cn/bzgk/gb/showGb?type=online&hcno=5F1960D0692A36C09136E04E6DE60B4E
16 1ha=15 Mu
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 9

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
under the premise of not affecting the normal growth of the improved grassland, the
grassland should be used reasonably and sustainably according to the local approved
livestock carrying capacity. For the project, totally 40,801.00 ha of degraded grassland have
been managed sustainably by grazing prohibition.
(3) Black soil beach restoration was implemented in moderately degraded grassland areas
where grass yield was less than 150 Kg/Mu and the proportion of bare patches in grassland
exceeds 40% which decreased by 21%-50% compared with the non-degraded grassland.
Reseeding grass, scientific fertilization and irrigation are carried out to restore grassland
vegetation greatly based on rodent and pest control on the "black soil beach" degraded
grassland in the project area. After reseeding the grass, the project area needs to be fenced
for 3 years to better restore grassland vegetation. Then under the premise of not affecting the
normal growth of the improved grassland, the grassland should be used reasonably and
sustainably according to the local approved livestock carrying capacity. The grass seeds
sowed were local high-quality forage such as Elymus nutans (Drooping tassel grass). In the
project, 9,896.00 ha of "black soil" degraded grassland have been reseeded grass.
In addition to these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and
restores grassland vegetation through grassland management measures to improve soil carbon
storage and local biodiversity, supplemented by daily management measures of other protection
projects, such as grassland fire prevention and rodent control, so as to ensure long-term
sustainable management of the project area. The project is estimated to generate GHG emission
removals of 11,698,413 tCO e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 2
292,460 tCO e. 2
The objectives of the project including:
Climate: Restore the degraded grassland ecosystem, increase grassland coverage, increase
grassland carbon sink function and reduce GHG emissions.
Community: Improve the livelihood of local herders, provide permanent and temporary job
opportunities for them, increase their income. Provide technical skills and training in sustainable
grassland management. Protect the sacred mountains (Kang Rinpoche) and holy waters (Lake
Manasarovar) widely respected by the Tibetan people which is conducive to the protection and
development of Tibet's traditional Zhangzhung culture. Zhangzhung culture is the traditional
culture of the Tibetan people, also known as the basic culture of Tibet. The traces of ancient
Zhangzhung culture run through all aspects of Tibet. From production to life, from folk custom17 to
belief, there is the shadow of Zhangzhung culture everywhere. For example, religious activities
such as offering sacrifices to mountain gods and turning mountains18 are all derived from the
Zhangzhung culture.
Biodiversity: Provide more suitable habitats for wild animals and increase local biodiversity.
17 The ancient Zhangzhung Buddha dharma occupies the supreme position in the traditional culture of ancient
Zhangzhung culture. It is the oldest Buddha Dharma in Tibet, the oldest Buddha Dharma in human history, and the
general source of all Buddha dharmas
18 A way for Tibetans to show piety
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 10

Project Summary: The Manoa REDD+ Project is a sustainable forest management project located in Manoa Farm in the cities of Cujubim, Itapoã do Oeste, and Porto Velho, state of Rondônia, Northern Brazil. The project aims to avoid the emission of 279.290 tons of CO2e per year or 8.378.697 tons of CO2e along 30 years by preventing deforestation of approximately 22.118 hectares. It also focuses on community benefits such as training local stakeholders on sustainable economic development, supporting the development of associations of small local rural producers, and improving the quality of life for the local population. Biodiversity benefits include the conservation of flora and fauna species, including mammals and birds in threat. The project location is accessed through BR-364 highway, Porto Velho-Ariquemes, and covers an area of 74,038.7 hectares.

Province: Rondônia

Country: Brazil

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION
VCS Version 3, CCB Standards Third Edition
Climate Benefits
Avoid the emission of 279.290 tons of CO2e per year or 8.378.697 tons of CO2e along 30 years
of project. This corresponds to 22.118 hectares of avoided deforestation.
Community Benefits:
The main objectives of the project for the community include the training of local stakeholders on
issues related to sustainable economic development and the valorization of forest resources; Support to
the development of associations of small local rural producers aiming at the social empowerment of these
actors; And to members of neighboring associations of the project area and the young and university
public of the state of Rondônia. These actions aim at improving the quality of life of this population, social
empowerment, the strengthening of small farmers and the dissemination of practices of sustainable
development in the region.
In the labor aspect of the property, it is expected the dissemination of knowledge about labor
rights and rules to its employees and collaborators, environmental education workshops and the support
in the training of skilled labor to operate in the supplychain of certified forest management and non-wood
forest management.
Biodiversity Benefits:
Maintenance of forest coverage, preventing deforestation of approximately 12,000 hectares along
30 years of project. Conservation of 177 of flora and more than 360 fauna identified species. Out of these
species, 12 are mammals and 9 are birds in some type of threat, according to IUCN. Maintenance of
"ecological corridors" with Conservation Units of the state of Rondônia, reducing negative impacts of the
region degradation.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology used in this project is ACM0002 version 12.1.0, which is the "Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources". This methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation projects, including installations of new power plants, capacity additions, retrofits of existing plants, or replacements of existing plants.

The methodology is chosen because it is applicable to the proposed project activity, which is the installation of a grid-connected wind power plant. It meets the conditions of being a Greenfield plant and involves capacity addition.

The methodology utilizes several tools, including AM_Tool_01 for the demonstration and assessment of additionality, AM_Tool_07 to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system, and others that are not applicable to this specific project.

The methodology does not apply to projects involving switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources or biomass-fired power plants. It also does not apply to hydro power plants that result in new reservoirs or increased reservoirs with a power density of less than 4 W/m2.

The project boundary includes the spatial boundary of the project activity.

SECTION B. Application of a baseline and monitoring methodology
B.1. Title and reference of the approved baseline and monitoring methodology applied to the
project activity:
>>
Methodology
• ACM0002 version 12.1.0 “Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity
generation from renewable sources” (EB58 Annex 7, 26 November 2010, version 12 valid from 17
Sep 2010 onwards)
The methodology refers to the following tools
• AM_Tool_01 version 05.2 “Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality”
• AM_Tool_02 version 02.2 “Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate
additionality” (this tool is not applicable to the project)
• AM_Tool_03 version 02 “Tool to calculate project or leakage CO emissions from fossil fuel 2
combustion” (this tool is not applicable to the project)
• AM_Tool_07 version 02 “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system”
B.2. Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it is applicable to the project
activity:
>>
This methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation project activities that (a)
install a new power plant at a site where no renewable power plant was operated prior to the
implementation of the project activity (Greenfield plant); (b) involve a capacity addition; (c) involve a
retrofit of (an) existing plant(s); or (d) involve a replacement of (an) existing plant(s).
Therefore, the methodology is applicable as the Proposed Project Activity is the installation of a
Greenfield, grid-connected wind power plant (a).
The methodology is applicable under the following conditions:

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is not explicitly mentioned in the given information. However, based on the provided details, this project is related to the energy industry and specifically wind power. It is a single project undertaken by Guodian Linghai Wind Power Co., Ltd. The project started on January 1, 2009, and the crediting period is from January 1, 2009, to April 1, 2011. The estimated greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions or removals for each year are provided: 116,862 tCO2e for 2009, 116,862 tCO2e for 2010, and 1,280 tCO2e for 2011. The total estimated emission reductions (ERs) for the project are 235,004 tCO2e over the course of three years. The project is located in Shengli Village, Dayou County, Linghai City, Liaoning Province, People's Republic of China.

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Suicheng District and Huanglo Town within Suixi County,
Zhanjiang City, Guangdong Province of China, with a total acreage of 6,545 ha for double-
cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project, the continuously flooded method
would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method
is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can
emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent 4
flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane
emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 9.15 tCO e/ha for double-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 59,906 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 599,060 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
1 Dr. Reiner Wassmann (2016). Coordinator, Climate Change Research. International Rice
Research Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org
1

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
Agricultural Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is
approved under sectoral scope 15 (agriculture) of CDM, this project is categorized as
sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra.
1.3 Project Eligibility
According to the Section 2.1.1 of VCS Standard version 4.4, this project activity meets two
of the scopes of the VCS program:1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases; and 4)
Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program, unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval. Accordingly, this
project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the six Kyoto 4
Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and it is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of VCS program.
This is in accordance with the definitions of eligible AFOLU project categories set out in
Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard, 4.4 and can be demonstrated from the following three

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector described in the context is Forestry and Land Use. The project involves the establishment of vegetative cover to improve soil and water conservation, as well as the assessment of forest and non-forest areas using satellite imagery.
inputs.context:
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
function of the remaining extant forest cover within the project area as well as the establishment of a
vegetative cover to minimize the intensity of desiccating winds, improve soil and water conservation.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14 Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU), under the category of
Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR). The project is a stand alone project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The eligibility analysis is performed for each of the compartments currently planted, considering the
year of establishment and the 10 previous years. This analysis evaluates the non-stable forest during
this period, which will be selected as the eligible area and the remaining areas will be defined as
ineligible areas. Landsat 7 and 8 medium-resolution multispectral images were used to obtain forest
and non-forest coverage through supervised classification.
Forest definition for the country3 and the project area are indicated as areas greater than 0.5 ha, with a
canopy density higher than 10% and a tree height above 5 m. Non-forest areas are composed of the
remaining areas, not meeting this definition.
Eligibility period: The project has planted areas between the years 2016 and 2019, therefore, the
period of eligibility includes the pairs of years: 2006 - 2016, 2007 - 2017, 2008 - 2018 and 2009 -
2019.
Eligibility analysis:
This analysis consists of i) the acquisition of Landsat 7 and 8 multispectral image data; ii) the
correction of multispectral images, iii) land cover classification; iv) classification accuracy, v) final layer
of forest and non-forest classification, and vi) final eligibility analysis, summing up the stable non forest
areas for each period Figure 1 summarizes the eligibility analysis methodology.
Figure 1 Eligibility analysis steps

VCS Project Description Template
The project site is located at 29o 01" N latitude and 770 45” E longitudes.
The project is located 32 km from district headquarter Meerut on the Meerut-Baraut road. The
nearest railway station is Meerut and nearest airport is Delhi Airport.
1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
The Project Activity Start Date is 23rd January, 2006 which is the commissioning date of the
turbine and boiler. This is the date on which the project activity began displacing Greenhouse
gases (GHGs) emissions into the atmosphere.
Crediting period start date:
The crediting period start date is 01/04/2006.
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
The project activity is a Greenfield project activity. It has been taken up at the new 160 KLPD
distillery unit at Kinauni, Meerut. In the absence of the project activity the PP would have
treated the spent wash in an anaerobic open lagoon and imported the electricity from the grid.
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG
emission reductions and/or removal enhancements:
The project activity involves treatment of the spent-wash in the anaerobic reactor and
capturing the generated biogas and also the utilization of captured biogas along with bagasse
for generation of steam and electricity. It is assumed that CO emissions from surplus biomass 2
do not lead to changes of carbon pools in the Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry
(LULUCF) sector.
In the absence of the project activity the Project Proponent (PP) would have treated the spent
wash in the anaerobic open lagoon system which would have resulted in emission of methane
enriched biogas into the atmosphere. In the absence of the project activity the PP would have
generated the steam by firing bagasse/biomass in a low pressure boiler and imported the
electricity from the grid. Thus, the generation of power in the project activity would result in
displacement of equivalent electricity generation in the grid and its associated CO emission. 2
Hence the Project activity reduces the CH4 emissions into the atmosphere that would have
been emitted from the treatment of the spent wash through open lagoon system and also
displaces the equivalent amount of electricity generation from the fossil fuel based grid
connected power plant and its associated GHG emissions
1.9 Project technologies, products, services and the
expected level of activity:

Turbine

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
During the construction period, Chongqing Gengfang Agricultural Development Co., Ltd.
(hereinafter "Chongqing Gengfang”) invested and cooperated with Agricultural and Rural
Committee of Tongnan District in the construction of ditches and reservoirs, while the local
farmers were hired to build the ditches and reservoirs. During the operation period, Chongqing
Gengfang is responsible for supervising technicians to patrol and maintain the ditches and
reservoirs. Furthermore, as the owner of the rice paddies, these farmers have right to authorize
Chongqing Gengfang as a representative of the carbon project owner and Chongqing Gengfang
has overall control and responsibility for the carbon project as the project proponent without
violating farmers’ right. Search Co2 was entrusted and appointed by Chongqing Gengfang as the
developer of rice emission reduction project. Therefore, Search Co2 has played two roles in
developing carbon reduction project.
Firstly, Search Co2 is the consultant which is responsible for helping the project proponent with
development and management of the carbon project, including compiling the monitoring plan,
organizing the training, etc. Secondly, Search Co2 is the purchaser, so it has right of speech for
marketing. Although Chonngqing Gengfang has already sold the carbon emission reduction
generated by this project to Search Co2, it does not affect Chonngqing Gengfang’s rights and
obligations as the project proponent.
1.8 Project Start Date
According to VCS standard, the project start date is the date on which activities that lead to the
generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are implemented (e.g., preparing land for
seeding, planting, changing agricultural or forestry practices, rewetting, restoring hydrological
functions, or implementing management or protection plans). For this project, according to the
requirements of the AMS-III.AU methodology applied, an entire cropping season is started from
land preparation and the emission reduction calculation is also started this day. So, the project
start date was in 9-May-20182 when the land preparation was started.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The crediting period of this project will be using a 7-year, twice renewable crediting period, for a
combined total project crediting period of 21 years from 11-May-2018 to 10-May-2039, and the
first 7-year period is from 11-May-2018 to 10-May-2025. Also, the project lifetime3 is 30 years
from 25-April-2018 to 24-April-2048.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.15 Participation under Other GHG Programs
Projects Registered (or seeking registration) under Other GHG Program(s)
The project has not been registered or is seeking registration under any other GHG programs.
Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The project has not been rejected by any other GHG programs.
1.16 Other Forms of Credit
Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project is not involved in an emission trading program or any other mechanism that includes
GHG allowance trading and has not been rejected by other GHG program. GHG emission
reductions and removals generated by the project will not be used for compliance under any
programs or mechanisms.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project has not sought or received another form of GHG-related environmental credit.
1.17 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
According to the applied methodology “Methane Emission Reduction by Adjusted Water
Management Practice in Rice Cultivation”, any effects of the project activity on GHG emissions
outside the project boundary are deemed to be negligible and do not have to be considered under
this methodology. So, leakage does not need to be considered.
Commercially Sensitive Information
None of the project documents will be considered as commercially sensitive information, and
all the documentation is available to any stakeholders.
Sustainable Development
The Project provides many benefits that will help achieve China’s Sustainable Development
Goals, a set of 17 universal goals covering the thematic areas of environmental, economic, and
social development.

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Fresh Breeze afforestation project covers 4,269.82, hectares of land, which are adjacent to
cattle, on which forest plantations for obtaining high-value, long-lived timber products and for
sequestering large amounts of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere will be established. The
project activity is established in the states of Tabasco, Nayarit and Chiapas, Mexico.
The project activity is categorized as a grouped project due to the project foresees an average
expansion of 1,200 hectares per year, adding new project areas and instances from the future
years.
The project will result in a significant contribution to sustainable development of Mexico, mainly
through: i) increased employment and quality of employment; ii) rural development
(decentralization); iii) increased gross value of production; iv) improved fiscal balance; v)
biodiversity preservation and vi) improvement and preservation of soil quality.
Overall objective of proposed A/R project activity
The overall objective of the A/R activity is to contribute to mitigate climate change while meeting
the growing demand for quality wood products from well managed plantation forests and
contributing to sustain environmental management, community development and poverty
alleviation in Mexico.
Specific objectives of the proposed A/R project activity
1) Capture carbon dioxide through forest planting, generating high quality emission reductions in
greenhouse gases (GHG) that can be measured, monitored and verified. The project
participants strive to demonstrate that carbon sequestration from forest plantations is a viable
instrument to encourage private investment in the forestry sector, especially on degraded
lands.
2) Promote environmental conservation such as soil conservation, water sources and
biodiversity of the region, protection of flora and fauna species. Proteak UNO SAB de C.V.
has a protection program of species during and after the project implementation.
3) Take care of the biodiversity, creating biological corridors within our plantations
4) Socio-Economic development in the local communities through:
- Promoting tree plantation and afforestation activities in the local communities.
- Providing employment opportunities.
- Proteak UNO S.A.B. de C.V. supports its employees paying them social insurance (which is
not the common practice in other companies of the region).
5) Develop local infrastructure; including roads, health centers, water supply and communication
systems.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is classified as a grouped project because new areas will be included in the future.
|
The sectoral scope of this project is Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses (AFOLU). Within
this category the project is of the Afforestation, Reforestation, Revegetation (ARR) type.
 The voluntary project activity, although being applied at the voluntary market, shall make
use of the following approved CDM methodology:
o AR-ACM0003: Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands v 1.0.0

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
 Being developed within the forestall sector, the proposed project activity can be classified
on the sectoral scope No.14: “Agriculture, Forestry, Land Use”, AFOLU project category
ARR (afforestation, reforestation and re-vegetation), activity type: Afforestation.
According to the AFOLU Requirements version 3.4 the following general requirements most be
fulfilled by the project activity in order to apply to be an eligible afforestation project.
“4.2.1. Eligible ARR activities are those that increase carbon sequestration and/or reduce GHG
emissions by establishing, increasing or restoring vegetative cover (forest or non-forest) through
the planting, sowing or human-assisted natural regeneration of woody vegetation. Eligible ARR
projects may include timber harvesting in their management plan. The project area shall not be
cleared of native ecosystems within the 10 year period prior to the project start date, as set out in
Section 3.1.6. of the VCS AFOLU requirements”.
In this case the Fresh Breeze Afforestation project is in line with the eligibility conditions of the
AFOLU requirements due to the project increase the carbon sequestration through the planting of
woody vegetation; the project include timber harvesting in their management plan (demonstrated
with the management plan of the project) and the lands weren’t native ecosystems (demonstrated
with the photos of each plantation). As a grouped project the future plantations of the project will
be in line with the eligibility requirements of the VCS.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology for this project is AMS-I.L: "Electrification of rural communities using renewable energy" version 04. This methodology is applicable to the project activity, which involves the installation of renewable electricity generation systems to electrify non-electrified communities and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The project includes the installation of a renewable hydropower generation system that displaces fossil fuel use.

The methodology also refers to the latest approved version of "Methodological tool 21: Demonstration of additionality of small-scale project activities" version 13.1 and AMS I F Renewable electricity generation for captive use and mini grid. V4.0.

The applicability of the methodology to the project is demonstrated in the table provided in the project description. The project meets the criteria and conditions specified in the methodology, such as the requirement for households to constitute at least 75% of the connected consumers and compliance with applicable international or national standards.

The methodology is applicable to permanent installation of renewable electricity generation systems and not applicable to portable systems. The aggregate installed capacity of the renewable energy generating systems should not exceed 15 MW.

For projects involving the installation of hydro power plants with reservoirs, the requirements prescribed under AMS-I.D - Grid connected renewable electricity generation shall be followed, although this is not applicable to this project.

inputs.answer:
The project summary is that it is a solar photovoltaic power project in Colombia. The project consists of multiple installations of solar photovoltaic power plants located in different departments within Colombian territory. The project aims to ensure energy security, diversify the grid generation mix, and promote sustainable growth in the electricity generation sector in Colombia.

The province where the project is located is Valle del Cauca, Bolivar, and Tolima. The country is Colombia.

The latitude and longitude coordinates for the project locations are not provided in the given information.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The proposed solar grouped project activity consists of an installation and implementation of
Solar Photovoltaic Power plants located in different departments within Colombian territory. The
implementation of grouped project activity ensures energy security, diversification of the grid
generation mix and sustainable growth of the electricity generation sector in Colombia.
All project activity instances within this grouped project activity will consist of single solar
renewable technology. Also, an individual project activity instance will either be small-scale
(having methodology AMS I.D version 18.0) or large-scale (having methodology ACM0002
version 19.0).
Before the implementation of the project activity, no power plants were installed at the project
site. The energy that will be generated by the grouped project is currently dispatched by other
power plants that are connected to the national grid, and that include fossil fuel power plants.
Hence, the baseline scenario and the scenario prior to project implementation are the same and
the project will help to reduce thermal power generation in the National Interconnected System
(SIN1) by providing renewable energy to the grid.
The first phase of the solar grouped project will have a total installed capacity of 229.45 MW, with
the installation of 742,289 Solar Photovoltaic units. The electricity generated by the grouped
project is expected to be around 447.09 GWh per year, which will be delivered to the SIN, to a
third party, or represents a project activity that results in savings of electricity that would have
been provided by the grid; avoiding part of the electricity generated by the grid-connected power
plants. Thus, it will contribute to sustainability by increasing the share of renewable energy and
reducing GHG emissions.
All the project activity instances i.e. renewable energy generation of Solar Photovoltaic – SPV
plants to be included in this grouped project, will be within Colombia only (see Table 1). Hence
the location and geographical boundary of the grouped project can be defined as Colombia. The
estimated annual emission reductions over a 10-year period of first crediting period from initial 6
project activity instances are 79,870 tCO e/year. The total emission reductions for 10 years 2
crediting period will be approximately 798,704 tCO e. 2
Table 1. Project activity instances details
1 In Spanish: Sistema Interconectado Nacional - SIN

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves several steps:

1. Step 2: Identify 4 projects that have been registered as CDM project activities based on information from the UNFCCC website.

2. Step 3: Identify similar projects to the proposed project activity in terms of technology used.

3. Step 4: Within the similar projects identified in Step 3, identify those that apply technologies different from the proposed project activity. Calculate the number of such projects (N.diff).

4. Step 5: Calculate the factor F, which represents the share of similar projects using different technologies compared to the proposed project activity. It is calculated as F = 1 - N.diff / N.

5. Determine if the proposed project activity is a "common practice" within the sector and geographical area. If the factor F is greater than 0.2 and N - N.diff is greater than 3, the proposed project activity is considered a common practice.

6. Apply the "Tool for demonstration and assessment of additionality" to assess if the proposed project activity fulfills additionality requirements and is additional.

7. Outcome of Step 4: If the proposed project activity is not considered a common practice, it is deemed additional.

8. Methodology Deviations: Confirm that the project activity does not deviate from the applicable methodology.

9. Quantification of GHG Emission Reductions and Removals: Calculate baseline emissions, which include only CO2 emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel fired power plants that are displaced due to the project activity. The methodology assumes that all project electricity generation would have been generated by existing grid-connected power plants and the addition of new grid-connected power plants.

The present project activity does not incur in any deviation from the applicable methodology.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector in question is Renewable Energy. The project involves the installation of wind turbines to harness wind energy and convert it into electricity, contributing to the sustainable development goals of social well-being, environmental well-being, economic well-being, and technological advancements in the field of wind energy.
inputs.context:
VCS Project Description  
 
 
 5 
View of the project participant on the contribu tion of the project activity to sustainable 
development  
 
The project proponent has essentially carried out investment in the project after analyzing the 
overall benefits to the community & environment. The approach is also in line with the sustainable development guidelines
2 of the Ministry of Environment & Forests (MoEF) of 
Government of India (GoI).  
 
1. Social well being: 
 
The wind installations are carried out depending upon the wind potential of the site and 
thus may not be implemented close to load centers. This results in the scattered 
implementation of wind projects thereby resulting in strengthening of local feeders and 
rural grids which in turn increases the availability of electricity in the nearby villages / 
suburban areas.   
Implementation of the project activity will also contribute towards meeting the electricity 
deficit in the state of Maharashtra / NEWNE regional grid of India. 
 
2. Environmental well being: 
 
The project activity essentially uses the available wind potential at the site which is 
converted into electricity; the operation of this facility is in tandem with environment as there are no emissions from the project activity. 
 
3. Economic well being: 
 Implementation of the project activity has helped in developing the local economy; create 
employment opportunities for the local skilled a nd semi skilled people, which is a priority 
concern for the Government of India.   
4. Technological well being: 
 
Increased interest in wind energy projects  will further push research efforts by technology 
providers to develop more efficient and better technology in  future.  Thus, the investment 
in candidate VCS project and other such projects will assist in promotion of better & new 
technologies.  
 
1.5 Project location including geographic an d physical information allowing the 
unique identification and delineation of the specific extent of the project: 
 The project is spread over three districts namely  Dhule, Sangli and Nandurbar in the state of 
Maharashtra.  The information allowing for the unique identification of the WEGs is as follows: 
 
 
 
                                                
 
2 http://envfor.nic.in/divisions/ccd/cdm_iac.html  - Sustainable Development Guidelines by MoEF, GoI.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is ACM0002 "Consolidated methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources", Version 12.1.0. This methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation projects that involve the installation, capacity addition, retrofit, or replacement of a power plant/unit of types such as hydro, wind, geothermal, solar, wave, or tidal power plants/units.

The methodology has certain conditions for applicability, such as the project activity being a greenfield plant or involving capacity addition, retrofit, or replacement. For capacity additions, retrofits, or replacements, the existing plant must have started commercial operation prior to a minimum historical reference period of five years, and no capacity expansion or retrofit of the plant should have been undertaken between the start of this minimum historical reference period and the implementation of the project activity.

For hydro power plants, the methodology applies if the project activity is implemented in an existing reservoir with no change in volume, or if the project activity is implemented in an existing reservoir where the volume is increased and the power density of the project activity is greater than 4 W/m2, or if the project activity results in new reservoirs and the power density of the power plant is greater than 4 W/m2.

The choice of methodology ACM0002 is justified for this project as it meets the relevant applicability criteria, including the installation of a new grid-connected renewable electricity generation plant and the construction of a new reservoir with a power density greater than 4 W/m2.

The greenhouse gases included in the project boundary and used in calculations of emission reductions are CO2 emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel-fired power plants that are displaced due to the project activity. Minor emission sources such as CH4 and NO2 emissions during electricity generation are considered negligible and not included in the baseline calculation for conservatism and compliance with the methodology. Emissions from the construction and operation of the plant are also considered minor and not included in the baseline calculation.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project is a VCS Version 4.2 project focused on leakage management. It does not have any potential negative environmental or socio-economic impacts. A local stakeholder consultation was conducted in different states in India, including Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Haryana. The consultation aimed to introduce Claro, discuss the project design and implementation, and highlight the benefits of the project to farmers. The project involves the use of solar pumps for irrigation to mitigate the effects of climate change.

Province: The project is implemented in multiple states in India, including Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Haryana.

Country: The project is located in India.

Latitude and Longitude: The specific latitude and longitude coordinates of the project are not provided in the given information.

2 SAFEGUARDS
2.1 No Net Harm
No potential negative environmental or socio-economic impacts have been identified for the
project.
2.2 Local Stakeholder Consultation
A Local Stakeholder Consultation was conducted physically by Claro in India in different states.
The states include Uttar Pradesh- Ayodhya (8th June 2022), Madhya Pradesh- Bhind(07th June
2022), Maharshtra- Buldhana (07th June 2022), Haryana (Jhajjar)- 10th June 2022. The meeting
included people from NGOs, local policy makers, academicians etc.
The objective of the stakeholder consultation was to introduce Claro, discuss the VCS Grouped
Project, project design and its implementation, project’s benefit to farmers and the process of
VCS project validation and Verification.
Potential and existing solar pump customers are prioritized as the most important stakeholders.
The means of invitation included displaying Notices at various locations, through emails to local
policymakers, NGOs etc. which was well in advance to give appropriate time to seek inputs.
The opening meeting was done by a Claro representative who gave introduction of the company
and its project. He presented the agenda of the meeting which was to have a discussion with the
stakeholders on the benefits of the Solar pump in irrigation and their feedback on any concerns
regarding implementation of the project.
The issue of Climate change and how use of solar pumps is helping PP in mitigating Climate
Change effects was discussed with the stakeholders. The purpose of the project was discussed

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Figure 2: Dam and other project components location
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project activity correspond a new hydropower Plant installed at a site with no other power
generation plants operating prior to the project initiation.
The project consider a new reservoir with a flood area of 282 ha which 132 ha are now flooded by
the river.
The power density of the project activity is calculated according the installed capacity of the
hydropower plant after and before the implementation of the project activity (0 and 150,000,000 W
respectively) and considering the area of the reservoir measured in the surface of the water, after
and before the implementation of the project activity (132 and 282 ha respectively) (equation 12 in
section 3.2 indicates how to determined the power density). Therefore, the power density of the
project activity results in 100 W/m2.
The project main purpose involves the generation of renewable energy. The project replaces
energy from the grid partially generated by fossil fuel-fired power plants reducing the GHG
emissions. It will help Chile as a developing country to stimulate and commercialise the use of grid
connected renewable energy technologies that are required according to the article 150 bis of the
Chilean General Electric service Law Directive (DFL4/2006), published on 17 January /2006 in the
Official gazette (available at www.bcn.cl).

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'San Pedro Hydropower Plant', 'project_summary': "San Pedro Hydropower Plant is a greenfield electricity generation project activity which consists in a run-off-river power plant to be developed by Colbún S.A., including a reservoir, adduction tunnels, a powerhouse, two turbines and an electrical substation. The nominal installed capacity of each turbine is 75 MW, with a resulting total installed capacity of 150 MW  and an expected average annual power generation of 932,400  MWh. The planned operational starting date will be on 01 May 2 017 and the project is fully authorised by the respective national authoritiesThe project is located in the San Pedro River, about 14.5 km downstream from the drain of Lake Riñihue, in Valdivia province in Los Ríos Region .The electricity generated is delivered to the Central Interconnected System (Sistema Interconectado Central – SIC) in the Substation Los Ciruelos located in the area of San José de la Mariquina, through a  220 kV power transmission line with a length of 40 km .The project activity is considered as Sectoral Scope 1, Energy Industries (renewableon renewable sources), as consists in the installation of a new grid-connected renewable power plant, then the baseline scenario is the following: Electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in the “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system” (version 03.0.0, EB70). The baseline scenario is the same as the scenario existing prior to the start of implementation of the project activity.The need to incorporate and use new technologies in all of energy areas, allows maintaining a parallel and efficient development to meet the requirement of different production areas of the country. In this context, and considering that hydropower use a renewable and non-polluting resource, and that does not depend on foreign issues, this project is presented as a convenient alternative to avoid the energy dependence on other countries and some of environmental problems, such as climate change.The energy generated by this project activity, will be produced from environmentally safe and sound technology of hydroelectricity generation equipment designed, engineered and manufactured by a respected supplier. Any of trusted manufacturers are then, going to transfer to the Host Party its know-how by means of training the power plant staff during the construction, commissioning and operation of the project activity.The implementation of this hydropower project will displace the dispatch of thermoelectric power plants currently operating in the system and will contribute with greenhouse gases (GHG) emission reductions, specifically by avoiding the emissions of CO2 produced by the combustion of fossil fuels, delivering clean energy to the grid that would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources. Thus, the expected annual emission reduction of the project activity is 610,724 tCO2.In addition, San Pedro Hydropower Plant diversifies the energy pool through the implementation of renewable energy sources helping to reduce Chile's dependence on natural gas coming from Argentina and other countries and to supply the progressive increase in the energy sector demand, which has grown strongly in recent years, thus contributing with the sustainable development of the country.", 'project_state_province': 'Valdivia province in Los Ríos Region', 'project_country': 'Chile', 'project_latitude': -39.75, 'project_longitude': -72.58}

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is described in the VCS Version 3 document. The project applies the Approved Consolidated Methodology ACM0002 version 16.0, which is titled "Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources". The methodology includes several reference tools such as the "Tool to calculate the emission factor of an electricity system", the "Tool for demonstration and assessment of additionality", and the "Methodological tool on Common practice".

The project activity is applicable to grid-connected renewable energy power generation projects that involve the installation of a Greenfield power plant. It can also be applied to capacity additions, retrofits, rehabilitations, or replacements of existing plants/units. The project activity in this case corresponds to a Greenfield power plant that will be connected to the grid.

The project may include renewable energy power plants/units such as hydro, wind, geothermal, solar, wave, or tidal power plants/units. In this case, the project activity involves the installation of a Greenfield run-of-river hydro power plant with a reservoir.

The methodology has specific applicability conditions based on the type of project activity. For example, in the case of capacity additions, retrofits, rehabilitations, or replacements, there are certain conditions related to the historical reference period and capacity expansion. In the case of hydro power plants, there are conditions related to the volume of reservoirs and power density calculations. The methodology also specifies that it is not applicable to projects involving switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources at the project site or biomass fired power plants.

Overall, the project activity meets all the methodological applicability conditions outlined in the VCS Version 3 document.

Greenfield power plant.

According to the Section 2.1.1 of “VCS Standard version 4.2”, this project activity meets two of
the scopes of the VCS program:
1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases.
4) Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG program,
unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Accordingly, this project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the 4
six Kyoto Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and it is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of VCS program.

1.6 Other Entities Involved in the Project
None.
1.7 Ownership
The ownership of the rice paddies of the agricultural land management project belongs to the
farmers, which has been confirmed by the local government and agricultural bureau. Since these
rice paddies are all legal agricultural fields, and the ownership is clear, there is no dispute over
land ownership in the project site.
During the construction period, Guangxi Meiluo Agricultural Science and Technology Co., Ltd.
(hereinafter “Meiluo”) invested and cooperated with Agricultural Bureau of Wuming District in the
construction of ditches and reservoirs, while the local farmers were hired to build the ditches and
reservoirs. During the operation period, Meiluo is responsible for supervising technicians to
patrol and maintain the ditches and reservoirs. Furthermore, farmers with tenure of rice paddies
have right to authorize Meiluo as a representative of the carbon project owner and Meiluo has
overall control and responsibility for the carbon project as the project proponent without violating
farmers’ right.
The ‘Methane Emission Reduction with Rice Cultivation Project Cooperation Agreement’ signed
by the farmers and the project proponent clarifies that the project proponent owns the rights to
the carbon credits generated.
1.8 Project Start Date
The project start date was on 06-April-2018 when the land preparation started.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
7

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Household Biogas Project in Madhya Pradesh & Jharkhand', 'project_summary': 'The purpose of the project is to replace the commonly used inefficient wood fired mud stoves technology, with clean, sustainable, and efficient biogas. Each household utilizes cattle dung to feed the digester to produce biogas for cooking purpose. This leads to reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by displacing conventionally used non-renewable biomass with renewable biogas and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions related to animal manure which is left to decay anaerobically. In addition, the hygienic conditions in the rural areas will be improved by an appropriate disposal of waste. Further, residue from the bio digesters can be used as organic fertilizer for land application. Project activity will contribute towards sustainable development by replacing non-renewable source of energy with biogas generated from the biodigesters. The Project is operational in India in the rural areas of Madhya Pradesh and Jharkhand.', 'project_state_province': 'Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 23.61, 'project_longitude': 85.28}

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
A professional legal analysis has confirmed that the landowners have the exclusive rights to all
environmental services provided by their land, comprising any ecosystem payments that cover
the cost of improving natural resources management and conservation activities in their land in
exchange for the carbon finance benefits, including communal landowners known as Ejidos,
Ejidos are a type of communal land in Mexico in which the traditional communities that inhabit
the area have the collective property and usufruct rights of the land given by the Mexican State,
as indicated in Article 9 of Mexico’s Agrarian Law3.
The grouped project area currently encompasses a total of 175,880 ha in the state of Nayarit.
More project activity instances will be added to this grouped project in later PD versions. Within
the grouped project area there are currently nine project activity instances, which are mainly
ejidos.
BlueMX Mangrove A.C. has been collaborating and engaging with each ejidos’ authority, called
Ejido’s Commissariat, in order to establish partnerships and obtain their free, prior, and informed
consent (FPIC) to develop the project activities. The Ejido’s Commissariat is responsible for the
execution of the deal publicly agreed at the ejido’s assembly, as well as the governance,
representation, and administrative management of all ejido activities (Article 32, Mexico’s
Agrarian Law).
The project proponent signed agreements with each ejido and private landowners. The
agreements confirm the landowner’s or ejido’s endorsement to develop the project activities,
recognise the required ownership transfer of the carbon credits to BlueMX Mangrove A.C., and
confirms the landowners’ collaboration as key partners of the blue carbon conservation project.
1.8 Project Start Date
The project start date is 23/04/2019.
The project proponent has been granted by Verra an exemption from Section 3.7.6 of the VCS
Standard, v4.1 for its grouped REDD+ projects in Mexico. The project proponent presented the
Draft PD v.1.0 for listing by 31 March 2022.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
Start date: 23/04/2019
End date: 22/04/2059
Total project duration: 40 years
Crediting period type: Fixed

Project Summary: The Nam Soi & Nam Cong Hydropower Project is a mega-project that aims to generate clean energy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The project was registered as a Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) project and is also eligible for Voluntary Emission Reductions (VCS). The project's first crediting period started on 10-04-2010 and ended on 21-06-2011. The estimated greenhouse gas emission reductions for this period were 48,354 tCO2e, with an average annual reduction of 40,296 tCO2e.

Province: The project is located in Son La province.

Country: The project is located in Vietnam.

Latitude and Longitude: The project's dam is located at approximately 20°54'55'' N and 103°44'04'' E, and the power plant is located at approximately 20°55'25'' N and 103°44'15'' E. The dam of Nam Cong hydropower is located at approximately 21°01'52'' N and 103°40'48'' E, and the power plant is located at approximately 21°02'19'' N and 103°42'29'' E.
