v3.0.1.pdf>Last visit on March 21st, 2019.
v3.3 12

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
TOOL12 Methodological tool: Project and leakage emissions from transportation of freight -
version 01.1.017.
TOOL16 Methodological tool: Project and leakage emissions from biomass - version 04.018.
TOOL30 Methodological tool: Calculation of the fraction of non-renewable biomass - version
01.019.
2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The methodology is applicable for project activities that avoid greenhouse gases emissions by
using renewable biomass in order to generate thermal energy. In addition, the methodology is
applicable if the project generates less than 45MW of energy, which is accomplished by the
project as it generates 6.98 MW.
There are no similar registered project activities in the region of the project activity once
Sustainable Carbon - Projetos Ambientais LTDA made a research and did not find any registered
small-scale CDM Project. Therefore, the proposed project activity is not saving the non-renewable
biomass accounted for by the other registered project activities.
The utilization of firewood from areas without any kind of management cannot be considered a
renewable source of biomass, since it interferes in the carbon pools and increases the carbon
emissions to the atmosphere, turning greenhouse effect even worse. Moreover, the native wood
provided from areas without a reforestation management plan does not fit any of the options of
UNFCCC definition of renewable biomass in Annex 18, EB 2320.
Firewood coming from reforestation activities is considered renewable according to option I of the
UNFCCC definition of renewable biomass (Annex 18, EB 23), as it fits all the assumptions below:
“The biomass is originating from land areas that are forests21 where:
(a) The land area remains a forest; and
(b) Sustainable management practices are undertaken on these land areas to ensure, in
particular, that the level of carbon stocks on these land areas does not systematically decrease
over time (carbon stocks may temporarily decrease due to harvesting); and
(c) Any national or regional forestry and nature conservation regulations are complied with.”
17 Project and leakage emissions from transportation of freight Available at:

should apply.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector is Forestry and Land Use. The project falls under the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) sector, specifically the Agriculture Land Management (ALM) category. The project focuses on improved cropland management practices that aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and increase soil organic carbon stocks.

inputs.context:
Ownership  
Implementation of the proposed project doesn’t involve any activity that causes alteration of any 
resource; therefore acquiring any specific legal right to do so is not applicable. However, the 
entitlement of the emission  reductions generated by the project shall be transferred to the project

VCS Project Description Template, v4.3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Heilongjiang Zhaoyuan Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to
as “the project”) is located in Zhaoyuan County, Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province, China. The
purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices to prevent
the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.
The improved agricultural land management practices of the project focus on no-tillage on fields
evenly mulched with crushed straw for two or three years, followed by plowing or subsoiling once
and continued no-tillage for another two or three years. No-tillage can effectively reduce the
loosening of the surface soil layer and soil disturbance, reduce the loss of water and nutrients in
the soil, ensure the retention of organic matter in the soil, reduce the degree of compaction of
the tillage equipment on the tillage soil layer, and preserve appropriate space for the growth of
crops, which is convenient for ventilation and keeps the soil with good water storage capacity.
The application of no-tillage sowing has solved the problem of sand blowing in bare farmland to
a certain extent and played a role in windbreak and sand fixation. No-tillage can maximize the
protective effect of straw mulching on soil.
The project plans to implement improved agricultural land management practices in 87,479 ha
corn field in the first crediting period to increase soil organic carbon (SOC). The project proponent
not only introduced more efficient and appropriate tillage method with Zhaoyuan Agriculture and
Rural Affairs Bureau (ZARAB) to the farmers, but also provide technical training and support to
the farmers.
The scenario existing prior to the project’s implementation is primarily conventional tillage with
straw mulching, which increase soil disturbance and the loss of soil organic matter (SOM).
During the first crediting period from 07-Apr-2021 to 06-Apr-2031, the project is expected to
generate GHG emission removals of 1,315,100 tCO e, with an average annual GHG emission 2
removal of 131,510 tCO e. 2
1.2 Audit History

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Table 1 List of titles held that make up the Rio Bravo Project.
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
1.10.1 Climate:
Weather data collected at La Milpa Field Station on the north-western Rio Bravo Conservation and
Management Area (but outside the defined Project Area) has provided a good estimate of weather
patterns. Since conditions alter across the Rio Bravo, those in the south and east can be assessed from
observations from the weather stations at Tower Hill (near Orange Walk Town) and Spanish Lookout.
Overall the area experiences a sub-tropical moist climate with marked wet and dry seasons, dominated
by weather systems moving through the Gulf of Mexico and western Caribbean. The wet season is May –
November and the dry season is December to April. Temperatures are fairly constant across inland
northern Belize, averaging 27o C (81oF), but rainfall increases from north-west to south-east. Thus mean
annual rainfall at La Milpa over the period 1995-2005 has been 1239 mm (49”) while that at Tower Hill is
somewhat higher (1353 mm, 53”) and Spanish Lookout is higher again (1546 mm, 61”). These data
suggest that the eastern RBCMA should receive 1440-1500 mm (57-59”) per annum. The La Milpa
rainfall and that estimated for the eastern RBCMA is rather lower than those given in previous
descriptions of the area. This conforms to a slight drying trend over the past decade (Meerman &
Cherrington, 2005).
v3.0

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03  
 
CDM – Executive Board     page 42  
 
100% of the respondents have some knowledge and understandings about wind farm projects. 
100% of the respondents do not disagree with the devel opment of the Project. About 87% of them believe 
that the Project will have overall positive impacts, such as “increase of job opportunities and income”, 
“improvement of living standard”, on their livelihoods, while the others believe there will be little impact 
on their livelihoods or do not know the impacts.  Among the negative impacts mentioned, the main con cerns are infield occupation and plants damage 
(81%),  noise (19%), waste water and electro-magnetism pollution (6%).  The main additional comment or suggestion on the Project construction is “accelerate the construction 
process and generation as soon as possible”, which reflected the support from the stakeholders. 
 
Conclusion 
 
The survey shows that the proposed project receiv es strong support from local people, which is closely 
linked to the fact that the majority of local village rs have some understandings with wind power projects. 
Most of the respondents believe that the project will have overall positive impacts on their livelihoods 
with better standard of living and reduced tariff which is quite high now. Among the negative impacts, 
the two main issues concerned are land use and envi ronmental pollution. However, as the environmental 
impact assessment demonstrates, both impacts only occur during construction period, and accompanied by mitigating measures such as enclosed operation, w aste landfill, and restored vegetation, the impacts 
will be minimized after the construction.  The survey forms are ava ilable from the company. 
 
E.3. Report on how due account was taken of any comments received:  
Focused on the negative comments received, for the in field occupation and plants damage, the project 
owner has provided compensation to the local resident s. For the noise, waste water and electro-magnetism 
pollution, as the EIA approval shown, the environmenta l protection method listed in EIA make the project 
construction minimized its negative impact on the local people and the ecological environment.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Winsome Textile Industries Ltd. (hereinafter also called as WTIL), a leading manufacturer of
textile product, started its operations in 1980 in Baddi, Himanchal Pradesh, India. WTIL has
given special stress to minimise contamination, both at pre-spinning and post-spinning stages
by adding machines like Vision Shield in Blow Room and Schlafhorst-338 with LOEPFE - 9001
(SIRO CLEANER) Contamination Control Channel at winding stage. Further addition was to
generate renewable electricity for captive consumption to minimise carbon foot print in long
term.
The project activity involves power generation from a 3.5 MW hydroelectric project based on
Manuni Khad stream, a tributary of river Beas at village Khaniara, Dharamshala, District
Kangra, Himachal Pradesh. The project activity is a run-of-river project being developed by
M/s Winsome Textile Industries Ltd. The project activity comprises 2 Numbers of Pelton
Turbines each with a generator output capacity of 1750 kW for generation of electricity.
The project was allotted to the M/s Winsome Textile Industries Ltd. on a Build, Own, Operate
and Maintain (BOOM) basis for a period of 40 years. Wheeling and Banking Agreement (PPA)
is being signed with the Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board (HPSEB), the generated
electricity will be used for captive consumption at its manufacturing unit Baddi.
The purpose of the project activity is to produce renewable energy using hydro power for
captive consumption. In the absence of the project activity equivalent amount of electricity
would have been generated by the operation of grid connected fossil fuel based power plants.
The Project activity thus reduces the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs)
in to the atmosphere associated with the equivalent amount of electricity generation from the
fossil fuel based grid connected power plant. The project activity has commissioned both the
turbine on 31/03/2017.
The estimated annual average and the total CO e emission reduction by the project activity 2
over the first renewable crediting period of 10 years are expected to be 17,619 tCO e and 2
176190 tCO e respectively. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral scope-01, Energy Industries (Renewable -/non renewable sources)
Project Type-I Renewable Energy Project
The project activity is not a grouped project.

VCS Project Description
In the absence of the project activity, an equivalent quantum of electricity would have
been generated by the fossil-fuel dominated Southern Regional Electricity Grid of
India6 generation mix. The same would in turn result in GHG emissions at the grid
end as per the carbon intensity of the above mentioned grid. This scenario has been
identified as the baseline scenario for the project activity under consideration (please
refer to section 2.4 of the VCS PD for further details).
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG emission reductions
and/or removal enhancements:
The project activity under consideration entails electricity generation through wind-
mills by harnessing wind power potential, a natural and renewable source of energy.
The project is expected to generate and export of 20.965 million kWh (approx) per
year to the Southern Regional Grid of India. In the absence of the project activity, an
equivalent quantity of electricity would have been generated by the Southern Grid by
a majority of fossil-fuel fired power plants. The same would have resulted in GHG
emissions as per the carbon intensity of the grid-mix.
As per the combined margin carbon intensity of the 0.928 tCO /MWh for the 2
Southern Grid, the bundled project activity would there by result in total CO emission 2
reduction of 194560 tonnes over the crediting period of 10 years. For detailed
calculation procedure and sample calculation tables of the GHG emission reduction
quantum from the project activity, please refer to Sections 4.2, 4.3 and 4.4 of the
VCS PD.
1.9 Project technologies, products, services and the expected level of activity:
In wind energy generation, kinetic energy of wind blowing at high speeds is
converted into mechanical energy while passing through the wind-turbine. The
rotation of the turbine blades results in the rotation of the generator mounted on the
same shaft, thus generating electricity. As there are no GHG emissions associated
with wind electricity generation, the technology is widely recognized as clean
technology. An upwind7 Horizontal axis wind turbine (HAWT)8 is used in the project
activity to generate power.
o Main Tower: This is what holds the windmill up into the airflow.
o Blades: The blades are basically the sails of the system. They are flat
objects connected to the centre shaft that converts the push of the
wind into a circular motion. When the wind forces the blades to move,
it has transferred some of its energy to the rotor
6 The Indian power grid system (or the National Grid) is divided into two regional grids namely NEWNE Regional Grid
and Southern Region Grid. These regional grids have independent state Load Dispatch Centres (LDCs) that manage
flow of power in their jurisdiction. Power generated by state owned generation units and private owned generation
units is consumed by the respective states. Power generated by central sector plants is shared by all states forming
part of the grid in a fixed proportion.
7 A type of wind turbine in which the rotor faces the wind
8 A wind turbine in which the axis of the rotor’s rotation is parallel to the wind stream and the ground.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided project description, the project sector would be Forestry and Land Use. The project involves changing the method of rice cultivation from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded conditions, which falls under the category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) within the sector of Agriculture, Forestry, and Other Land Use (AFOLU). This project aims to reduce methane emissions, increase rice productivity, and provide job opportunities.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Nanbu County within Nanchong City, Sichuan Province of China,
with a total acreage of 15,978 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this
project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was
cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter
in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of 4
anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water
conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the continuously
flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 3.50 tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 55,905 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 559,050 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
1 Dr. Reiner Wassmann (2016). Coordinator, Climate Change Research. International Rice Research
Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org
1

So, this\nproject can be categorized as eligible ALM\nactivity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within the 10 years period prior to\nthe project start date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.2'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems\nby increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil\nN O emissions, and/or reducing CH\n2 4\nemissions.', 'This project practices intermittent flooded\nmethod on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH emissions. So, this project is an eligible\n4\nICM activity.']]
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
Agricultural Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is
approved under sectoral scope 15 (agriculture) of CDM, this project is categorized as
sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra.
1.3 Project Eligibility
According to the Section 2.1.1 of VCS Standard version 4.3, this project activity meets two
of the scopes of the VCS program:1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases; and 4)
Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program, unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval. Accordingly, this
project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the six Kyoto 4
Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and it is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of VCS program.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector in question is Agriculture, specifically Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under the Agriculture, Forestry, and Other Land Use (AFOLU) category. The project involves implementing intermittent flooded conditions during rice cultivation to reduce methane emissions and improve water conservation and rice productivity.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Anlu City within Xiaogan City, Hubei Province of China, with a total
acreage of 13,298 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project,
which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded
method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded
method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition
can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the 4
intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase
and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.32tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 57,504 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 575,040 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
 Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
 Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
 Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers;
 Increase in the number of individuals with improved capacity due to diversified
educational opportunities from Trainings.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
1 Dr. Reiner Wassmann (2016). Coordinator, Climate Change Research. International Rice Research
Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org
4

So, this\nproject can be categorized as eligible ALM\nactivity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within the 10 years period prior to\nthe project start date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.2'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems\nby increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil\nN O emissions, and/or reducing CH\n2 4\nemissions.', 'This project practices intermittent flooded\nmethod on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH emissions. So, this project is an eligible\n4\nICM activity.']]

Agricultural Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is
approved under sectoral scope 15 (agriculture) of CDM, this project is categorized as

1.3 Project Eligibility
According to the Section 2.1.1 of VCS Standard version 4.3, this project activity meets two
of the scopes of the VCS program:1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases; and 4)
Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program, unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval. Accordingly, this
project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the six Kyoto 4
Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and it is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of VCS program.
This is in accordance with the definitions of eligible AFOLU project categories set out in
Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard, 4.3 and can be demonstrated from the following three

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Heishan LN1 Household Biogas Project in Jinzhou, Liaoning Province', 'project_summary': 'Heishan LN1 Household Biogas Project in Heishan Jinzhou, Liaoning Province (the project) is located in Heishan County, Jinzhou City, Liaoning Province, and P.R. China. The project is designed to construct methane recovery and utilization system for each rural household of 13,104 in total. According to the construction plan, the construction is conducted in steps and phases. 3,429 household biogas digesters installation are carried out in 2008; 5,675 household biogas digesters are installed in 2009; the remaining 4,000 biogas digesters installation are constructed in 2010. The construction is strictly based on National Standard GB/T4750-2002 for biogas digester and GB/T 3606-2001 for biogas stove. The main objective of the Project is to dispose the raw manure from pigs by anaerobic digester with a volume of 8m 3 , and to collect biogas generated during the treatment process for thermal supply which meets the cooking and water heating demands of the rural household itself by biogas stove with a thermal flow of 3.26kW each one. Before implementing the Project, all the manure would be left to decay in the uncovered anaerobic mature management system, i.e. deep pit with depth of 1meter at least; the methane generated would be emitted to the atmosphere. In addition, the heat would in the absence of the project activity be generated by stove fired with fossil fuels 1 , which is stated in the investigation report on rural household biogas utilization by Heishan County on September, 2007. The scenario in the absence of the project activity is identical to the baseline scenario.', 'project_state_province': 'Liaoning', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 41.6, 'project_longitude': 122.08}

SECTION D. Environmental impacts
D.1. Analysis of environmental impacts
>>
According to the requirements of Chinese environmental protection laws and regulations，there
is a Statement for Environmental Impact Assessment of the project released by Heishan
Environmental Protection Bureau. The Statement ensures that:
The proposed project does no harm to the local environment, and it is not included in the
categories9 that need Environmental Impact Assessment, it doesn’t need an Environmental
Impact Assessment. The local Environmental Bureau also gave a document to prove the
significant positive environment impacts.
In addition to reducing the GHG emissions, the proposed project also has positive environment
impacts. With the biogas digester constructed in households, animal manure management system
can be improved, the environment in the pigpen and latrine can be improved and the odour can
be reduced. With the new pigpen and latrine, less disease on human and animal will be caused
and transmitted by bacterial and virus. And all the manure is fed into the tank, which will reduce
pollution to soil and water caused by direct discharge of animal waste. Using biogas for cooking
is good for improving indoor air condition. Cooking with coal produces a large amount of SO , 2
CO and smoke, which is harmful to human’s health. But cooking with CH ,only producing H O 4 2
and CO , is environmental friendly. In general, the environmental impacts are: 2
 GHG emissions being strongly mitigated in comparison to baseline treatment alternative;
 The environment and odour in pigpen and latrine being improved;
 Improving the indoor air condition, protecting human from SO ,CO,smoke; 2
 Avoiding pollution to soil and water caused by direct discharge of animal waste.
 Using biogas slurry instead of traditional non-fermented animal manure. The process of
generating biogas will kill many of the pathogenic bacteria found in manure that can be passed on
to humans causing intestinal diseases.
As indicated above, the proposed project can improve the rural environment and living
conditions in the project areas while reducing greenhouse gas emissions. No significant negative
environment impacts have been identified Heishan Environment Protection Bureau approved the
proposed project on December 10, 2007.
9 Published on Feb 20th 2009 by the Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People’s Republic of China

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': '1.5 MW Rice Husk Based Cogeneration Project at Rajaram Maize Products, Mohad, Dist. Rajnandgaon (CG), India', 'project_summary': 'Rajaram Maize Products (RMP) is operating a Starch, Glucose & Dextrose Monohydrate manufacturing plant at Village Mohad, Dist. Rajnandgaon in Chhattisgarh. In the production process, steam and electricity are required as source of energy. Before the project activity, steam was generated in two solid fuel fired boilers (One 10 TPH for regular operation and one 6 TPH as a standby) and electricity was taken from state electricity grid. Fuel for boiler was mostly coal. In order to improve electricity availability and plant productivity the plant management decided to go for captive power generation.  The plant management had mainly two options for choosing fuel for co-generation plant, viz. coal & rice husk. The management decided to go for rice husk fired co-generation plant. Thus the project activity aims at reducing the GHG emissions that would have been generated by using coal as a fuel for co-generation plant.', 'project_state_province': 'Chhattisgarh', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 21.08, 'project_longitude': 81.08}

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology used in this project is ACM0008 - "Abatement of methane from coal mines" (version 08.0). This methodology applies to project activities that aim to use or destroy methane extracted from working or abandoned coal mines. The project activities include treating the captured methane either by destroying it without energy production (e.g., flaring) or by using it to produce energy (such as electricity, heat, or vehicle fuel). 

The project in question falls under category (b) as it uses low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from the Jinyan coal mine for power generation to supply electricity to the coal mines where the project is located. 

Emission reductions in this project are claimed by displacing or avoiding energy from other sources. The emissions reduction comes from two sources: 1) Methane (CH4) emissions resulting from previously vented gas that will be captured and destroyed in the project scenario, and 2) CO2 emissions from the production of the equivalent amount of electricity replaced by the project that would have otherwise been purchased from the CSPG. 

The project applies various tools and methodologies such as the "Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality" (version 07.0), the "Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system" (version 07.0), the "Baseline, project and/or leakage emissions from electricity consumption and monitoring of electricity generation" (version 03.0), "Common practice" (version 03.1), and "Investment analysis" (version 11.0).

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
Based on the provided context, the methodology of this project involves the following:

1. Project Boundary: The project boundary is defined as the notional margin around the project within which the project's impact, in terms of carbon emission reductions, will be assessed. For the Cuyamel project, the boundary includes emissions from activities that occur at the project location.

2. System Boundary: The system boundary for the proposed project is defined as the national grid in Honduras. The project boundary for the baseline includes all direct emissions related to the electricity produced by the facilities and power plants to be replaced by the Cuyamel project. This includes emissions from displaced fossil fuel use at power plants.

3. Baseline Development: The baseline for the proposed project activity is determined using the methodology specified in the applicable project category for small-scale CDM project activities contained in Appendix B of the simplified M&P for small-scale CDM project activities. Specifically, for project category Type 1.D (AMS-I.D), the appropriate baseline is the average of the "approximate operating margin" and "build margin."

4. Baseline Study: The baseline study was prepared by EcoSecurities Ltd., a third-party entity that is not a project participant. The study was completed on 01/03/2005 and can be contacted at Tel: +1-646-202-9899 (contact: Eron Bloomgarden, eron@ecosecurities.com).

Please note that this information is based on the provided context and may not cover all aspects of the project methodology.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project involves the construction of high standard rice fields in Miluo County, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, China. The project aims to implement an intermittently flooded water regime in the rice fields to improve rice cultivation.

Province: Hunan Province

Country: China

Latitude: Between 28°28′ and 29°27′ North

Longitude: Between 112°51′ and 113°27′ East
inputs.context:
[['15-July-2019', 'The ex-ante investigation report (Baseline survey) of Miluo\nCounty in 2019 from Yueyang Academy of Agriculture Science\nwas completed.'], ['15-October-2019', 'The Approval of High Standard Farmland Construction Task in\n2019 was issued by Yueyang Agricultural Bureau.'], ['30-October-2019', 'The construction of high standard rice fields was started'], ['12-December-2019', 'The construction of high standard rice fields was finished and\nall have passed the final acceptance.'], ['04-April-2020', 'The project activity was started, which means the land\npreparation was started.'], ['15-August-2022', 'The draft PD was completed']]
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.12 Project Location
The project is implemented in Miluo County, which is a county under the jurisdiction of Yueyang
City, located in the Southern of the city. The geographical coordinates are between latitude 112°
51′~113°27′ East and 28°28′~29°27′ North. Miluo, or Luocheng for short, is part of
Yueyang City, Hunan Province. It is located in northeastern Hunan Province, close to the eastern
shore of Dongting Lake and downstream of Miluo River. Miluo borders Changsha County and
Wangcheng District of Changsha City in the east and southeast respectively, Xiangyin County and
Yuanjiang City in the west, Yueyang County in the north, and Pingjiang County in the northeast.
The project's activity is located in Miluo County. The second figure indicates the location of
Yueyang City, and the third figure indicates the location of Miluo County. The project zone is
specified by the VCS standard as Miluo County, and the project area is defined as the rice fields
in Miluo County that are subjected to an intermittently flooded water regime. The project area
and zone boundaries are depicted in figures below, and a KML file has been submitted as well.
Figure 1. the map of China
10

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
Figure 2. the location of Hunan Province and Yueyang City
Miluo
Figure 3. the map of Miluo County
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Intermittent flooded water regime requires that irrigation and drainage can be controlled
according to the growth needs of rice during its cultivation. However, prior to the project initiation,
economic conditions in the project area are not very good and farmers’ income was low, which
resulted in that the farmers in the project area had no extra money to build the cement ditches,
ponds and other infrastructure for intermittent irrigation. In addition, farmers in the project area
have low education level, so they lack intermittent irrigation technology. So, the project has not
been implemented to generate GHG emissions for the purpose of their subsequent reduction,
removal or destruction. Since the conditions existing prior to the project initiation is the same as
baseline scenario, please refer to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario) to see the detail information.
Besides, this project does not affect the environmental conditions, including climate, hydrology,
topography, soils, relevant historical conditions, type of vegetation, ecosystems, etc., so, the
present and prior environmental conditions of this project are the same, which are listed as
follows.
11

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project is a 30.24 MW run-of-river hydro power plant called Dogancay HPP. It includes Dogancay-1 and Dogancay-2 regulators with a capacity of 15.12 MW each. The project started electricity production on 1 May 2012 and feeds the produced electricity into the national grid. It aims to bring carbon neutral electricity production to the Turkish grid, resulting in an average emission reduction of 94,454 tCO2e per year.

Province: Sakarya Province

Country: Turkey

Latitude of Weir and Power Plant: 40° 34' 47" N (Dereköy Weir and Dogancay-1 HPP), 40° 38' 23" N (Kızılkaya Weir and Dogancay-2 HEPP)

Longitude of Weir and Power Plant: 30° 20' 08" E (Dereköy Weir and Dogancay-1 HPP), 30° 20' 28" E (Kızılkaya Weir and Dogancay-2 HEPP)

VCS Project Description
1.4 A brief description of the project:
Dogancay HPP is a 30.24 MW run-of-river hydro power plant. It
includes 15.12 MW Dogancay-1 and 15.12 MW Dogancay-2 regulators. It
is expected to start electricity production on 1 May 2012. Produced
electricity is being fed into the national grid.
The project generates a substantial emission reduction by bringing
carbon neutral electricity production to the Turkish grid. The
overall emission reductions shall amount to 94,454 tCO2e per year on
average.
The hydro project shall be registered as a voluntary emission
reduction project under the Voluntary Carbon Standard, thus enabling
its implementation by obtaining co-financing from carbon market
proceeds.
1.5 Project location including geographic and physical
information allowing the unique identification and
delineation of the specific extent of the project:
The project is located in north-west of Turkey, in the south-east of
Marmara Region, within the boundaries of Sakarya Province Geyve Town,
on Sakarya River. The project area is accessible through existing
service roads of the villages; however, they are going to be improved
for the project purposes. The geographical coordinates of the Weirs
and the Power plants are as follows:
Table 2: GPS coordinates of Dereköy Weir and Dogancay-1 HPP
Table 3: GPS coordinates of Kızılkaya Weir and Dogancay-2 HEPP

Project Area
Map 1: Location of the project
1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
The project is expected to start with the initial commercial
operation of the turbines on 1st May 2012.
A two-times renewable crediting period over 10 years shall apply.
Thus, the first crediting period shall begin on start date of the
commercial operation of the plant and last until 30th April 2022.
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
Dogancay HPPs project site is located on Sakarya river in the North-
west region of Turkey (see Map 1 above). There are large dams such as
Porsuk, Sarıyar and Gökçekaya, and smaller dams and irrigation
structures at upstream of the Project. Therefore, the water potential
computations are made with total monthly flows. The project will
involve two weirs(see also section 1.9 below)

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves using a combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality. The steps involved in this methodology are as follows:

1. STEP 0 - Demonstration whether the proposed project activity is the First-of-its-kind.
2. STEP 1 - Identification of alternative scenarios.
3. STEP 2 - Barrier analysis.
4. STEP 3 - Investment analysis.
5. STEP 4 - Common practice analysis.

These steps are completed using the methodological tool mentioned, which is the "Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality". The project activity is considered additional based on the methodological tools used.

There are no methodology deviations applied in this project. The quantification of estimated GHG emissions reductions and removals is based on the baseline emissions scenario, which includes methane emissions from the open-air SWDS, electricity generation using fossil fuels or supplied by the grid, heat generation using fossil fuels, and natural gas used from the natural gas network in the absence of the project activity. The calculation of baseline emissions is done according to the methodology ACM0001 V. 19.
inputs.context:
VCS Project Description Template, v4.3
methodological Tool: “Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate
additionality”, Version 07.0:
The following steps from the Tool are completed below in Section 3.5 of the PD:
• STEP 0 – Demonstration whether the proposed project activity is the First-of-its-kind;
• STEP 1 – Identification of alternative scenarios;
• STEP 2 - Barrier analysis;
• STEP 3 – Investment analysis;
• STEP 4 – Common practice analysis.
Hence, in accordance with the methodological tools as stated in Section 3.5 of the PD, the
project activity shall be considered additional.
3.6 Methodology Deviations
No methodology deviation is applied in the project
4 QUANTIFICATION OF ESTIMATED GHG
EMISSION REDUCTIONS AND
REMOVALS
4.1 Baseline Emissions
Baseline emissions scenario of the project is the methane from the open-air SWDS, and the
electricity supplied by the grid to be substituted, which will be calculated as follows according to
the methodology ACM0001 V. 19.
It comprises the following sources:
Methane emissions from the SWDS in the absence of the project activity;
Electricity generation using fossil fuels or supplied by the grid in the absence of the project
activity;
Heat generation using fossil fuels in the absence of the project activity; and
Natural gas used from the natural gas network in the absence of the project activity.
58

The project hasn’t sought or received another form of GHG-related environmental credits.
▪ Supply Chain (Scope 3) Emissions
All equipment is locally manufactured in workshop and installed by the Project
proponent only. Hence, the project proponent is solely owning the carbon credit.
1.1 Sustainable Development Contributions
The primary objective of the project is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to provide better
treatment of animal manure and wastewater sludge. Other benefits are odor reduction, improve
working conditions and net generation of jobs (temporary and permanent), income distribution,
access to technology, capacity building of the people involved and encouraging regional
integration.

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Gansu Tianshui Afforestation Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is located in the
suburbs of Qinchuan District, Maiji District, Qingshui County, Qin’an County, Gangu County,
Wushan County and Zhuangjiachuan County, Tianshui City, Gansu Province of China, whose
aim is to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by
planting trees on the barren or degraded lands. The project is implemented by Tianshui Forestry
Science Institute.
19,853.31 ha (297,799.68 Mu13) of forest is to be planted by direct planting on barren lands in
Tianshui City, including two suburbs and five counties: Qinchuan District, Maiji District, Qingshui
County, Qin’an County, Gangu County, Wushan County and Zhuangjiachuan County. All the
project sites were previously barren lands. There is no natural renewal and afforestation before
the project.
The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and improve local
environment through growing of the trees, increase income of local residents by offering job
opportunities from the project, enhance the capabilities of local communities and residents by
providing their relevant technical skills and training, and increase local biodiversity as a result of
establishing a forest of native trees (Pinaster, Cypress, Robinia and Rhus typhina).
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 20,313,257 tCO e in 60 years, 2
with an average annual GHG emission removal of 338,554 tCO e. 2
2.1.2 Project Scale
2.1.3 Project Proponent (G1.1)
13 A Chinese metric unit of district, 1ha = 15 Mu.

Project Summary: 

The project aims to address land degradation and poverty in Kenya by establishing profitable forestry operations that connect small-scale tree farmers to high-value wood markets. Komaza, a social enterprise founded in 2006, works with smallholder farmers to convert degraded or unused plots into productive forestry through afforestation. They provide farmers with high-quality seedlings, training, tree management, and harvest services. Farmers receive fair payment at harvest based on the volume of wood removed and prevailing market prices. The project has already established over 8,000 hectares of new commercial forests and planted close to 7 million trees involving over 25,000 smallholder farmers.

Province: 
The project operates in two main locations in Kenya - Coastal Kenya within Kilifi and Kwale counties, and Central Kenya within Nyandarua county.

Country: 
Kenya

Latitude and Longitude: 
The latitude and longitude coordinates for the project are not mentioned in the provided information.
inputs.context:
CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Komaza is a social enterprise founded in 2006, incorporated in the USA with operations in Kenya. It was
started with the mission of getting subsistence farmers out of poverty by building a profitable forestry
business that connects thousands of small-scale tree farmers to high-value wood markets.
Komaza’s business model is unique in its promotion of decentralized smallholder forestry. Komaza works
with smallholder farmers on their own land, where the land remains under the ownership of the farmers,
but the trees are owned by Komaza, and the benefits are shared between the parties. Collectively, small-
scale farmers possess enough land and labor resources to plant billions of trees, overcoming major barriers
to commercial forestry in Kenya (namely access to land and high establishment cost), while developing
particularly strong environmental benefits.
● Scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project
Komaza currently operates in two main locations, Coastal Kenya within Kilifi and Kwale counties, and
Central Kenya within Nyandarua county.
In Coastal Kenya, a large share of the native ecosystem has already been lost, leaving a mosaic of lowland
forest patches, bushlands and scrublands with mostly infertile soil. Farmers aren’t used to planting trees,
and terrestrial reforestation and afforestation efforts remain limited due to difficulties associated with the
fragmented nature of the landscape and insufficient access to finance. Because of the increasing pressure
from local economic development, in the absence of intervention it is likely that further land degradation
would occur, causing significant loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services.
In Central Kenya, a more fertile area than the coast, there is also environmental degradation caused by
land use changes and poor agricultural practices. Some farmers already plant trees for timber and
fuelwood, but not at a pace or in a way that can reverse the ongoing degradation, with large amounts of
agricultural land still left fallow. In the absence of new large-scale, attractive tree growing initiatives, it is
likely that further land degradation would occur and increase the vulnerability of smallholder farmers to the
impacts of climate change.
● How Komaza generates GHG emission removals
Komaza works with smallholder farmers who own degraded, unused, or sub-utilized plots, to turn this land
into productive forestry (afforestation). Komaza provides high-quality seedlings, training, as well as tree
management and harvest services to farmers. No upfront cash investment nor forestry knowledge is
required to participate. Farmers receive a fair payment at harvest, based on the volume of wood removed
from the farm and the prevailing market prices.
12
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
As of 2022, Komaza has established over 8,000 ha of new commercial forests and has planted close to 7
million trees involving over 25,000 smallholder farmers. Three species are planted namely the fast-growing
hybrid Eucalyptus grandis x camaldulensis, Eucalyptus grandis and indigenous species Melia volkensii, all
suited for the local climatic conditions and product needs.
The project will include all Komaza’s planting since 2017 and future planting in Kenya. Over the lifetime of
the project (30 years) Komaza will plant at least 45,088 ha of smallholder plantations with rotations of 8, 10
and 15 years for Eucalyptus (Central), Eucalyptus (Coast) and Melia (Coast) respectively, both in replanting
and coppicing management regimes. This grouped project will result in an annual average GHG removal
of 212,780 tons over 30 years and a total GHG removal (long-term average) of 6,383,391 tCO2e.
● Komaza’s climate, community and biodiversity objectives
Co-benefits from this project include, but not limited to:
- New income opportunity for smallholder farmers, which doesn’t require any cash investment and
is climate-resilient
- Dissemination of forestry knowledge and skills in the communities, including better environmental
awareness
- Women empowerment through innovative contract and payment model
- Increased forest cover in a landscape that provides habitat for many species
- Reduced land degradation and desertification
- Reduced pressure on natural forests and other protected ecosystems
2.1.2 Project Scale
2.1.3 Project Proponent (G1.1)

The afforestation project will include all of Komaza’s planting since 2017 and future planting in Kenya, establishing over 45,000 hectares of micro tree farms with 100,000 smallholder farmers. It will monitor carbon emission removals and co-benefits on climate, communities and biodiversity, including improved livelihoods, women empowerment, community training, reduced land degradation and reduced pressure on natural forests.', 'project_state_province': 'Kilif, Kwale and Nyandarua counties', 'project_country': 'Kenya', 'project_latitude': -3.51, 'project_longitude': 39.91}

1.7 Ownership
The plots included in the project area are privately owned lands. The landowners are the
participating farmers who are included in the project after a comprehensive consultation
process on the project and project activities and provide their consent to participation. The
farmers/farmer groups enter into an agreement with IFHD where they waive their carbon rights
to IFHD and give IFHD the right to operate and manage the project on their behalf for the
duration of the first crediting period, renewable to cover succeeding crediting periods over the
projectlifetime.IFHDwaives therighttothecarbontoVNV.
It's important to note that participation in the project is entirely voluntary. Throughout the
awareness-raising, enrolment, and farmer/farmer group registration process, the project -
through field-based staff - maintains ongoing communication with potential farmers, local
authorities, and influential community leaders to ensure that all stakeholders have access to
the information they need to make an informed decision about joining the project. The farmers
retain full and undisputed legal rights over their lands. In the project area, land ownership is

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is ACM0002: Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources, Version 20.0. This methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation project activities that involve the installation of a greenfield power plant, capacity addition to existing plants, retrofit of existing operating plants/units, rehabilitation of existing plants/units, or replacement of existing plants/units. The project activity in this case is the installation of a new power plant at a site where no renewable power plant was operated prior to the implementation of the project activity. The methodology provides tools for calculating emission factors, assessing the validity of the baseline, and determining the remaining lifetime of equipment.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Yangquan Guzhuang 8MW CMM Power Generation Project', 'project_summary': "Yangquan Guzhuang 8MW CMM Power Generation Project is located at the former site of Guzhuang Coal Mine Cement Plant in Yangquan, Shanxi Province. The Project utilizes coal mine methane (CMM) with a methane concentration of 16% to generate electricity, and the electricity generated is fed into the North China Power Grid for the self-consumption of the Guzhuang Coal Mine, while the heat output is recovered by a waste heat hot water boiler, replacing the original coal-fired boiler for heating in the mine area. The Project Owner is Yangquan Zhonglian Energy Technology Co.\r\nThe purpose of this project is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through the combustion of methane in the coal mine gas during the power generation process. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. The total installed capacity of the project is designed as 8MW, with eight 1000kW gas-fired internal combustion generator sets, which utilize coal mine gas with a concentration of less than 30% to generate electricity, and utilize the waste heat hot water boiler to recover the flue gas waste heat at the tail end of the units. After running at full load, the project can consume 1,262.88*104Nm3 of pure gas per year, with an estimated annual power generation of 4800*104kWh, which will be used for the mine's self consumption through integration into the North China Power Grid, and 5.184*104GJ of residual heat per year, which will be supplied to the outside world for the heating of the buildings on the site. However, to be conservative, emission reductions will not be claimed for waste heat recovery.\r\nDuring the renewable 7-year crediting period(28-Oct-2022 to 27-Oct-2029, both days included), the total GHG emission reduction of the project can reach 1,748,817 tCO2e, with an average annual emission reduction of 249,831tCO2e.", 'project_state_province': 'Shanxi', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 37.98, 'project_longitude': 113.53}

CGM Ceramic VCS Project Description
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
The use of native wood without sustainable management as fuel is a
prevalent practice among the ceramics industries in Brazil. Wood from
deforestation is delivered and utilized in the ceramic facilities and
this non renewable biomass is offered with low prices.
Although firewood from deforested areas used has been for many decades as
fuel in Brazil, it is impossible to define a start date on which this
kind of non-renewable biomass began to be applied. Firewood used to be
the most employed source of primary energy until the decade of 1970, when
the petroleum started to supply the majority of Brazilian´s energy
needs 10 . Moreover the Brazilian´s Energy and Mine Ministry has been
monitoring every energetic sectors of Brazil since 1970, and firewood
appears over the years monitored as a significant source of thermal
energy for ceramic sector11.
According to Seye (2003) 12 , in Brazil, the red ceramic devices are
produced through an inefficient and traditional process using wood
without forest management to generate thermal energy. In this industry
segment the use of wood represents about 98% of the total fuel employed
stimulating
Therefore, the employment of this fuel stimulates the increase in
Brazilian deforestation rates. The baseline identified for this project
activity is the employing of a total of 22,800 m3 of native wood per year
to provide thermal energy to the ceramics’ kilns.
The project activity focuses on the use of wood from sustainable forest
management plan areas, sawdust, Algaroba wood, residues form cashew tree
and babaçu coconut husk as renewable biomasses for energy supply. The
entrepreneur aims to use municipal garden's residues and elephant grass
in the future.
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG
emission reductions and/or removal enhancements:
The emission reductions will be achieved by displacing the use of wood
from areas with no sustainable forest management to provide thermal
energy in the ceramic companies. Therefore, the emissions launched during
the combustion of wood were not compensated by the replanting. An
opposite scenario occurs with the renewable biomasses employed in this
project activity, which have carbon neutral cycle.
1.9 Project technologies, products, services and the
expected level of activity:
Currently Gomes de Matos Ceramic uses two Hoffman13 kilns and one Câmara14
kiln constitutes the production line of CGM Ceramic.
The process for reducing water content in the ceramic devices is realized
with the employment of two dryer plants that utilize the heat originated
10Brito, J.O. “Energetic use of Wood”. Available at:
<http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0103-
40142007000100015&script=sci_arttext&tlng=ES> visited on: March 13 th, 2009
11 Energy Research Company. National Energy Balance - energy consumption per sector.
Available at <http://www.mme.gov.br/download.do?attachmentId=16555&download> visited
on: March 13th, 2009
12 Seye, Omar. Análise de ciclo de vida aplicada ao processo produtivo de cerâmica
estrutural tendo como insumo energético capim elefante (Pennisetum Purpureum
Schaum) / Omar Seye. Campinas, SP: [s.n.], 2003.
13 “Hoffman” kilns have parallel chambers where the heat from one chamber is used in
the next, therefore recycling the generated heat in the previous chambers.
14 The “Câmara” is a kind of continuous kiln with chambers without chimney. It is
usually employed to burn bricks

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Core Farming in Tamil Nadu', 'project_summary': "The proposed ‘Core Farming in Tamil Nadu’ activity is practised by individual farmers practised by about 1,60,000 farmers and organic grower cooperatives covering 1,19,500 hectares of cropland in the state of Tamil Nadu to be implemented in the first phase. The project aims at increasing the capacity of soil to sequester carbon, enhance the carbon sequestration by agroforestry practices such as planting of trees, reduce emissions from the use of synthetic fertilizers and reduce emissions from burning of crop residue by application of VCS methodology: VM0017 Sustainable Agricultural Land Management (SALM). Several SALM practices and technologies have been proven to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and prevent climate change by enhancing carbon storage in soils, preserving existing soil carbon, and reducing carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide emissions. Those practices include conservation tillage, cover crops, enhanced crop rotations, residue retention, agroforestry and avoidance of crop residue burning. The project holistically aims at achieving sustainable management practices which improve soil health, reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and develop the socio-economic status of the project area. The project aims to reduce and sequester carbon leading to estimated GHG emission reductions or removals (tCO2e) of 871824tCO2e / year. This project's climate benefits include emissions reduction or removals of approximately 34872968tCO2e over the lifetime of the project.", 'project_state_province': 'Tamil Nadu', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 8.08, 'project_longitude': 80.33}

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.6 Other Entities Involved in the Project
1.7 Ownership
BlueMX has secured or is securing agreements with landowners who are participating or want to
participate in the project. The landowners have provided or will provide proof of legal title to the
land where it has been confirmed and verified with the National Official Public Registry of where
the land is located. The agreements set the foundations for the collaborative scheme with the
landowners and secure the transfer of carbon credits rights for BlueMX. The agreements outline
the roles and responsibilities of all parties involved related to the project implementation and
monitoring activities.
A professional legal analysis has confirmed that the landowners have the exclusive rights to all
environmental services provided by their land, comprising any ecosystem payments that cover
the cost of improving natural resources management and conservation activities in their land in
exchange for the carbon finance benefits, including communal landowners known as Ejidos,
Ejidos are a type of communal land in Mexico in which the traditional communities that inhabit
the area have the collective property and usufruct rights of the land given by the Mexican State,
as indicated in in Article 9 of Mexico’s Agrarian Law3.
The grouped project area currently encompasses a total of 87,751 ha in the state of Campeche.
More project activity instances will be added to this grouped project in later PD versions. Within
the grouped project area there are currently 32 project activity instances.
BlueMX Mangrove A.C. has been collaborating and engaging with each ejido’s authority, called
Ejido’s Commissariat, to establish partnerships and obtain their free, prior, and informed consent
(FPIC) to develop the project activities. The Ejido’s Commissariat is responsible for the execution
of the deal publicly agreed at the ejido’s assembly, as well as the governance, representation,
and administrative management of all ejido activities (Article 32, Mexico’s Agrarian Law).
The project proponent signed agreements with each ejido and private landowners. The
agreements confirm the landowner’s or ejido’s endorsement to develop the project activities,
recognize the required ownership transfer of the carbon credits to BlueMX Mangrove A.C., and
confirms the landowners’ collaboration as key partners of the blue carbon conservation project.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
This is a green-field project developed to provide steam to steam customers described earlier.
This implemented utilising rice husk from internal sources, i.e., rice milling
operations of Yihai Kerry (Baicheng) Oils, Grains and Foodstuffs Industries Co., Ltd., who will
utilise the steam from this project. Prior to the project, the steam requirement did not exist for the
steam customers because those facilities started concurrently with project and hence the project
does not displace any existing steam generation project. Hence, there was no generation of rice
husk that is used in the project.
The excess rice husk available in the region is subjected to unplanned disposal including
dumping and/or burning in an uncontrolled manner. As per current practice in the region, rice
husk from different plants in the area are normally dumped in an unplanned manner and/or burnt.
Some of the rice husk decays and the rest are taken away by local villagers for various domestic
uses such as poultry feed, etc. The project, therefore, does not create any GHG emissions for
subsequent removal.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The project is in compliance with existing local regulation6 encouraging implementation of rice
husk based thermal energy production. The local environmental regulations provide requirements
for pollution control from the project. The PP has assessed if there are any significant
environmental impacts due to the project and concluded there are not any such impacts. An
environmental impact assessment study report has been approved by the local pollution control
authority. The has provided for various inspections required for the project
equipment as per the local regulations.
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
In respect of the GHG emissions that will be reduced by operation of the project described in this
PD, the ‘business license’ available as the proof of project title demonstrates the project
operator’s right of use on the project.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project activity’s emissions reduction is not included in an emissions trading program and do
not take place in a jurisdiction with binding limits on GHG emissions.
1.12.3 Participation under Other GHG Programs
The project has not participated in any other GHG program.
1.12.4 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project has not created any other forms of environmental credits. In China, the other
environmental credit that could have been created is Certified Emission Reductions (CER) under
the CDM process. The project has not participated in the CDM process.
6 ‘The Renewable Energy Law of the People’s Republic of China’ adopted at the 14th Session of the Standing
Committee of the 10th National People’s Congress on February 28, 2005

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on the approved baseline methodology ACM0002 (Version 6) for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources. This methodology is applicable to the project because it meets the criteria for a grid-connected zero-emission renewable power generation activity from wind sources.

The sources of greenhouse gases in the project boundary are primarily the fired power plants in the East China Power Grid, which emit CO2, CH4, and N2O. However, the proposed project is a grid-connected zero-emission wind power project, meaning it does not emit greenhouse gases.

The project will also utilize the approved consolidated monitoring methodology ACM0002 (Version 6) for monitoring the zero-emissions grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources.

For more information on the methodology, you can refer to the UNFCCC website: http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/approved.html.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03.1
CDM – Executive Board page 6
SECTION B. Application of a baseline and monitoring methodology
B.1. Title and reference of the approved baseline methodology applied to the project activity:
>>
Baseline methodology:
ACM0002(Version 6): Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation
from renewable sources.
“Tool for the Demonstration and Assessment of Additionality (version 03)”.
Monitoring methodology:
Approved consolidated monitoring methodology ACM0002 (Version 6): “Consolidated monitoring
methodology for zero-emissions grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources”.
Reference: UNFCCC website: http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/approved.html
B.2 Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it is applicable to the project
activity:
The proposed project can meet the applicability criteria of the baseline methodology (ACM0002),
therefore, the methodology is applicable to the proposed project.
(cid:1) The proposed project is a grid-connected zero-emission renewable power generation activity
from wind source;
(cid:1) The proposed project is not an activity that involves switching from fossil fuels to renewable
energy at the proposed project site.
(cid:1) The power grid (the East China Power Grid) which the proposed project is to be connected to
is clearly identified and information on the characteristics of this grid is publicly available.
(cid:1) The methodology will be used in conjunction with the approved consolidated monitoring
methodology ACM0002 (Consolidated monitoring methodology for grid-connected electricity
generation from renewable sources).
The latest version of ACM0002 (version 6, effective from 19 May 2006) has been applied.
B.3. Description of how the sources and gases included in the project boundary
For this project, the sources of the greenhouse gases may mainly be the fired power plants in the East
China Power Grid, in which the greenhouse gases mainly consist of CO2 and others gases, such as CH4
and N2O. However, the proposed project is a grid-connected zero-emission wind power without the
emission of GHGs.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: The project sector in this context is Forestry and Land Use.
inputs.context:
MONITORING REPORT: 
           CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3 
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.4  9  GENERAL 2
 Project Description 2.1
2.1.1  Implementation Description 
The International Small Group and Tree Planting Program (TIST) is a combined reforestation and 
sustainable development project carried out by subsistence farmers in Kenya. The farmers plant trees on 
their land and retain ownership of the trees and their products. They receive training from TIST and a 
share of the carbon revenues from CAAC.  
TIST empowers Small Groups of 6 to 12 subsistence farmers in India, Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda to 
combat the devastating effects of deforestation, poverty and drought. Combining sustainable 
development with carbon sequestration, TIST already supports the reforestation and biodiversity efforts of 
over 91,000 subsistence farmers. Carbon credit sales generate participant income and provide project 
funding to address agricultural, HIV/AIDS, nutritional and fuel challenges. As TIST expands to more 
groups and more areas, it ensures more trees, more biodiversity, more climate change benefit and more 
income for more people. The carbon credits create a new ‘virtual’ cash crop for the participants, who gain 
all the direct benefits of growing trees and also receive quarterly cash stipends based on the GHG 
benefits created by their efforts. The maturing trees and Conservation Farming will provide additional 
sustainable benefits that far exceed the carbon payments. These include improved crop yield, improved 
environment, and marketable commodities such as fruits, nuts, and honey.  
TIST provides an administrative backbone that supplies training in building nurseries, tree planting, 
Conservation Farming, building fuel-efficient stoves and malaria and HIV/AIDS prevention. Part of the 
backbone is a two-way communications network that includes newsletters, weekly meetings at the Small 
Group level, monthly meetings where groups of Small Groups receive training, periodic seminars at the 
national level and an award-winning monitoring system based on hand-held computers and GPS. TIST is 
available to everyone and all are considered equal. The rotating leadership and the Small Group rules 
empower women and the undereducated. Those who are the most successful, regardless of education 
levels or gender, become mentors and leaders. This project seeks to maximize environmental and social 
impact while supporting and improving existing agricultural activities. Planting trees on privately owned 
farms in conjunction with agricultural activities is minimally disruptive, resulting in virtually no leakage or 
baseline emissions. The project will continue to monitor the potential for leakage in the regular 
implementation of baseline surveys which assess the presence of displacement and other activities that 
could result in leakage. TIST representatives will regularly conduct site visits to farms to monitor farmers’ 
activities. Further discussion of leakage management can be found in section 3.2.3. Similarly, TIST will 
assess non-permanence factors through regular site visits. By aiming to visit farms once every 18 months 
the project will collect substantial amounts of data to make assessments of any losses and corresponding 
risk factors.  
This monitoring report is for a subset of the TIST project in Kenya and applies to 1,567 Small Groups, 
10,007 farmers, 6,321 project areas and 2,293.154 ha. The main species planted are Gravellia, Cyprus, 
and Acacia. TIST farmers use a mosaic restoration approach, planting on thousands of individual farms 
spread across the landscape.  
 
TIST estimates this project will result in as annual average GHG removal of 98,967 tCO2 and a total GHG 
removal of 5,937,992 tCO2.  
The total GHG emission removals generated in this monitoring period is 28,467 tCO2, and the net 
removals is 24,560 tCO2.

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summarized Project Description (G1.2)
The Jari/Pará REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Investimentos Ambientais S.A.
and Jari Celulose, belonging to the Grupo Jari, with the purpose of promoting forest conservation and
reducing potential greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) based on a model of local economic development
that values the “standing forest” through the integration of Multiple Use Forest Management (timber and
non-timber) and the commercialization of environmental services.
The Project is located in the municipality of Almeirim, in the State of Pará, and borders the State
of Amapá to the North. There is a very important role in this region as it serves as a home for many rural
families and as an ecological corridor, with several Conservation Units (CUs) in its vicinity. There are
several communities directly or indirectly influenced by the Project, either because they are
geographically within the Project Area or because they provide manpower, some of them being: Nova
Vida, Braço, Cafezal, Recreio & Serra Grande.
It has a very rich biodiversity, its vegetation includes ten forest and non-forest formations, the
most representative is the Dense Ombrophylous Forest, which has several variations according to its
location on the ground. In addiction to species of extreme ecological importance (27 species of flora and
fauna have some degree of threat according to the IUCN Red List) and social (extractive communities
have diverse flora as a source of income and food). The main rivers are the Tueré River, the Jari River
(state border Pará/Amapá), the Paru River and the Amazon River (to the south).
Based on the studies developed, it is noted that the main agents that threaten the integrity of the
Project region are squatters and small farmers through agriculture and livestock activities and major
infrastructure works. Therefore, the components of this Project have been developed and aligned to
minimize and avoid deforestation, as well as to promote benefits for the climate, communities and
biodiversity.

The main components of the Project relate to forest protection and monitoring; activities aimed at

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project is a Greenfield wind power project and does not involve generation of GHG
emissions for the purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction. Thus prior
to project initiation, there was nothing at site. In absence of project activity, the continuation
of current practice i.e. generation of equivalent amount electricity would have been
generated from grid connected fossil fuel dominated power plants. Thus for project activity
baseline scenario is electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have
otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the
addition of new generation sources.
Please refer to section B 4 of PDD of the UNFCCC registered CDM project with Ref No.
7133 through the web link
