inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on the approved CDM methodology AR-ACM0003 "AR Large scale - Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands", version 2. Several CDM methodological tools are used in accordance with this methodology, including the "Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality", "Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs in A/R CDM project activities", "Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks in dead wood and litter in A/R CDM project activities", "Estimation of non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting from burning of biomass attributable to an A/R CDM project activity", "Tool for estimation of change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of A/R CDM project activities", and "Tool for demonstrating appropriateness of volume equations for estimation of aboveground tree biomass in A/R CDM project activities".

The applicability conditions of the methodology AR-ACM0003 are that the land subject to the project activity does not fall in the wetland category and that soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10% of the area in land containing organic soils or land subjected to specific land-use and management practices.

The project boundary includes the areas of land where the project activity is conducted, which are former agricultural and pasture lands. Wetlands, degraded forests, and other protected sites are not included in the project boundary. Soil analysis confirms that plantations are not established on wetlands, and the project only involves soil disturbance during soil preparation before plantation, which affects a maximum of 10% of the area.

The project also utilizes other tools for estimating aboveground tree biomass and calculating the number of sample plots for measurements within the project activities. The project activity meets the applicability conditions of these tools.

Overall, the methodology and tools used in this project aim to ensure the accurate estimation of carbon stocks and changes in carbon stocks in different pools, as well as the appropriate management of soil organic carbon stocks.
inputs.context:
3 APPLICATION OF METHODOLOGY
3.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
Approved CDM methodology: AR-ACM0003 “AR Large scale - Afforestation and reforestation of
lands except wetlands”, version 2
These CDM methodological tools will be used in accordance with the methodology:
 “Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality”, version 01
 “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs in A/R CDM
project activities, version 4.2
 “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks in dead wood and litter in A/R
CDM project activities, version 3.1”
 “Estimation of non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting from burning of biomass attributable to an
A/R CDM project activity”, version 4.0
 “Tool for estimation of change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of
A/R CDM project activities”, version 01.1.0
 Tool “Demonstrating appropriateness of volume equations for estimation of aboveground
tree biomass in A/R CDM project activities”, version 1.0.1
3.2 Applicability of Methodology
Applicability conditions of the methodology AR-ACM0003: Afforestation and reforestation of
lands except wetlands (Version 2) are:
(a) The land subject to the project activity does not fall in wetland category
San Pedro plantations are established on former agricultural and pasture lands. Wetlands,
degraded forests and other sites are protected as part of the FSC certification scheme.
According to the soil classification of the IPCC, all gleysols are considered wetland soils and
therefore the respective areas are treated commonly as wetlands.
According to internal SOP’s, plantations are not established on wetlands. Soil analysis of the
plantations, which were conducted by independent consultants confirm this procedure. The most
represented soil types on the FMU 9 are Rhodic Ferralsol and Rhodic Acrisols. The data of a
Rhodic Ferralsol, which occurs on 1,100 ha of the FMU 9 is shown in Table 11. Very common are
also Rhodic Acrisols in FMU 9 (700 ha). These soil types belong to the IPCC class of “Low activity
clay soils”. However, some FMUs, incorporate gleysols typical for wetlands. Whenever this is the
case, these areas are protected and not used for afforestation or any other purposes. This is
supported by baseline and project land use plans. The plantations are established only on former
agriculture or pasture land. Further, soil analysis results are available upon request.

Table 11. Sample data of a Rhodic Ferralsol soil type, data HWSD
Parameter Value
Dominant soil group Rhodic Ferralsol
Topsoil texture Fine
Drainage class Moderately Well
Topsoil sand fraction (%) 13
Topsoil silt fraction (%) 25
Topsoil clay fraction (%) 62
USDA Texture classification Clay (heavy)
Reference Bulk density (kg/dm3) 1.18
Topsoil gravel content (%) 0
Topsoil organic carbon (% weight) 1,2
Topsoil pH 5.3
Topsoil CEC (cmol/kg) 9
(b) Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10 per cent of
area in each of the following types of land, when these lands are included within the project
boundary:
(i) Land containing organic soils;
(ii) Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land-use and management practices and
receives inputs listed in appendices 1 and 2 to the methodology.
Soil disturbance in the project only happens during soil preparation before plantation. This
activity is conducted only in the lines where trees will be planted, with a width of maximum 50 cm
and up to 50 cm depth. The maximum density of plantations uses a spacing of 5 x 2 m, with a
separation of 5 meters between lines and 2 m between trees for pure plantations. In the case of
silvopastoral systems, trees are established in double rows of 5 x 2 m like pure plantations, and
then separated by a wider alleyway in between of 9 m. In the worst case scenario using the
spacing of 5 x 2 m, soil disturbance affects 10 % of the area considering:
 A line of trees every 5 m results in 20 lines/ha
 20 lines * 0,5 m of width * 100 m of length/ha = 1,000 m2 of soil disturbance/ha
Applicability conditions of the tool: “Demonstrating appropriateness of allometric equations for
estimation of aboveground tree biomass in A/R CDM project activities” (Version 01.0.0)
This tool has no internal applicability conditions
Applicability conditions of the tool: “Calculation of the number of sample plots for measurements
within A/R CDM project activities” (Version 2.1.0)
This tool has no internal applicability conditions

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the given information, the project sector is Forestry and Land Use (specifically, Improved Cropland Management under Agricultural Land Management).
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.2 SECTORAL SCOPE AND PROJECT TYPE
The project falls within:
Sectoral Scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)
Project Category: Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land Management
(ALM)
The project is not a grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project activity is eligible under the scope 14 (AFOLU)of the VCS program in accordance with
specific requirements set out in Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard (Version 4.2) as below:
(1) According to the AFOLU requirement regarding for ALM projects, eligible ALM activities are
those that reduce net GHG emissions on croplands and grasslands by increasing carbon
stocks and woody biomass and /or decreasing CO , N O and/or CH emissions from soils. 2 2 4
The project is an eligible ALM activity as the project reduces CH emissions on croplands by 4
changing the irrigation method from the continuously flooded method to an intermittent
irrigation in the rice cultivation paddy fields. The project will contribute to reducing the rice
field N O emissions by carefully managing the nitrogen fertilizer use as well as the depths of 2
irrigation drainage. However, the project does not intend to claim emission reductions on N O 2
mitigation.
(2) The project area shall not be cleared of native ecosystems within the 10-year period prior to
the project start date.
Based on the detailed information and data from Taishan City Government1, the project area
does not involve any clearance of native ecosystems within 10 years prior to the project start
date.
(3) Eligible ALM activities include: Improved Cropland Management (ICM)：this category
includes practices that demonstrably reduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems by
increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil N O emissions, and/or reducing CH emissions. 2 4
The project qualifies as an ICM activity as it demonstrably reduces CH emissions on 4
croplands by changing the irrigation method from the continuous flooding to intermittent
irrigation in the rice cultivation paddy fields.
1The data source from People’s Government of Taishan City at http://www.cnts.gov.cn/
5

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector is Agriculture, specifically Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land Management (ALM).
inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice
cultivation is conducted in the west of Tongren City, Guizhou Province, China, with a total acreage
of 18,892 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the project, which provides ditches to conduct
intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued,
so the scenario that rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline
scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded conditions can emit a large amount
of methane because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittently flooded method is more
beneficial to water conservation, production increase, and less methane emission reduction than
the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir
construction, pumps and valves installation, training, etc. According to the needs of rice growth,
farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water
resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice
paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in
the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 3.13
tCO e/ha. 2
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to
413,980 tCO e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 2
59,140 tCO e. The project aims to reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase the rice 2
productivity resulting in higher living standards of local farmers and provide more job
opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project described falls under the Renewable Energy sector. It involves the use of renewable biomass as a fuel source to replace coal and natural gas in the steam production process.
inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Godrej Industries Limited (Chemicals Division) has a modern, integrated manufacturing facility at
Valia in the Indian state of Gujarat1. This faculty uses vegetable oils as the raw material to
manufacture Fatty Acids, Glycerine, Fatty Alcohols & Surfactants such as Sodium Lauryl
Sulphate and Sodium Lauryl Ether Sulphate. The installed capacity for Fatty Alcohols is 65,000
MT per annum which includes a dedicated Export Oriented Unit of 30,000 MT. The facility is
ISO9001 and ISO14001 certified for manufacturing Fatty Acids, Fatty Alcohols and Glycerin. The
project participant - Godrej Industries Limited is referred further as GIL or PP further in this
document.
The chemical production plant at the site has a steam demand of 18 TPH. In pre-project scenario,
the stream demand was met by two natural gas (NG) based boilers – 12.7 TPH and 13 TPH
each. Under the present project activity, a new 12 TPH renewable biomass based boiler will
partly displace steam from existing NG based boilers. Both the existing boilers will be kept under
part operations and as standby even after implementation of the project activity.
The project will use renewable biomass briquette purchased in the market. As the biomass is
generated from agro processing industry, it is a renewable biomass as per definitions in ‘Glossary
of CDM Terms Ver 07.0’2.
At the time of project planning, GIL had option to choose a coal based boiler (an economically
attractive alternative as shown in the following sections) for meeting the captive steam demand.
However, considering the GHG emission reduction opportunity, the project proponent has chosen
a renewable energy based project.
Project Location: Village – Kanerao, Taluka – Valia, District – Bharuch, Gujarat, India
How project reduces emissions: The project uses renewable biomass residue and replaces use
of coal (in baseline, and pre-project natural gas fuel in part) that would have otherwise led to
equivalent CO emissions (please refer following Sections for details). 2
Pre-project scenario: The project is located at a chemical production plant. The chemical
production plant has a steam demand of 18 TPH. In pre-project scenario, the stream demand
was met by two natural gas (NG) based boilers – 12.7 TPH and 13 TPH each.
The project is expected to reduce average 13,888 tCO annually over the crediting period. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
As per simplified modalities and procedures for small scale CDM project activities, the project
qualifies under the

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The “Improved cropland management project in Gaotang” aims to raise farmer's awareness on
the benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices to help in
climate change mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers
that prevent adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical
assistance where needed. The objectives of the project is to reduce emissions from agricultural
practices and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of practices that
change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the specific
activities are the following:
A. Reduce fertilizer (organic or inorganic) application;
B. Reduce tillage/improve residue management; and
C. Improve crop planting and harvesting.
The project is located in Gaotang County, Liaocheng City, Shandong Province, where is in the east
of China. The project activities includes reducing fertilizer application, no tillage and straw
returning to improve residue management. It also involves crop rotations of wheat and corn to
improve crop planting and harvesting. The project will cover 50,000 ha located in Gaotang County.
Prior to the start of the implementation of the project, there was no similar sequestration of
carbon, removals or net reduction of GHG activities. The baseline scenario is the continuation of
pre-project agricultural land management practices, which are common agricultural practices in
Shandong Province. The project will generate an estimated annual average removal and
reduction of 120,000 tCO e. Over the 20 years of the first crediting period, the project is expected 2
to reduce the GHG emissions by 2,400,000 tCO e in this period. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project falls under the sectoral scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry and other land use (AFOLU).
The category of the project is Agriculture Land Management (ALM). The project is a large project
using the methodology VM0042 “Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land
Management”(version 1.0). They type of the project activity is improved cropland management
activity (ICM) since the practices involved in the project activity demonstrably reduce net GHG
emissions of cropland systems by increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing N O emissions, and/or 2
reducing CH emissions. 4
1.3 Project Eligibility
4

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector is Renewable Energy. The project involves the utilization of biomass residues, specifically rice husk, as a renewable source of energy to generate heat, thereby reducing reliance on fossil fuels and mitigating greenhouse gas emissions.
inputs.context:
14The proposed project activity will lead to generation of employment and 
development in the local region. More prominently employment is generated 
amongst the local contractors, laborers and others for biomass handling at the 
project site. This is in addition to the employment generated as a result of the 
operations and commissioning of the unit. Thus the implementation of the 
project activity is expected to contribute to the provision of basic amenities to the local region, which is relatively backward and under-developed. 
 Economic well being
 
 
The proposed project activity will lead to economic development in the region at 
the micro-level by facilitating alleviat ion of poverty amongst local people. At 
the macro-level, the project activity aids to sustainable development by 
substitution of fossil fuels by renewable biomass. This reduces the country’s 
reliance on fossil fuels, majority of which is imported and provides economic 
value to crop residues, which previously had no commercial value.  
  
Environmental well being  
 
The project activity will result in GHG emission reduction by utilising biomass 
residues as fuel and avoiding use of displacing fossil fuel. In addition to the reduction in carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions the project implementation will 
avoid the emission of other harmful gases (NOx and SOx) that arise from the 
combustion of coal used in heat generation. The project will also lead to reduced ash generation since the ash content in rice husk is lower than that of Indian 
coal.  
 
Technological well being
 
 
The proposed project activity under cons ideration uses greener technology, 
which promotes sustainable development. While the project showcases an innovative way for energy utilization of  biomass (rice husk) which are not 
normally used for heat generation purposes. The emphasis on using renewable 
biomass as the fuel firmly sets an example for implementing technological processes that help mitigate the green house gas emissions. The initiative is also 
in line with the global focus towards sustainable development. 
 
1.17  List of commercially sensitive information
 (if 
applicable) :

inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The Lock Haven Improved Forest Management Project Area is a 4,905.59-acre parcel in Clinton County, Pennsylvania. It has been put under a conservation easement with The Nature Conservancy (TNC) to conserve the property and manage its forest resources sustainably. The project aims to extend the rotation age of the timber resource on the property, reducing carbon emissions and increasing carbon sequestration.

Province: Clinton County

Country: Pennsylvania, United States

Latitude: Not specified

Longitude: Not specified
inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Lock Haven Improved Forest Management Project Area (“Project Area”) is a 4,905.59-acre parcel
situated in Clinton County, Pennsylvania. The Project Area has been put under a conservation easement,
in perpetuity, with The Nature Conservancy (TNC) with the intention of conserving the property and
managing its forest resources sustainably into the future. The Project Area has ecological, scientific,
educational and aesthetic value in its present state as a natural area that has not been subject to
development or severe resource exploitation.
The Project Area is comprised of primarily native forest types characteristic of the region. The forest
protects the West Kammerdiner Run and McElhattan Run, headwaters of the Susquehanna River and the
Chesapeake Bay. The Project Area contains significant stands of diverse mixed hardwoods as well as
oak hickory forest types and wetlands that provide habitat for a multitude of species and natural
communities.
In the 20 years preceding the project’s inception, the forest across the property have been largely
unmanaged. The tracts have been heavily influenced by fire, deer browse pressure, ice damage and
forest pests but these factors have led to different trajectories of forest development based on soils,
aspect and other ecological and management factors. Major portions of Lock Haven City Authority
(LHCA) properties have been high-graded. Overall, LHCA tracts can be characterized as fully stocked,
mid-successional dominated, dry hemlock/white pine and mixed oak stands that have degraded
understory conditions with moderate encroachment of undesirable competing plants that are negatively
impacting stand dynamics surrounding composition, structure, and regeneration.
The project will extend the rotation age of the timber resource on the property by approximately 45 years
compared to Common Practice, thereby reducing carbon emissions and increasing carbon sequestration.
The project activity will employ a sustainable level of harvesting, as specified in the FSC compliant
management plan required by the conservation easement, and will facilitate improvements in the overall
health of the forest. The project on average will generate 6,383 mtCO2e annually and 370,187 mtCO2e
total GHG emission reductions and removals.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The Project is within sectoral scope 14; Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU). The AFOLU
project category is Improved Forest Management, Extended Rotation Age (IFM ERA) and the
methodology applied is VM0003 v1.2. The Project is an individual project.
v3.2 3

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The Hunan Northern and Northwestern Area Afforestation Project aims to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on barren lands in 6 counties and 4 districts in Hunan Province, China. The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 9,109,113 tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 227,728 tCO2e.

Province: Hunan Province, China

Country: China

Latitude: 29°00′33.6024″N ~ 29°30′58.7772″N

Longitude: 111°26′52.8126″E ~ 112°13′05.2497″E
inputs.context:
CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Hunan Northern and Northwestern Area Afforestation Project (herein after referred as
“The project”) is located in 6 counties and 4 Districts in Hunan Province, China, including
Guzhang County, Dingcheng District, Jinshi County, Shimen County, Hanshou County,
Xiangyin County, Ziyang District, Heshan District, Yuanjiang county and Wangcheng
District. The geographical coordinates of the project area is 111°26′52.8126＂~112°
13′05.2497＂E, 29°00′33.6024＂~29°30′58.7772＂N. The project’s aim is to
increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting
trees on barren lands. The project proponent is Jilin Forest Industry Environmental
Technology Co., Ltd.
The project area is 41,317.962 ha., with some of the project land being state-owned and
managed and operated by forest farms, while the rest being collective-owned and used
by local villages. These land owners/operators have signed land leasing agreement with
Yiyang Senhua Forestry Development Co., Ltd. and the Yiyang Senhua Forestry
Development Co., Ltd has authorized Jilin Forest Industry Environmental Technology Co.,
Ltd. the right of forest management within the project boundary in the project’s life time.
All the trees are native species, including Chinese fir, Masson pine and Poplar.
Prior to the project activity, according to the baseline survey15, the project area has been
barren since 1989, causing substantial soil and water erosion, biodiversity loss, climate
change, and perpetuated low income and poor living condition in local communities. There
are mainly scatter shrub and grass land in the project area prior to the project activity.
The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and improve
local environment by planting trees, enhance biodiversity conservation and climate
change adaptation, improve soil and water conservation in project zone, strengthening the
lifelihood skills of local communities and residents by providing their relevant technical
skills and training and create more permanent job opportunities for local women and
increase income for local communities.
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 9,109,113 tCO e in 40 2
years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 227,728 tCO e. 2
15 Yiyang Senhua Forestry Development Co., Ltd carried out the baseline survey on Nov 2014.
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 7

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.10 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
The project activity falls under small-scale project category since the annual average GHG
emission reductions are less than 300,000 tCO e. 2
1.11 Description of the Project Activity
The project activity intends to tap the waste heat of the exit gases from preheater, AQC and
also DG by the Waste Heat Recovery (WHR) captive power plant consisting of WHR boilers,
steam turbine and generator.
The project activity includes installation of 6 WHR boilers (4 for preheater exit gas and one
each for clinker cooler exit gas and DG exit gas) and one 13.2 MW steam turbine generator.
The project activity generates electricity from this generation system that would replace
equivalent amount of electricity supplied by the grid thereby reducing the emission of CO 2
from burning of fossil fuels at thermal power plants supplying power to the grid. The system
consists of four sets of WHR preheater boilers equipped with evaporator and super-heater,
8


Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
This project activity intends to eliminate the need for importing 13.25 MW from AVVNL and
generate it in-house by installation of the Waste Heat Recovery (WHR) Captive Power Plant,
utilizing the exit gases from preheater, AQC and also DG. In the absence of the project
activity, the power demand would have been met by grid which is predominantly based on
fossil-fuel fired generation plants. The project activity itself, would not contribute to any
additional GHG emissions since the chemical composition of the waste gas at the inlet and
outlet of the WHR boilers remains same and no other secondary fuel is fed in the boiler.
Thereby the project activity reduces the dependence on fossil fuel based generation units
and as there are no associated emissions with this project it contributes to the reduction of
greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions.
1.14 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
There is no a legal requirement for cement industries in India to utilize the heat content of
waste gases from the manufacturing process to generate electricity. The project proponent
would implement the project activity over and above the national or sectoral requirements
with an objective to utilize waste resources available from manufacturing process and use it
to generate electricity for its own utilization. The project proponent received the Consent to
Operate from local Pollution Control Board. It also received Host Country Approval (HCA)
from India’s CDM DNA – Ministry of Environment and Forest for registration in UNFCCC
CDM. In the absence of the project activity the equivalent electricity requirement of the
facility would be met by AVVNL grid supply resulting in CO emissions from the thermal 2
power stations (supplying electricity to grid). However, due to project activity, project
proponent would be able to replace equivalent amount of generation mix, resulting in
reduction of corresponding CO emissions at the thermal power plants. 2
1.15 Participation under Other GHG Programs
Projects Registered (or seeking registration) under Other GHG Program(s)
Project has been registration with UNFCCC under Clean Development Mechanism program,
Registration reference number is 02842.
Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The Project is not rejected by any other GHG programs.
1.16 Other Forms of Credit
Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
2 https://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/DB/TUEV-SUED1140718710.42/view
12

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
India is Non-annex1 country and there is no compliance with an emission trading program
or to meet binding limits on GHG emissions for this project activity. The project is registered
under CDM and UNFCCC (Registration ID 0284). Project Proponent has submitted
undertaking that they will not claim same GHG emission reductions of the project from CDM
and VCS. Project Proponent would not use net GHG emission reductions by the projects for
compliance with emission trading program to meet binding limits on GHG emissions.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
Project has been registered with UNFCCC under Clean Development Mechanism program.
Registration reference number is 0284. Project Proponent has submitted undertaking for not
availing other forms of environmental credit for the same crediting period under
consideration.
1.17 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
No leakage emissions are considered in accordance with the applied methodology ACM004,
Version 01
Commercially Sensitive Information
There is no commercially sensitive information accounted for the determination of baseline,
net GHG removals and for demonstration of additionality for the present project activity.
Sustainable Development
JKCL believes that project activity would lead to sustainable economic and industrial growth
in the long run and help conserving natural resources like coal. Various benefits associated
are as follows:
Social Well-being - Project activity would increase small fraction of employment for semi-
skilled and skilled labour and professionals in the region by providing direct and indirect
employment.
Economic Well-being - The project activity brings in related economic benefits for the local
community and would lead to sustainable economic and industrial growth in the region. The
project activity shows less dependence of project proponent on grid-supplied electricity.
Environmental Well-being- A major share of the region’s electricity is generated from fossil
fuel sources, mostly from coal based thermal power plants. The project activity would be
able to displace/ replace electricity generated by grid-connected power plant thus saving
further exploitation and depletion of natural resources – coal, or else increasing its
availability to other important processes.
13

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1.11 Description of the Project Activity
The project activity involves installation of rooftop Solar PV based electricity generation units with
the capacity of 10.3 MWe. The rooftop solar PV system produces DC power in Solar PV array (PV
modules are connected in series and parallel to form an array to get the desired DC voltage and
power. Modules in series, called strings, are grouped together through appropriate combiner
boxes (AJB/SMU) to ensure that the inverter inputs match with the output of the combiner boxes),
converted to AC supply through inverters and step it up to an appropriate level for supply it to the
project facility. The inverter/power conditioning unit extracts the maximum available power from
the solar array.
The project activity is designed to meet up the captive demand and electricity generated is
measured at the power plant level and are to be used as basis for quantifying electricity
generation.
Detailed specifications of the technology used are given in the Table 2:
Table 2: Technical Specifications
1.12 Project Location
The project site lies between 36 º 46' 14.1911" - 36º 46' 18.7324" E longitudes and 37º 35'
56.5221" - 37º 44' 54.6154"N latitudes. It is located at Kavlaklı Mahallesi, Onikişubat İlçesi,
Kahramanmaraş/Turkey . The location of project is shown below:
8

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
Figure 1. Location of the project site
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project is a Greenfield rooftop solar power project and does not involve generation of GHG
emissions for the purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction. Thus prior to
project initiation, there was nothing at site. In absence of project activity, the continuation of
current practice i.e. generation of equivalent amount electricity would have been generated
from grid connected fossil fuel dominated power plants. Thus, for project activity baseline
scenario is electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been
generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new
generation sources.
1.14 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The following applicable mandatory laws and regulations have been identified:
1. Electricity Market Law2
2. Law on Utilization of Renewable Energy Resources for the Purpose of Generating Electricity
Energy3
3. Energy Efficiency Law4

Consumption of clean electricity generated in the project activity by harnessing renewable energy (solar) resources has resulted in avoidance of grid power that was used by the project facility/project owner in the pre-project scenario. The project activity has therefore resulted in curbing emission of greenhouse gas, which would have been emitted from generation of equivalent amount of electricity in the grid tied power plant, that has been avoided due to the project activity. The project activity encompasses a rooftop solar power project with the capacity of 10.3 MWe. The proposed project activity deployed in Turkey by MEM Tekstil Sanayi ve Ticaret Anonim Şirketi. The project is expected to result in an average annual supply of 8,974 MWh/year. The average annual emission reduction from the project is estimated to be around 5,822 tCO2e/annum and a cumulative emission reduction of 40,753 tCO2e for the entire crediting period of 7 years.', 'project_state_province': 'KAHRAMANMARAŞ', 'project_country': 'Turkey', 'project_latitude': 37.6, 'project_longitude': 36.77}

1.3 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
1.4 Project Eligibility
1.4.1 General eligibility
The Zambia Western Province Cashew Agroforestry Project (ZAP) project falls under the scope of
the VCS Program. According to the list of eligible AFOLU projects described in Appendix 1 of VCS
Standard Version 4.5, the present project activity falls under the “Afforestation, Reforestation and
Revegetation” (ARR) category. The project aims at increasing the vegetation cover through the
plantation.
It will result in the long-term sequestration of carbon dioxide, one of the seven Kyoto Protocol
greenhouse gases, into woody biomass through cashew seedlings plantation, using a methodology
that has been approved under the VCS Program VM0047, in its latest version. It does not fall under
any of the exclusions in Table 1 of the VCS Standard Version 4.7.
1.4.2 AFOLU project eligibility
The Zambia Western Province Cashew Agroforestry Project (ZAP) will increase carbon
sequestration by planting cashew nuts seedlings. The project activities have been designed to meet
the eligibility requirements of the framework of the VCS Program by Verra, as described in the VCS
Standard v.4.7.
The project uses a CDM methodology, as approved under the scope of the VCS Program as the
project includes AFOLU activities, for ARR projects category, and follows the eligibility requirements
as specified by this methodology. This methodology is applicable under the following conditions:

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
Based on the provided information, the methodology of this project involves several steps:

1. Determining Additionality and Investment Barrier: The project aims to demonstrate additionality, which means proving that the proposed project activity is not economically or financially feasible without revenue from the sale of certified emission reductions (CERs). In this case, the project involves providing fruit trees to communities and farmers for agroforestry, which does not generate revenue. Therefore, an investment analysis is deemed non-applicable.

2. Methodology Deviations: The project uses an area-based approach with a deviation that sets leakage to 0. Leakage refers to the inadvertent transfer of emissions. Since the project matches the requirements of the VCS-VM0047 standard for a census-based approach, where continuous vegetative cover is not produced on any contiguous area exceeding one hectare, leakage is set to 0.

3. Satellite Imagery for Stocking Index Calculations: The project utilizes satellite images to calculate stocking indexes, which measure the density of trees in a given area. Complete coverage for the dry season is preferred to minimize the effect of grass vegetation. However, for the year 2010, there are not enough images available, so the coverage from 2009 will be used as an initial reference. Satellite coverages for the years 2011 and 2012 are not available, so those years will be skipped for stocking index calculations.

4. Implementation Status: The project implementation is reported to be on track, following the business plan and approved methodologies. A monitoring plan is in place, which includes steps such as geo mapping of cashew fields, random sampling of plots, carbon estimation through field measurements and remote sensing, and determining additionality and baseline through performance benchmarking.

5. Stakeholder Engagement: The project has conducted a thorough stakeholder mapping and has an engagement plan in place. Local Stakeholder Consultations (LSC) have been ongoing throughout the project life to address concerns, enhance transparency, and build confidence in the project.

Overall, the methodology involves demonstrating additionality, using an area-based approach with a deviation for leakage, utilizing satellite imagery for stocking index calculations, and following a monitoring plan while engaging with stakeholders.

Since parameters ΔSI and ΔSI were deemed significantly different (via Z test control,t=4 wp,t=4
applied as shown in equation (A5) of VCS VM0047), the project demonstrates additionality for
the performance benchmark in the first verification at time t=4. The result of the Z test
performed is 2.071, and the full process followed to obtain it is outlined in section 7.2. Baseline
emissions.
Investment barrier
As per the Tool 1 Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality - Version 07.0.0
the aim of the present step is to determine whether the proposed project activity is not
economically or financially feasible, without the revenue from the sale of certified emission
reductions (CERs). As the project consists in providing freely to the communities and farmers
fruit trees in order for them to introduce agroforestry, raising their own revenues, there is no
revenue for the project activity, thus the investment analysis is non applicable.
3.6 Methodology Deviations
The project uses an area-based approach to all its territories with a deviation that set
leakage is set 0 as the project matches almost totally with the VCS - VM0047 requirement for
census-based approach of “not produce continuous vegetative cover (associated with the
planting units) on any contiguous area exceeding one hectare”. This requirement justifies that
in this type of project leakage is set to 0, and there are no pre-existing activities that could
inadvertently transfer emissions (leakages).
The objective of the project was to plant millions of trees in an immense territory on the lands
of thousands of small subsistence farmers, to benefit local communities, and due to the
characteristics of land ownership in Zambia, this means that some plots have an area less
than 1ha, although the average of the 1,715 plots finally included in the project is 1.22 ha.
A few plantation plots (only 7, less than 0.3%), are smaller than 0.09 ha or narrower than 30
meters, equivalent to just one Landsat pixel (30x30 meters, or 0.09 ha) so for the generation
of the performance benchmark project plots must be eliminated from the selection to ensure
having good quality stocking indexes calculations.
Satellite images have been chosen to have each year a complete coverage for the dry season,
to minimize the effect of grass vegetation, when available. However, for year 2010 (t-10) there
are not enough images to have a complete coverage of the area and some of the images have
clouds that affect the project plots, so a coverage for year 2009 (complete and cloud free
withing the working area) will be used as initial reference.

VCS Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report Template, v4.3
4 IMPLEMENTATION STATUS
4.1 Implementation Status of the Project Activity
The project implementation is on track as aligned with the business plan that details the targets
and the milestones. The project activities building on to its establishment and consequent
implementation have all been in compliance with the approved methodologies (including the
VERRA standard) being applied and the safeguards. The Project has followed all the
recommendations in the Strategic Environmental and Social Assessment (SESA for the CIDP)
as summarized in the Environmental Social Management Plan. A monitoring plan is in place
and will be adhered to throughout the project monitoring period covering mainly the following
key steps;
1. Geo Mapping of the Cashew fields using a designed project specific app
2. Random sampling (using R Program) of the plots in the cashew field growing areas
across the Project Landscape for carbon estimation. With the selection of the plots,
the carbon in each of the plots is quantified through the field measurements and remote
sensing determining emissions reductions (or removals) and providing the basis for
ascertaining project performance.
3. Additionality and the baseline of the project are determined with the performance
benchmark, comparing the project plots with the control plots.
Currently, data and documentation for the verification process are being collected
systematically and prepared along with the project implementation activities.
A thorough stakeholder mapping has been conducted and the engagement plan in place to
provide the basis for integrating concerns in the design and implementation strategy. The Local
Stakeholder Consultations (LSC) has created awareness and built confidence in the project
thereby enhancing transparency and addressing core issues that if not observed would
adversely affect the project. The LSC has been considered as an ongoing process throughout
the project life.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is the "Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources" (ACM0002/Version 09). This methodology was chosen because it is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation projects that involve electricity capacity additions. The methodology includes tools such as the "Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system" and the "Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality". The project activity displaces power from the NEWNE grid, and therefore, the baseline calculation is carried out according to the approved large-scale CDM methodology ACM0002. The methodology is applicable to various types of renewable power plants, including hydro, wind, geothermal, solar, wave, and tidal power plants. The geographic and system boundaries of the relevant electricity grid can be clearly identified and information on the characteristics of the grid is available. The project activity exports the generated electricity to the western region grid through Gujarat Urja Vikas Nigam Limited (GUVNL). The project does not involve grid-connected electricity generation from landfill gas capture. Since it is a Greenfield project, historical data is not required. The methodology is not applicable to projects that involve switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy at the project site. The baseline scenario includes CO2 emissions from electricity generation as the main emission source, while minor emission sources, such as CH4, are not included. The project boundary includes the project site and all power plants connected physically to the electricity system that the project power plant is connected to. The project boundary for baseline estimation includes all power generation facilities connected to the NEWNE grid. The wind farm (project activity) has a distinctive physical demarcated boundary.

JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
Baseline Scenario:
As per the applicable methodology, a Greenfield power plant is defined as “a new renewable
energy power plant that is constructed and operated at a site where no renewable energy power
plant was operated prior to the implementation of the project activity”.
As the project activity falls under the definition of a Greenfield power plant, the baseline scenario
as per paragraph 22 of Section 5.2.1 of applied methodology is the following:
If the project activity is the installation of a Greenfield power plant, the baseline scenario is
electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the
operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as
reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in the “Tool to calculate the
emission factor for an electricity system”.
Hence, pre-project scenario and baseline scenario are the same.
Total emission reductions achieved in this monitoring period:
During the Current Monitoring Period from 09/01/2018 to 01/10/2019 (First and last date included)
the project activity has supplied 780,723.39 MWh of electricity, and thus contributing to the GHG

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: The project sector in this case is Forestry and Land Use. The project involves afforestation of degraded areas with Eucalyptus and Acacia agroforestry plantations, aiming to produce high-quality timber for the veneer, plywood, and sawmill industry. The project generates greenhouse gas removals through tree and soil carbon sequestration. It falls under the eligible AFOLU project category of "Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR)" according to the VCS Standard.
inputs.context:
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The proposed VCS grouped project “Afforestation in Eucalyptus and Acacia plantations for
Burapha Agroforestry Co., Ltd.” (hereafter ‘Burapha’), represents one of the first major
afforestation projects of the private sector in Lao PDR. It promotes and implements
afforestation of Eucalyptus and Acacia agroforestry plantations on degraded areas. These
areas are either village owned or part of governmental “Forest Protection Areas”, which entirely
are degraded by swidden agriculture for rice cropping by local communities.
The plantations are established in the Prefecture of Vientiane and the Provinces of Vientiane,
Xayabouly, and Saysomboun in Lao PDR. Local villagers are allowed to use the plantations for
intercropping or grazing, which is part of the Agroforestry approach of the project. Burapha is a
Lao-Swedish company that aims to produce high quality timber for the veneer, plywood and
sawmill industry. The project generates GHG removals through tree and soil carbon
sequestration. These credits are generated using the CDM methodology AR-ACM0003:
“Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands” (version 2).
Burapha is also FSC certified and managed to plant successfully about 3,475 ha by 2020,
contracted from 23 villages and plans to scale up its plantations to 15,000 ha by 2021. The
future goal is to manage 68,750 ha of forests in total, consisting of approximately 55,000 ha of
plantations and 13,750 ha of protected areas. These protected areas correspond to 20% of the
total area, which are set aside for conservation management.
The main tree species of the project are the exotic species of Eucalyptus cumadulensis or cross
with E. urophylla, E. pellits, or E. grandis) which is planted on 66% of the area and Acacia
auriculiformis with subsequent 33% of the planting area. The rotation period is 7 years and
during the first years the local farmers can do intercropping. Between years 3 to 7 cattle
grazing is allowed on the plantation areas and in the years 3 and 4 the plantations get thinned
out. After the first rotation the Eucalypts get coppiced and replanted after each second rotation.
The project will generate average removals of 130.2 t CO2/ha. Over a crediting period of 20
years the project will generate 408,682 tCO e and 20,434 tCO /yr. 2 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
5

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
According to VCS Standard document version 4, the project activities fall under the eligible
AFOLU project category of “Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR).
The proposed project is designed as a VCS grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project supports the scope of the VCS program by initiating project activities that sequester
carbon through afforestation of degraded lands.
A) 10 years no clearance of native ecosystems
According to the VCS Standard (V4), eligible ARR areas must be areas that have been cleared of
native ecosystems at least 10 years prior project establishment (Appendix 1.1). Furthermore,
the VCS Program (V4, AFOLU requirements) states: “Activities that convert native ecosystems to
generate GHG credits are not eligible under the VCS Program.”1
Burapha establishes its plantations on degraded areas, formerly used by swidden agriculture.
The occurring fallow forest is not deemed a native ecosystem. If clearing occurred 10 years
prior the plantation establishment the plantations are eligible under the VCS.
In terms of the land acquisition process, Burapha follows a participatory approach to identify
suitable areas for its afforestation plantations, which is described in the SOP “Land Acquisition
Operations Manual” (provided as supporting documentation, see page 13):
“Land seemingly without conflicting land use risks, in particular not with permanent agriculture.
Land shall meet the government’s definition for “degraded land2” and land allowed for forest
production (not flat land suitable for agriculture/paddy rice production).”
Burapha defined a number of guiding principles of this process, the “Land Selection Criteria”
(SOP Land Acquisition Operations Manual, Appendix 1). Amongst others, the socio-economic
criteria mention suitable land for Burapha plantations shall be “land currently without any
permanent agriculture production, primarily abandoned shifting cultivation land and where
there is minimal risk of land use conflicts.”
And furthermore:
“The previous land use shall be recorded, divided on a number of given land uses and the year
of last use of the land for economic production shall be recorded. Representative photos shall
be taken to record current land type.”
1 https://verra.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/VCS-Standard-v4.0_Updated.pdf
2 Def, Forestry Law 2019; Art 2,15: “Degraded Forest Land”: “Degraded forestland is a forestland area that has been heavily
and continuously disturbed for many years and will take a number of decades to regenerate naturally. Degraded forestlands
have a tree crown cover of no more than 10%, and a standing tree volume of no more than 20m/ha, measuring only those
trees of over 10 cm in diameter;
6

The project is not a grouped project.
According to section 3.10.3 of VCS Standard v4.4: “where applying a methodology with
scale and/or capacity limits, it shall be demonstrated that the project is not a fragmented
part of a larger project or activity that would otherwise exceed such limits. The project shall
be considered a fragmented part of a larger project if within one kilometer of the project
boundary there exists another project where:
1) The project proponents for both projects are the same.
2) The sectoral scope and project activity for both projects are the same.
3) The other project has been registered under the VCS Program or another GHG program
within the previous two years.”
The project applied a small-scale methodology, according to the KML file of the project
boundary and checking the areas within 1 km of the project boundary, there is no another
project exists, hence the project is not a fragmented part of a larger project.

The ownership of the rice paddies of the agricultural land management project belongs to
the farmers, which has been confirmed by the local government and agricultural and rural
bureau. Since these rice paddies are all legal agricultural fields, and the ownership is clear,
there is no dispute over land ownership in the project site.

have authorized Xuwen Xinpenggang Building Materials Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as
Xuwen Xinpenggang) as the sole carbon project owner which is fully responsible for carbon
project development and trading 3 . Xuwen Xinpenggang has overall control and
responsibility for the carbon project as the project proponent without violating farmers’ rights.

1. Description of Project
1.1 Project title

1.2 Type/Category of the Project
This Project activity falls under the UNFCCC Scope 1: Energy industries (renewable - / non-renewable

Over a 10-year crediting period, the total net Emission Reductions from heating and drying is

Installation of a biomass boiler at Arbec inc.
Draft VCS-PD version 1.0
1.4 Brief description of the Project
Arbec Forest Products G.P. (hereafter Arbec) operates a sawmill facility located on the banks of the
Péribonka river, at the outskirts of the village of L'Ascension-de-Notre-Seigneur, in the Lac Saint-Jean
region, Province of Quebec. The company sells both green and dried wood, the latter being the
preferred product, especially in the United States.
In July 2008, Arbec bought a nearby sawmill, which had its own logging rights. Arbec chose to close
down the newly acquired sawmill and transfer the logging rights to its Péribonka sawmill, which had
additional sawing capacity. With this recent acquisition of logging rights and the addition of new
production equipment, the production capacity of the Peribonka sawmill increased significantly to
approximately 227 MBF1 on an annual basis. However, Arbec’s drying capacity could not match this
substantial increase in sawing capacity. Before the expansion of the sawmill production capacity, Arbec
operated three (3) wood dryers, with a total drying capacity of 134 MBF per year. Hence, Arbec was
faced with an estimated drying deficit of 93 MBF per year.
In 2008 and 2009, Arbec’s drying capacity deficit did not yield significant impacts on Arbec’s business
because of the overall lower demand for lumber products due to the economic recession. However, with
the recovery of lumber markets, demand for Arbec’s products is increasing and Arbec is beginning to
operate at full capacity once again. Hence Arbec’s limited drying capacities cannot meet the increasing
demand for its products. This led Arbec’s management to consider the installation of a new wood dryer
at its Peribonka facility.
Prior to the Project, energy needs at Arbec’s L’Ascension operation were supplied as follows:
• Three dryers equipped with burners that directly fire butane to produce heat for wood drying;
• A fuel oil-fired boiler producing hot water for space heating of the sawmill building.

1.8 Project Start Date
According to VCS standard, v4.2, the project start date is the date on which activities that lead
to the generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are implemented (e.g., preparing land
for seeding, planting, changing agricultural or forestry practices, rewetting, restoring hydrological
functions, or implementing management or protection plans). For this project, according to the
requirements of the AMS-III.AU methodology applied, an entire cropping season is started from
land preparation and the emission reduction calculation is also started on this day. So, the
project start date was 07-April-20202 when the land preparation was started.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The crediting period of this project will be using a 7-year, twice renewable crediting period, for a
combined total project crediting 21 years from 07-April-2020 to 06-April-2041, and the first 7-
year period is from 07-April-2020 to 06-April-2027. Also, the project lifetime3 is 30 years from
20-March-2020 to 19-March-2050.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves determining whether the proposed project activity is a "common practice" within a sector in the applicable geographical area. This is assessed based on two conditions: the factor F being greater than 0.2 and the difference between Nall and Ndiff being greater than 3. If both conditions are fulfilled, the project activity is considered a common practice; otherwise, it is not.

In this specific project, the outcome of the common practice analysis shows that the project activity is not a common practice. The project activity is also deemed not financially attractive, and therefore additional.

There are no deviations from the methodology outlined.

Regarding estimated greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions and removals, the baseline emissions are calculated based on CO2 emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel-fired power plants that are displaced due to the project activity. The methodology assumes that any additional electricity generation above baseline levels would have been produced by existing grid-connected power plants and the addition of new grid-connected power plants.

The baseline emissions are calculated using the formula BE = EG x EF y PJ,y grid,CM,y, where BE represents baseline emissions in year y, EG represents the quantity of net electricity generation resulting from the project activity in year y, and EF represents the combined margin CO2 emission factor for grid-connected power generation in year y.

The combined grid emission factor is calculated using the latest version of the "Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system."
inputs.context:
JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
As per methodological tool “common practise” version 03.1, the proposed project activity is a
“common practice” within a sector in the applicable geographical area if the factor F is greater
than 0.2 and Nall - Ndiff is greater than 3.
Thus if both conditions are fulfilled, then project activity will be a common practise otherwise, the
project activity is treated as not a common practise.
Outcome of Common Practise analysis:
As,
i. F = 1; is greater than 0.2
ii. N - N = 0; is not greater than 3 all diff
The project activity does not satisfy second condition. Hence, project activity is not a common
practice.
Thus, the proposed project activity is not a “common practice” within a sector in the
applicable geographical area.
The above discussions show that solar power development is not a common practice and the
project activity is not financially attractive; hence the project activity is additional.
2.6 Methodology Deviations
There is no methodology deviation.
3 ESTIMATED GHG EMISSION REDUCTIONS AND REMOVALS
3.1 Baseline Emissions
As per the approved consolidated Methodology ACM0002 (Version 18.1) para 44:
Baseline emissions include only CO emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel fired 2
power plants that are displaced due to the project activity. The methodology assumes that all
project electricity generation above baseline levels would have been generated by existing grid-
connected power plants and the addition of new grid- connected power plants. The baseline
emissions are to be calculated as follows:
BE = EG x EF y PJ,y grid,CM,y
Where:
BE = Baseline emissions in year y (t CO /yr) y 2
EG = Quantity of net electricity generation that is produced and fed into the grid as a PJ,y
result of the implementation of the CDM project activity in year y (MWh/yr)
EF = Combined margin CO emission factor for grid connected power generation in grid,CM,y 2
year y calculated using the latest version of the “Tool to calculate the emission
factor for an electricity system” (t CO /MWh) 2

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03.1.
CDM – Executive Board
page 2
SECTION A. General description of project activity
A.1 Title of the project activity:
>>
Heilongjiang Muling Daimagou Wind Farm Project (phase 1)
PDD version 2.0
Completed on 7 December 2007
A.2. Description of the project activity:
>>
The proposed Heilongjiang Muling Daimagou Wind Farm Project (phase 1) (hereinafter referred to as the
Project) is to generate renewable electricity using wind power resources and to sell the generated output
to the Northeast Power Grid (NEPG) on the basis of a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA). The proposed
project activity will generate greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions by avoiding CO emissions from 2
electricity generation of fossil fuel fired power that is supplied to the NEPG.
The Heilongjiang Muling Daimagou Wind Farm Project (phase 1) is located in the Muling City,
Heilongjiang. A decision has been made to install a total of 35 wind turbines, each of which has the
capacity of 850 kW to best suit the local conditions. The total power capacity, therefore, of the proposed
project activity is 29.75MW. The expected net supplied power to the grid is 65,695 MWh per year.
The project will assist China in stimulating and accelerating the commercialisation of grid-connected
renewable energy technologies and markets which is an important objective of the Chinese Government.
The project will therefore help reduce GHG emissions versus the high-growth, coal-dominated business-
as-usual scenario. Furthermore, the project will improve air quality and local livelihoods and promote
sustainable renewable energy industry development. The specific goals of the project are to:
• generate clean electricity
• reduce greenhouse gas emissions in China compared to a business-as-usual scenario;
• helping to stimulate the growth of the wind power industry in China;
• creating local employment opportunity during the assembly and installation of wind turbines, and
for operation of the wind farm;
• reducing other pollutants resulting from the fossil fuel fired power plants compared with a
business-as-usual scenario.

>>

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project involves installation of Solar Photovoltaic (SPV) Panels on rooftops, car ports and
ground mounted in the premises of Hyderabad Metro Project by AMPSolar Generation Private
Limited. All the rooftop, car ports and ground mounted solar panel units involved in the project
are implemented under DBFOT model, i.e., Design, Build, Finance, Operate and Transfer. The
owners of the metro project are the customers of the power generated from the rooftop, car ports
and ground mounted solar panels who purchase the power from AMPSolar Generation Private
Limited under long term power purchase agreements. The purchased power by the customers is
used for captive purpose and consumed/utilized by the customers in the metro stations and
depots.
Before installation of the solar units, the Hyderabad Metro premises used to meet the electricity
demand from the national grid of the India. The project thus replaces fossil fuel dominated grid
electricity thereby reducing the equivalent amount of GHG emission.

The annual estimated emission reductions over 1st crediting period are 11,212 tCO 2e/annum.
The project is in operational phase in the same way as it has been described in the Joint PD MR
report since the commissioning.
The actual emission reductions in the current monitoring period (26-December-2020 to 31-
October-2022) are 17,798 tCO e 2 .
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project activity will have the following parameters:
Sectoral Scope: 01 - Energy industries (renewable / non-renewable sources)
Project Type: I - Renewable Energy Projects
Project Category: The project activity will apply only small-scale solar technology.
AMS-I.F.: Renewable electricity generation for captive use and mini-
Methodology:
grid – Version 05.0
The project is not a grouped project activity.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project activity involves installation and generation of electricity using renewable energy
resources i.e., by using the solar energy (renewable sources) replacing electricity supply from a
fossil-fuel dominated electricity, thus leads to reductions of anthropogenic GHG emissions from
atmosphere. Hence the project activity is eligible Sectoral scope 1 i.e., energy industries
(renewable/ non-renewable sources) under the scope of the VCS Program.
As the electricity produced by all the rooftop, car ports and ground mounted solar units involved in
the proposed project is intended to be used by the captive consumers, 100% of the electricity
generated by the solar PV units is to be accounted for emission reduction.

ProjectDescription:VCS Version4.1
1. PROJECTDETAILS
1.1. SummaryDescriptionof theProject
The project to change rice planting from continuous flooding to intermittent flooding was carried
out in Wuyishan City, Nanping City, Fujian Province, with a single season rice planting area of
10,492hectares.Withoutthisprojectprovidingditchestoconductintermittentfloodedmethod,the
continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by
continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under
floodedconditioncanemitalargeamountofmethane(CH 4)becauseofanaerobicdecomposition,
the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and
methaneemissionremovalthanthecontinuously flooded.
Withtheprojectimplementation,thecementditches,reservoirsandrelevanttechnicaltrainingare
provided for these farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice
cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. During rice cultivation,
controllableirrigationanddrainageaccordingtoricegrowthrequirementscannot onlysavewater
resources, but also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions(inthefloodedstate).Inthiscase,theCH 4emissioncanbe declinedbyanaverageof
48%1.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to
254,212 tCO e in the first seven-year period with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 2
36,316tCO e. 2
Thisprojectaimsto:
- Sequester greenhouse gas andmitigate climate changes;
- Increaselivingstandard oflocal farmers;
- Providemore jobopportunities,especially women workers.
1.2. Sectoral Scopeand ProjectType
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural
Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under
sectoral scope 15 (agriculture) of CDM, this project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU)
under Verra. This is in accordance with the definitions of eligibleAFOLU project categories set out
inAppendix1oftheVCSStandard,4.3 andcanbedemonstratedfromthefollowingthree points.

1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Project Ownership
Theparak Wind Co., Ltd is the sole owner of project activity, however it have authorised Kosher
Climate India Pvt. Ltd to act as the project participant on their behalf. Further the Ownership is
demonstrated through the following documents.
 Commissioning certificates for the Wind projects in the name of Theparak Wind Co., Ltd
 Power Purchase Agreement with EAGAT by Theparak Wind Co., Ltd
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
Not Applicable. The project activity has applied for registration under VCS programme only and
hence GHG emission reductions and removals generated by the project will not be used for
compliance under such programs or mechanisms. Further it is clarified that GHG emissions from
Project activity are not included in any other emissions trading program or any other mechanism
that includes GHG allowance trading.

Not Applicable.

The project is not seeking registration under any other GHG programs.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03  
 
CDM – Executive Board     
   
   Page 10 
 
 
The project boundary includes the equipment installed fo r the operation of the new power plant, the m ain 
elements of which are the boiler, turbine generator, condenser, water treatment plant, effluent treatment 
plant, electrostatic precipitator, step up plant/tran sformers, transmission lines and the Northern regional 
grid.  The project activity is connected to the Uttar Pr adesh grid which is part of Northern regional grid 
which is now a part of NEWNE grid. The boundary will also extend to the area where biomass residues 
are collected. The means for transporting biomass residue  to the site are also included in the project 
boundary.  
 
        
 
As per the methodology, following emission sources are to be included for the purpose of determining GHG emissions of the project activity  
 CO
2 emissions from on-site fossil fuel and electricity consumption that is attributable to the project 
activity. This includes fossil fuels co-fired in the project plant, fossil fuels used for on-site 
transportation or fossil fuels or electricity used fo r the preparation of the biomass residues, e.g., the 
operation of  shredders or other equipment, as well as any other sources that are attributable to the 
project activity;  
 CO 2 emissions from off-site transportation of biomass residues that are combusted in the project 
plant; and  
 where applicable, CH 4 emissions from anaerobic treatment of wastes originating from the treatment 
of the biomass residues prior to their combustion. 
 There is no on-site fossil fuel & electricity consumpti on that is attributable to the project activity. There 
are CO
2 emissions from off-site transportation of biomass residues but since these emissions happen in 
baseline scenario as well, these are not  included in the project emissions. There is no treatment of biomass 
prior to combustion and hence no CH 4 emissions from anaerobic treatment of wastes are involved. 
 For the purpose of determining baseline emissions, following emission sources are to be included.  
 CO
2 emissions from fossil fuel fired power plants at the project site and/or connected to the electricity 
system; and 
 CO 2 emissions from fossil fuel based heat generati on that is displaced through the project activity. 
 
CO 2 emissions from fossil fuel fired power plants c onnected to the electricity system have been 
considered. There is no displacement of fossil fuel based heat generation by the project activity.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'PingQin Water Management with Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': "The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Ping’an Town and Qinlao Town, Qing'an County, Suihua City, Heilongjiang Province, China, with a total acreage of 17,536 ha for single-cropping rice. The project area contains the project fields of rice merely, and the data of total area is confirmed by the Agriculture and Rural Affairs Bureau of Qing'an County. The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by replacing continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, this method can reduce the flooded time of rice in the whole growth cycle and the methane (CH4) emissions, and is more beneficial to production increase than the continuously flooded as well. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.", 'project_state_province': 'Heilongjiang Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 46.96, 'project_longitude': 127.62}

1.14 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The project is a project utilizing renewable energy. The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)
report was approved by Environmental Protection Bureau of Shandong Province on 28/11/2008,
and the Feasibility Study Report of the project was approved by Shandong Development and
Reform Commission on 19/12/2008. The project got CDM LoA from China DNA on 30/01/2010.
These approvals demonstrate that the project meets the requirement of national laws and
regulations, including Renewable Energy Law of the People's Republic of China and
Environmental Protection Regulation for Wind Power Project, etc.
1.15 Participation under Other GHG Programs
Projects Registered (or seeking registration) under Other GHG Program(s)
The project was registered as CDM project on 19/07/2012, and the registration number is 6580,
for which a renewable crediting period of 3×7 years will be used under the CDM GHG Program.
The project has not claimed any other forms of environment credit. The first 7-year renewable
crediting period under CDM is from 01/08/2012 to 31/07/2019. In total 133851 CERs from
01/08/2012 to 31/01/2014, among which 38199 CERs from 01/08/2012 to 31/12/2012 and
95652 CERs from 01/01/2013 to 31/01/2014, have been issued under CDM mechanism.
Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The project has not been rejected by any other GHG programs.
1.16 Other Forms of Credit
Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project has been registered as VCS project with Ref. VCS 1304. All credits of the project will
be only claimed under VCS program as VCUs for the project to avoid double counting, which will
not be used for compliance with emission trading programs or to meet binding limits on GHG
emissions.
China has initiated ETS in July 2021. As per the Notice (Huan ban qi hou [2021]No.9) issued by
Ministry of Ecology and Environment of P.R.China (MEE), the fossil fuel power and/or heat
generation plants are covered by China ETS, and also other seven industries will be included in
the future. However, as per the notice, the project is not covered by the mandatory emission
control scheme and there is no emission cap enforced for the project owner. Besides, the
allowance (CEA) for power generation industries will be allocated on the basis of carbon emission
intensity, i.e. the CEA allocation is not related with the components of local grid. Net GHG
emission reductions generated by the project will not be used for compliance under other
programs or mechanisms.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves monitoring and reporting on various aspects of the proposed project. After the project is registered and begins its operation, monitoring reports are prepared by the data recording department and reviewed by the CDM Manager before the verification of the Designated Operational Entity (DOE). The reports cover the monitoring of grid-in power generation, grid-off power to the plant, check reports, calculation of the emission reductions, and records of monitoring instrument repair and calibration.

The baseline study and monitoring methodology for the project were completed on 29/03/2010. The responsible individuals/entities involved in the study are Tsuyoshi Nakamura from Mitsubishi Corporation and Sun Yuping from Liuzhou City Xin’neng Biomass Power Generation Co., Ltd.

The project activity has a starting date of 28/08/2008, which is the date of signing the purchase agreement of steam turbines and generators. The expected operational lifetime of the project activity is 20 years.

The crediting period for the project is chosen to be 7×3 years, meaning there will be a total of 21 years of renewable crediting. The first crediting period starts on 01/07/2010 or the registration date, whichever is later, and has a length of 7 years. There is no fixed crediting period applicable to this project.

Project Summary: The project involves the implementation of agroforestry plantations in selected divisions of Bareilly Forest Circle in Uttar Pradesh, India. The project aims to plant approximately 35 lakhs trees and involves regular monitoring of the plantations. The project is focused on collecting information for conducting a Carbon finance project and designing the Project Description (PD). The project also includes support for data collection, logistical support for visits and monitoring activities, and the transfer of direct financial benefits to farmers.

Province: Uttar Pradesh

Country: India

Latitude: The latitude coordinates for the project area are approximately 27°27'N to 28°54'N.

Longitude: The longitude coordinates for the project area are approximately 78°16'E to 80°27'E.
