inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Strengthening rural livelihood through carbon finance: Agroforestry practices in Bareilly Forest Circle of Uttar Pradesh', 'project_summary': 'The proposed ARR VCS project plans to promote sustainable agroforestry for small-scale farmers to provide them with financial benefits and ensure GHG mitigation in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. The project is being conducted in five divisions of Bareilly Forest Circle of Uttar Pradesh, namely Bareilly Social Forestry Division. The main agroforestry tree species planted by farmers for the year are Eucalyptus, Poplar, Teak, Guava and Mango. These species have higher productivity that leads to sequestration of carbon dioxide at faster pace and ultimately reduces GHG emissions.This project will also help in increasing tree outside forest (TOF) that will add in mitigating climate change. The project shall also enhance the income of farmer communities along with biodiversity conservation and improvement of soil health.', 'project_state_province': 'Uttar Pradesh', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 28.35, 'project_longitude': 79.42}

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project is a wind power plant located in the District of Hatay, Turkey. It generates electricity from wind energy and supplies it to the national electricity grid. The project uses 15 wind turbines supplied by Vestas, with a hub height of 67 m and a rated output of 2.0 MW. The entire net electricity production is expected to be 91,275 MWh per year. The wind turbines are connected to the Wind Park substation through underground cables, and the electricity is transferred to the National Electricity System via a 27 km 154 kV transmission line. The installation and operation of the wind turbines are environmentally safe and do not require an Environmental Impact Assessment.

Province: Hatay

Country: Turkey

Latitude: Not provided

Longitude: Not provided
inputs.context:
VER – Verified Emission Reductions page 5
A.4.1.1. Host Party(ies):
Host party is the Republic of Turkey.
A.4.1.2. Region/State/Province etc.:
District of Hatay
A.4.1.3. City/Town/Community etc:
Sebenoba and Gözene Village
A.4.1.4. Detail of physical location, including information allowing the unique
identification of this project activity (maximum one page):
The elevation at the site of the Project Activity is approximately 400 m above the sea level and its
geographical coordinates are UTM ED50 37S 0230552/3993477. The site is 510 km from Ankara.
A.4.2. Category(ies) of project activity:
Category: Renewable electricity in grid connected applications
Sub-type: Wind power plant
Sectoral scope: 1 Energy industries
A.4.3. Technology to be employed by the project activity:
The proposed project activity generates electricity from wind energy and supplies it to the national
electricity grid. The wind turbines are supplied by Vestas. 15 wind turbines of the hub height of 67 m
will be used. The entire net electricity production is expected to be 91,275 MWh per year.
The 3 rotor blades turbines are of the type V80 of 80 m diameter. The turbine together with its variable
speed and active pitch control system was designed for a rated output of 2.0 MW, at a frequency of 50
Hz.
The wind turbines will be connected to the Wind Park substation through underground cables and the
produced electricity will be transferred to the National Electricity System (Antakya III Transformer
Station) by a 27 km 154 kV transmission line.
Installation and operation of the wind turbines do not pose any environmental hazards. The technology
of generating wind power through wind turbines is environmentally safe and sound. The host
Government also agrees to this fact and does not ask for Environmental Impact Assessments for this
type of projects, as a preliminary Environmental Impact study has been carried out that leads to the
conclusion that no negative impacts are expected. This is stated by a “No EIA required” document.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project is focused on reforestation in the Odisha State, India. Healthy saplings from good nurseries are being used for planting, and harmful pesticides are being avoided to protect the saplings and the health of the villagers and employees involved in the project. The reforestation activity is being monitored regularly to ensure the survival of the plant saplings. A record is being maintained of all plantations enrolled in the project, including details such as the name of the villager, identity card details, bank account particulars, acreage and survey number of the land, and the species of plants grown.

Province: Odisha State

Country: India

Latitude: Between NL 17° 50' and 22° 23'

Longitude: Between EL 81° 27' and 87° 23'

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
Healthy saplings from good nurseries were used for planting. Harmful pesticides were avoided
to protect the saplings and the health of the villagers and employees involved in the project.
Management & Monitoring
The reforestation activity is being monitored regularly by the PP to ensure the survival of the
plant saplings. The PP is maintaining a record of all plantations enrolled in the project, such as,
name of the villager, her/his identity card details, bank account particulars, acreage and survey
number of the land and the species of plants grown. A dedicated team of the PP regularly
monitors all the participating farmers and addresses any issue immediately.
1.12 Project Location
The project activity is located in Odisha State, India. Each project activity instance will be
implemented spread across Odisha State. The Odisha state lies between NL 17° 50’ and 22°

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Ban Odisha 05', 'project_summary': 'Core CarbonX Solutions Private Limited (CCX) is a carbon management consultancy company with a registered office in the state of Telangana. CCX is the Project Proponent (PP) of the carbon offset project called “Ban Odisha 05” in all districts of Odisha. The Project Activity will lead to considerable carbon sequestration in the project areas and will contribute strongly to the sustainable development of rural villages involved in the project.\r\nThe project quantifies the GHG removals occurring from agroforestry plantations through the use of AR-ACM0003: “Afforestation and reforestation project activities implemented on lands other than wetlands”, Version 02.0 developed under the Clean Development Mechanism for large-scale plantations. The project plans to generate carbon credits for the voluntary market under the VCS standard. Such planting activity would result in carbon credits that would be sold in the carbon market to generate revenue. As per the Carbon-offset agreement entered into between the farmers and CCX, 60%-80% of the carbon income generated from the sale of carbon credits would be distributed among the farmers. The project activity was implemented in 1900 hectares. Through carbon sequestration by the planted trees, the project is expected to generate annual average GHG emission reductions or removals of 15671 tCO2e.', 'project_state_province': 'Odisha', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 20.54, 'project_longitude': 84.69}

inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector is Renewable Energy. The Siliping Small-Scale Hydro Power Project is a run-of-river hydro power facility that generates low emissions electricity using renewable hydroelectric resources.
inputs.context:
PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM-SSC-PDD) - Version 03  
 
CDM – Executive Board    page 3

SECTION A.  General description of small-scale  project activity  
 
A.1  Title of the sma ll-scale project activity :  
 
Siliping Small-Scale Hydro Power Project 
 
Version 5  
14 June 2008  
 
A.2. Description of the small-scale project activity : 
 
The Siliping Small-Scale Hydro Powe r Project (hereafter referred to as the “Project”) developed by 
Panzhihua Reshuihe Electric Power Development Co ., Ltd (hereafter referred to as the “Project 
Developer”) is a small-scale run-of-river hydropower pr oject in Sichuan Province in the People’s Republic 
of China (hereafter referred to as the “Host Country”). Tota l installed capacity of the Project will be 10 
MW, consisting of two 5 MW turbines, with a predicted power supply to the grid of 43,968 MWh per 
annum. 
 
The project will utilise the hydrological resources of the Wenquan River in a run-of-river hydro power 
facility that will generate low emissions electricity for the Central China Power Grid (her eafter referred to 
as the “Grid”). The project is expected to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by an estimated 42,872 t 
CO 2e per year. 
 
The project is contributing to the sustainable developm ent of the Host Country. Specifically, the project: 
 
• Increases employment opportunities in the area where the project is  located (approximately 30 
people will be permanently employ ed for the project op eration and the construction of the project 
secures jobs in the construction sector)  
• Enhances the local investment environment and therefore improves the local economy 
• Diversifies the sources of electri city generation, whic h is important for meeting growing energy 
demands and the transition away from dies el and coal-supplied el ectricity generation 
• Makes use of renewable hydroelectric resources  
• Contributes to poverty allevia tion through income and employmen t generation: the Project will 
employ people throughout project operation.

The power generation in Maharashtra was totally dominated by the thermal route of generation

the target of 220 MW — for the month of September 2005 — is 620 MW.
The installed capacity3 in Maharashtra was 6.250 MW & 48.750 MW respectively for 2003-04

the start of the project activity, the wind power industry was still in embryonic stage. The State

v3.3 8

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
According to ACM0002 Version 19.0 and since the project activity is the installation of a new grid
connected renewable power plant (Greenfield) the baseline scenario is the following: “Electricity
delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation
of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as reflected in the
combined margin (CM) calculations described in the “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an
electricity system.”
Baseline emissions include only CO2 emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel fired
power plants that are displaced due to the project activity. The methodology assumes that all
project electricity generation above baseline levels would have been generated by existing grid-
connected power plants and the addition of new grid-connected power plants.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
Till date, there are no regulations and policies preventing the implementation of the project
activity.
The main Moroccan legislation with regards to the environment consist of the following, which the
proposed plant will be required to comply with:
• Law No 12-03 concerning the environmental impact study process.
Promulgated by Dahir No. 1-03-06 of 10 Rabii I 1424 (12 May 2003), lists the projects subject, the
procedure of implementation and methodology of impact studies.
This Act establishes the creation of a national committee and regional committees entrusted with
the review of the environmental impact studies.
• Law No 11-03 concerning the protection and improvement of the environment.
This law sets the general framework for the protection of the environment in Morocco, by
identifying:
o Principles of environmental protection related to human settlements and the protection of nature
and natural resources;
o Principle for establishing discharge standards and the definition of nuisances;
o Management tools and protection of the environment that are described within the impact
studies, plans and standards.
o Standards of environmental quality and financial and tax incentives. The law also establishes a
national fund for the protection and enhancement of the environment;
v3.3 9

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector is Forestry and Land Use. The North Pikounda REDD+ Project is focused on protecting and conserving a selective logging concession in the Congolese forest, specifically the North Pikounda Unité Forestière d’Exploitation. The project aims to cancel planned degradation activities and instead protect the forest area while maintaining biodiversity. It falls under Sectoral Scope 14: Agriculture, Forest, and other Land Use (AFOLU) and is categorized as a Reduction Emission from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) project.
inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The North Pikounda REDD+ Project (the Project) is a reducing emission from deforestation and
degradation plus conservation and sustainable forestry (REDD+) project designed to protect 92,530
hectares (ha) of unlogged native Congolese forest, legally designated as a selective logging
concession. The area is comprised of 60% of dry land mixed forest and 40% of areas designated as
wetlands. The anticipated selective logging would normally have been undertaken on the dry lands,
consisting on an area of 55,950 ha. Those dry lands constitute the project crediting area.
The concession is owned by Congolaise Industrielle des Bois (CIB) which has been established as a
timber operator in the North of Congo since 1968. The company currently has five active sawmills,
dryers and moulding units in Pokola and Loundoungou and employs over 900 people permanently
and more than 100 subcontractors. Four forest concessions are allocated to the CIB and all have
been engaged in sustainable forest management for several years. CIB was the first timber company
to submit a Forest Management Plan in Congo in 2005 and the first to become FSC certified in 2006.
The North Pikounda Unité Forestière d’Exploitation or Forest Exploitation Unit (UFE) was allocated to
CIB by Ministerial Decree in 2002 and is 92,530 ha (the Project Area).
The Project is located in the Northern Congo region of Sangha, of the Northern Congo forest sector.
The UFE is part of Pikounda Unité Forestière d’Aménagement (UFA)– a Forest Management Unit
(FMU), which is divided in two UFEs:
1. North Pikounda UFE, designated for timber extraction being allocated to CIB, and;
2. South Pikounda UFE, has been decreed to become "Tokou-Pikounda Protected
Area.”
The main activity of the North Pikounda REDD+ Project is the cancelation of the planned degradation
activities and the decision to instead protect the forest area, while maintaining and protecting the
biodiversity of the area. This is particularly important as the Project Area has considerable
biodiversity, including one of the largest known lowland gorilla populations in the Congo basin.
From the implementation of the Project, it is estimated that around 4,900,000 tonnes of GHG
emissions will be avoided which would have been emitted into the atmosphere over a period of 30
years in the absence of the Project, not including the Project’s Non-Permanence Risk Buffer amount,
leakage, if any, which will be accounted for over the life of the project.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14: Agriculture, Forest and other Land Use (AFOLU).
Project Category: Reduction Emission from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD).
Type of Activity: Improved Forest Management – Logged to Protected Forests (IFM-LtPF).
The project is following the steps of methodology VM0011, “Estimating Greenhouse Gas Emissions
Reductions From Planned Degradation (Improved Forest Management)” developed by Carbon Planet
to estimate the emissions that would have occurred if the legal harvesting of the North Pikounda UFE
would have occurred.
The project is not a grouped project.
North Pikounda REDD+ Project: an Improved Forest Management – Logged to Protected Forests 10

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1.4 Project Design
The project is designed to include only one project activity (ARR project) in a single defined area (East
part of the estate Oka Ecole 2).
Two types of plantations will be created:
- Agroforestry plantation combining Acacia auriculiformis and Cassava (Manihot esculenta)
foodcrop. The latter are planted only during the first two years of plantation as a co-benefit
regarding food production and do not have any relevance regarding carbon removals. The
Acacia trees are logged in short rotation cycles to produce charcoal;
- Acacia mangium "carbon sink" forest plantation: in contrast to the agroforestry plantation
described above, here the Acacia trees are left in free evolution from planting, trees are not
logged.

To include other PAIs in the Grouped Project, ownership must be demonstrated according to the
following conditions:
• New areas owned by Symbiosis, with clear supporting documentation.
• New areas owned by other participants of the Grouped Project, but with contractual rights
established with Symbiosis.
The Land Titles are available for consultation at Appendix 1.
1.8 Project Start Date
According to the VCS Standard, v4.4, the project start date of an AFOLU project is: “the date on
which activities that led to the generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are
implemented”.
The Project start date is September 09, 2020, when planting first commenced on the plots
included in the Project Area at Fazenda Novo Horizonte. This information can be found in the
operational records maintained by Symbiosis.2
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The Project Crediting Period is 30 years, starting on September 9, 2020 until September 8, 2050.
1.10 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
Considering the possibility of the grouped project, the project scale aims at large project.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: The project described in the given context is categorized under the sector of Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU). Specifically, it falls under the activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land Management (ALM).
inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Tongnan District, Chongqing City, where located in southwestern China
with a total acreage of 19,190 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this
project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward
continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by
continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under
flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic
decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation,
production increase and less methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir
construction and necessary training for the farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded
water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method.
Controllable irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth can not only save water
resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions (flooded state) In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 3.12
tCO2e/ha for rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to
419,076 tCO in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 2e
59,868 tCO 2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes.
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers.
- Provide more job opportunities, especially female workers.
- Use a proportion of benefits to improve the local children’s education.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral
scope 15 (agriculture) of CDM, this project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under
Verra. This is in accordance with the definitions of eligible AFOLU project categories set out in
Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard, 4.1 and can be demonstrated from the following three points.

[['Requirements', 'Evidence'], ['Eligible ALM activities are those that reduce net\nGHG emissions on croplands and grasslands by\nincreasing carbon stocks and woody biomass\nand/or decreasing CO , N O and/or CH\n2 2 4\nemissions from soils.', 'This project reduces CH emissions on croplands\n4\nby replacing intermittent flooded method by\ncontinuously flooded method. So, this project can\nbe categorized as eligible ALM activity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within the 10 year period prior to the\nproject start date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.1'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems by\nincreasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil N O\n2\nemissions, and/or reducing CH emissions.\n4', 'This project practices intermittent flooded method\non croplands, which is demonstrated that can\nreduce net GHG emissions by reducing CH\n4\nemissions. So, this project is an eligible ICM\nactivity.']]

1.3 Project Eligibility
According to the Section 2.1.1 of “VCS Standard version 4.1”, this project activity meets two of
the scopes of the VCS program:
1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases.
4) Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG program,
unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Accordingly, this project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the 4
six Kyoto Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and it is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of VCS program.
1.4 Project Design
The project is an instance of a single project activity.

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Prior to the project initiation the users of the solar water heaters, both residential and commercial
13,14 users, were using electric geysers.
With regards to the PV systems, prior to the project implementation, the users were importing
electricity from the grid and/or using a captive generator.
The grouped project has no direct GHG emissions and reduces the use of fossil fuel or electricity
generated with fossil fuels, and therefore has not been implemented to generate GHG emissions
for the purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction.
The baseline is the same as the scenario prior to the implementation of the project.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
There exists no mandatory law or regulation in the host country requiring the introduction of clean
energy products, therefore the project is a voluntary effort by the project proponent.
The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) indicated that Environmental Impact
Assessment is not required for clean energy product distribution projects.
The project does not violate any laws, statutes and or other regulatory frameworks in India.
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
Through the distributing organisation, it is ensured that for each clean energy product the
ownership of the rights to any emission reductions are passed on from the user (of the clean
energy product) to the buyer of the project emission reductions. At the point of sale of the clean
energy product, a warranty card will be issued to the customer clearly stating that the rights to
any carbon credits have been waived by the customer and are passed to the Project Proponent.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
There is no emissions trading programme or binding limit on GHG emissions in India that applies
to the users of the clean energy products.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project will not generate any other form of GHG-related environmental credit for GHG
emission reductions claimed under the VCS program. Where available the serial ID number of
each clean energy product distributed under the project is recorded, and each unique serial ID is
assigned to a single user whose details are recorded at the time of the purchase. Products
distributed under this programme carry the Selco logo. A searchable database containing these
details enables cross checking.

inputs.question: What are the project proponents, including organization name, phone number, email address, state/city and country of the entity responsible for managing this carbon project?
inputs.answer:
The project proponent for this carbon project is the Worldview International Foundation (WIF). The contact person is Dr. Arne Fjortoft, the Secretary General of WIF. The organization's address is 70 Yaw Min Gyi Street, Dagon Township, Yangon, Myanmar. The telephone number is (+95-18) 375292, and the email address is arne@wif.foundation.

Another entity involved in the project is the Yae Ngan Gyi Village Tract Administration Committee. The contact person is Soe Pai, the Chairman/Village Tract Administrator. The address is Yae Ngan Gyi Village, Bokpyin Township, Kawthong District, Tanintharyi Region, Myanmar. The telephone number is +95 9751227356, and the email address is not available.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project is a renewable energy generation grouped project in Africa, specifically in Tanzania. It aims to develop renewable energy resources in Africa, starting with Tanzania. The project consists of two run-of-the-river hydro sites with a total installed capacity of 3.001 MW. The first phase has an installed capacity of 1.001 MW and is expected to generate approximately 7.1 GWh of electricity annually. The second phase has an expected installed capacity of 2.0 MW and is expected to generate approximately 14.3 GWh of electricity annually. The project aims to supply approximately 21.4 GWh of energy annually to the Tanzanian grid.

Province: Njombe district in Njombe region, Tanzania

Country: Tanzania

Latitude: Not provided in the given information

Longitude: Not provided in the given information
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Renewable Electricity Grouped Project in Africa (hereafter referred to as “grouped project”) is a renewable
energy generation grouped project by Rift Valley Energy (RVE) (hereinafter referred to as “the project
owner” and “project developer”), the energy division of Rift Valley Corporation (RVC), which aims to
sustainably develop renewable energy resources in Africa starting with Tanzania (host country for project
instance). The grouped project activity will support the development of new renewable energy projects
(hydropower, wind, solar etc.) in the target countries (target countries shall be limited to Least Developed
countries (listed in appendix 1) in line with section 2.1.1 of the VCS Standard Version 4.2).
At present, the singular instance in the grouped project consists of greenfield hydro power project
instance in Tanzania owned by Luponde Hydro Limited, a fully owned subsidiary of Rift Valley Energy
(RVE).
Instance 1: The project instance 1 is located in Njombe district in Njombe region in Southern
Tanzania. The project instance consists of two run-of-the river hydro sites totalling 3.001 MW
(1.001 MW + 2.0 MW) installed capacity (Turbine capacity). Phase 1 of the project instance is
the Luhololo hydro (on Mwiha stream) with an installed capacity of 1.001 MW which is expected
to generate approximately 7.1 GWh of electricity annually. Phase 2 of the project instance is the
Igola hydro (at Lufuo stream) with an expected installed capacity of 2.0 MW1 which is expected
to generate approximately 14.3 GWh of electricity annually. Thus, project instance expects to
supply approximately 21.4 GWh of energy annually to the Tanzanian grid.
The renewable electricity generated by project instances under the grouped project activity will be
predominantly supplied to the national grid, besides supplying to local industry/community via rural mini-
grid, displacing the consumption of fossil fuel-based electricity generation. As a conservative measure
the carbon credits will be claimed only for project electricity that displaces grid-electricity.
Thus, project electricity is deemed sustainable with no damage to the environment. According to the AMS
I.D., “Grid Connected Renewable Electricity Generation” version 18.0, the baseline scenario (same as
pre-project scenario) for a project activity that consists of the installation of a Greenfield power plant
(which is the case of the project) is as follows:
“The baseline scenario is that the electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have
otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of
new generation sources into the grid.”
It is estimated that the first project instance will reduce GHG’s emissions, 10,208 tCO e per year. 2
More project activity instances shall be included in the grouped project activity subsequently. These new
instances shall be small scale (<=15MWe) grid connected renewable energy projects in LDCs.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Mandatory Sectoral Scope: 01 – Energy Industries (renewable / non-renewable sources)
1 The PO of turbine has not been placed yet and hence the capacity stated is expected, based on feasibility report. Actual
implementation may differ slightly depending upon availability of Turbine. Unless the installed capacity differs by more than
10% of the stated capacity, it shall not be construed as a deviation from project description.

1.4 A brief description of the project:
The project under consideration is set up to produce clean power from the wind electric
converters (WEC). The generated electricity is transmitted using the state transmission
system for sale to Electricity Board. The Project leads to reduced greenhouse gas (GHG)
emissions because it displaces electricity from fossil fuel based electricity generation
plants. The project considered has used the barren land at Ahemadnagar District in the
state of Maharashtra. The project is helping in bridging the gap between demand and
supply of electricity by using wind as a source for generating electrical energy.
The project activity consists of the 25 machines of Enercon make of 800 kW each,
totaling to the capacity of 20MW. The Project considered harnesses renewable resources
in the region, thereby displacing non-renewable natural resources based electricity, and
ultimately leading to sustainable economic and environmental development. Enercon
(India) Ltd (“Enercon” or “EIL”) is the equipment supplier and is also the operations and
maintenance contractor for the Project.
1.5 Project location including geographic and physical information allowing the unique
identification and delineation of the specific extent of the project:
The Project is located across villages in Panchpatta village in Akole Taluka of
Ahemadnagar District. The location of the units is on the micrositing data to get optimum
performance. The project area extends between latitude 190 45’ to 190 50’North and
longitude 73045’ to 73055’4’ East. The site is located at a distance of 120 km from
Pune by road. The Unique identification number of the turbines is as follows:

1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
The project activity is located in the NEWNE grid which is dominated by fossil fuel fired
thermal power stations. The grid is also doomed by power deficit and hence the addition
of renewable wind energy generation will help in the sustaining and catering to the power
demand. The electricity generated from the wind power project will be used for grid
supply which will increase the ration of renewable energy in comparison to non-
renewable energy.
India has two regional grids i.e. NEWNE (North, Eastern, Western and North-Eastern)
and Southern grid. The project is located in the NEWNE region and hence the baseline
for the project activity will be emissions that would have occurred by the operation of
grid connected power stations and by the addition of new generating stations. The detail
of the baseline calculation is provided in the section 4.1 of the PD.

The respective commissioning certificate for project activity are the supporting documents to
demonstrate the project ownership. This demonstrates the right of use according to clause 3.6.1

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
In the absence of the bio-methanation project activity, the waste material would have been
dumped unscientifically and ordinary landfills thereby allowing them to undergo anaerobic
decomposition resulting emission of methane gas. The baseline identified in section 3.4 is same
as the pre-project scenario.
1.14 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The Project has received necessary approvals for development and commissioning in the name
of each individual project owners and is in compliance to the local laws and regulations.
1. The applicable law in the waste management sector in India is MSW Rule 2000. The law
stipulates that all municipalities in the country should implement effective MSW treatment
facilities by 2003. Thus, all the above alternatives are legal requirement in India, but the
compliance rate of Indian Municipal Corporations with the MSW Rule 2000 is much less than
50% since municipalities across the country faces acute resource crunch (both financial and
technical) to set up modern MSW processing plant. the project activity being the most
superior form of waste management technology among other alternatives as it involves
integration of more than one technology. Thus, the project activity faces more barriers than
other alternatives.
2. Generation of Bio CNG from waste is not a legal requirement or a mandatory option.
3. Solid waste management Rules, 2016
4. Gas Cylinders Rule 2004 and 2016
5. Environment Protection Rules, 1986
1.15 Participation under Other GHG Programs
Projects Registered (or seeking registration) under Other GHG Program(s)
The Project has not participated in any other GHG programs.
Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The Project is not rejected by other GHG programs.
1.16 Other Forms of Credit
Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
Net GHG emission reductions or removals generated by the Project will not be used for
compliance with an emissions trading program or to meet binding limits on GHG emissions in any
Emission Trading program or other binding limits. The details for each proposed grouped project
activity instances added shall be described later.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The Project has no intent to generate any other form of GHG-related environmental credit for GHG
emission reductions or removals claimed under the VCS Program.
The initial project activity instances are neither has nor intends to generate any other form of
GHG related environmental credit for GHG emission reductions or removals claimed under the
VCS Program. The details for each proposed grouped project activity instances added shall be
described later.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.17 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
Leakage emissions are considered as per the applicable tool.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Sustainable Development
The National CDM Authority (NCDMA), which is the Designated National Authority (DNA) for the
Government of India (GOI) under the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change
(MoEFCC), has mentioned four indicators for the sustainable development in the interim approval
guidelines for Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) projects from India. Thus, the project’s
contribution towards sustainable development has been addressed based on the following
sustainable development aspects:
Social well being
The project activity will provide job opportunity to local people during erection, commissioning
and maintenance of the project. This directly and indirectly positively effects the economy of
nearby populace.
Environmental well being
Bio CNG generation is one of the cleanest renewable energy powers and does not involve any
fossil fuel. There are no GHG emissions. The impact on land, water, air and soil is negligible. Thus,
the project activity contributes to environmental well-being without causing any negative impact
on the surrounding environment. Further the project leads to generation of energy from waste
thus solving a major environmental concern for waste management.
Economic well being
The project activity generates permanent and temporary employment opportunity within the
vicinity of the project.
Technological well being
The Project will also contribute towards achieving sustainable waste management in the city. The
design and operation of this project, in conjunction with the avoidance of methane emissions
and production of compost as a soil amendment, will serve as an example to many other urban
areas in the country that are facing similar waste management challenges
Further Information
There are no information or incidents that will have bearing on the eligibility of the project, the
net GHG emission reductions or removals, or the quantification of the project’s net GHG emission
reductions or removals.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
The project is not a grouped project.
According to section 3.9.3 of VCS Standard v4.3: “where applying a methodology with
scale and/or capacity limits, it shall be demonstrated that the project is not a fragmented
part of a larger project or activity that would otherwise exceed such limits.The project shall
be considered a fragmented part of a larger project if within one kilometer of the project
boundary there exists another project where:
1)The project proponents for both projects are the same.
2)The sectoral scope and project activity for both projects are the same.
3)The other project has been registered under the VCS Program or another GHG program
within the previous two years.”
The project applied a small-scale methodology, according to the KML file of the project
boundary and checking the areas within 1 km of the project boundary, there is no another
project exists, hence the project is not a fragmented part of a larger project.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Hubei Jianshi IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”)
is implemented in Jianshi County, Enshi Tujia and Miao Autonomous Prefecture, Hubei Province of China
by State-owned Gaoyanzi Forest Farm in Jianshi County,the geo-coordinate of the project proponent is
109°33'E -110°13'E and 30°06'N - 30°54'N, the total area is 2665 km2, which includes the Improved
Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 7753.86 ha, including 475 subcompartments spreading over Gaoping
Town, Guandian Town, Hongyansi Town, Jingyang Town, Yezhou Town, Huaping Township, Maotian
Township, Longping Township,Sanli Township,Changliang Township,Xiaojiaping Forest Farm of Hubei
Jianshi. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned or collective-owned, and have the
legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project are Broadleaf Mix,Quercus and Pinus
massoniana.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable
government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of
the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about
1,597,176 tCO2e in 30 years, the average annual emission reduction is 53,239 tCO2e and Verified
Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 1,245,797 tCO2e in 30 years, and average annual VCUs with
buffer deduction is 41,527 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification
prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU)
Improved Forest Management: Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF)
1.3 Project Eligibility
Eligible IFM (Improved Forest Management) activities are those that increase carbon sequestration and/or
reduce GHG emissions on forest lands managed for wood products such as sawtimber, pulpwood and fuelwood
by increasing biomass carbon stocks through improving forest management practices. The baseline and project
scenarios for the project area shall qualify as forests remaining as forests, such as set out in the IPCC 2006
Guidelines on National GHG Inventories, and the project area shall be designated, sanctioned or approved for
wood product management by a national or local regulatory body (e.g., as logging concessions or plantations).
Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF): This category includes practices that reduce net GHG emissions by converting
logged forests to protected forests. By eliminating harvesting for timber, biomass carbon stocks are protected
and can increase as the forest re-grows and/or continues to grow. Harvesting of trees to advance conservation
purposes (e.g., the removal of diseased trees) may continue in the project scenario.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on ACM0002, which is the Consolidated Baseline Methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources. This methodology is applicable to the proposed project under the following conditions:

1. The proposed project involves the addition of grid-connected zero-emission renewable electricity capacity from wind sources.
2. The project does not involve switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy at the project site.
3. The geographic and system boundaries of the Northeast China Power Grid can be clearly identified, and information on the grid's characteristics is publicly available.

The project boundary includes all power plants connected to the Northeast China Power Grid. The baseline scenario assumes that the electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and the addition of new generation sources, as reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in the "Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system."

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves several steps and calculations. 

1. Step 5 of the Common Practice tool involves calculating the factor F, which represents the share of similar projects using a technology similar to the proposed project activity that delivers the same output of capacity. The formula for calculating F is F = 1 - N_diff/N_all, where N_diff represents the number of different projects and N_all represents the total number of projects.

2. The project activity is considered "common practice" within the sector in the applicable geographic area if the factor F is greater than 0.2 and N_all - N_diff is greater than 3.

3. In this specific project, the factor F is calculated to be 0, which is below 0.2, and N_all - N_diff is 0, which is below 3. Therefore, the proposed project activity is determined to not be common practice.

4. The additionality tool and common practice guideline are used to assess the project's additionality, and it is concluded that the proposed project activity is additional.

5. The official methodology AMS-I.D/Version 17, "Indicative simplified baseline and monitoring methodologies for selected small-scale CDM project activity categories," is applied to the project activity without any deviations.

6. The quantification of GHG emissions reductions and removals involves calculating baseline emissions, which include only CO emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel-fired power plants that are displaced due to the project activity. The calculation is done using the formula BE = EG x EF, where BE is the baseline emissions, EG is the quantity of net electricity generation produced and fed into the grid as a result of the project activity, and EF is the combined margin CO emissions factor for grid-connected power generation.

These are some of the key aspects of the methodology used in this project.

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
network. In addition, the construction of the plant will also enable organic waste producers in the
region to have their waste disposed at the plant.
The expected goals of the project are as follows:
a) Biodigestion of large animal manure will result in the production of biogas, which will be converted
into heat and electrical energy in the cogeneration plant. The obtained heat energy will be used for the
plant's internal needs. The energy can be economically evaluated.
b) The collected animal manure will be digested and sterilized into a more stable form and will be
transformed into a hygienic, odorless, and environmentally friendly fermented product.
c) The fermented product will contain less odor and more free nitrogen (N) compared to raw manure.
The potentially harmful organisms and pathogens that may be present in raw manure will be destroyed.
d) The recovery of organic waste collected from the environment will be ensured. Organic waste that
takes a long time to become stable under external conditions will be used in biogas and fermented
product production with the help of mesophilic bacteria in anaerobic conditions.
e) CH4 emissions arising from the current manure storage activities will be prevented.
f) Digested animal waste will be processed into fermented products. The fermented product will contain
less odor and more free nitrogen (N) compared to raw manure. The potentially harmful organisms and
pathogens that may be present in raw manure will be destroyed.
The use of animal manure as raw material in the facility will also contribute to the reduction of
greenhouse gas emissions. In this way, methane gas, which is a greenhouse gas, will be used in the
production of electrical energy and heat energy without being released into the nature.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral scopes: 01 (Energy Industry – Renewable /Non-renewable Sources) and 13 (Waste handling
and disposal).
The proposed project activity is a biogas power plant project, capturing GHGs, methane in particular,
generated from animal manure in anaerobic conditions and utilizing them via cogeneration units, for
electricity generation. Thus, the project’s type can be determined as “Waste Handling and Disposal”.
Consequently, the project falls under the Sectoral Scope 13, namely ‘waste handling and disposal’.
The project activity is not a grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Fengxi Geothermal Space Heating Project in Xi’an city, Shaanxi Province', 'project_summary': 'Fengxi Geothermal Space Heating Project in Xi’an city, Shaanxi Province (hereafter referred to as “Project”) includes two sub-projects - Non-interference geothermal energy heating project in the middle and deep layers of Fengjingyuan (hereafter referred to as “Project A”) and Fengrun Regional Comprehensive Energy Supply Station (hereafter referred to as “Project B”). \r\nThe project is planned and designed to introduce geothermal energy-based space heating system to realize heat supply to a series new residential and commercial buildings in Xi’an City over winter season, which would have received heat supply from fossil fuel-based heat supply system as a business-as-usual scenario.\r\nEmission reduction credits will be earned using geothermal energy instead of the combustion of fossil fuel for space heating.', 'project_state_province': 'Shaanxi', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 34.31, 'project_longitude': 108.73}

inputs.context:
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.2
Figure 6. Mechanical wood cutting in an SLB planting
Cutting is part of the fully mechanized operations at SLB, as at other forest operators in the
region. The considerable reduction in costs made possible by these machines means that skilled
machine operators are much better paid than manual blue-collar workers (at three to four times
more).
The appearance of the farms evolves and differs from the young plantations after the first
thinnings, creating greater diversity and increased luminosity. In fact, the lower density of trees
and the arrival of the sun to the ground allows some development of the undergrowth, regrowth
of stumps, and regeneration/enrichment of the soils in organic matter.
Finally, SLB has measured its social and environmental impact through the company Kinomé and
has made an impact monitoring plan with concrete actions, objectives, and KPIs to improve its
impact.
1.12 Project Location
The project expansion area is located in the state of Paraná, in the southeast of Brazil. The first
instance comprises an area of 949.6 ha that was planted in the 2018-2020 period and is
distributed in the Paraíso, Santa Bárbara, São José, and Santo Antonio Farms, which are located
in the municipalities of Tomazina, Sapopema, and Arapoti (see Figure 7 and Table 4).7

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project activity is set up to produce clean power from the wind energy converters (WEC’s)
which can be also named as Wind Turbine Generator (WTG). The project activity involves supply,
erection, commissioning and operation of 25 machines of rated capacity 800 kW each comprising
of 20 MW. The project is Greenfield project. There was no project installed prior to commissioning
of this project.
The purpose of the project activity is to utilize renewable wind energy for generation of electricity.
The project activity replaces anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (GHG’s) into the
atmosphere, by displacing the equivalent amount of electricity generation through the operation of
existing fuel mix in the grid comprising mainly fossil fuel based power plants and future capacity
expansions connected to the grid.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology applied to the project activity is the Grid connected renewable electricity generation methodology (AMS I.D.), version 13. This methodology is approved by the UNFCCC and is used for small-scale clean development mechanism (CDM) project activities.

The choice of this methodology is justified by the fact that the project satisfies the applicability conditions of AMS I.D., version 13. These conditions include the installed capacity of the hydropower stations being below 15 MW and the electricity generated being supplied to electricity grid systems that are or would have been supplied by at least one fossil fuel fired generating unit.

The methodology considers the baseline scenario and the project's impact on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The project boundary includes the project site and all power plants connected physically to the Southern China Power Grid (SCPG) and the Central China Power Grid (CCPG). The system boundary of the project is defined as the SCPG and CCPG grids due to regional grid definitions and substantial power exchanges among the sub-grids.

The methodology also takes into account the GHG sources, sinks, and reservoirs. In the case of the project, there are two hydropower plants with reservoirs, and their power densities determine the treatment of project emissions. The power density of the two components falls within the range specified by the methodology, allowing for the use of current approved methodologies and default emission factors.

For more detailed information about the methodology, you can refer to the websites provided in the context section.

2.VCS Methodology:
2.1. Title and reference of the VCS methodology applied
to the project activity and explanation of
methodology choices:
As per Appendix B of the UNFCCC’s “Simplified
modalities and procedures for small-scale clean
development mechanism project activities”, following
approved small-scale CDM methodology is applied to
the Project:
Project Type: I-Renewable Energy Projects
Project Category/Methodology: AMS I.D. – Grid
connected renewable electricity generation (Version
13, 14th December 2007, EB 36)
For more information about the methodology, please
refer to the following website:
http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/SSCmethodologies/
approved.html
For the calculation of the combined margin baseline
emission factor, the approved “Tool to calculate the
emission factor for an electricity system” (Version
01.1, EB 35) is used. For more information, please
refer to the following link:
http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/a
pproved.html
2.2. Justification of the choice of the methodology and
why it is applicable to the project activity
The project satisfies following applicability
conditions of the approved small-scale CDM
methodology AMS.I.D, Version 13:
• All individual hydropower stations under the
Grouped Project represent renewable electricity
generation projects with an installed capacity
below 15 MW
• The electricity generated is supplied to
electricity grid systems that are or would have
been supplied by at least one fossil fuel fired
generating unit (in this case the respective
regional grids: SCPG and CCPG)
42

2.3. Identifying GHG sources, sinks and reservoirs for
the baseline scenario and for the project:
The spatial extent of the project boundary includes
the project site and all power plants connected
physically to the Southern China Power Grid (SCPG)
and the Central China Power Grid (CCPG). The system
boundary of the proposed project is defined as the
SCPG and CCPG grids due to following reasons:
1. China has a layered dispatch system, therefore the
grid boundary definitions are determined based
upon regional grids;
2. The project power plants are connected to SCPG and
CCPG. SCPG is a large regional grid, which
consists of 4 sub-grids: Guangdong Power Grid,
Guangxi Power Grid, Yunnan Power Grid and Guizhou
Power Grid; CCPG likewise consists of 6 sub-grids:
Sichuan Power Grid, Chongqing Power Grid, Hunan
Power Grid, Jingxi Power Grid, Henan Power Grid
and Hubei Power Grid.
3. There is a substantial inter-grid power exchanges
among the above mentioned sub-grids of SCPG and
CCPG respectively;
4. SCPG and CCPG can be clearly identified as
regional grids and the information on the
characteristics of the grids is publicly
available;
5. There is a guidance from the Chinese CDM
Designated National Authority (National Climate
Change Coordination Office)7 on identifying project
boundaries and calculating the grid emission
factor for specific regional power grids,
including SCPG and CCPG.
6. Further to this, there are only two hydropower
plants under the grouped project having reservoirs
(74_Puti 1 and 75_Puti 2), and the power densities
of the two individual components (given as the
total capacity (in W) divided by the surface area
of the full reservoir (in m2)) are shown to be 16
W/m2 and 57 W/m2 (to the nearest whole W/m2).
According to Annex 5, EB 23, hydroelectric power
plants with power densities greater than 4 but
less than 10 W/m2 can use current approved
methodologies but have to use a default emission
factor of 90 gCO2eq/kWh and hydro electric power
plants with a power density greater than 10 W/m2
may neglect project emissions from the reservoir.
7 National Climate Change Coordination Office
http://cdm.ccchina.gov.cn/WebSite/CDM/UpFile/2008/20081230102527637.pdf
43

1.17 Sustainable Development Contributions
The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) defined REDD+ strategies
and initiatives as a global mechanism to provide incentives in the forestry and land use sector through
different activities. REDD+’s aim is seizing the capacity of forests to act as CO2 sinks in order to
improve community development based on actions that reduce deforestation and contribute to
ecosystem conservation and sustainable forest management so that measurable conservation results
can be obtained.
With the ACABA REDD+ Project, different activities will be planned, including sustainable
management, the improvement of degraded areas, boundary delimitation, and the destination of
areas for different land uses (agriculture, natural conservation, etc.). Other planned activities that will
benefit the local communities are related to drinking water supply, basic sanitation, and access to
information technology. They will generate multiple direct benefits and co-benefits during the project
design and implementation phases, contributing positively to the achievement of the targets set in
the Sustainable Development Goals.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project involves a new process installation at a production facility of Propylene Oxide (PO) at
MTP HPPO Manufacturing Co., Ltd, a joint venture between The Siam Cement Public Co., Ltd
and The Dow Chemical Company, which is Hydrogen Peroxide-based Propylene Oxide (HPPO)
technology instead of the conventional Chlorohydrin process. The conventional Chlorohydrin
process is one of the typical processes in the Propylene Oxide industry that involves
hydrochlorination process. In the Chlorohydrin process, Propylene (C H ) is combined to 3 6
hypochlorous acid to form a Chlorohydrin intermediate which is subsequently dechlorohydronated
to PO and leads to the formation of salts. While in the HPPO process, Propylene and Hydrogen
peroxide is combined to produce PO.
The HPPO technology will be able to reduce GHG emissions and waste generation during PO
synthesis compared to the Chlorohydrin process. GHG emissions and waste generation
reductions are owing to usage of lesser GHG intensive reagents and reduced process energy
requirements in the HPPO technology. The project activity is expected to prevent 239,356 tCO 2
emissions in a year and a total of 2,393,569 tCO for a period of 10 years. 2
The new plant will be located within the Asia Industrial Estates (AIE) site near Map Ta Phut,
Rayong, Thailand.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project activity falls under the category 5, chemical industry. The project is a single project
activity and not a grouped project.

For the crediting period, there are two options mentioned in the document. 

1. Renewable crediting period: The first crediting period starts from the registration date and lasts for 7 years. However, the specific start and end dates for the renewable crediting periods are not provided in the given information.

2. Fixed crediting period: Not applicable. No specific start date or length is mentioned for the fixed crediting period.

Please note that without further information, it is not possible to determine the exact start and end dates of the crediting periods for this project.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is Category AMS-I.E: Switch from Non-Renewable Biomass for Thermal Applications by the User – Version 01 from February 01 of 2008 onwards. This methodology is applicable for project activities that aim to avoid greenhouse gas emissions by using renewable biomass to generate thermal energy. The project activity involves the use of small thermal appliances that displace the use of non-renewable biomass by introducing new renewable energy end-user technologies. The project proponent utilizes the thermal energy generated by the new renewable energy technology. The methodology was chosen because it aligns with the project's goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and utilizes renewable biomass as a source of energy. There are no similar registered small-scale CDM project activities in the region, and the project activity does not overlap with the non-renewable biomass accounted for by other registered projects. The utilization of firewood from areas without proper management is not considered a renewable source of biomass due to its negative impact on carbon pools and increased carbon emissions. The methodology helps ensure that the project activity meets the criteria for renewable biomass defined by the UNFCCC.

The project’s emissions from the combustion of native wood are accounted in

2.2 Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it
is applicable to the project activity:
The methodology applied is Category AMS-I.E: Switch from Non – Renewable
Biomass for Thermal Applications by the User – Version 01 from February 01
of 2008 onwards which is applicable for project activities that avoid
greenhouse gas emissions by using renewable biomass in order to generate
thermal energy.
This category comprises small thermal appliances that displace the use of
non-renewable biomass by introducing new renewable energy end-user
technologies. The end-user technology in the case of this project can be
established as the project proponent, who utilizes the thermal energy
generated by the new renewable energy technology.
There are no similar registered small-scale CDM project activities in the
region of São Miguel do Guamá once Social Carbon Company made a research and
did not find any registered small–scale CDM Project activity in the region.
The sources of registered small-scale CDM project activity consulted were
the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)17 and
Brazilian´s Technology and Science Ministry 18 . Therefore, the proposed
project activity is not saving the non-renewable biomass accounted for by
the other registered project activities.
The utilization of firewood from area without any kind of management can not
be considered a renewable source of biomass, since it interferes in the
carbon pools and increases the carbon emissions to the atmosphere, turning
greenhouse effect even worse. Moreover, the native wood provided from areas
without a reforestation management plan does not fit any of the options of
UNFCCC definition of renewable biomass in Annex 18, EB 23.
Furthermore, firewood has been used for many centuries as fuel in Brazil19.

 Sub-step 1b. Consistency with mandatory laws and regulations:  
The Chinese power sector has undergone a transformation to a market-oriented system, therefore 
investment in a power generation project is an indi vidual power project developer’s decision based on the 
project return and risk profile
7. There are no laws compelling the project developer to develop wind 
power plants, thus Alternatives 1 and 2  identified are in line with all applicable laws and regulations.  
 The main sectoral policy relevant to this Project activity is the Renewable Energy Law of the People’s 
Republic of China, which came into effect 1 January 2006 and aims to promote renewable energy in P.R. 
China. This Law demonstrates the Chinese Government ’s commitment to the development of renewable 
energy as part of the overall energy developmen t strategy, and encourages grid-connected power 
generation from renewable sources. Nevertheless, there are no direct incentives such as financial grants, 
higher tariffs or subsidised loans available for these types of project.  
 
In addition to the above, although energy efficiency and renewable energy were included in the agenda 
for the P.R. China’s 11th Five-Year Plan (2006-2010), there is no legislative requirement to meet the 
projections under this Plan

1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The grouped project has not been implemented to generate greenhouse gas emissions for the
purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction. The solar PV facilities have been
developed primarily to provide security of electricity supplies to the electricity purchasers. South
Africa has been beset by “load shedding” since 20075, which has affected the security of
electricity supplies in the country. The struggle with erratic and inconsistent electricity supply in
addition to tariff increases have resulted in the exponential increase in demand for alternative,
reliable energy supply.

1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
Agreements confirming ownership of any and all GHG emission reductions created for all dwellings
will be tracked and maintained in the CDR. The recipients of weatherization voluntarily complete an
agreement transferring ownership of carbon emissions reductions to NASCSP for the purpose of
expanding the WAP. States enter an agreement with NASCSP validating the transfer of ownership
of Carbon Credits from recipients of weatherization services to NASCSP.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
For states that participate in RGGI, pursuant to which GHG emissions from certain electricity
generators in the state are regulated and subject to reduction targets for those states, the project
activity described in this project document does not count emission reductions resulting from
electricity efficiency improvements within a dwelling, only emission reductions from avoided fossil
fuel consumption. This eliminates any risk of double counting. The CDR tracks the documentation
and calculations exclude electricity savings and associated carbon emissions savings. This is
determined individually with each RGGI-participating state, as some RGGI states may be able to
count the emissions reductions.

The project has not applied for registration under any other GHG program.

The project is being developed solely under the VCS with the intention of generating VCUs.

The project has not applied for registration under any other GHG program and has not been
rejected by any other GHG program.

inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project involves the installation of a 7.2 MT/hour rice husk-based steam boiler to replace a 5 MT/hour coal-fired boiler. The project aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by displacing coal and avoiding the emission of methane from rice husk decay. It also contributes to the reduction of fossil fuel use for thermal energy production.

Province: Tien Giang Province

Country: Vietnam

Latitude: 10°22’27.04’’N

Longitude: 105°59’56.89’’E
inputs.context:
and due to natural decay in the absence of the project activity, the rice husks used in
the project would have emitted methane. Thus, in addition to reducing GHG
emissions through displacing coal, the project avoids emission of methane.
The project prevents the generation and release of methane into the atmosphere, apart
from causing local environmental problems such as river congestion and ecological
damage, and at the same time, contributes to the greenhouse gas (GHG) emission
reduction by avoiding potential use of fossil fuels (in this case, coal) for thermal
energy production.
1.5 Project location including geographic and physical information allowing the unique
identification and delineation of the specific extent of the project:
The project will be located at Hau Thanh Commune, Cai Be District, Tien Giang
Province, Vietnam. The GPS coordinates are 10°22’27.04’’N and 105°59’56.89’’E.
The project site is about 65 km from Can Tho City. Figure 1 and Figure 2 show the
geographical location of Tien Giang Province and Cai Be District in Tien Giang
Province, respectively.
Tien Giang
Province
Figure 1: Geographical Location of Tien Giang Province

Cai Be
District
Figure 2: Geographical Location of Cai Be District in Tien Giang Province
1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
The PP has proceeded with this project involving the installation of a 7.2 MT/hour
rice husk based steam boiler (refer section 1.4). The initial financial commitment for
the project was made on 31 July 2008 based on the ‘Authorised Financial Capital
Expenditure’ (“AFCE”) which is a management level approval document to evaluate
and authorize initial investments for any new project.
The commissioning (total stoppage of coal-fired boiler) and the delivery of steam to
processing plants of the PP, after stabilization of the steam production, was 1 March
2010. The crediting period requested is 10 years. The project is expected to be
operational for at least 10 years and the start date of crediting period will be 1 March
2010.
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
Prior to project initiation, a 5 MT/hour coal-fired boiler was used to meet steam
generation requirements for the rice bran pelletization facility. In the VCS project, the
operation of the 5 MT/hour coal-fired boiler has been fully stopped, and a new 7.2
MT/hour rice husk based boiler has been installed.
inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Cai Be Rice Husk Thermal Energy Generation Project', 'project_summary': 'Wilmar Agro Vietnam Company Limited produces rice bran oil, in Can Tho province, Viet Nam. The rice bran is procured from rice mills locally available within a radius of 150 km and stabilized at a pelletization plant closer to the sources of rice bran (within 60 km) in Cai Be District.  Additional steam requirement led to ceasing of existing coal-fired boiler without going for any retrofit for capacity enhancement, and the implementation of a 7.2 MT/hour green-field risk-husk based boiler. The new boiler has a rated capacity to supply 1.5 MPa pressure steam at around 198oC.  The rice husks generated in rice mills in the region are generally in excess and get disposed in unplanned ways into nearby rivers. As a result of such disposal and due to natural decay in the absence of the project activity, the rice husks used in the project would have emitted methane. Thus, in addition to reducing GHG emissions through displacing coal, the project avoids emission of methane.', 'project_state_province': 'Tien Giang Province', 'project_country': 'Vietnam', 'project_latitude': 10.37, 'project_longitude': 106.0}

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves several key aspects:

1. Risks, costs, and benefits to local stakeholders: The project considers the potential impact on local stakeholders and assesses the risks, costs, and benefits associated with the project.

2. Compliance with laws and regulations: The project ensures adherence to all relevant laws and regulations concerning workers' rights in the host country.

3. VCS Program validation and verification: The project follows the process of VCS Program validation and verification, including a validation/verification body's site visit.

4. Environmental impact assessments: If applicable, the project conducts environmental impact assessments to evaluate the potential environmental effects of the project.

5. Public comments: The project takes into account any comments received during the public comment period and either updates the project design accordingly or demonstrates the insignificance or irrelevance of the comments.

6. AFOLU-specific safeguards (for AFOLU projects): For projects related to agriculture, forestry, and other land uses (AFOLU), the project identifies local stakeholders, assesses risks to them and their resources, ensures ongoing communication and consultation, and establishes a grievance redress procedure to resolve conflicts.

7. Methodology application: The project applies the methodology AR-ACM0003, which focuses on afforestation and reforestation of lands except for wetlands. It utilizes various tools, including a combined tool for identifying the baseline scenario and demonstrating additionality, estimation tools for carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs, and a tool for estimating change in soil organic carbon stocks.

8. Applicability conditions: The project meets the applicability conditions of the AR-ACM0003 methodology, specifically that the land subject to the project activity does not fall in the wetland category. The project's planting plots belong to the IPCC class of Low activity clay soils (LAC) based on the IPCC's soil classification decision tree.

Overall, the methodology ensures that the project is conducted in a manner that considers the interests of local stakeholders, complies with relevant regulations, assesses environmental impacts, and follows recognized methodologies for carbon sequestration projects.

1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the project initiation. There is
no forestry land in the project area before the project. The lands will remain barren without the
project. Section 2.4 provides more detail information on baseline scenario.
The condition prior to the proposed carbon sequestration forestation project is summarized as
follows.5
Landscape
Huangzhong County, Huangyuan County, Datong County and Huzhu county are all located in
strong rise in Qilian Mountain, which is between Daban Mountain and Laji Mountain. If we take
Huangshui River as the boundary, the north part is south slope of the end of Daban Mountain.
Most of the terrain slopes are between 25°and 38°, and the terrain are comparatively complete.
The tributary of Huangshui River originates in the northern mountain area and runs into
Huangshui River in the south.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Yaprak Weir and HEPP', 'project_summary': 'Yaprak Weir and HEPP is a grid-connected power project in Turkey. Project activity is installed by Albe Enerji Elektrik Elektronik Danýþmanlýk Müþavirlik San. ve Tic. Ltd. Þti. (Albe Enerji in short). The project uses renewable source of Gevye River’s hydro power in Alanya/Antalya/Turkey. The total installed capacity of Yaprak Weir and HEPP is 9.28 MW. There are four turbines. Three of them have 1.445 MW’s and one of them has 4.945 MW capacity. Yaprak Weir and HEPP will be connected with a transmission line of 9.5 km of 34.5 kV to the transformer station which is connected to the transmission grid of 154 kV. The project activity will produce 24.84 GWh per year. Based on the Turkey’s Combined Margin Emission Factor of 0.4855 tCO2e/MWh, the project is expected to produce 12,060 tonnes of CO2eq GHG reductions each year. PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The present project activity aims to generate electricity using wind energy by Wind Turbine
Generator (WTG) in Badamsha Village, Kazakhstan. The project is a wind energy project
which will generate clean and renewable electricity that will displace fossil fuel-based
electricity through operation of or new addition of alternate fuels (fossil fuel) based power
plants in regional grid. Hence, this project would lead to GHG emissions and also various
air pollutants such as SOx, NOx, PM avoidance. In addition to contribute towards GHG
emissions reductions the project will also:
• Promote renewable energy projects in the region
• Contribute to the sustainable development of the region, socially, environmentally
and economically
• Lead to reduction in usage of fossil fuels such as coal, oil, gas and so on and
conservation of natural resources
The total capacity of the present wind power project is equivalent to 48 MW and the annual
average of estimated net electricity generation and estimated annual emission reductions
is expected to be 198.1 GWh/year and 172,406 tCO e per year respectively. 2

Chubu Electric Power Co., Inc. is Japan’s third-largest electric power company in terms of power
generation capacity, total assets, electric energy sold, and operating revenues. The company has total
generating capacity of 32,585 MW and total assets of 53,110 million U.S. Dollars as of March 31, 2005,

central Japan, an area with a population of around 16 million people. This area is known as one of Japan’s

tools, electric components, and new materials, are centred.
