inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on the approved monitoring methodology titled "Grid Connected Renewable Electricity Generation" with reference to Category I.D - Renewable Energy Projects: Approved Small Scale Methodology AMS –I.D. / Version 14. The monitoring for this project consists of metering the electricity generated by the renewable technology.

The purpose of monitoring is to monitor and verify the project's performance in terms of greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions and conformance with relevant criteria. It involves developing data collection methods and interpretation techniques for monitoring and verification of GHG emissions, focusing on technical/efficiency/performance parameters. The monitoring plan allows for review, scrutiny, and benchmarking of information against the M&V plan.

The aim is to have a clear, credible, and accurate set of monitoring, evaluation, and verification procedures. The purpose of these procedures is to continuously monitor project performance and key indicators to determine project outcomes and GHG emission reductions. Effective monitoring is crucial for quantifying and tracking the GHG emission reductions achieved by the project.

A proactive and efficient monitoring system helps identify any flaws in the system and provides opportunities for improvement. The general monitoring principles are based on ensuring the quantification of GHG emission reductions and maintaining the required level of reduction.
inputs.context:
VCS Project Description Template
3 Monitoring:
3.1 Title and reference of the VCS methodology (which includes the
monitoring requirements) applied to the project activity and explanation of
methodology choices:
Title of Approved Monitoring Methodology: ‘Grid Connected Renewable Electricity
Generation’
Reference of the Approved Monitoring Methodology: Category I.D - Renewable
Energy Projects: Approved Small Scale Methodology AMS –I.D. / Version 14
As per the Indicative simplified baseline and monitoring methodology AMS-I.D./
Version 14,
“Monitoring shall consist of metering the electricity generated by the renewable
technology”
Please refer to the subsequent Sections 3.2, 3.3 and 3.4 of the VCS PD for details
pertaining to the monitoring aspects for the project activity.
3.2 Monitoring, including estimation, modelling, measurement or calculation
approaches:
• Purpose of monitoring:
The Monitoring and Verification (M&V) procedures define a project-specific standard
against which the project's performance (i.e. GHG reductions) and conformance with
all relevant criteria will be monitored and verified. It includes developing suitable data
collection methods and data interpretation techniques for monitoring and verification
of GHG emissions with specific focus on technical / efficiency / performance
parameters. It also allows scope for review, scrutiny and benchmarking of all these
information against reports pertaining to the M & V plan.
The M&V Plan provides a range of data measurement, estimation and collection
options/techniques in each case indicating preferred options consistent with good
practices to allow project managers and operational staff, auditors, and verifiers to
apply the most practical and cost-effective measurement approaches to the project.
The aim is to enable this project have a clear, credible, and accurate set of
monitoring, evaluation and verification procedures. The purpose of these procedures
would be to direct and support continuous monitoring of project performance/key
project indicators to determine project outcomes, greenhouse gas (GHG) emission
reductions.
Effective GHG abatement monitoring and realization of associated benefits stand on
the quantification and keeping a track of the GHG emission reductions the project
results in. The project activity would reduce the carbon dioxide whereas an
appropriate monitoring system would ensure this reduction is quantified and helps
maintaining the required level.
Also a proactive and efficient monitoring system brings about the flaws in the system
if any are identified and opens up the opportunities for improvement.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project "Agroforestry and Forest Restoration for Ecological Connectivity, Poverty Reduction and Biodiversity Conservation in Cerro San Gil, Caribbean Guatemala" aims to improve forest cover and biodiversity, enhance food security and rural incomes, and mitigate climate change. It involves afforestation, reforestation, and restoration activities on 4,000 hectares of land in the buffer zone, multiple use zone, and zones of influence of the Cerro San Gil Protected Area in Guatemala. The project is implemented by the international private fund "Livelihoods Fund" and the Guatemalan NGO "Fundación para el Ecodesarrollo y la Conservación" (FUNDAECO).

Province: Izabal

Country: Guatemala

Latitude and Longitude: The exact latitude and longitude coordinates are not provided in the given information.
inputs.context:
JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
Project Details
1.1 Summary Description of the Project and its Implementation Status
The project “Agroforestry and Forest Restoration for Ecological Connectivity, Poverty Reduction
and Biodiversity Conservation in Cerro San Gil, Caribbean Guatemala” is a grouped project for
the afforestation, reforestation and/or revegetation (hereafter referred to as “ARR”) of lands in
Guatemala. The project started in 2013 and its main goals are: improve connectivity and / or
continuity of forest cover without negative effects on biodiversity at the community and landscape
level; improving food security and rural incomes; improving the conditions of conservation and
protected area management at the regional level, including better community resilience to climate
change; climate change mitigation; recover watersheds; reduce erosion; and generate
sustainable incomes for farmers.
The project proponent of this grouped project is an international private fund “Livelihoods Fund”
(LIVELIHOODS), co-managed by private companies (Danone, Crédit Agricole, CDC Climat,
Schneider Electric, Michelin, Groupe La Poste, Hermès, Voyageurs du Monde, Firmenich and
SAP).
The project implementing partner, of the first project activity instances, is the Guatemalan NGO
“Fundación para el Ecodesarrollo y la Conservación” (FUNDAECO). FUNDAECO is a private,
non-political and not-for-profit organization dedicated to Nature Conservation and Sustainable
Community Development. It was created in 1990, and has a history of more than 20 years of
environmental work in Guatemala and Central America. FUNDAECO is registered as a co-
managing partner in the National Protected Areas Council (CONAP).
First project activity instances pretend the afforestation, reforestation and restoration of 4,000 ha1
using four different planting systems: mixed forest trees plantations, mixed fruit tree family
orchards, rubber tree plantations and agroforestry systems in degraded lands. Project will be
implemented in more than 20 rural communities located in the buffer zone, multiple use zone and
zones of influence of the Cerro San Gil Protected Area, Department of Izabal. Project will consist
in ARR activities in small lands owned by local people/communities. Local people, with the
support of FUNDAECO, will be in charge of the implementation of project activities. This type
ARR projects promotes the sustainable development in the Region, brings benefits to the
communities, improves connectivity and / or continuity of forest cover without negative effects on
biodiversity at the community and landscape level and protects the existent natural resources.
The land uses previous to the project activity are croplands and grasslands in degraded lands.
Potential project leakage and non-permanence risk factors will be monitored and managed by
FUNDAECO following the guidelines included in this PD&MR document and in the internal project
documents.
The annual average GHG removals by sinks, in the first project activity instance (2013-2016), are
estimated ex–ante as 39,499.38 tCO -e, with a total value over the crediting period of 2
1,184,981.42 tCO -e. 2
1 See area of the first project activity instance in section 1.9.
v3.0 4

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Agroforestry and forest restoration for ecological connectivity, poverty reduction and biodiversity conservation in Cerro San Gil, Caribbean Guatemala', 'project_summary': 'The Project will establish 4,000 hectares of Agroforestry Systems and Forest Plantations in community lands surrounding the remaining rainforests of this key protected area in Caribbean Guatemala, between the international Borders of Belize and Honduras; these forests are a vital link in the Mesoamerican Biological Corridor and the caribbean migratory funnel of Central America. The Cerro San Gil is the region´s largest and most bio-diverse tropical rainforest in Caribbean Guatemala. The remaining forests of this region are truly biodiversity treasures:  phenomena of isolation and differentiated evolution took place in the coastal mountains of this region, which explains their amazing biological diversity and endemism.  Although very close in distance, these forests present assemblages of biodiversity and endemic species that differentiate them.  Due to deforestation, these forests have become “biological islands”, which must be protected and connected.', 'project_state_province': 'Izabal', 'project_country': 'Guatemala', 'project_latitude': 15.64, 'project_longitude': -89.0}

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03 .1.  
 
CDM – Executive Board     
   
   page 4 
 
 
are located at a distance of 200 km from Bangalore by road.  The nearest railway station is at 
Bangalore.  A location map is attached at Appendix – 1. 
 
 A.4.2. Category(ies) of project activity : 
>> 
The project activity is considered under CDM catego ry zero-emissions ‘grid-connected electricity 
generation from renewable sources’  that generates electricity in excess of 15 MW (limi t for small 
scale project).  Therefore as per the scope of the project activity enlisted in the ‘list of sectoral scopes 
and related approved baseline and monitoring method ologies (version 02 Mar 05/07:23)’, the project 
activity  may principally be categorized in Scope Number 1, S ectoral Scope - Energy industries 
(renewable/ non-renewable sources). 
 
 A.4.3.  Technology to be employed by the project a ctivity :  
>> 
The Project involves 38 wind energy converters (WEC s) of Enercon make (600 kW E-40) with internal 
electrical lines connecting the Project with local evacuation facility.  The WECs generates 3-phase 
power at 400V, which is stepped up to 33 KV. The Pr oject can operate in the frequency range of 47.5–
51.5 Hz and in the voltage range of 400 V ± 12.5%. The other salient features of the state-of-art-
technology are: 
• Gearless Construction - Rotor & Generator Mounted o n same shaft eliminating the Gearbox. 
• Variable speed function – has the speed range of 18  to 33 RPM thereby ensuring optimum 
efficiency at all times.   
• Variable Pitch functions ensuring maximum energy ca pture. 
• Near Unity Power Factor at all times. 
• Minimum drawal (less than 1% of kWh generated) of R eactive Power from the grid. 
• No voltage peaks at any time. 
• Operating range of the WEC with voltage fluctuation  of -20 to +20%. 
• Less Wear & Tear since the system eliminates mechan ical brake, which are not needed due to low 
speed generator which runs at maximum speed of 33 r pm and uses Air Brakes. 
• Three Independent Braking System. 
• Generator achieving rated output at only 33 rpm. 
• Incorporates lightning protection system, which inc ludes blades. 
• Starts generation of power at wind speed of 3 m/s. 
 
Enercon (India) Ltd has secured and facilitated the  technology transfer for wind based renewable 
energy generation from Enercon GmbH, has establishe d a manufacturing plant at Daman in India, 
where along with other components the "Synchronous Generators" using "Vacuum Impregnation" 
technology are manufactured.  
 
A.4.4  Estimated amount of emission reductions over the ch osen crediting period :  
>> 
Crediting Period for the Project: fixed for 10 year s

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is "AR-ACM0003 A/R Large-scale Consolidated Methodology Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands Version 02.0." This methodology provides guidelines for the implementation of afforestation and reforestation projects on degraded pasture lands. The project applies several tools referenced in the methodology, such as the Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality, Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs, Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks in dead wood and litter, Tool for estimation change in soil organic carbon stocks, Estimation of non-CO GHG emissions resulting from burning of biomass, Estimation of the increase in GHG emissions attributable to displacement of pre-project agricultural activities, Calculation of the number of sample plots for measurements, Demonstrating appropriateness of allometric equations for estimation of aboveground tree biomass, and AFOLU Non – Permanence Risk Report. The methodology is applicable under the condition that the land subject to the project activity does not fall into the wetland category.

An eligibility analysis has been developed taking into account all the eligibility criteria proposed by

with the criteria established by the methodology to define the area for the first instance (see next

a) The new instances shall meet the applicability conditions set out in the methodology applied
to the project:
 The project activity should be under the control of the project participants (PPs).
 The VCS project activity may contain more than one discrete area of land.
 Project areas are only eligible if the area had not been a forest for 10 years prior to the
project start or since the first of January 1, 1990. This criterion will be proven by ground-
truthing, satellite images, aerial photographs, official maps or land-use records (the
methodology used to define the first project activity instance is described below).
b) Are subject to the baseline scenario determined in the project description for the specified
project activity (Reforestation) and geographic area (Orinoco region in Colombia).

with the initial instances for the specified project activity and geographic area. For example,
the new project activity instances have financial, technical and/or other parameters (such as
the size/scale of the instances) consistent with the initial instance, or face the same
investment, technological and/or other barriers as the initial instance.

There is not leakage management in the project area.

2.2 Applicability of Methodology
This methodology is applicable under the following conditions:
a) The land subject to the project activity does not fall into the wetland category.
The project complies with this condition. The land cover in the grouped project area is degraded pasture.
Without intervention, it is expected that this cover would remain or that it would be partially reforested at a
rate of reforestation that has been commonly observed in the periods prior to the VCS proposal mainly
because the socio-economic conditions that created them are still and will continue to be present. A multi-
temporal assessment of land use changes, using satellite images, was developed, in order to prove the
state of land cover until 2011. These grasslands have been degraded by the ranching activity that
traditionally has taken place in the entire Orinoco region29.

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
By adopting conservation agriculture practices, the project contributes to achieving sustainable
development goals in the following aspects:
SDG12 Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns
The project is expected to make fundamental changes to the traditional
agricultural production which is deemed as unsustainable. During each
monitoring period, the amount of crop residues added to the fields and the soil
carbon stock will be monitored and reported.
SDG 13 Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts
The project is expected to achieve significant GHG removals, hence contributing
to climate change mitigation. During each monitoring period, the GHG
reductions and removals will be monitored, calculated and reported in
accordance with the applied methodology VM0042 (version 1.0).
SDG 4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning
opportunities for all
Farmers participating in the project are provided with trainings pertaining to the
idea, principle and procedures of conservation agriculture. During each
monitoring period, training records will be provided.
1.18 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
The leakage emissions are 0 (refer to Section 4.3 for details), and leakage management is not
applicable.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Further Information
There is no further information that may have a bearing on the eligibility of the project, the net
GHG emission reductions or removals, or the quantification of the project’s net GHG emission
reductions or removals.
14

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
2 SAFEGUARDS
2.1 No Net Harm
The project is not expected to cause harm to the environment. Instead, the project will achieve
GHG emission reductions and removals, maintain soil fertility and benefit local cropland
ecosystem.
Likewise, the project is not expected to result in any harm in the socio-economic aspect, either.
The project provides local population with opportunities to learn and adopt conservation
agriculture, promotes sustainable crop production, and ensures corn yield and hence farmers’
revenues, especially during years of extreme weather events. VCU sales revenues shared with
farmers will also improve their household income and life quality.
2.2 Local Stakeholder Consultation
In early 2021, the project proponent spent several months visiting villages in Zhenlai County
and had initial contact with farming households to get themselves informed of the agricultural
practices adopted as well as farmers’ general opinions about conservation agriculture. In the
meantime, the project proponent also established contact with Bureau of Agriculture and Rural
Affairs of Zhenlai County to have a “big picture” on conditions of local agriculture development.
In general, local farmers expressed hesitancy, doubt or reluctance towards the adoption of
conservation agriculture. They were doubtful about effectiveness of conservation practices in
assuring crop yield and maintaining soil fertility; they were reluctant to spend money on
machineries required to undertake the project activity; most importantly, there was a general
lack of knowledge and skills among local population to allow them to properly adopt
conservation practices.
After learning about local conditions, the project proponent decided that they would pay for
machineries if required by farmers and provide training sessions to them to build their capacity
in conservation practices.
On various dates in July and August 2021, the project proponent organized theme meetings at
each of the villages involved, invited local farmers as well as representatives from Bureau of
Agriculture and Rural Affairs of Zhenlai County.
On each of the meetings, the project proponent explained the concept and principle of
conservation agriculture; they ensured that they would provide technical guidance to farmers
during the entire cropping season. The project proponent further asked the attendees about
their doubts or worries in implementing the project activity and explained measures accordingly.
In addition, they also gave a brief introduction of the VCS program and its project development
process.
15
inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Jilin Zhenlai Improved Agricultural Land Management Project', 'project_summary': 'Jilin Zhenlai Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) implements conservation agriculture (crop residue addition and no or reduced tillage) in 60,000 hectares (or 900,000 Mu  ) of monocropping corn fields located in villages under the administration of Zhenlai County, Baicheng City, Jilin Province, China.\r\nThe project is expected to replace conventional farming practices and promote conservation agriculture, which entails incorporating crop residues in the field after the harvest and applying no or reduced tillage prior to sowing. No or reduced tillage minimizes soil disturbance; crop residues incorporated in the fields contribute to soil organic matter increase and avoid greenhouse gas emissions which would otherwise occur due to burning or other management measures.', 'project_state_province': 'Jilin', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 45.8, 'project_longitude': 123.38}

more than 500m far away from the wind machines. So it will not make significant impact to the
sound quality of the environment of residents. Noise on the impact of small wild animals is also
small. Therefore, the noise is acceptable during the construction.
2. Impact of waste residue
The solid waste produced during the construction period is mainly the domestic waste produced by
the constructors, which will be consigned to the environmental health department to collect and
carried out from the site. So the negative impact on the environment will not last.
Besides during the operation period the domestic waste produced by the working staff of the
project will be periodically carried out by tracks. The project itself will not have any apparent
influence on the environment.
3. Impact of sewage water
The sewage water produced during construction period includes mainly domestic sewage and
construction waste water. The sewage will be treated to meet the national standard.
4. Main Ecological Impacts
The project site had only some drought-resistant grasses. There are no rare plants. The wind farm
covers an area of mainly grassland, therefore, the project's overall impact on the local vegetation is
not significant. According to the survey, this area has no large wild animals, mammals, mainly
rabbits, rats and other small animals, and therefore, the impact on wildlife during the construction
period will be minor.

MONITORING REPORT : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Implementation Status of the Project
The International Small Group and Tree Planting Program (TIST) empowers Small Groups of
subsistence farmers in Kenya, Uganda, India and Tanzania to combat the devastating effects of
deforestation, poverty and drought. Combining sustainable development with carbon
sequestration, TIST supports the reforestation and biodiversity efforts of about 87,000
subsistence farmers. Carbon credit sales generate participant income and provide project
funding to address agricultural, HIV/AIDS, nutritional and fuel challenges. As TIST expands to
more groups and more areas, it ensures more trees, more biodiversity, more climate change
benefit and more income for more people.
Since its inception in 1999, TIST participants organized into over 12,000 TIST Small Groups have
planted over 18 million trees on their own and community lands. GhG sequestration is creating a
long-term income stream and developing sustainable environments and livelihoods. TIST in
Uganda began in 2003 and has grown to about 14,500 TIST participants in about 2,200 Small
Groups.
UG PD-VCS-002 is a small scale AFOLU project, eligible under the Afforestation, Reforestation
and Revegetation (ARR) category. It is a subset of the TIST project in Uganda and initially
applied to 17 of the Small Groups, 94 members, 22 project areas and 169 ha. The PD was
validated and first verified on 20 March 2012 by Environmental Services, Inc. (ESI).
UG-VCS-002 was verified a second time 27 October 2014 by JACO CDM. The verification period
was 07 October 11 to 31 December 2013. The verification demonstrated 22 project areas, 154
ha and 150,306 trees.
This is the third verification of UG-VCS-002 and was conducted by EPIC Sustainability. The
verification period was 01 January 2014 to 17 April 2019. The monitoring demonstrated 17
project areas, 141 ha and 116395 trees.
The following is the verification history, including the total GHG removals generated in this
monitoring period
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is registered under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS 3.7) as an Afforestation,
Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) project and has been developed in compliance with the
VCS Guidance for Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use Projects (VCS Version 3.6). It is not
a grouped project.

1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
According to VCS Standard document version 4.2, chapter A1.1 (19.09.2019) the project
activities fall under the eligible AFOLU project category of “Afforestation, Reforestation and
Revegetation (ARR)”. The proposed project is a grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The proposed project activity supports the scope of the VCS program by initiating project activities
that sequester carbon through afforestation of former agricultural and implanted and natural
pasture land, encompassing 344.5 ha and 610.5 ha of first instance plantations, respectively.
The following eligibility criteria have to be met, to be accounted as AFOLU, ARR project under the
VCS.
10 years no deforestation of native ecosystems:
According to the VCS Standard (V4.2) Appendix 1.1., eligible AR areas must have been cleared of
native ecosystems at least 10 years prior project establishment. Furthermore, according to
chapter 3.2.4, activities that convert native ecosystems to generate GHG credits are not eligible
under the VCS Program1.
The project area consisted of agricultural fields, mostly mechanized soy, or implanted pasture,
before tree planting took place.
Through a historical forest cover analysis of the project area, areas where conversion of natural
forests took place less than 10 years before project start were identified and excluded from the
scope of the Carbon Project. Small patches where conversion took place were conducted by
previous owners (Figure 1 and Figure 2). Therefore, 1.5 ha have been excluded from this
validation process.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector of this project is Agriculture, specifically under the category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) within the sectoral scope of Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU).
inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice
cultivation is conducted in Tonghe County, Harbin City, Heilongjiang Province, China, with a total
acreage of 17,621 ha of single-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches,
pumps, valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional
continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was
cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic
decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of
methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water,
improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir
construction, pumps and valves installation, training, etc. According to the needs of rice growth,
farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water
resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice
paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in
the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 3.33
tCO e/ha. 2
The project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions by 410,298 tCO e in the first seven-year 2
period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 58,614 tCO e. The project aims to 2
reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living
standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

So, this project\ncan be categorized as eligible ALM activity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within 10 years before the project\nstart date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.1'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems by\nincreasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil N O\n2\nemissions, and/or reducing CH emissions.\n4', 'This project practices intermittently flooded\nmethods on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH emissions. Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
03/08/2008 and fixed crediting period of 10 years has been chosen for this project activity
in VCS. Hence crediting period of the project activity becomes same as CDM crediting
period i.e 12/11/2010 to 11/11/2020. Hence project is eligible under VCS as VCS crediting
period is not breaching the CDM crediting period.
1.4 Project Design
The proposed project activity employs state of art technology that uses solar radiation to
heat up ambient water. The Solar water heater works on the principle of absorption of solar
radiation by black body. Solar energy is received on earth surface in form of radiation
comprises mostly of the visible and infrared wavelength. The black body intercepting the
solar radiation converts solar energy into heat which is transferred to the fluid. The
collector are insulated at the bottom and exposed to solar radiation. As the black surface
absorbs radiation in the complete wave length region of the solar spectrum, it gains heat
and starts loosing heat to the surrounding. To prevent the heat loss the collector is
enclosed within a glass enclosure that provides a greenhouse effect. Glass allows
transmitting most of the visible part of the radiation and part of the near infra-red radiation
however it is opaque to infrared wavelength range in which the hot plates emit radiation.
The heat absorbed by the solar collector is transferred to the water flowing through it.
Heated water is collected in the tank which is insulated to prevent heat loss. Circulation of
the water from the tank through the collector and back to the tank continues automatically
due to the density difference between the hot and cold water by thermo syphon effect.
Eligibility Criteria
Not applicable to this project activity as this is not a grouped project.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
Based on the provided information, the methodology of this project includes the following steps:

1. Monitoring and Recording: Qixia Runlin Wind Power Development Co., Ltd. is responsible for monitoring and recording the output from the project. Two meters are used, with one main meter used for both emission reduction purposes and sales of the electricity generated to the grid company.

2. Calibration and Accuracy Check: The meters used for monitoring will be calibrated and checked annually for accuracy. The maximum error allowed is 0.5% of the full-scale rating.

3. Approval and Storage: The monthly net generation data will be approved and signed off by Mr. Lin Jinghao before it is accepted and stored.

4. Internal Audit: An internal audit will be conducted to identify any potential improvements to monitoring and reporting procedures in future years.

5. Reporting to DOE: If any improvements are proposed, they will be reported to the DOE (Department of Energy) and will only be operationalized after approval from the DOE.

6. Calculation of Project Share: As the proposed project is likely to share the substation with other projects in the future, the output data from each turbine is used to calculate the share of the project in the overall output and losses from the substation.

Overall, the project follows a monitoring plan and involves various stakeholders, including Qixia Runlin Wind Power Development Co., Ltd., specialists from CRM and NCPG, monitoring staff, and auditing staff. The project activity started on September 15, 2006, and is expected to have an operational lifetime of 20 years. The first crediting period is not specified in the provided information.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves the installation of a new landfill gas (LFG) capture system in an existing or new solid waste disposal site (SWDS) where no LFG capture system was previously installed. Alternatively, it can involve making an investment into an existing LFG capture system to increase the recovery rate or change the use of the captured LFG. The captured LFG can be flared or used in various ways such as generating electricity, generating heat, supplying to consumers through a natural gas distribution network, or supplying compressed/liquefied LFG to consumers using trucks. The methodology also requires that the project does not reduce the amount of organic waste that would be recycled in the absence of the project activity.

The methodology is applicable if the baseline scenario confirms that the most plausible scenario is the atmospheric release of the LFG or capture of LFG and destruction through flaring to comply with regulations or contractual requirements, address safety and odor concerns, or for other reasons. In the case of using LFG for electricity or heat generation, the baseline scenario assumes that the electricity would be generated in the grid or in captive fossil fuel-fired power plants, and the heat would be generated using fossil fuels in equipment within the project boundary. If LFG is supplied to end-users through a natural gas distribution network, trucks, or a dedicated pipeline, the baseline scenario assumes displacement of natural gas. In the case of a Greenfield SWDS, the baseline scenario is the atmospheric release of the LFG or capture of LFG in a managed SWDS and destruction through flaring to comply with regulations or contractual requirements, address safety and odor concerns, or for other reasons.

The methodology is not applicable in combination with other approved methodologies or if the management of the SWDS is deliberately changed during the crediting process to increase methane generation compared to the situation prior to the implementation of the project activity.

In terms of emissions, the methodology considers CO2 emissions resulting from the organic waste decomposition but does not consider the emissions of N2O from solid waste disposal sites.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Hyundai Steel Waste Energy Recovery Co-Generation Project Phase II (hereafter
referred in this document as the ‘proposed project’) is a 400MW cogeneration plant at Dangjin
Hyundai Steel Mill, which is developed by Hyundai Green power CO., Ltd(hereafter referred in
this document as the ‘project owner').
The project utilizes surplus waste gases including BFG(Blast Furnace Gas), COG(Coke Oven
Gas) and LDG(Converter Gas) produced by Dangjin Hyundai Steel Mill, to generate electricity.
The waste gases created by Dangjin Hyundai Steel Mill are reused by the steel mill and the
rest are consumed by the proposed project. Through this project, approximately
2,306,076MWh electricity will be sent to power grid, and steam will also be produced and sent
to Hyundai steel mill. Without the proposed project the rest of waste gases are emitted to
atmosphere after incineration, the electricity generated by the proposed project will be
supplied by grid.
The Project has significant benefits:
- Energy saving (recycling) by using waste energy,
- Using local energy as opposed to importing energy from foreign countries,
- Reducing environmental pollution, and meeting the current environmental policies of South
Korea.
Additionally, the project is innovative in that it differs from the traditional thermal electricity
generation process, as it uses a high efficiency compound generation system decreasing the
amount of imported fuel and reducing emissions by approximately 1,441,680tCO e/year. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project activity pertains to sectoral scope 1 (Energy industries (renewable / non-
renewable) & 4 (Manufacturing industries)
1.3 Project Proponent

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on the approved consolidated methodology ACM0002/Version 13.0.0, which is the "Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources" as approved by the CDM Executive Board. The project also uses the "Tool to calculate emission factor for an electricity system" (Version 02.2.1) to calculate the emission factor of the Turkish electricity grid and the "Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality" (Version 06.1.0) to prove additionality and calculate the grid emission factor.

The project activity falls under the applicability conditions of the ACM0002 methodology, which applies to grid-connected renewable power generation activities. The project complies with the specific conditions mentioned in the methodology, such as the type of power plant (hydro, wind, geothermal, solar, wave, or tidal), the location (Yeşilırmak River basin), and the specifications of the power plant (3 Kaplan turbines with 9.75 MW power each).

The project boundary includes the project power plant and all power plants physically connected to the electricity system that the CDM project power plant is connected to.

Overall, the methodology ensures that the project activity meets the necessary requirements and standards for calculating emissions and demonstrating additionality in grid-connected renewable power generation.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
2 APPLICATION OF METHODOLOGY
2.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
For the purpose of calculating the emission factor of the Turkish electricity grid,” Tool to calculate
emission factor for an electricity system”, Version 02.2.1 is employed.14 The baseline and
monitoring plan for the project was established through the official methodology of
ACM0002/Version 13.0.0, “Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity
generation from renewable sources”15 as approved by the CDM Executive Board. Also, to prove
additionality and to calculate the grid emission factor, the official methodology: “Tool for the
demonstration and assessment of additionality, Version 06.1.0”16 is used. Conservative options and
data were selected during the implementation of the methodology.
2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation activities under
certain conditions. The applicability conditions of the approved consolidated methodology and how
the project activity complies with them are described below:

1.7 Ownership
Land Ownership
In Mexico, land ownership consists of two forms. There are community-owned parcels of land known as
“Ejidos”, modelled after traditional Amerindian models of land ownership. The rights to these lands exist
with the respective communities, and any activities that leverage those rights are required to get the
consent of the entire community, or at least the “Ejido Council” that governs the community. In some
instances where the Ejidos have subdivided the rights associated with a certain domain or piece of land
to a subset of the community, the consent of that subset of the community is required. All Ejidos are
protected by Mexico’s La Ley Agraria (The Agrarian Law) and are recorded in the Registro Agrario
Nacional2 in Mexico City.
In addition to Ejidos, there are also direct private ownerships of land by individuals or organizations, who
have land records to substantiate their claims to the land, and these are recorded in the Public Property
Registry of each state in Mexico3.
Credit Ownership
The individuals or entities enrolling their lands irrevocably assign the right, title and interest to the
Greenhouse Gas Reductions and Removals thus generated on their lands during the project to
ConserWater Technologies Inc (doing business as Boomitra). The individuals or entities enrolling their
lands disclaim all right, title and interest to any Carbon Credits that may arise from the Land. This is
covered by legal agreements with the individuals and/or entities enrolling their lands.
1.8 Project Start Date
Project Start Date: 1st July 2017

1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Project Ownership
The Project Proponent of the Project Activity, Southern Power Company, holds the Right of Use
of the Project Activity consistent with Clause (3) of Section 3.11.1 of the VCS Standard, v3.7.
Southern Power Company has full ownership of the wind power plant, equipment, and systems
that generate the GHG emission reductions, and has not been divested of such ownership.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
There are no local, state, or federal emissions trading programs or other regulatory binding
requirements for the Project or wind power generation in the United States.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The Project has not sought or received any other form of GHG environmental credits. The Project
Activity, as a result of supplying renewable energy to the SPP grid, would be eligible for
Renewable Energy Certificate (REC) issuances. However, the Power Purchase Agreement (PPA)
for the Project has a stated clear objective to generate verified emission reduction credits (VERs)
instead of RECs, and The Project Proponent will not issue RECs while applying for issuance of
VERs for the same instances of power generation, as this would result in double counting.
Consistent with the VCS Standard, the Project Proponent will track all instances of power
generation and only issue either VERs or RECs in accordance with the VCS Registration and
Issuance Process. RECs in the state of Kansas are tracked by the North American Renewables
Registry (NAR), consistent with the Kansas Renewable Energy Standard.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves several steps. Here is an overview of the methodology:

1. Step 4: Identify similar projects: In this step, the project identifies other projects that have similar technologies to the proposed project activity.

2. Step 5: Calculate the factor F: The factor F is calculated as 1 minus the ratio of the number of similar projects (N diff) to the total number of projects (N all). This factor represents the share of similar projects using a similar technology to the proposed project activity.

3. Determine if the proposed project is a common practice: If the factor F is greater than 0.2 and the difference between N all and N diff is greater than 3, then the proposed project is considered a "common practice" within the sector and geographical area. If not, it is considered additional under common practice analysis.

4. Methodology deviations: There are no deviations from the methodology mentioned.

5. Quantification of GHG emissions: The project uses a stepwise approach to calculate the baseline emissions and emission factors for the electricity system. The national grid of Turkey is used as the electric power system, and the emission factor for imports from neighboring countries is considered zero. The project does not consider transmission capacity investments for the baseline emissions calculation.

Please note that this is a summary of the methodology based on the provided context. For more detailed information, it is recommended to refer to the specific documents and references mentioned in the context.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
3 QUANTIFICATION OF GHG EMISSION REDUCTIONS AND REMOVALS
3.1 Baseline Emissions
Stepwise approach of „Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system” version
04.0.0 36 is used to find this combined margin (emission coefficient) as described below:
Step 1. Identify the relevant electric systems
There are 21 regional distribution regions in Turkey but no regional transmission system is
defined. In Article 20 of License Regulation it is stated that:
“TEIAS shall be in charge of all transmission activities to be performed over the existing
transmission facilities and those to be constructed as well as the activities pertaining to the
operation of national transmission system via the National Load Dispatch Center and the
regional load dispatch centers connected to this center and the operation of Market Financial
Reconciliation Center37”.
As it can be understood from this phrase, only one transmission system, which is national
transmission system is defined and only TEİAŞ is in the charge of all transmission system related
activities. Moreover, a communication with representative of TEIAS, which indicates that: “There
are not significant transmission constraints in the national grid system which is preventing
dispatch of already connected power plants” is submitted to the DOE. Therefore, the national grid
is used as electric power system for project activity. The national grid of Turkey is connected to
the electricity systems of neighboring countries. Complying with the rules of the tool, the emission
factor for imports from neighboring countries is considered 0 (zero) tCO /MWh for determining the 2
OM.
There is no information about interconnected transmission capacity investments, as TEİAŞ, who
operates the grid, also didn’t take into account imports-exports for electricity capacity
projections.38 Because of that, for BM calculation transmission capacity is not considered.
Step 2. Choose whether to include off-grid power plants in the project electricity system
(optional)
According to Tool project participants may choose between the following two options to calculate
the operating margin and build margin emission factor:

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is titled "Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources" and it is referenced as ACM0002: Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources - Version 19.02. The project activity involves generating grid-connected electricity from renewable solar energy with a proposed capacity of 969.3 MW. The project meets the eligibility criteria of a large-scale project as it exceeds 15 MW. The methodology falls under the category of Approved Consolidated Methodology (ACM0002) for Energy industries (renewable / non-renewable sources). Tools referred to in this methodology include a tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system and a methodological tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality. The project activity contributes to sustainable development by promoting social well-being through employment generation, economic well-being through clean technology investment and reducing the demand-supply gap, environmental well-being through the use of renewable energy and avoidance of GHG emissions, and technological well-being by encouraging solar-based power generation and participation in similar projects.
inputs.context:
JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
Ministry of Environment and Forests, has stipulated economic, social, environment and
technological well-being as the four indicators of sustainable development. The project
contributes to sustainable development using the following ways.
1. Social well-being: The project would help in generating employment opportunities during the
construction and operation phases. The project activity will lead to development in infrastructure
in the region like development of roads and also may promote business with improved power
generation.
2. Economic well-being: The project is a clean technology investment in the region, which would
not have been taken place in the absence of the VCS benefits the project activity will also help to
reduce the demand supply gap in the state.
3. Environmental well-being: Solar being a renewable source of energy, it reduces the
dependence on fossil fuels and conserves natural resources which are on the verge of depletion.
Due to its zero emission the Project activity also helps in avoiding significant amount of GHG
emissions and specific pollutants like SOx, NOx, and SPM associated with the conventional
thermal power generation facilities.
4. Technological well-being: The successful operation of project activity would lead to
promotion of Solar based power generation and would encourage other entrepreneurs to
participate in similar projects.
Further Information
Not Applicable

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.7 Ownership
The project's plantations are carried out on private land belonging to farmers. Hence, carbon credits
generated by the project will be allocated to them. This has been ensured by developing an institutional
mechanism (mentioned in appendix 2 ) to ensure that the benefits reach the farmers without any hassle.
Nevertheless, project proponent (Gujarat Forest Department) will be responsible of administrative tasks
(monitoring system, organization of audits, etc.), and carbon credits intended for village communities will
be received by the Conservator of Forests Bharuch Circle, Gujarat Forest Department. A contractual
system will be set up between Conservator of Forests Bharuch Circle, Gujarat Forest Department and
farmers in order to transfer financial flows to village communities.
1.8 Project Start Date
The project start date is the date on which activities that lead to the generation of GHG emission
removals are implemented specifically land preparation and planting. The execution of the on-the-ground
plantation establishment started in 1st June, 2018.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The project-crediting period will be of 20 years starting from 1st June, 2018 to 30st June, 2038. The
crediting interval is five years.

Sustainable Development
The sustainable development priorities of India are described in the “India Vision 2030”. Under
the economic vision and strategy, one of the priorities is to raise incomes from agriculture
through increased agricultural production and value addition. Furthermore, under the social
strategy, one priority is to improve the capacity for adaptation to global climate change.
The project contributes to both nationally stated sustainable development priorities through:
1) Increasing yields of crops- thus, raising agricultural production and incomes; and
2) Improved management of agricultural land as a result of adoption of good practices –thereby
increasing the adaptive capacity of the farming system to climate change impacts.
Further Information

This project is designed to have a positive impact on the environment by improving the local ecological
conditions favourable for the farmers as the monoculture farming could be harmful for soil health and
thus, practicing agroforestry can reverse the harmful effects on the soil. Also, this project does not use
any fertilizers and pesticides which are considered harmful to the local environment. The project is
designed to improve environmental services and socio-economic values. This is held in high regard in
every phase of the project development from design to implementation to monitoring. The holistic
approach of the project must achieve better soil fertility, and biodiversity conservation. This project also

Leakage Management
The applicability conditions of VM0003 and the VCS standard prohibit any activity shifting leakage
as result of the implementation of an IFM project. As the Bethlehem Project Area is the only
working forestland owned/managed by BA, this requirement is automatically met. Market effects
leakage is calculated based on a comparison of the percentage of merchantable timber per acre
on the project site compared to other forests within the region (See section 3.3 for a detailed
description of all leakage calculations). Market effects leakage will be re-assed at each
verification but does not require additional specific leakage management activities.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The "Improved Cropland Management Project in Guyuan" aims to raise farmer's awareness on sustainable agriculture and implement practices to mitigate and adapt to climate change. The project includes activities such as reduced fertilizer application, improved water management, reduced tillage, and improved crop planting and harvesting.

Province: The project is located in Guyuan city within the boundary of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region.

Country: The project is in China.

Latitude and Longitude: The specific latitude and longitude coordinates are not provided in the given information.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The “Improved Cropland Management Project in Guyuan” developed by Gansu Hongmao
Agriculture Development Co., Ltd. aims to raise farmer’s awareness on the benefits of
sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices to help in climate change
mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers that prevent
adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical assistance
where needed. The objective of the project is to reduce emissions from agricultural practices
and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of practices that change
the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the specific activities are
one or combination of the following:
• Reduced fertilizer(organic or inorganic) application;
• Improved water management/irrigation;
• Reduced tillage/improved residue management;
• Improved crop planting and harvesting (e.g., improved agroforestry, crop rotations, cover
crops)
The project activity is located in Guyuan city within the boundary of Ningxia Hui Autonomous
Region, a western province in China. Prior to the start of the implementation of the project,
there was no similar sequestration of carbon, removals or net reduction of GHG activities. The
baseline scenario is the continuation of pre-project agricultural land management practices,
which are common agricultural practices in the project area. Over the 20 years of the first
crediting period, the project will generate an estimated annual average removal and reduction
of 160,000 tCO e. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project falls under the sectoral scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry and other land use
(AFOLU). The category of the project is Agriculture Land Management (ALM). The project is a
project using the methodology VM0042 “Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land
management”(version 2.0). They type of the project activity is improved cropland management
activity (ICM) since the practices involved in the project activity demonstrably reduce net GHG

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The “Improved cropland management project in Jiaoqu” aims to raise farmer's awareness on the
benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices to help in climate
change mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers that
prevent adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical
assistance where needed. The objectives of the project is to reduce emissions from agricultural
practices and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of practices that
change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the specific
activities are the following:
A. Improve fertilizer (organic or inorganic) application; and
B. Reduce tillage/improve residue management.
The project is located in Jiaoqu District, Jiamusi City, Heilongjiang Province, where is in the
northeast of China. The project activities includes reducing fertilizer application, reducing tillage
and straw returning to improve residue management. The project will cover 69,440 ha located in
Jiaoqu District.
Prior to the start of the implementation of the project, there was no similar sequestration of
carbon, removals or net reduction of GHG activities. The baseline scenario is the continuation of
pre-project agricultural land management practices, which are common agricultural practices in
Heilongjiang Province. The project will generate an estimated annual average removal and
reduction of 156,240 tCO e. Over the 20 years of the first crediting period, the project is expected 2
to reduce the GHG emissions by 3,124,800 tCO e in this period. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project falls under the sectoral scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry and other land use (AFOLU).
The category of the project is Agriculture Land Management (ALM). The project is a large project
using the methodology VM0042 “Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land
Management”(version 2.0). They type of the project activity is improved cropland management
activity (ICM) since the practices involved in the project activity demonstrably reduce net GHG
4

1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
Project Start Date:
As per VCS 2007.1, the project start date shall not be before 1st January, 2002. The first WTG
of the project activity was commissioned on 11th August, 2004 which is also the start date of
the present project activity. The Crediting Period will last for ten years starting from 1st April
2006 up to 31st March 2016.
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
Electricity in Southern Grid is mainly generated from the fossil fuel dominated power plants.
In the absence of the project activity, equivalent amount of electricity would have been
generated by the operation of fossil fuel dominated power plants. The electricity grid is power
deficit and hence the new capacity has to be added in the grid system which would be fossil
fuel dominated electricity generation.
The land on which the project activity took place is barren and unfertile. Prior to the project
activity, the land had no beneficial use. PPs have bought the land for a worthwhile application
and obtained necessary approvals for installation of wind turbines. No dislocation of people is
involved in the course of the project activity. The project was implemented on forest land
leased out by the government of India for the explicit purpose of the setting up of renewable
energy projects.
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG
emission reductions and/or removal enhancements:
The project activity is a bundled wind power project activity with a totalled installed capacity
of 6.25 MW and is expected to generate 13831 MWh per annum. The electricity thus
generated is sold to the TNEB. In the absence of the project activity, equivalent amount of
electricity would have been generated by the operation of existing/proposed grid connected
fossil fuel dominated power plants. The Project activity will thus reduce the anthropogenic
emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) in to the atmosphere associated with the equivalent
amount of electricity generation from the fossil fuel dominated grid connected power plant.
7
inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Positive Climate Care 6.25 MW Bundled Wind Power Project Activity in the state of Tamilnadu, India.', 'project_summary': 'The project activity consists of a bundle of 13 wind electric generators (WEGs) for a total installed capacity of 6.25 MW that includes 3 MW (750 kW X 4 machines), 2 MW (250 kW X 8 machines) and 1.25 MW (1250 kW X 1 machine) located at District Coimbatore & Tirunelveli in the state of Tamilnadu. The electricity generated is fed to the Tamilnadu Electricity Board (TNEB). The TNEB forms part of the Southern Regional Grid of India and it depends primarily on fossil fuels. Therefore, this project contributes to reduced GHGs emissions caused by reliance on fossil fuels. The project is promoted by Savita oil Technologies Ltd., Jasmine Industrial Corporation and Dhanlaxmi Fabrics Ltd. In addition to the strategic objectives to achieve increased share of renewable energy in the Indian context through a focus on wind energy, increased rural incomes,reduced poverty and empowerment of the vulnerable sections of society, the project in turn contributes to the sustainable development of the region.', 'project_state_province': 'Tamil Nadu', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 10.61, 'project_longitude': 77.18}

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Pasture accounts for virtually all the deforested land occupation in the project region3. The
implementation of this BAU activity is usually financed by means of initial capital obtained in wood
logging. It is believed that the same pattern of deforestation and land uses observed in the
Reference Area might be fairly replicated into the Project Area in the absence of this REDD
Project.
Figure 5. Map of land use in the project region in 2009, showing predominance of pasture
as final land use in deforested areas (Source: MMA, 2009).
The Project Area has a forest cover characterized as Open ombrophylous forest (As, according to
Brazilian Vegetation Map, IBGE). The following tables have a compilation of data on the content
of biomass in this typology of vegetation, according to forest inventories performed in the region.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Fortaleza Ituxi REDD Project', 'project_summary': 'The FORTALEZA ITUXI REDD PROJECT aims at protecting forests located in one of the regions having the highest deforestation rate in the Amazon Biome: the municipality of Lábrea. As the southernmost municipality in the Brazilian state of Amazonas, Lábrea is geographically located nearby the “Arc of Deforestation” and neighbours other highly deforested municipalities. Over the life of the project, the following benefits are expected:- Estimated net GHG emission reductions: 720,470 tCO2e, corresponding to avoidance of deforestation of 1,836.5 hectares over 30-years;- Technical training on sustainable cattle raising and forest management, fire brigades, study for a small non-wood product processing plant, production of Brazil-nuts (already in place) etc.;- Seedling Production Nursery: capacity of 50,000 native-species seedlings per year and donation for neighbors wishing to plant.- Implementation of technical education frameworks;- Complementary monitoring of labor conditions in Project Area;- Implementation of health insurance plan for workers;- Monitoring the attendance of young in schools;- Commercial activity in “Castanhal Fortaleza” company (job generation beyond timber management).', 'project_state_province': 'State: Amazonas', 'project_country': 'Brazil', 'project_latitude': -8.91, 'project_longitude': -66.16}

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION: VCS Version 3
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
The Project Owner is the Project Proponent, Servicios Comerciales de Energía, S.A. de C.V.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project is included in the CDM Programme of Activities “Mexican Renewable Energy Alliance PoA”
however, under this programme, the project’s crediting period is 7 years renewable, starting on January
16, 2015. Thus, the energy generated prior to January 16, 2015 is not subject to any emission-trading
program or any other binding limit; for the remaining of the crediting period, the project implementer will
choose to claim emission reductions under one carbon programme only in order to avoid double-
accounting.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project is not subject of any other type of environmental credit.
1.12.4 Participation under Other GHG Programs
The project is included in the CDM Programme of Activities “Mexican Renewable Energy Alliance PoA”
Refer to section 1.12.2.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The project has not been rejected of any GHG program.
1.13 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Eligibility Criteria
This is not a grouped project.
Leakage Management
The project does not comprise any fossil-fuel backup generator for generating electricity to be supplied to
the grid. Nevertheless, there is a 100 kW diesel generator that is being used for generating energy for
internal use during emergencies. Emissions associated to fossil consumption in this generator will be
estimated in order to ensure conservativeness in the emission reductions calculations. The monitoring
information for the consumed fuel in this generator is provided in sections 4.1 and 4.2 of this PD.
Commercially Sensitive Information

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
San Andrés Hydroelectric Project is a run of river hydroelectric power plant that will be
implemented on the San Andrés River located in the San Andrés de Cuerquia Municipality on the
northern region of the department of Antioquia in the Republic of Colombia. The power-plant will
have an installed Effective capacity of 19.9 MW and Annual Power Generation delivered to the
grid of 172 GWh; total estimated emissions reduction for the crediting period is 473,170 tonnes of
CO e; the power-plant will be connected to the national grid on the Yarumal II substation, with a 2
36km 110kV transmission line.
The installation of the project is expected to be finished on October 1st 2013. The project is fully
authorized by the respective national authorities including the Unique Environmental License,
which is awarded to Celsia S.A. E.S.P. by Resolution Nº130 TH 12079241 and the authorization
of the CRE (energy regulation commission).1

Project Summary: The project involves the establishment of plantations in the Yoni and Masimera Chiefdoms within the Tonkolili and Port Loko Districts in Sierra Leone. The project aims to promote sustainable forestry practices and mitigate climate change.

Province: The project is located in the Northern District of Sierra Leone.

Country: The project is located in Sierra Leone.

Latitude: The project is situated between latitudes 8.31 and 8.51.

Longitude: The project is located between longitudes -12.18 and -12.35.
inputs.context:
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
As a final comment, it is important to point out that Miro Forestry is not located within a jurisdiction
covered by a jurisdictional REDD+ program9.
1.12 Project Location
The project plantations are located in the Yoni and Masimera Chiefdoms within the Tonkolili and Port
Loko Districts, in the Northern District of Sierra Leone (Figure 7). The Company’s current landholding is
26,897 ha. The landholding is located between latitudes 8.31 and 8.51, and longitudes -12.18 and -
12.35 and is located adjacent to the main highway heading east from Freetown and Port Loko into the
provinces. This road network provides access to Freetown and the major port sites of Sierra Leone. The
plantation is nearest to Yonibana a small town, nearly 91 miles from Freetown.
Figure 7. Project Location in Sierra Leonne, and the location of the plantations (yellow
polygons).
9 South Pole research under the verification standards database
25

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
Tonkolili District is referred to as the midpoint District of Sierra Leone because of its central location in
the middle of the country, bordering 6 out of 11 other districts that constitute the country. In the north,
it is bordered by the northern region Districts of Bombali and Koinadugu; in the east, by the eastern
region District of Kono; in the south east by the eastern region District of Kenema and southern region
District of Bo; in the south by southern region District of Moyamba and in the west by the north western
region District of Port Loko.
According to the new (2017) re-districting and re-regionalisation, Tonkolili District lies in the Northern
region of Sierra Leone and Port Loko District lies in the north western region.
In 2011 the Company signed a land lease for 20,980 ha, split into Yoni Block A and Block B (Figure 8),
leased from the traditional landholders and ratified by the Government. In 2017 3,137 ha of forest
management within this land lease area were certified by the FSC with certification number C135138.
In 2018 a further 1,800 ha were leased in the Masimera Chiefdom, this area is known as the
Masimera plantation.
Figure 8. Project Area: First Leasing block A (north), block B (south) and Blocks D, E, F for leases
after 2011. Source: ESIA 201810
All the properties leased are distributed across different communities, divided by the Chiefdom as
follows (Table 14):

Climate
The project is located within an area that has a humid tropical climate, with two rain regimes: the wet
season from May to November and is related to the tropical maritime monsoon, that flows from
southwest to northeast; and the dry season which ranges from December to April and is associated
with the dry Harmattan winds that blows from the Sahara region12. The mean yearly rainfall for the

inputs.ground_truth:
{'project_name': 'Reforestation of Degraded Lands in Sierra Leone', 'project_summary': 'Miro Forestry has over 10,000 hectares of standing plantations, expanding this plantation area at a rate of 3,000 hectares per year and producing sustainable timber products including plywood, rotary veneer, poles, sawn timber, and wood biomass.
The plantations are Forest Stewardship Council™ (FSC™) certified meaning the voluntary compliance with the international gold standard of responsible forest management.
The Yoni Plantation is around 8.5° north of the equator and has a tropical climate with average monthly temperatures ranging between 26°C and 36°C and annual rainfall in excess of 2,000mm. The dry season typically spans between December and March having less than 100mm of rainfall.
The land on which the Company is establishing plantation forests was once forested with primary forest, however, the land now consists of secondary growth including grasses, low level bush and palms. The land is being leased under longterm agreements with landowners ratified by the chief’s and government as legal custodians.
The land area has limited subsistence farming going on which is primarily centered around the low lying swampy areas for rice cultivation unsuitable for forestry. The Company works in ongoing consultation with local farmers and aims to bring additional benefit to such farmers through opening up swampy areas for rice cultivation and enabling controlled agroforestry thus providing clear land for subsistence farming, mutual crop protection and keeping the land free of nutrient sapping undergrowth.
Miro Forestry aims to conform to high environmental, ethical, financial and social standards, and achieve international forestry certification on all plantations. It aims to be the preferred partner for local communities, the national government, and international development and finance.', 'project_state_province': 'Tonkolili and Port Loko Districts', 'project_country': 'Sierra Leone', 'project_latitude': 8.47, 'project_longitude': -12.34}

The project focuses on reducing greenhouse gas emissions resulting from unplanned deforestation and forest degradation, as well as promoting the conservation of natural resources and sustainable socioeconomic development within the Arara do Igarapé Humaitá Indigenous Land. The project aims to generate financial resources through the commercialization of REDD+ credits registered in the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS). It also emphasizes the preservation of biodiversity and the cultural heritage of the Shawãdawa people.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
A summary description of the technologies/measures to be implemented by the project.
The Malawi Bamboo Afforestation Project will distribute seedlings of giant bamboo,
Dendrocalamus asper, to individual agricultural homesteads in rural Malawi. The project will
also provide educational support and outreach for the long-term care of bamboo clumps.
The location of the project.
The project is located within the political boundary of the Republic of Malawi.
An explanation of how the project is expected to generate GHG emission reductions or
removals.
The project will generate GHG emission reductions by sequestering carbon in live above- and
belowground biomass. When individual bamboo clumps reach the end of their lifespan, they will
be replaced by a new clump, ensuring carbon remains sequestered over the project lifetime.
A brief description of the scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project.
Smallholder agricultural homesteads are widespread across Malawi. A variety of trees are
grown on farms, in gardens, and around homesteads to serve as fuel, timber, and other uses.
However, fast-growing giant bamboo is not grown in Malawi at a large scale.
An estimate of annual average and total GHG emission reductions and removals.
Estimated annual average GHG emissions reductions: 174,301 tCO2e
Total GHG emission reductions: 5,054,739 tCO2e
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry, and other Land Use (AFOLU)
Project Type: Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation
Activity: Bamboo planting
Grouped Project: Yes
This project is being registered under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) and Climate, Community &
Biodiversity Alliance (CCBA) Standard as an Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation project. It
4

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
has been developed in compliance with the Verified Carbon Standard1, Version 4.4 and the VCS
AFOLU-specific requirements, as well as the Climate, Community & Biodiversity Standard, Version
3.12. The project will sequester carbon through bamboo plantings.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project activity increases carbon sequestration by establishing vegetative cover in the form
of planted bamboo clumps, qualifying as an ARR project type under the AFOLU category (VCS
4.4, A1.1). Harvesting of bamboo is expected and allowed under the ARR project type. The
planting location of each bamboo clump will not be cleared of native ecosystems with the 10-
year period prior to the project start date.

Eligibility Criteria

Project instances are defined as a Village.
New project instances must meet the following criteria:
1. Located within the Republic of Malawi.
2. The land subject to the project activity does not fall in wetland category as defined by the
IPCC and results in any change to hydrology.3
3. The displacement of pre-project activities is not expected to cause, directly or indirectly, any
drainage of wetlands.
4. Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10 per cent of
area in each of the following types of land, when these lands are included within the project
boundary:
(i) Land containing organic soils;
(ii) Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land-use and management practices and
receives inputs listed in AR-ACM003 v2.0 appendices 1 (Cropland in which soil

Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project neither has nor intends to generate any other form of GHG-related environmental credit for
GHG emission reductions or removals claimed under the VCS Program. The VCS Program has a central
project database, which lists each approved project. The VCS Project Database is the central storehouse
of information on all projects validated to VCS criteria and all Verified Carbon Units issued under the
program. Every VCU can be tracked from issuance to retirement in the database, allowing buyers to
ensure every credit is real, additional, permanent, independently verified, uniquely numbered and fully
traceable online. This project has not been registered under any other credited activity, and no VCUs have
been assigned to the project area so far. Thus, any possibility of double counting of credits is eliminated.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology used in this project is the Version 12.3.0 of ACM0002: "Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources." This methodology is applied to demonstrate the applicability of the project. The project's characteristics and applicability criteria are specified in section B.2 of the registered Project Design Document (PDD). The project activity is validated under the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) program, so certain sections related to baseline emissions, project emissions, additionality, leakage, and summary of GHG emission reductions and removals are not mandatory as per the VCS Standard, Version 3.3. For more detailed information, you can refer to the registered PDD.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector is "Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)" specifically under the category of "Improved Cropland Management (ICM)" in the "Agricultural Land Management (ALM)" category.
inputs.context:
