Project Summary: The EREN Hydroelectric Power Project, developed by IRMAK Enerji Üretim San. ve Tic. A.Ş., is a run-of-river hydro power plant located on Soganli creek in Safranbolu district, City of Karabuk, Turkey. The project has an installed capacity of 35.186 MW and annually produces around 141.899 GWh of emission-free electricity.

Province: Karabuk

Country: Turkey

Latitude: Not provided

Longitude: Not provided
inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
IRMAK Enerji Üretim San. ve Tic. A.Ş. (referred to as Irmak Enerji from here on) has developed EREN
Hydroelectric Power Project (in short: EREN HEPP), a run-of-river hydro power plant (HPP) on Soganli
creek. EREN HEPP will use water supply of Soganli creek in Safranbolu district which is located in City of
Karabuk. The project is in borders of nine villages (Yukariguney, Sofcular, Alakaya, Kayaoren, Caykasi,
Terke in Kastamonu, Asagiguney,Geren in Karabuk, Kavak in Cankiri). EREN HEPP is a run-of-river
hydro power plant where regulator located on Soganli creek at 524.50 meters. Overflow flux is calculated
as 433.76 m3/sec. Transmission canal for the plant is approximately 35 km. Flowing water then pass
through transmission pipes which has a diameter of 3.2 meters and length of 500 meters into power
house where 3 Francis turbines each having power of 12,346 kW produce energy.
EREN HEPP is a run-of-river hydro power plant (HPP) project with an installed capacity of 35.186 MW , e
which annually feeds an amount of around 141.899 GWh of emission free electricity into the Turkish
national grid according to Electricity Production License, thereby creating an emission reduction of 73,776
tCO . Irmak Enerji made Right of Water Use Contract with Devlet Su Isleri (DSI - State Hydrolic Works) 2e
on 22.09.2008 and already obtained the electricity generation license of EREN HEPP from Enerji
Piyasası Düzenleme Kurumu / Electricity Market Regulatory Authority (EPDK / EMRA) on 25.12.2008 for
the duration of 49 years. Grid Connection Contract with Turkiye Elektrik Iletim A.S. (TEIAS – Turkey
Electricity Transmission Co.) was made on 17.08.2011.
Purpose of the Project:
a) The scenario existing prior to the start of the implementation of the project is that the electricity demand
is satisfied by the National Grid of Turkey.
b) The project is a newly built hydro power plant with the installed capacity of 35.186 MW . The Project e
will utilize the water resources of Soganli Creek to generate electricity which will be delivered to the
National Grid of Turkey without CO emissions. The Project Activity will achieve greenhouse gas (GHG) 2
emission reductions by avoiding CO emissions from the business-as-usual scenario, electricity 2
generated by those fossil fuel-fired power plants connected into the National Grid of Turkey.
c) The baseline scenario of the Project is the same as the scenario existing prior to the start of the
implementation of the Project.
Contributions to Sustainable Development:
In addition to reduce GHG emissions by producing clean energy, the Project will also make contributions
to the sustainable development of the local communities and the host country by means of;
tter use of renewable hydro power energy and play a positive role in the local renewable
energy industry,
energy demand,
o the business-as-usual scenario, which is electricity generation
by the country’s generation mix mainly dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants,
opportunities
Building a HEPP contributes to a sustainable expansion path of the Turkish energy system, as it serves
the steadily growing electricity demand in an environmentally suitable way. The project also contributes to
dissemination of state-of-the-art new renewable energy (REN) technology, thus increasing the use of
ecologically sound domestic energy sources in Turkish electricity supply.
The project's ecological impact has been assessed by preparing first a project presentation file (Turkish:
Proje Tanıtım Dosyası, PTD). The PTD was finalized and submitted to the Turkish Ministry of

In fact, there are essential positive environmental effects, as highly polluting electricity generation
technologies are displaced by the project. Pollution not only comprises greenhouse gases but other local
air pollutants such as SO , NO , or Particulate Matter, as well. x x
As for social impacts, significant positive employment effects will be occurred especially during the
construction and installation period, where more than 50 people have been working for the project. . It is
aimed to employ local people to add social impact to the project. Moreover, local companies benefit from
the project, as construction services and material are mainly sourced from local suppliers. Management,
operation and maintenance of the HEPP create permanent jobs which require high qualification,
contributing to capacity building and know-how dissemination in Turkey.
In addition to contribution to local economy, the project will also contribute the use of local and renewable
resources to meet the increasing energy demand of Turkey and reduce dependency on fossil fuels. In
terms of fuel dependency, EREN HEPP is expected to contribute to domestic energy production by
reducing that much imported energy, which will, in addition increase air quality and access to affordable
energy services in national level. EREN HEPP displaces electricity from the current generation mix which
is based to a large amount on thermal power plants and will affect the planned capacity extension of the
electricity system. EREN HEPP thus leads to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emission reductions which are to
be accounted for by verifying and issuing carbon credits under the Verified Carbon Standard Version
3.4., (in short VCS version 3.4.).
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
According to guidance from VCS version 3.4 EREN HEPP falls under sectorial scope no. 1 "Energy
(renewable/non-renewable)".The project type is Renewable Energy (REN). More specifically, it is a run-
of-river HEPP project. EREN HEPP is not a grouped project if referring to the relevant VCS version 3.4.
rules.

inputs.context:
__ PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Forest Resource Management Transfers
In 1996, the Government of Madagascar passed the law GELOSE 96-025 - legislation that
enables the devolution of natural resource management to local communities. The law allows
the delegation of limited tenure and sustainable use rights of renewable natural resources to a
legally-recognized local community institution (a Communauté de Base (COBA)), in exchange
for a contractual obligation vis-à-vis the government to conserve the transferred natural
resources. Decree 2001-122 governs the implementation of devolved forest resource
management to local communities (Decree 2001-122, Décret fixant les conditions de mise en
oeuvre de la Gestion Contractualisée des Forêts de l’Etat (GCF)). It allows forest specific
community management contracts. Under GCF, contracts are signed between the
government and the representative of the COBAs, the Community Management Committee
(COGE). The request must come from the local community. In 2004, CI began working with
the Ministry of Water and Forests and the communities surrounding the COFAV forests to
implement community-managed GCF sites within the community use zone of the project area.
The COFAV project makes use of the GELOSE legislation in some areas to transfer
management rights of forests to local communities.
Dina
Dina are traditional laws established by the community through broad consensus. For
COFAV, local communities established Dina for the community management of their forest
resources in fulfilment of the GELOSE/GCF. In compliance to forestry law, the Dina were
agreed to and formalised by all of the main stakeholders, including the local communities
(COBAs) to which the management of forest resources were transferred, the local authorities,
and the regional representatives of the Ministry of Environment and Forests and the Ministry
of Justice for each of the GELOSE / GCF sites implemented.
A complete list of relevant Malagasy legislation is presented in Appendix 3: Relevant
Malagasy legislation.
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Proof of Title
The Government of Madagascar (GoM) through the Ministry responsible for forests (the
Ministry of Environment and Forests - MEF at the time of PD development) is the project
proponent and owner of the VCUs generated by the project activity. All the forest in the
project area is owned by the Government of Madagascar and the government is responsible
for project activities and therefore VCUs generated remain the property of the government.
The Government of Madagascar has delegated the protected area management to CI through
a management delegation contract. The delegated project manager and local community
associations are all part of the management structure and will therefore share responsibility
for deciding how the revenues from the sale of VCUs will be used to achieve the project
objectives through the development of annual work plans and budgets that have to be
approved by the whole management structure.

boundaries have been defined in the protected area management plan based on public

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is the "Grid connected renewable electricity generation" methodology, specifically the approved small scale methodology AMS.I.D, version 15. This methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation projects that involve electricity capacity additions. The baseline scenario is determined by calculating the emission factor for the electricity system using either a combined margin (CM) approach or the weighted average emissions of the current generation mix. In this project, the "Combined Margin" approach is used to determine the baseline emission reductions.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: VCS Version 3

and distribution loss.
The above details the contribution of the project activity to sustainable development.
2 APPLICATION OF METHODOLOGY
2.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
Title : Grid connected renewable electricity generation
Reference : Approved methodology small scale – I D, version 151, dated 16th October, 2009
EB Meeting : 50
Methodological Tool
“Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system” version - 1
2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The approved small scale methodology AMS.I.D, version 15 has been used for the project activity
which is applicable to grid-connected renewable power generation project activities that involve
electricity capacity additions.

As per AMS I D, (Version 15, 16/10/2009), paragraph 10 and 11 “the baseline is the kWh
produced by the renewable generating unit multiplied by an emission coefficient (measured in kg
CO2e/kWh) calculated in a transparent and conservative manner as:
(a) A combined margin (CM), consisting of the combination of operating margin (OM) and build
margin (BM) according to the procedures prescribed in the ‘Tool to calculate the emission factor
for an electricity system’.
OR
(b) The weighted average emissions (in kg CO2e/kWh) of the current generation mix. The data of
the year in which project generation occurs must be used.”
The approach proposed in the “Option (a)” i.e. “Combined Margin” has been used for ascertaining

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: The project sector in this case is Forestry and Land Use.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Guangshui City within Suizhou City, Hubei Province of China, with
a total acreage of 13,351ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this
project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously
flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously
flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded
condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, 4
the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase
and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. Hence, with the proposed
project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.38tCO e/ha for single- 2
cropping rice is expected. Annua average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the
project activity is 58,541 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 585,410 2
tCO e during the fixed 10 years crediting period. 2
This project aims to:
• Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
• Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
• Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers;
• Increase in the number of individuals with improved capacity due to diversified
educational opportunities from Trainings.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
Agricultural Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is
approved under sectoral scope 15 (agriculture) of CDM, this project is categorized as
sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra.
4

So, this\nproject can be categorized as eligible ALM\nactivity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within the 10 years period prior to\nthe project start date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.1'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems\nby increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil\nN O emissions, and/or reducing CH\n2 4\nemissions.', 'This project practices intermittent flooded\nmethod on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH emissions. So, this project is an eligible\n4\nICM activity.']]
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.3 Project Eligibility
According to the Section 2.1.1 of VCS Standard version 4.3, this project activity meets two
of the scopes of the VCS program:1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases; and 4)
Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program, unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval. Accordingly, this
project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the six Kyoto 4
Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and it is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of VCS program.
This is in accordance with the definitions of eligible AFOLU project categories set out in
Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard, 4.3 and can be demonstrated from the following three
points.

1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The Project neither has nor intends to generate any other form of GHG related environmental
credit for GHG emission reductions or removals claimed under the VCS Program; therefore no
such credit has been or will be cancelled from the relevant program. This is the first instance of
this Project claiming GHG environmental credits.
1.12.4 Participation under Other GHG Programs
The Project has neither been registered nor sought registration under any other GHG program.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The Project has not been by rejected by any other GHG programs.
1.13 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Eligibility Criteria
N/A. This is an individual project.
Leakage Management
The applicability conditions of VM0003 and the VCS standard prohibit any activity shifting leakage
as result of the implementation of an IFM project. As the Lock Haven IFM Project Area is the only
working forestland owned/managed by LHCA, this requirement is automatically met. Market
effects leakage is calculated based on a comparison of the percentage of merchantable timber
per acre on the project site compared to other forests within the region (See section 3.3 for a
detailed description of all leakage calculations). Market effects leakage will be re-assed at each
verification but does not require additional specific leakage management activities.
Commercially Sensitive Information
None of the contents of this PD are considered commercially sensitive information. However,
elements of the supporting documentation and reference material provided separately to this PD,
for validation and verification purposes, may be considered confidential.
Further Information
N/A

1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the project initiation. This
scenario is described in Section 2.4 (Baseline scenario). Environmental conditions of the project
area are described here.
Climate:
The annual average rainfall of the Sundarbans is 1,600 mm with annual variations of 1,300 to
2,000 mm. Studies between 1990 and 2008 show that there has actually been an increase of
rainfall over the Delta (WWF 2010). The annual mean (over a period of ten years: 2000-2009)
min and max temperatures vary between 12°C and 28°C respectively.
Hydrology:
The area is inundated twice per day, during high tide. The salinity decreases along the coast from
west towards east (and of course from the sea towards inland). The weather has a high
seasonality, with around 80 percent of the annual rainfall occurring during monsoon (June-
October) (Chowdhury 2010)2.
Soils:
Regarding other geophysical parameters, all areas in the delta generally exhibit good site
conditions for mangrove planting. Soils of the mudflats mainly consist of silt, sand and clay in

A key ecosystem restoration objective of the project is to re-establish the ecosystem functions relating to wave and wind erosion control to protect embankments, and to re-establish functioning ecosystems that can also enhance biodiversity. The socio-economic rationale for the project is to protect important livelihood functions for local communities. The project proponent will implement the project together with local communities. The A/R activity will provide greenhouse gas mitigation benefits and also important adaptation benefits in addressing climate change impacts. 1.3 Project Eligibility
The project generates renewable and clean electricity by using wind power
that would otherwise have been provided by North China Power Grid (NCPG),
which reduces the emissions of CO2 from fossil fuel-fired generation in the grid,
and falls into the category of the six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases.
CDM methodology ACM0002 Version 20.0 “Grid-connected electricity
generation from renewable sources” is adopted, which is the methodology
approved under a VCS approved GHG program and is eligible for VCS by Verra.
The project is to utilize wind power for electricity generation. Prior to the
implementation of the project, the equivalent electricity supplied by the
project was sourced from NCPG. Apparently, the project does not generate
GHG emissions primarily for the purpose of their subsequent reduction,
removal, or destruction.
Thus, the project is eligible under the scope of the VCS Program.

The project includes a single location or installation only and is not a grouped
project.

follow the requirements of para 3.7.1 of the VCS Standard ver4.4 which states the evidence to
establish project ownership should be “An enforceable and irrevocable agreement with the holder
of the statutory, property or contractual right in the plant, equipment or process that generates
GHG emission reductions and/or removals which vests project ownership in the project
proponent.”
These agreements confirm that the ownership rights of the VERRA project and the carbon assets
generated from this project lie with the project proponent. The customer under the End User
Agreement “releases all rights to the greenhouse gas reductions and carbon credits produced by
the use of the clean energy product in the favour of VPA implementors and agree to not sell or
transfer the GHG or carbon credits to any other third party or use these credits for any other
purposes”. The MoU between VPA implementer and PP also states “VPA implementer has agreed
to sell and deliver the carbon credits generated from the sale and use of the product to MEC and
the entire legal and beneficial title, all rights to and interests in the carbon credits and the
underlying greenhouse gas reductions corresponding to such project transaction will vest with
MEC”. Sample end user agreement and MoU has been shared with the VVB.
1.8 Project Start Date
13 April 2021 i.e., the date of sale of first clean energy product (Project Activity Instance under
the Grouped project and first Project Activity)

inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector is Renewable Energy. The project involves the implementation of household biogas digester units to capture greenhouse gases (specifically methane) produced through the anaerobic decomposition of animal manure. These captured gases are used to generate renewable biogas, thereby displacing the use of non-renewable biomass for energy generation.

1.4 Project Eligibility
1.4.1 General eligibility
The initiative entails the implementation of a household biogas digester unit project designed to
capture Greenhouse Gases (GHGs), specifically methane, produced through the anaerobic
decomposition of animal manure. These captured gases are effectively harnessed through
biogas generator units, with the deployed biogas plants adopting diverse models such as
Deenbandhu, KVIC, and Janata. The project achieves a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions
by displacing the conventionally employed non-renewable biomass with the utilization of
renewable biogas. This shift not only mitigates environmental impact but also aligns with
sustainable practices for energy generation.
In accordance with Section 2.1.1, Point 4 of the VCS standard Version 4.52, the project activities
are underpinned by an approved methodology endorsed by an established GHG program (AMS-
I.E)3. This methodology, recognized and eligible within the VCS framework, facilitates the
integration of the project into the broader carbon credit ecosystem. Importantly, the project
activity does not fall within the scope of Table 1 as stipulated in Section 2.1.3 of the VCS standard
Version 4.5.
The project commenced installations of household biogas units on 9 September 2022, in
Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh, an accomplishment of establishing a total of 12,802 and
2,542 biogas plants respectively, has been realized. Considering the specific guidelines for non-

v4.5-updated-11-Dec-2023.pdf.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Huaneng Daqing Xinli Wind Farm Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is developed by
Daqing Lvyuan Wind Power Co., Ltd. The project is located at Middle Songnen Plain of Datong
District, Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province, People’s Republic of China. The project involves the
installation of 16 wind turbines, each of which has a rated output of 3,000 kW, providing a total
installed capacity of 48 MW. The annual output of the project to Northeast China Power Grid
(hereafter referred to as NEPG) is estimated to be 119,760 MWh after operation. Electricity
generated from clean renewable energy by the project activity will displace equivalent amount of
electricity generated from the fossil fuel-fired power plants of NEPG, and thus GHG (CO ) 2
generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation
sources of NEPG (which is dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants) could be reduced. The
estimated annual GHG emission reductions of the project are 115,397 tCO e. 2
For the project:
The scenario existing prior to the start of the implementation of the project is that electricity
delivered to NEPG by the project would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-
connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources.
The project scenario is that the implementation of the project, i.e. the installation and operation of
16 sets of 3,000kW wind turbines with a total installed capacity of 48MW which will supply an
average annual electricity generation of 119,760 MWh to NEPG, replace the equivalent amount
of electricity generation by fossil fuel fired power plants connected into NEPG and thus reduce
the GHG emissions.
The baseline scenario is the same as the scenario existing prior to the start of implementation of
the project.
The project will not only supply renewable electricity to grid, but also contribute to sustainable
development of the local community and the host country by means of:
- Accelerating the economy development of the local area and increasing the local revenue;
- Reducing the GHG emissions which are caused by the grid-connected fossil fuel-fired power
plants;
- Increasing the employment opportunities of the local area;
- Ameliorating the energy structure of the local area.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The Project falls in the sectoral scope 1: energy industries (renewable-/non-renewable
sources).
Project type: Renewable (wind) power project
The Project is not a grouped project.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector appears to be Forestry and Land Use. The project involves the assessment of greenhouse gas CO2 production/absorption in a lagoon environment used for fishing purposes. It focuses on the reduction and control of CO2 emissions in agricultural activities and includes the management of both tree and non-tree vegetation and soil in the emerged part of the lagoon.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
saline characteristics of the water are the classic lagoon ones with saline increases during the summer
(40 ppt) and fresher water wedges during the winter (20 ppt). The other average chemical-physical
parameters are: Temp 5-28 °C, pH 8-8.5, O2 5-8 ppm. In the event of an overflow of the Sile River, flows
of fresher water can enter the valley and be used for the winter surface freezing of the fishponds. A
system of sluices allows the environment to be separated in the event of weather and climate adversity.
The maintenance of this equilibrium, which is indispensable for the development of a greenhouse gas
absorption effect, takes place by means of appropriate man-made changes of tidal seawater through
special mobile interface bulkhead locks.
Before the start of the project the valley was partially controlled with a traditional environmental
management. It was already practiced the conventional fish production.
The project is integrated into a human-controlled lagoon environment called the ‘fishing valley'. The
property is intended to ensure and improve the inflow of brackish water from the external environment
by favouring the maximum biological balance and biodiversity of the internal ecosystem. The presence of
mobile (closed) gates controlled by man, make it possible to control the quality of the water introduced,
excluding from the circuit (closed gates) external lagoon water with low oxygen content and rich in
metabolites/catabolites. Further actions are the continuous maintenance with the deepening of the inlet
channels that form the basis for proper environmental vivification. In addition, the natural presence of
nutrients (iron and nitrogenous substances) in the seabed favours the development of macro-algae that
capture carbon (CO2) from the atmosphere during the photosynthetic phase, organise it and transport it
to the seabed after their death during the cold season as described by Doimi M. (2021) : Human
Controlled Wetland Project for Carbon Capture and Storage in the Venetian Lagoon, Italy - Journal of
Environmental Science and Engineering A - Volume 10, Number 1. In addition, the proper management
of both tree and non-tree vegetation and soil in the emerged part will optimise the project.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project consists of assessing the production/absorption of greenhouse gas CO2 in a eutrophic lagoon
environment used for fishing purposes (Fishing Valley). According to the UNFCCC CDM criteria, this project
should be considered for the standard. VCS, AFOLU ARR project type and the voluntary assessment of
carbon credits based on Annex A of the Kyoto Protocol, which falls into the following category:
- 'Reduction and control of CO2 emissions in agricultural activities'
Based on the VCS standard v 4.1 Program par. 3.9.1 is a medium project: less than 300,000 tonnes of
CO2 per year.
The project is part of the voluntary assessment of carbon credits based on Annex A of the Kyoto Protocol,
which includes the following types/categories
- 'Reduction and control of CO2 emissions in agricultural activities', AFOLU ARR project type: Net
greenhouse gas removals by sinks
The methodology is varied and is selected according to the two lagoon ecological zones: land and water.
5

This methodology is applicable to the project activity, as it has been registered as a UNFCCC CDM project with reference number 5659. The project follows the guidelines and requirements outlined in the PDD (Project Design Document) sections B.3, B.4, B.5, B.6, and B.6.4. There are no deviations from the adopted methodology, and the quantification of GHG (Greenhouse Gas) emissions reductions and removals is outlined in sections B.6 and B.6.4 of the PDD.

Project Summary: The project aims to create a model of sustainable competitiveness in the natural rubber sector in Guatemala by introducing innovative practices. This includes creating a sustainable mechanism for project finance using carbon finance, developing a comprehensive tool-kit for carbon project development, and certifying the rubber tree plantations under the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) principles.

Province: The project consists of farms located in two different regions of Guatemala - Izabal and Alta Verapaz in the north along the Atlantic Coast, and Suchitepéquez in the south along the Pacific Coast.

Country: Guatemala

Latitude and Longitude:
1) Palmeras farm: Latitude 14o26'0.8.14'', Longitude 91o17'26.78''
2) Bello Horizonte farm: Latitude 15o36'13.43'', Longitude 88o57'7.01''
3) Rio Frio farm: Latitude 15o40'31.96'', Longitude 88o55'5.64''
4) El Horizonte farm: Latitude 14o20'49.4'', Longitude 91o10'56''
5) Asuncion farm: Latitude 14o28'35.10'', Longitude 91o13'34.2''
6) Los Patos farm: Latitude 14o23'51.8'', Longitude 91o28'54.0''

VCS Project Description - PICA
effective planted area corresponds to 2,252.23 hectares which is given by planting density of natural rubber plantations. This
area excludes other vegetated areas within project boundary such as creeks, borders’ vegetation, and small spots of vegetation.
The H. brasiliensis plantations owned by the project participants are changing the socio-economic conditions of the region by
improving employment rates and incomes. Currently PICA, the project proponent, is seeking a financial solution that will allow
not only the expansion of its own plantations as well as the plantations of the small and medium enterprises (SMEs) but also to
allow doing good practices of responsible management within rubber plantations, that provide rubber to PICA’s industrial
plant, thereby increasing the amount of raw material available for processing.
The project aims to create a model of sustainable competitiveness in the natural rubber sector in Guatemala introducing
several innovative practices. The first will be to create a sustainable mechanism for project finance, introducing carbon finance
as a new and key financial tool to reach the required rate of return for investors in rubber plantations. The second innovation
will be to create a comprehensive tool-kit of methods and knowledge related to carbon project development, monitoring, and
management for new rubber tree plantations. The third innovation represents a milestone in sustainable management of
rubber tree plantations in Latin America, as the plantations established by the project will be certified under the Forest
Stewardship Council (FSC) principles and criteria.
FSC certification for the rubber tree plantations established by the project activity ensures that the project will comply with
stringent standards for social and environmental responsibility. In addition to generating emission reduction credits, the
plantations will serve as a buffer area for 675 hectares of the Cerro San Gil natural rainforest reserve in Izabal Department. As
required by FSC certification, new plantations added to the grouped project will not cause deforestation or degradation of
existing forests. Also, not only will the project create new employment opportunities for stakeholders, it will strive to protect
worker safety and rights while maintaining a good relationship with neighbouring communities.
PICA currently works with 350 rubber suppliers (plantation owners), most of them SMEs that are not participating in the
project. In accordance with PICA’s strategic plan, the knowledge and experience gained through the project will be replicated
with additional suppliers to expand the areas of their plantations.
1.5 Project location including geographic and physical information allowing the unique identification and delineation of
the specific extent of the project:
The project area consists of seven different farms comprising discrete areas located in two different regions of Guatemala.

Verapaz. The farms situated in the South of Guatemala along the Pacific Coast are located in the Department of Suchitepéquez.

of them is included in Annex F.
1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
The effective start date of the project is May 31, 2007. This is the date that the formal decision to commit financial resources
to the development of a carbon project to create an incentive for the establishment of natural rubber plantation was
documented and signed by the board of directors of PICA6, Project Proponent.
The crediting period runs from June 30, 2007 until 2049, total of crediting period 42 years. June 30, 2007 is the start date
marked by the implementation of the first project activity, which was the preparation of the soil for the establishment of the
first rubber plantations within the project boundary. The first trees were planted in 2007 and the final trees under the project
will be planted in 2013. The plantations’ rotation cycle for rubber tree is 36 years.
The VCS project crediting period and the carbon project lifetime is 42 years.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is based on the UNFCCC CDM (United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change Clean Development Mechanism) small-scale methodologies AMS-I.F and AMS-I.D. AMS-I.F, Version 02, titled "Renewable electricity generation for captive use and mini-grid," is applicable when the project activity involves renewable energy generation (wind) that supplies electricity to one or more users and displaces electricity from an electricity distribution system supplied by a national or regional grid. AMS-I.D, Version 17, titled "Grid-connected renewable electricity generation," is applicable when the project activity is wind that supplies electricity to a national or regional grid and may also displace grid-supplied electricity consumption at the user end. The project also utilizes the UNFCCC CDM methodological tools "Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system," Version 03.0.0, and "Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality," Version 07.0.0. The project boundary includes the wind energy conversion system, associated ancillary equipment, and the MRO (Midwest Reliability Organization) bulk electricity system within the United States.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
• UNFCCC CDM small-scale methodology AMS-I.F, Version 02, “Renewable electricity
generation for captive use and mini-grid”
• UNFCCC CDM methodological tool “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity
system”, Version 03.0.0
• UNFCCC CDM Methodological Tool “Tool for the demonstration and assessment of
additionality”, Version 07.0.0
2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The Project Activity meets the applicability conditions of the UNFCCC CDM small-scale
methodology AMS-I.D, Version 17:
• The Project Activity is wind that supplies electricity to a national or a regional grid (re:
paragraph 1.a. of the methodology).
• The Project Activity may also displace grid supplied electricity consumption at the user end
(re: paragraph 2 and Table 2 of the methodology). In such case Methodology AMS-I.F
would apply.
• The Project Activity involves the installation of new power plants at a site where there was
no renewable energy power plant operating prior to the implementation of the Project
Activity (re: paragraph 3 of the methodology).
Project activity instances displacing grid energy at the end user will meet the applicability
conditions of the UNFCCC CDM small-scale methodology AMS-I.F, Version 02:
• The Project Activity is renewable energy generation (wind) that supplies electricity to one or
more users, and displaces electricity from an electricity distribution system supplied by a
national or region grid (re: paragraph 1.a. of the methodology).
• The Project Activity may also supply electricity directly to a national/regional grid (re:
paragraph 3 and Table 2 of the methodology). In such case Methodology AMS-I.D would
apply.
• The Project Activity involves the installation of new power plants at a site where there was
no renewable energy power plant operating prior to the implementation of the Project
Activity (re: paragraph 6 of the methodology).
2.3 Project Boundary
The Project Boundary includes the wind energy conversion system and associated ancillary
equipment of each Project Activity Instance and the boundary of the MRO bulk electricity system,
including all power plants within the MRO system within the United States only.7 The MRO

1.17 Sustainable Development Contributions
This Plantation project contributes to the sustainable development of the homestead croplands.
The project results in the achievement of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),
specifically SDGs numbering 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 12, 13, 15, 16 and 17.
SDG 1: No Poverty
Agriculture being one of major sectors of India’s economy, has been the source for survival and
income for a large proportion of India’s population. When farmers own lands which become
degraded due to non-cultivation, their incomes are affected as they are often mostly small and
marginal farmers and their lands are not productive enough. These farmers/land owners have
often only one source of income making them vulnerable to poverty in case of crop failure.

inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project carried out changes from a continuously flooded regime to an intermittently flooded
regime during rice cultivation in Chengmai County, Hainan Province, China, with a total acreage
of 12,488 ha of double-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches, pumps,
valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously
flooded method would be continued. The original scenario for rice cultivation by the continuously
flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded
conditions can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition, the
intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water, increasing rice yield, and
reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.
The implementation activities of the project include constructing high-standard farmland, annual
training, conducting the intermittently flooded method, etc. According to the needs of rice growth,
farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water
resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice
paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in
the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 4.74
tCO e/ha. 2
The project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions by 414,337 tCO e in the first seven-year 2
period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,191 tCO e. The project aims to 2
reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living
standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

So, this\nproject can be categorized as eligible ALM\nactivity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within 10 years before the project\nstart date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.1'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems\nby increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil\nN O emissions, and/or reducing CH emissions.\n2 4', 'This project practices intermittently flooded\nmethods on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH emissions. So, this project is an eligible ICM\n4\nactivity.']]
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.3 Project Eligibility
Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM, this project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra. This is by the
definitions of eligible AFOLU project categories set out in Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard, v4.2,
and can be demonstrated from the following three points.
According to Section 2.1.1 of “VCS Standard version 4.2”, this project activity meets two of the
scopes of the VCS program:
1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases.
4) Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Accordingly, this project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the 4
six Kyoto Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program – United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of the VCS program.
The project is an individual project, not a fragmented part of a larger project or activity.

The project is contributing to sustainable development defined by the government of Indonesia
specifically as follows:
Social well-being:
• The project contributes to the development of the region by increasing community
development and corporate social responsibility of PT. PLN (Persero) such as infrastructure
development (road, bridges); funds for building a new school, church and mosque in the
region; upgrading health care facilities (a small clinic) as well as free medicines in the vicinity
of the project for the benefit of the community.
• During both construction and operation, various kinds of mechanical work are required,
providing employment on a regular and permanent basis.
Economic well-being:
• The project activity generates direct and indirect employment for skilled and unskilled
manpower during construction phase as well as during operational stage and thus helped in
controlling migration from the region and alleviation of poverty in the local area.
• The generated electricity is fed into regional grids through the local grid, thereby improving
the availability of electricity to local consumers (villagers and sub-urban inhabitants) by
increasing the electricity supply. Due to increased new opportunities for industries and
economic activities arise with a chance for more local employment and better overall
development.
• The project activity leads to diversification of the national energy supply that is dominated by
conventional-fuel-based generating units.

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The Agropalma REDD+ Project aims to promote forest conservation, carbon stock maintenance, and climate change mitigation by reducing greenhouse gas emissions from land use change. It also intends to generate social and environmental benefits through sustainable economic development practices and the conservation of local flora and fauna.

Province: The project is located in the northeastern mesoregion of Pará State in Brazil.

Country: The project is located in Brazil.

Latitude and Longitude: The specific latitude and longitude coordinates are not provided in the given information.
inputs.context:
CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
The Agropalma REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Ambipar Environmental and Agropalma
Group and its purpose is to promote forest conservation, maintenance of carbon stocks and mitigation of
climate change through the reduction of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from land use change. In
addition to the climate benefits, the Project also intends to generate social benefits based on sustainable
economic development practices and improved well-being of the surrounding communities, as well as
environmental benefits through actions aimed at the conservation of local flora and fauna.
The Project area covers 50,519 hectares of Amazon forest and is located almost entirely in the northeastern
mesoregion of Pará State, including the municipalities of Tailândia, Moju, Tomé Açu and Acará. It is located
near the PA-150, an important highway for the distribution of the state's agricultural production, and on the
banks of the Acará River. We identified communities that are directly or indirectly influenced by the Project,
either because they supply labor to Fazenda Agropalma or because they are geographically close to the
Project Area and depend on its ecosystem services.
The region has great relevance in relation to its biodiversity, since it is located in the Belém Center of
Endemism (CEB), a place with a large concentration of rare and endemic species. The predominant
vegetation is Dense Ombrophylous Forest with a high density of medium and large trees, besides woody
lianas and epiphytes. It is home to at least 28 species of fauna and flora with some degree of threat
according to the IUCN Red List, some of which are endemic to the region.
It was identified that the main agents of deforestation and forest degradation in the region are small,
medium-sized family farmers or even large landowners. They are mostly rural producers who own areas in
agrarian reform settlements, squatters, and land grabbers who are in areas not yet recognized by the
agrarian reform or officially registered in the responsible public agencies and practice deforestation to
expand areas of agricultural and livestock production with low productivity or to search for raw material to
sustain the illegal trade in wood.
Based on this context, the Project's activities were designed to guarantee the conservation and protection
of biodiversity and natural resources, through mitigating and preventive measures such as the
strengthening of patrimonial vigilance, social inclusion and regional socioeconomic development through
alternative practices to deforestation, and the development and strengthening of value chains, the
establishment of a biodiversity conservation program, promoting in situ monitoring of the fauna and flora in
the Project Area, in addition to environmental education as a strategy to discourage predatory hunting and

D.1. Documentation on the analysis of the environmental impacts, including transboundary

A Project Identification File has been prepared for Caykara HEPP project by KARCEV CEVRE
YONETIM VE ARITIM TEKNOLOJILERI Co. in April 2009, in order to assess the Environmental
Impacts of the project, including its location, its characteristics, capacity, interaction with other plants in
the vicinity, usage of natural resources, waste management, social and economical impacts, any natural
and historical protected areas within the project boundaries, assessment of geological and seismic aspects
of the project site.
This Report has been evaluated by the relevant local government agencies and by the Ministry of
Environment and Forestry and the Environmental Effects Evaluation and Planning General Management.
After evaluation of the project and comments of the local agencies, the Ministry of Environment and
Forestry has concluded that project does not have any significant environmental effect and gave a
decision on 09.04.2009 that no EIA is required for the project activities. The EIA not required certificate
is given in Annex 5.
D.2. If environmental impacts are considered significant by the project participants or the host
Party, please provide conclusions and all references to support documentation of an environmental
impact assessment undertaken in accordance with the procedures as required by the host Party:
Caykara HEPP project is a run of river energy generation project without any dam. The environmental
impacts of the project are negligible. The HEPP will not change any water volume or cause any water
pollution. No negative impact of the project activities has been identified. Land use, grazing or
agricultural activities will not be affected negatively by the project activity. All necessary permissions
including, environmental, health and safety, have been acquired from the relevant agencies and all the
precautions have been applied strictly by the owners.
In order to protect the river habitat, 1.5 m3/s flow will be continuously released from the weir. In order to
prevent any negative impact on environment, all relevant regulation will be applied strictly. 52

1.17 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
1.17.1 Leakage Management
According to Para 3.7.2 of Methodology requirements, the methodology shall establish
procedures to quantify all significant sources of leakage. Leakage is defined as an increase in
GHG emissions that occurs outside the project boundary (but within the same country) and is
measurable and attributable to the project activities. All leakage shall be accounted for in
accordance with Section 3.7. The two types of leakage are Arable farming and charcoal
production. To address such leakage the project has identified leakage management areas
located within the leakage belt. As part of the periodic monitoring process, such leakages if
occurring shall be quantified and reported. The Activity-shifting leakage occurs when the actual
agent of deforestation and/or forest or wetland degradation moves to an area outside of the
project boundary and continues its deforestation or degradation activities elsewhere. To
address such leakage the project has identified leakage management areas located within the

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is described in the document "CDM Small Scale Methodology AMS-I.F - Renewable electricity generation for captive use and mini-grid (Version 3.0)". The project activities involve installing new renewable power plants using solar electrical technologies that convert solar radiation into electrical energy. The project activities must meet certain conditions, such as displacing grid electricity consumption or captive fossil fuel electricity generation, and not exceeding a certain capacity limit of 15 MW. The methodology also includes tools for calculating CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion, electricity consumption, and biomass, as well as determining the emission factor for an electricity system. The methodology does not consider leakage and does not involve commercially sensitive information.

{'project_name': 'Community-based Mangrove Restoration Initiative – Lep Lep', 'project_summary': 'The objective of this project is to restore degraded mangrove sites in Kafoutine in Senegal. The project will create a healthy mangrove ecosystem in degraded lands.
The components of the project are reforestation, providing important ecosystem services, climate change mitigation, socio-economic improvements, and active participation of the local community.
Under this grouped project degraded mangroves are restored and enriched. In the first project activity, up to 1.9 million mangroves will be planted in an area of 750 ha, starting in 2023. The species selected for this reforestation project are indigenous and local, namely Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans.
Training and awareness-raising of the local communities are crucial for the success for the project. From the start of the project, stakeholders potentially affected by the project have been involved in the process. This included providing information on all project activities and teaching basics on forest management, monitoring, forest protection activities, climate change, and carbon sequestration. Depending on the given conditions, up to 3,500 seedlings per hectare will planted. The project will sequestrate an estimated 355,000 tCO2 in the 750 ha over a period of 20 years.
The empowerment of the communities is central to the project. The labor requirement for the project will be fulfilled with local employment. Therefore, most of the budget for labor and an additional 50/50 share of carbon credit revenues will remain in the country. The project will promote a working family model where more than 50% of women can actively participate in the project.
Mangrove restoration will further increase fish populations and improve biodiversity. To measure the positive impact on biodiversity, annual biomonitoring will be conducted using eDNA.
Over the 20-year period, the project team will create a healthy mangrove ecosystem, improve the socio-economic status of the community, and foster climate change mitigation.', 'project_country': 'Senegal', 'project_latitude': 12.91, 'project_longitude': -16.69}

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
M/s Evergreen Ecotech Pvt. Ltd. (EEPL), a renewable energy consultancy firm actively involved
in promoting renewable energy in the region. EEPL is the project participant for this bundled
project activity. The project activity involves number of grid connected WTGs and solar panels
installed across various state of India.
The bundled project activity comprises of sub projects that sell the generated electricity to the
southern grid and North eastern grid governed by Power Purchase Agreement (PPA)/third party
sales, which are classified as Group A, and sub projects that wheel the generated electricity via
the grid for captive usage governed by Energy Purchase Agreement (EPA), classified as Group
B. The Project will generate emission reductions by displacing electricity generation from grid
connected fossil fuel-fired power plants that would otherwise be generating electricity.
Purpose of the project activity
The purpose of project activity is to generate electricity using the windmills and solar panels
which replaces the power generated by fossil fuel intensive thermal power plants thus reducing
the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) in to the atmosphere. The average
lifetime of the WTGs and panels is 20 years1. The project activity will generate approximately
MWh of electricity to southern grid and NEWNE annually thus contributing 50,000 tCO2e of
emission reductions per year.
In recent years, India has witnessed a huge increase in power consumption. Both public and
private parties are struggling to meet the demand for electricity. The proposed wind project will
contribute in a sustainable manner to bridge the gap between supply and demand of power on a
regional and national level.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project activity falls under the following guidelines set in the Clean Development Mechanism
under the Kyoto Protocol:-
Sectoral Scope : 1 Energy industries (renewable - / non-renewable sources)
Project Type : Electricity from Wind Turbo Generator and solar panels
Project activity is not a grouped project

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project sponsor is Modern Road Makers Pvt. Ltd. (herein referred to as MRMPL). It is a
subsidiary of IRB Infrastructure Developers Limited (IRBIDL). It is involved in the construction,
operation and maintenance of roads through various infrastructure projects in the road sector and
is one of the major road developers in India.
The project is the generation of electricity from wind power by installation of 16 Wind Turbine
Generators (WTG) at Jaisalmer, Rajasthan. Each WTG has an installed capacity of 1.25 MW.
The total installed capacity of the project is 20 MW. The purpose of the project is to produce
power from clean source and to reduce the dependence on fossil fuels for energy requirements.
Project proponent has signed a power purchase agreement (PPA) with “Jodhpur Vidyut Vitran
Nigam Limited” (JVVNL) to export the electricity to local grid.
The project displaces electricity from the grid (North East West North East (NEWNE) grid, India).
This helps in significant reduction of GHG emissions as the NEWNE Grid is mostly dependent on
fossil fuel generated electricity. The estimated annual emission reduction is 32,788 tCO2e per
year.
The project is registered with UNFCCC CDM (UN ref. no. 3839) on 27/11/2010 with crediting
period 27/11/2010 to 26/11/2020.

Project Type : I - Renewable Energy Projects

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology applied to the project is the approved consolidated baseline and monitoring methodology ACM0002 "Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources", Version 09. This methodology is applicable to the project because it is a grid-connected renewable power generation project that meets all the applicability criteria stated in the methodology. The project boundary includes the wind power plant itself and the Northeast China Power Grid, which is composed of Jilin Power Grid, Liaoning Power Grid, and Heilongjiang Power Grid. The sources and gases included in the project boundary are CO2 and CH4. The methodology also includes exclusion criteria for CH4 and NO2, which are considered conservative according to ACM0002.

inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector is Agriculture, Forestry, and Other Land Use (AFOLU).
inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice
cultivation is conducted Qing’an County, Suihua City, Heilongjiang Province, China, with a total
acreage of 17,513 ha of single-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches,
pumps, valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional
continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was
cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic
decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of
methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water,
improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir
construction, pumps and valves installation, training, etc. According to the needs of rice growth,
farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water
resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice
paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in
the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 3.23
tCO2e/ha.
The project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions by 395,430 tCO2e in the first seven-year
period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 56,490 tCO2e. The project aims to
reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living
standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

So, this project\ncan be categorized as eligible ALM activity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within 10 years before the project\nstart date.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.1'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This\ncategory includes practices that demonstrably\nreduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems by\nincreasing soil carbon stocks, reducing soil N2O\nemissions, and/or reducing CH4 emissions.', 'This project practices intermittently flooded\nmethods on croplands, which is demonstrated\nthat can reduce net GHG emissions by reducing\nCH4 emissions. inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project activity consists of the construction of two Greenfield run-of-river hydroelectric power plants
(HEPPs): Murat I and Murat II. They will both be located on the Göksu River flowing through Besni,
Adıyaman in Turkey‟s South-eastern Region.
Murat I and Murat II belong to Murat HEPP Energy Electricity Generation and Trade Inc. (hereafter
referred as the “project owner”). Murat I‟s installed capacity is 24.081 MW whereas, Murat II is 13.14 MW.
Therefore, the project‟s total installed capacity is 37.221 MW.
As it can be seen on the generation licence of Murat Projects, There is one Project consist of two power
plants.
The main purpose of the project is to generate approximately 150.39GWh/year1 of electricity to supply the
national grid using a renewable resource. The project activity reduces greenhouse gas (GHGs) emissions
that would have otherwise occurred in the absence of the project activity by avoiding electricity generation
from fossil fuel sources. The average annual emission reductions of the proposed Project are estimated
to be 97,754 tonnes of CO e (tCO e). 2 2
The Murat HEPP Project contributes to the region‟s sustainable development in particular and Turkey‟s
sustainable development in general by:
 increasing the use of renewable energy sources for generating electricity
 meeting the need of electricity generation and supply in Turkey in a sustainable way,
 decreasing the consumption of fossil fuels,
 reducing emission of GHGs from the national electricity grid, thereby reducing the effects of
global climate change in the medium and long term, and
 114 people have been hired during the construction phase and 23 people will be employed during
the operation phase. The project owner is committed to prioritize local labour force in selecting
construction and operating workers. As a result the employment rate and income generation in
the region will increase.
It is worth mentioning that the project has been certified to the following standards:
 OHSAS 18001:2007, occupational health and safety management certificate, valid until 05-May-
2013,
 TS EN ISO 14001:2004, environmental management system certificate, valid until 05-May-2013,
and
 TS EN ISO 9001:2008, quality management system certificate, valid until 05-May-2013.
During the certification process all the employees (including subcontractors) were trained on the
requirements established in these standards. Moreover, the project owner has organized monthly
trainings and inspections to maintain these certifications.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project, as described in the provided context, involves the implementation of various tools and conditions to estimate carbon stocks and changes in carbon stocks, as well as the estimation of non-CO2 greenhouse gas emissions and the increase in GHG emissions attributable to displacement of pre-project agricultural activities. 

The project activity focuses on the plantation of eligible trees in identifiable and separate plots spread over various districts of Odisha. The land selected for the project activity is privately owned agricultural and fallow lands that do not fall into the wetland category. Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10% of the area in specific types of land. The project is in compliance with applicable legal and regulatory requirements.

The project also involves the estimation of carbon stocks and changes in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs, dead wood and litter, and soil organic carbon stocks. The tools used for these estimations have specific applicability conditions, which are described in the provided context.

Additionally, the project includes the estimation of non-CO2 greenhouse gas emissions resulting from burning biomass attributable to the project activity. This tool will be applied for fire incidents that affect an area greater than 0.5ha, where the accumulated area of fires in any year is higher than ≥5% of the project area. It is mentioned that no fires have occurred in the past.

Overall, the methodology of this project involves the use of various tools, compliance with applicability conditions, and estimation of carbon stocks, changes in carbon stocks, and greenhouse gas emissions.

Sustainable Development:
This project activity will achieve sustainable development of the local Sangli region in
following ways.
1. Social well being
The region under NEWNE Grid is reeling under power shortage. The power generated from
this wind power project activity will be fed to the NEWNE Grid. This project activity will
provide solace to end users under the grid region during the power shortages.
2. Environmental well being
The energy generated from the wind power project activity is one of the cleanest forms of
energy. It is environmental friendly, as this project activity will not be emitting any harmful
pollutants in the atmosphere during its operations. Overall the project activity will be
resulting into an environmental well being.
3. Technological well being
The power generation technology used in this project activity is provided by Suzlon Energy
Ltd., which is well known in wind power technology. The products are technologically
superior & safe. The wind turbines in this project activity are S-66 class. The implementation
of this project activity will provide required impetus to promote commercialization of WTGs
of small capacity.
4. Economical well being
The project activity will provide fillip to economic activity in the region by putting additional
power in to the NEWNE Grid, stimulating growth of commercial activities. The project
activity will be resulting into direct & indirect employment generation in local area. The
project activity will be resulting into generation of income in this part of Maharashtra.
In view of the above, the project promoter considered this project activity profoundly
contributes to the sustainable development in the region.
Eligibility of the project activity is discussed under the section 2.2. Quantification of emission
reductions or removal enhancements is discussed under the section 1.3. The information
regarding geographic, site-specific information is discussed under section 1.5.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is "Thermal energy production with or without electricity" under the VCS (Verified Carbon Standard) framework. It falls under the category of "Renewable energy power project" and specifically "Thermal Energy production with or without electricity". The methodology has been chosen because the project activity involves biomass-based steam generation using rice husk. The project fulfills the criteria of having a total installed thermal energy generation capacity of less than 45 MW thermal. The project activity does not involve co-fired systems or delivery of energy to other facilities. It is a new installation and does not involve retrofitting or modification of an existing facility. The project activity does not use charcoal or briquettes as biomass fuel. Overall, the project meets all the applicability criteria of the selected methodology.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03
CDM – Executive Board
page 2
SECTION A. General description of project activity
A.1. Title of the project activity:
>>
CECIC Zhangbei Gaojialiang Wind farm Project
PDD version 4.0
Completed on 25/10/2010
PDD revision history
A.2. Description of the project activity:
>>
CECIC Zhangbei Gaojialiang Wind farm Project (hereinafter referred to as the proposed project) is a
newly-built wind farm project, which is located in Zhangbei County, Hebei Province, and is developed by
CECIC Wind Power (Zhangbei) Yunwei Co. Ltd. As per the FSR, the calculations for the net supplier
power of the proposed project are carried out using professional WASP software (www.wasp.dk)
designed for wind energy. The output is maximised through selection of the most suitable turbines,
optimal turbine distribution in the wind farm, and considering the specific turbine characteristics, and the
grid connection. So the proposed project is to install and operate 66 wind turbines of 750kW and net
supplied power of 94,050 MWh per year will be exported to the North China Power Grid (NCPG) on the
basis of a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA).
As the baseline scenario, which is the same as the scenario existing prior to the implementation of the
project activity, comparable capacity or electricity generation addition provided by the NCPG, is
dominated by the thermal power generation, the operation of the proposed project will lead to emission
reductions of CO , which is estimated to be approximately 89,366 tonnes of CO e per year. The proposed 2 2
project will therefore help local government to promote the economy development and improve the air
quality.
The proposed project promotes local sustainable development through the following aspects:
• reducing CO , SO and NOx emissions; 2 2
• creating local employment opportunity during the assembly and installation of wind turbines, and
for operation of the proposed project;
• reducing other particulate pollutants resulting from the fossil fuel fired power plants compared with
a business-as-usual scenario.
A.3. Project participants:

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Guizhou Xintian CMM Power Generation Project', 'project_summary': 'Guizhou Xintian CMM Power Generation Project (hereafter referred to as “the Project”) refers to a power plant which utilizes low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) for power generation to supply electricity to the Xintian coal mine and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG). The Project is located in Gantang Town, Qianxi County, Bijie City, Guizhou Province, People’s Republic of China.\r\nThe purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted low concentration CMM to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM)  or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. It was planned that CMM power generators with a total capacity of 17.6 MW would be installed for the Project. Based on ex ante estimates, the power plant will destroy a total amount of 35.2 million m3 (under normal conditions ) of methane and export 82,720 MWh of electricity every year, when all power generators are in full operation. The generated electricity is supplied to the Xintian coal mine through the electricity distribution network in the coal mine area; part of the electricity produced by the Project is exported to CSPG after the coal mine demand is fully met.\r\nThe Project achieves emission reductions in two aspects: 1) it reduces methane emissions by capturing and destroying methane which would have been directly vented into the air in the baseline scenario; 2) it reduces CO2 emissions by displacing an amount of electricity that would otherwise have been supplied by CSPG.', 'project_state_province': 'Guizhou', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 27.11, 'project_longitude': 106.1}

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
Moreover, the intermittently flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production
increase, and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded. The project aims to
replace the traditional cultivation method with an intermittently flooded method for GHG
reduction whilst contributing to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the project zone.
18,676 ha of rice paddies are changed to apply the intermittently flooded method in Fuling
District, where the rice used to be cultivated under continuously flooded conditions.
The project is in Fuling District. The total population of Fuling District is 1,115,016. All the rice
paddies belong to the farmers. During the construction period, Chongqing Municipal Agricultural
and Rural Affairs Committee (hereinafter “agricultural authority”) was the main manager, with
the cooperation and participation of Gengfang, of the construction of ditches and reservoirs,
while the local farmers were hired to build the ditches and reservoirs. During the operation period,
Gengfang is responsible for supervising technicians to patrol and maintain the ditches and
reservoirs. Besides, Gengfang has been fully authorized by all the farmers to act as the project
proponent, who oversees the project development and management, including compiling the
Monitoring and Quality Control Manual, organizing the training, etc. Moreover, the local
agricultural authority is responsible for technical training. Farmers are the main operators to
practice intermittently flooded water regimes and are supposed to record the cultivation
logbooks. The technicians should carry out monthly inspections according to the Monitoring and
Quality Control Manual requirements. The profit from this carbon reduction project is shared with
farmers.
The implementation of the project activity generates 59,243 tCO e per year and contributes to 3 2
SDGs.
This project is not located within a jurisdiction covered by a jurisdictional REDD + program.
The implementation schedule of this project is listed as follows:
1.12 Project Location
The project is in Fuling District, Chongqing City, China. The geographical coordinates of the project
are between 106°56' E-107°43' E and 29°21' N-30°01' N.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Fuling Water Management with Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project is to change from continuously flooded regimes to intermittently flooded regimes during rice cultivation in Fuling District, Chongqing City, China, with a total acreage of 18,676 ha of single-cropping rice. A total of 8,645 households (36,136 farmers) were involved in the project. Without the project, local villagers would not have access to intermittently flooded technology and intact facilities to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to water efficiency, improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.\r\nThe implementation activities of the project include promoting intermittently flooded technology, technical training for the farmers, facility repair and replacement, etc. According to the needs of rice growth, farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in the rainy season.\r\nThe project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by 414,701 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,243 tCO2e. The project aims to reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.', 'project_state_province': 'Chongqing', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 29.37, 'project_longitude': 106.95}
