inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION
VCS Version 3, CCB Standards Second Edition
1.7 Project Crediting Period (G3)
The duration of the VCS project crediting period is 60 years, 1 January 2010-31 December 2069. In
CCBA terminology, this is both the project lifetime and the GHG accounting period.
Thr methodology (page 8) requires that the baseline is fixed for periods of ten years and then
adjusted as necessary. Each ten year period is called a fixed baseline period. The first fixed baseline
period will run from 1 January 2010-31 December 2019.
27

PROJECT DESCRIPTION
VCS Version 3, CCB Standards Second Edition
2 DESIGN
2.1 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is an Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) project under the Reduced
Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) project category. Specifically, the project is of
the “Avoiding unplanned deforestation and degradation” (AUD) type. This project is not a grouped
project.
The project is only claiming credits generated from avoided unplanned deforestation. This is a
conservative approach since the planned activities should also avoid the risk of future planned
deforestation and avoid any future worsening of degradation (currently occurring at negligible levels
from the perspective of GHG emissions).
Increased carbon sequestration from reforestation or assisted natural regeneration is not a major
objective of the project. Some of the forest areas where deforestation is prevented may increase in
carbon stock naturally due to recovery from past logging, and in theory this might be eligible for
additional credits, but to reduce project complexity no credits will be claimed for this during the first
fixed baseline period.
2.2 Description of the Project Activity (G3)
Objectives and conceptual model
The objectives of the REDD project in the Core Area link directly to the over-arching management
objectives of the SPF. The original vision for the SPF was developed at a multi-stakeholder workshop
in July 2006 (WCS/FA 2006b). This consultation included representatives from all the relevant
government agencies, local government, village leaders and civil society. The agreed Vision for the
site was: A well-managed forest landscape that supports increasing wildlife populations and improving
livelihoods for the people who currently live there. At the same meeting a general conceptual model
for the project was developed, linking the goal to four key measurable targets, a set of direct and
indirect threats and a set of interventions. This was then used to develop the first three year strategic
plan, 2008-2011, the annual workplans and the draft Subdecree.
Figure 2.1 shows the current conceptual model, based on the 2006 results, which was revised and
updated slightly during the design of the REDD project based on the analysis of threats set out in
Section 4.5.
Subdecree 143 (2009) lists nine management objectives for SPF, which map closely to the four high
level Targets in the conceptual model. These are listed below in relation to the three CCBA themes -
climate, community and biodiversity. The activities are then discussed in more detail.
Climate objectives
The SPF Subdecree contains the following two relevant objectives.
3- To contribute to protection and conservation, to meet the goals of the National Millennium

Project Summary: The project involves agroforestry plantations in Gujarat, a state in India. The project aims to validate and verify the implementation of the project through a third-party independent assessor. The role of communities, particularly farmers, is emphasized, including taking care of saplings, encouraging other farmers to plant agroforestry tree species, and ensuring the completion of the harvesting cycle before selling timber.

Country: India

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Voluntary Carbon Market Project for Agroforestry Plantation in Anand and Kheda, Gujarat', 'project_summary': 'The demand for timber and other tree-based products is increasing day by day and one feasible alternative to fulfil such a demand would be adopting agroforestry practice as this is one system that can provide both wood and food while at the same time conserve and rehabilitate ecosystem. The proposed ARR VCS project plans to promote sustainable agroforestry for small-scale farmers to provide them with financial benefits and ensure GHG mitigation in the state of Gujarat, India. The project is being conducted in the Ahmedabad circle spread across Anand and Kheda district. The total project area in Anand district is 2272.75 hectares and 3096.5 hectares in Kheda district, together making a total project area of 5369.25 hectares. The agroforestry plantations done by the farmers from 2018 to 2020 have been considered. The main agroforestry species planted in each village during 2018, 2019 and 2020 in Anand comprises of Eucalyptus (Eucalyptus globulus), Arduso (Ailanthus excelsa), Malbari Limbda (Azadirachta Indica), Baval (Acacia nilotica), Teak (Tectona grandis) and Melia Dubia (Melia dubia), whereas in Kheda, the main agroforestry species planted during 2018,2019 and 2020 are Eucalyptus (Eucalyptus globulus), Arduso (Ailanthus excelsa), Malbari Limbda (Azadirachta Indica), Teak (Tectona grandis) and Melia Dubia (Melia dubia) and Mango (Mangifera indica).', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 22.56, 'project_longitude': 72.96}

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Shandong Wendeng Zhangjiachan Wind Farm Project (hereinafter referred to as the proposed
project) is to utilize wind resources for electricity generation through the construction of a wind
farm with a total capacity of 49.3MW in Wendeng City, Shandong Province, P. R. China. The
electricity generated from the project will be sold to North China Power Grid (NCPG). The
proposed project will achieve obvious greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions through the
displacement of electricity delivered by NCPG which is a fossil-fuel dominated grid.
The proposed project is located in Wendeng City, Shandong Province, P. R. China. The
proposed project involves the installation of 58 wind turbines with capacity of 850 kW each, which
amount to a total installed capacity of 49.3MW. The proposed project is constructed and operated
by Wendeng Zhangjiachan Wind Power Co., Ltd.. The estimated annual net electricity generation
and average annual emission reductions of the proposed project are 90,997MWh and 84,709
tCO2e, respectively.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Category: Renewable electricity in grid connected application
Sectroal Scope 1: Energy Industry
The project is not a grouped project.

1.4 Other Entities Involved in the Project
There are no other entities involved.
1.5 Project Start Date
26/02/2011(commissioning start date)
v3.2 3


PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
The project is a renewable resource based on wind power project without GHG emissions during
operation period. Therefore, it was confirmed that the project has not been implemented to
generate GHG emissions for the purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The project complies with all Chinese relevant laws and regulations. It also obtained the approval
letters from governmental authorities: Development and Reform Commission (DRC), as well as
Environment Protection Bureau (EPB) of Shandong Province. The two approvals well
demonstrate that local government permits the construction of the project. Consequently, the
project is compliance with laws, status and other regulatory frameworks.
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
The business license is the evidence for right of use. The approval of FSR and EIA are evidences
for legislative right. Besides, the purchasing contract of wind turbine and the power purchase
agreement are the evidences for the ownership of the plant, equipment and process generating.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project has been registered as a CDM project on 17/01/2012 with Ref No.5655, for which a
renewable crediting period of 3*7 years will be used under the CDM GHG Program. Therefore,
CO emission reductions generated by the project during the CDM crediting period will be verified 2
as unique CERs, but not VCUs to avoid double counting. As to the project under VCS standard
(Version. 3.4), only emission reduction achieved from 26/02/2011 to 29/02/2012 will be
considered as VCUs.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project neither has nor intends to generate any other form of GHG-related environmental
credit for GHG emission reductions or removals claimed under the VCS Program for the period
from 26/02/2011 to 29/02/2012.
1.12.4 Participation under Other GHG Programs
The project has been registered as CDM project and the registration number is 5289, the CDM
crediting period is form 01/03/2012 to 28/02/2019.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
NA

1.12 Project Location
The grouped project is located in Spain. All planting sites have the same baseline scenario and are
identified and classified as degraded land by combining soil mapping with visual assessments (see
section 1.13). Remote sensing analysis is conducted on all of the sites to determine existing
forests/trees/canopy cover, with most cases using multiple drone flights. On sites with pre-exisiting
trees, the vegetation is left undisturbed and are cropped out of the designated project area, creating
a very detailed KML file. Each project instance is defined using their exact location, delineated by the
polygons layered on the maps presented below.

1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the project initiation. The
description of the scenario is explained in Section 3.4. Therefore, the prior conditions are not
repeated in this section.
This section focuses on the conditions generated by the temperate climatic conditions that
characterise the areas within which the first instances of the project are located, as well as the
historic human-induced influence on the land. All land has reached a certain level of degradation and
would not have been restored without intervention, as shown in part 1.13.3 of this section. Analyses
of conditions prior to project initiation are largely supported by Land Life’s Remote Sensing
Dashboard (RSD).

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Land Life Reforestation and Restoration of Degraded Land in Spain - B', 'project_summary': 'The proposed ARR-VCS project is a large-scale grouped project that aims for the long-term restoration of Spain’s forests, achieved through native mixed-species reforestation that reverses the impact of land degradation and the loss of flora and fauna. Land regeneration and biodiversity rejuvenation are central objectives of this reforestation project, which employs the latest technologies and planting techniques. Project activities are implemented by Land Life, a Dutch technology-driven reforestation company that grows forests by planting trees at scale. Land Life uses innovative technology for the planting of native tree species by optimizing tree selection, survival, and resilience. Science-driven nature restoration activities ensure the highest tree survival rate and support the permanent establishment of native forests that complement rural communities.\r\n\r\nProject activities are implemented and monitored according to the VCS-approved project methodology AR-ACM0003, with the expectation that additional project instances are to be added over the coming years. The first group of instances of the project covers 285.56 of degraded land in Spain, located at two planting sites: Vega de Doña Olimpa, (116.21 ha), located in the province of Palencia, and Ariza (169.35 ha), located in Zaragoza province. While each project instance is expected to sequester carbon across the entire 100-year crediting period, the ex-ante estimate focuses on the initial 40 years for practical reasons to determine the annual average profile. These project instances (implemented across 2020 and 2021) are expected to sequester approximately 79,613 tCO2e over the initial 42 years of the 100-year crediting period. The estimated annual average of GHG emission removals is 1,990 tCO2e. A total of 245,927 native trees are expected to become established in the project areas described in this PD.', 'project_state_province': 'Valderrábano, Palencia', 'project_country': 'Spain', 'project_latitude': 42.53, 'project_longitude': -4.63}

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Virginia Coast Reserve Seagrass Restoration Project', 'project_summary': 'The Virginia Coast Reserve (VCR), managed by The Nature Conservancy’s (TNC) Virginia State Chapter, encompasses protected lands and coastal bays of the Virginia Eastern Shore that constitute the longest expanse of coastal wilderness remaining on the United States East Coast. This area is owned by the Commonwealth of Virginia, under authority of the VA Department of Environmental Quality. The VCR Seagrass Restoration Project, initiated in 2015, involves the restoration of seagrass meadows at the VCR through direct seeding. Seagrass meadows remained absent from the coastal bays of the VCR until the late 1990s. In 1999, TNC and the Virginia Institute of Marine Science (VIMS) began a large-scale eelgrass restoration effort at the VCR. By the project start date in 2015 eelgrass restoration efforts had already maximized natural recruitment, and continued seed additions were necessary to further increase eelgrass extent across the VCR coastal bays. Data collected at restoration plots established by direct seeding revealed a larger habitable area than the natural recruit distribution, indicating that eelgrass extent could reach up to 107 square kilometers with continued seed additions. Direct seeding of restoration plots will continue in the carbon project to further expand seagrass coverage. The University of Virginia (UVA) and VIMS have studied the seagrass restoration effort at the VCR since its inception, increasing understanding of the long-term effects of expanding eelgrass coverage at the VCR and the potential role for seagrass meadows in mitigating climate change. Seagrass restoration directly increases carbon storage in submerged aquatic vegetation (SAV) and marine sediments, enhancing greenhouse gas (GHG) emission removals from the atmosphere. Over the 30-year crediting period the project activity is  estimated to generate 40,486 t CO2e net GHG emission removals.', 'project_state_province': 'VA', 'project_country': 'United States', 'project_latitude': 37.31, 'project_longitude': -75.84}

inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Côte d’Ivoire has experienced dramatic deforestation for the last decades: forest area decreased from
16 Mha in 1960 to 2.9 Mha in 2021. Deforestation is driven first by slash-and-burn agriculture for both
food and cash crops by smallholders.
To address this issue, the Government of Côte d’Ivoire adopted in 2019 a Strategy for the Preservation,
Rehabilitation and Extension of Forests (SPREF) that opened, notably, the involvement of the private
sector in the management of gazetted forests through concession instruments. The current project falls
under this framework, specifically in the “Forêt Classée du Haut-Sassandra” (FCHS), in center west of
Côte d’Ivoire.
15 years ago, the 104,000 ha of Haut-Sassandra forest were still covered by a magnificent semi-
deciduous forest. As of today, 95% of its surface has been deforested and is now under illegal cocoa
plantations and fallows.
aDryada (a French development company specialized in nature-based solutions and biodiversity
conservation) and its Ivorian partner, Agromap, signed an agreement with the Ministry of Water and
Forest for the rehabilitation of the FCHS. A 40-year concession agreement is currently being negotiated.
The project aim is the permanent reestablishment of a largely natural and largely intact forest over
70,000 ha of the FCHS. The main activities to be implemented are: 1/ plantation of a very diversified mix
of native species in both fallow and cocoa parcels and 2/ Assisted natural regeneration in remaining
degraded forests. As the main goal is to reestablish a natural forest and its biodiversity, no harvesting
activities are envisaged. The project is expected to generate significant GHG removals of c. 36.8 MtCO2e
over the crediting period and an annual average of c. 890 ktCO2e.
Agroforestry schemes are implemented in the remaining 34,000 ha as well as around the FCHS to ensure
sources of sustainable livelihoods to local populations, contributing to the long-term success of the
project.
Karidja project includes an important package to support sustainable economic transition, social
infrastructures improvement and trainings to provide long term social co-benefits to local communities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope: 14. Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)
AFOLU project category: Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR).
Grouped: Yes. The project will consist of several project activity instances located across the Haut-
Sassandra gazetted forest.

1.3 Project Eligibility
The project is eligible under the scope of the VCS Program based on:
• Being an Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation project (ARR) – one of six eligible
AFOLU project categories. Within the ARR category, the project will include both reforestation
and revegetation activities.
• Adopting a Verra methodology. In compliance with section 3.1.4 of the VCS “Registration and
Issuance process” document (V4.3 of the 17 of January 2023), our pipeline project applies a
methodology that is still under assessment by a VVB: “Methodology for Afforestation,
Reforestation and Revegetation Projects, version 0.1 issued on December 17, 2021, by Verra,
with contributions from Terra Carbon and Silvestrum Climate Associates."
• Reporting on changes due to the project activity in carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, and
methane, some of the seven Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gasses.
• Not including the excluded project activities listed in Table 1, Section 2.1 of the VCS Standard
(v4.4, 17 January 2023).
• Each project activity instance area has not been cleared of native ecosystems within a 10-
year period prior to the start date.
• The project will not be implemented in wetlands.
1.4 Project Design
The project includes multiple project activity instances and is being developed as a grouped project. All
the project activity instances will be located within the limits of the Haut-Sassandra gazetted forest.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project, referred to as AR_AMS0007, involves the planting of diverse species of trees and shrubs on multiple parcels of land. The baseline scenario is the continuation of the pre-project land use, which in this case was barren lands with no forest cover. The project aims to demonstrate additionality, meaning that the project activity would not have occurred anyway due to certain barriers.

To demonstrate additionality, the project proponents can either use the barrier analysis outline contained in Appendix 1 of the methodology or an approved standardized baseline applicable to their project. In this case, the project makes use of the analysis outline in Appendix 1.

The project activities involve planting activities carried out by grassroots organizations with experience in tree planting and a close relationship with local communities. The species of trees and shrubs selected are determined by stakeholders and implementation partners, considering the suitability for each location and the desired planting composition. The project faces technical barriers, such as lack of access to planting material and the expertise required for planning and managing the planting design.

The saplings for all the selected species are sourced from private nurseries, requiring a significant investment. The project includes various stakeholders or landowners across multiple locations, and there is no funding available for such planting activities, leading to investment barriers.

Based on the presence of both investment and technological barriers, the project is considered additional.

There are no deviations from the methodology outlined in AR_AMS0007 for this project.

Regarding the quantification of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reductions and removals, baseline emissions are calculated using Equation 1 as specified in Section 5.4, paragraph 17 of the methodology. However, the specific details of Equation 1 are not provided in the given context.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Following Section 5.2, paragraph 14, of the methodology AR_AMS0007, the baseline scenario
is the continuation of the pre-project land use. The plantation site or plots prior to the start of
the project were barren lands, with no forest cover and would have remained as such in the
absence of the project.
3.5 Additionality
As per section 5.2, para 15 of the methodology the Project Proponents (PPs) shall demonstrate
that the project activity is additional by selecting one of the following options:
(a) Using the barrier analysis outline contained in appendix 1 of the methodology; or
(b) Using an approved standardized baseline applicable to their project.
The project makes use of the analysis outline in Appendix 1 of the methodology
Project Proponents (PPs) shall demonstrate that the project activity would not have occurred
anyway due to at least one of the following barriers.
The project activities comprise planting of diverse species of trees and shrubs on multiple
discrete parcels of land. The planting activities are undertaken through several grassroots
organisations with experience in tree planting, and a close relationship with the local
communities. The species selected are selected by the stakeholders and with the expertise of
the implementation partners. The mix and diversity of species used in the project require
technical expertise to assess suitable species for each location and the right planting
composition. Hence the project faces technical barriers including lack of access to planting
material in addition to the expertise required to planning and managing the planting design.
The saplings for all the species selected are sourced from private nurseries. This requires a
significant investment. The project species comprise of forest, fruit, medicinal and other
species and there is no profit to the PP due to project implantation. In addition, the project has
multiple stakeholders or landowners, spread across several locations. There is no funding
available for such types of planting activity, and hence the project faces investment barriers.
‘Therefore the project faces investment and technological barriers and is deemed additional.
3.6 Methodology Deviations
There are no methodology deviations.

REDUCTIONS AND REMOVALS

As per Section 5.4, para 17, equation 1, the baseline removals are calculated using Equation 1.

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Core CarbonX Solutions Private Limited (CCX) is a carbon management consultancy company with
registered office in the state of Telangana. CCX is the Project Proponent (PP) of the carbon offset project
called “Ban Odisha01” in all districts of Odisha. The carbon credit rights is transferred to CCX which in
turn will share the carbon revenue to farmers on realisation of carbon credits. The individual farmers are
the owners of the lands on which trees are being grown to sequester carbon and reduce greenhouse gas
emissions from the atmosphere. CCX has mobilized the farmers in the selected states of India to plant
various tree species on their lands. These tree species range from fruit bearing trees like Indian
blackberry, Guava, Mango, lemon to commercial species like cashew, arjuna, asana, teak, mahogany,
etc. Simple tree cultivation techniques involving planting saplings in the pits with minimum disturbance
to the lands have been employed by the selected farmers.
The villages under the project area predominantly have an agrarian economy where most of its population
depends on agriculture. The condition prior to the project initiation was barren land or agriculture as
maize, chili, pulses and paddy or other commercial crops were grown by the farmers on their farmlands
with limited agroforestry species. The planation was done by the farmers and utilized the subsidies to
avail the saplings. The saplings do the sequestration of carbon dioxide at faster pace and ultimately
reduces GHG emissions.
The Project Activity will lead to considerable carbon sequestration in the project areas and will contribute
strongly to the sustainable development of rural villages involved in the project.
The project quantifies the GHG removals occurring from agroforestry plantations through the use of AR-
ACM0003: “Afforestation and reforestation project activities implemented on lands other than wetlands”,
Version 02.0 developed under the Clean Development Mechanism for large-scale plantations. The project
plans to generate carbon credits for the voluntary market under the VCS standard. Such planting activity
would result in carbon credits that would be sold in the carbon market to generate revenue. As per the
Carbon-offset agreement entered into between the farmers and CCX, 60%-80 of the carbon income
generated from the sale of carbon credits would be distributed among the farmers. The project activity
was implemented in 1900 hectares. Through carbon sequestration by the planted trees, the project is
expected to generate annual average GHG emission reductions or removals of 15671 tCO2e.
The selected farmers are those farmers who did not plant anything on their lands as they were fallow
lands. CCX company held workshops in the villages and advised the villagers to grow certain types of fruit
and commercial trees in a sustainable manner to earn carbon revenue. The idea of earning additional
revenue caught the farmers attention and they decided to enter into carbon-offset agreements with the
CCX company.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope: 14: Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)
Type of activity: Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR).

CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
The Republic of the Congo Improved Forest Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “The
project”) is located in UFA Djua-Ikié, The Republic of the Congo. It is implemented by Société
d’Exploitation Foresrière Yuan Dong (hereinafter referred to as “SEFYD”) as the project
proponent. The project is to protect the forest that was planned to be logged.
UFA Djua-Ikié is located in the Souanké and Semé Districts of the Sangha administrative
Province. The project is designed to improve forest management in 338,589 ha of native
Congolese forests legally designated for logging. By avoiding previously planned logging and
implementing improved forest management and conservation activities, this project will increase
the carbon stock through protecting the forest.
Prior to the implementation of the project, the forests in the project area were harvested following
the guidelines in Timber Harvest Plan approved by the local forestry authority. In order to protect
the forest ecosystem, improve the ecological environment, increase carbon sinks, reduce GHG
emission reductions and slow down climate change, the project proponent decided to stop the
logging and implement this improved forest management project activities from 01-August-2020
to 31-July-2040.
The project is expected to generate approximately 53,140,400 tCO e during the 20 years’ 2
crediting period, with the annual emission reductions of 2,657,020 tCO e. 2
The project’s climate, community and biodiversity objectives:
⚫ Reduce GHG emissions and mitigate climate change; and
⚫ Improve soil and water conservation and contribute to sustainable development; and
⚫ Provide experience of forest management and risk prevention and control for local
stakeholders; and
⚫ Improvement of the biodiversity and ecological environment of the project area and its
surrounding area; and
⚫ Increase employment opportunities and raise the income level of local residents; and
⚫ Protect the local tree species from being cutting down.
2.1.2 Project Scale
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 8

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on the following tools and guidelines:

1. Tool 01: This tool is used for the demonstration and assessment of additionality. It provides a general framework for demonstrating and assessing the additionality of a wide range of project types.

2. Tool 7: This tool is used to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system. It is applied when calculating baseline emissions for a project activity that substitutes grid electricity.

3. Tool 11: This tool is used to assess the validity of the original/current baseline and update the baseline at the renewal of the crediting period. It is used to determine the emission factors for the baseline scenario.

The project, Uluabat HEPP, meets the applicability criteria of ACM0002, which is applicable to grid-connected renewable energy power generation projects. The project involves the installation of a new grid-connected renewable electricity generation project and results in the formation of a new reservoir with a power density greater than 4 W/m2.

The project also applies the applicability conditions of Tool 7 and Tool 01. Tool 7 is used to calculate baseline emissions for the project activity that substitutes grid electricity, which is the case for Uluabat HEPP. Tool 01 is used for the demonstration and assessment of additionality, and it is considered applicable for this project.

Furthermore, Tool 11 is referred to for the changes required in the methodology implementation and baseline scenario in the second and third crediting periods. The project participants are advised to refer to Tool 11 for the updated emission factors.

The project boundary is defined as the installation of a Greenfield power plant, and the baseline scenario is based on the electricity that would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and the addition of new generation sources. The emission sources included in the project boundary are identified based on the combined margin (CM) calculations described in Tool 7.

Uluabat HEPP is connected to the Turkish National Grid through Görükle-Akçalar Substation, using an 11-kilometer-long transmission line.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1

01” from here on,13
• “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system,” Version 07 (referred to as “Tool
7” from here on), as well as with the,
• “Assessment of the validity of the original/current baseline and update of the baseline at the
renewal of the crediting period,” Version 03.0.1 (referred to as “Tool 11” from here on)
3.2 Applicability of Methodology
The “Applicability” Section in ACM0002 states:
“This methodology is applicable to grid connected renewable energy power generation project activities
that (a) install a Greenfield power plant […] [...] The methodology is applicable under the following
conditions:
• The project activity may include renewable energy power plant/unit of one of the following
types: hydropower plant/unit with or without reservoir, […]
• In case of hydropower plants, one of the following conditions shall apply: […] The project
activity is implemented in existing single or multiple reservoirs, where the volume of the
reservoir(s) is increased and the power density […] is greater than 4 W/m2 […].”14
Uluabat HEPP meets all these criteria and conditions. The project;
• Involves the installation of a new grid connected renewable electricity generation project,
• Does not involve switching from fossil fuel use to renewable energy at the site of the project
activity,
• Results in the formation of a new reservoir whose power density is higher than 4 W/m2, as
demonstrated in Section 4.2 below.
Moreover, ACM0002 explicitly requires applying the applicability conditions of the Tool 7 and Tool 01. The
Section “Scope and applicability” in the Tool 7 states: “[…] This tool may be applied […] when calculating
baseline emissions for a project activity that substitutes grid electricity that is where a project activity
supplies electricity to a grid [..].”15 This is the case for Uluabat HEPP.
In Tool 01, the Section “Scope and applicability” states: “[…] The document provides a general framework
for demonstrating and assessing additionality and is applicable to a wide range of project types. […]”16
As the project type of Uluabat HEPP is per ACM0002, and at the same time ACM0002 refers to the Tool
01, the latter can be considered as applicable.

activities do not occur on wetlands, drain native ecosystems, nor degrade hydrological function.
Participating growers will continue to follow all applicable local, state, and federal regulation on
wetlands and waterways, and project activities are expected to be neutral or beneficial to field
hydrology and local water quality. Lastly, CIBO will demonstrate that project activities resulting in
GHG benefits have been implementedandmaintainedduringeachverificationperiodinaccordance
with the steps outlined in Section 5 of this project description.
VCS Standard AFOLU requirements regarding jurisdictional REDD+ programs (VCS Standard
Section 3.2.2) are not applicable since this is not a REDD+ project. Likewise, VCS guidance on
implementation partners acting in partnership with the project proponent (VCS Standard Section
3.2.3) is not applicable since CIBO is the sole project proponent and implementation entity.
1.4 Project Design
The project is a grouped project with multiple project activities, including no-till, reduced till, use of
living winter cover, and reduced N fertilizer. The project area covers the United States Corn Belt
region, defined as North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Minnesota, Iowa, Missouri,
Wisconsin, Illinois, Michigan, Indiana, Ohio, and Kentucky. Within the project area, one or more of
the project activities may occur on each enrolled field.
Eligibility Criteria
In accordancewithVCSStandardSection3.5.15and3.5.16,CIBOhasdeterminedasetofeligibility
criteria for all initial and future project instances included within the grouped project. These criteria
apply to allareaswithinthegeographicboundariesofthisproject–theUSstateslistedabove–andall
project activities. These criteria ensure that project instances meet the eligibility guidelines in the
VCS Standard as well as the applicability conditions of the methodology, VM0042.CIBOwillreview

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
The Saf I HEPP Project contributes to the region‟s sustainable development in particular and Turkey‟s
sustainable development in general by:
 increasing the use of renewable energy sources for generating electricity
 meeting the need of electricity generation and supply in Turkey in a sustainable way,
 decreasing the consumption of fossil fuels,
 reducing emission of GHGs from the national electricity grid, thereby reducing the effects of
global climate change in the medium and long term, and
 providing job opportunities as expectedly 80 people will be hired during the construction phase
and 15 people will be employed during the operation phase. The project owner is committed to
prioritize local labour force in selecting construction and operating workers. As a result the
employment rate and income generation in the region will increase.

 A mosque will be constructed by the help of project owner.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves information collection and management, as well as monitoring and verification of data. The project owner is responsible for providing necessary information and data for validation and verification. All monitoring data is recorded and kept under the safe custody of the power plant site manager. The measurement of production data is controlled and stored in an identified management department.

Any changes within the project boundary, such as changes in spare or equipment, are recorded, and any change in emission reduction due to such alterations is studied and documented. Physical documents are stored by the project owner, and a copy is kept to facilitate verification by the Designated Operational Entity (DOE). A reliable and well-tested software control system is used to manage data and information collection and recording, with the aim of clear and easy operation of the wind farm without extensive computer skills required.

The power supplied to the grid, invoices, relevant accounting documents, billing receipts, and calibration results are collected in a central place by the project owner. Data records are archived for a period of 2 years after the crediting period to which the records pertain.

In case of damaged metering equipment, the project owner follows specific procedures for estimating net supply to the grid. If the main meter is damaged, the backup meter is read. If both the main meter and backup meter are damaged, the project owner and the grid company jointly calculate a conservative estimate of power supplied to the grid according to the Power Purchase Agreement. A statement is prepared, signed by both parties, indicating the background to the damage, the assumptions used for estimating net supply, and the efforts taken to restore normal monitoring procedures.

The project owner is required to prepare an annual monitoring report, which includes a summary of daily operations, metering values of power supplied to and received from the grid, copies of sales/billing receipts, a report on calibration, and a calculation of emission reductions.

The baseline study and monitoring methodology for this project were completed on 08/08/2008. The responsible person for determining the baseline study and monitoring methodology is Feng Shijun, a consultant at the Hebei CDM Project Office.

The project activity started on 06/06/2007 (construction date), and the expected operational lifetime of the project activity is 20 years.

The choice of the crediting period is a renewable crediting period. The starting date of the first crediting period is 10/10/2008 or the date of registration in the Executive Board (EB), whichever is later. The length of the first crediting period is 7 years. There is no fixed crediting period mentioned in the project documentation.

5. Information collection and management
It is the responsibility for the project owner to provide necessary information and data for validation and
verification. All the monitoring data should be recorded and kept under safe custody of the power plant site
manager.
The measurement of the whole production data is controlled and stored in an identified management
department.
Any change within the project boundary, such as change in spare or equipment will be recorded and any
change in the emission reduction due to such alteration will also be studied and recorded.
Physical document will be stored by the project owner and kept one copy in order to facilitate the verification
of DOE.
A very reliable and well-tested software control system will be used to manage data and information collecting
and recording. The software presentation pursues clear and easy operation of the wind farm, without need for
extensive computer skill.
The power supplied to the grid and received from the grid, invoices, relevant accounting documents and billing
receipts and the results of calibration shall be collected in a central place by the project owner. Data record will
be archived for a period of 2 years after the crediting period to which the records pertain.
6. Procedure in case of damaged metering equipment
In case metering equipment is damaged and no reliable readings can be recorded the project owner will
estimate net supply by the proposed project activity according to the following procedure:
a. In case the main meter is damaged only:
By reading the backup meter.
b. In case both the main meter and the backup one are damaged:
The project owner and the grid company will jointly calculate a conservative estimate of power supplied to the
grid according to the Power Purchase Agreement. A statement will be prepared indicating
 The background to the damage to metering equipment
 The assumptions used to estimate net supply to the grid for the days for which no record could be
recorded the estimation of power supplied to the grid. The statement will be signed by both a
representative of the project entity as well as a representative of the grid company.
 The project entity will furthermore document all efforts taken to restore normal monitoring procedures.
7 Monitoring Report
The Project owner will annually prepare a monitoring report which will include among others a summary of
daily operations, metering values of power supplied to and received from the grid, copies of sales/billing
receipts, a report on calibration and a calculation of emission reductions.

1.8 Project Start Date
According to VCS standard, the project start date is the date on which activities that lead to
the generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are implemented (e.g., preparing
land for seeding, planting, changing agricultural or forestry practices, rewetting, restoring
hydrological functions, or implementing management or protection plans). For this project,
according to the requirements of the AMS-III.AU methodology applied, an entire cropping
season is started from land preparation and the emission reduction calculation is also
started this day. So, the project start date is 11-May-20184 when the land preparation was
started.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The crediting period of this project will be using a 7-year, twice renewable crediting period,
for a combined total project crediting period of 21 years from 11-May-2018 to 10-May-2039,
and the project lifetime is 30 years5 from 11-April-20186 to 10-April-2048.

Project Summary: The project involves a wind farm located within Pingdingbu Town, Guyuan County, Zhangjiakou City, Hebei Province, P.R.China. The project site covers an area of approximately 55 km2. The project aims to generate electricity by connecting to a 10 kV backup line that is connected to the grid. The electricity imported from the grid is continuously measured by an electricity meter installed on the 10 kV backup line, with a measurement precision of at least 1.0.

Province: Hebei Province

Country: P.R.China

Latitude: 41°36′36′′ North

Longitude: 115°45′08′′ East

carbon crediting scheme. In the future, the emission reductions that apply for issuance under
VCS will not be issued under CDM or GS project or under any other voluntary carbon crediting
scheme.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector described in the context is Forestry and Land Use. The project involves the establishment of forests on degraded lands previously deforested and/or converted (croplands or settlements) in Inner Mongolia, China. The project aims to control soil and water erosion, enhance biodiversity conservation, and generate income for the project participants and local community.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Inner Mongolia Yitulihe-Genhe Afforestation Project (hereafter “the project”) is located in northern
part of the western side of Greater Khingan Mountains, Hulun Buir City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous
Region, P.R.C. The project is jointly implemented byInner Mongolia Yitulihe Forestry Co. LTD and Genhe
Forest Industry Co. LTD, both of which belong to the China Inner Mongolia Forest Industry Group. The
project is designed to establish forests on degraded lands previously deforested and/or converted
(croplands or settlements).
Most of the lands to be planted were deforested since 1950s. Significant deforested lands were
converted to croplands and settlements to support livelihood for increased residents. Other land
remained as barren lands and have never been reforested since then. Due to human disturbance,
desertification and sandification as well as soil erosion, the barren lands are degraded and degrading
which would continue under the without project scenario.
2,059.4 ha of forest is to be established by direct planting on degraded lands in 12 forestry farm of
Yitulihe Forestry Bureau and 12 forestry farms of Genhe Forestry Bureau. 66.3%% of reforestation
activities are carried out in a mixture of different tree species for a purpose of enhancing resilience.
Major species and Afforestation models include 480.64 ha of Spruce (Picea meyeri Rehd.et Wils),
214.6 ha of Mongolian Scotch pine (Pinus sylvestris var. mongolica Litv.), 546.0 ha of mixture of spruce
and larch (Larix gmelinii (Rupr.) Kuzen), 43.8 ha of mixture of spruce, Scotch pine and elm (Ulmus
macrocarpa Hance), 187.2 ha of spruce and elm, 459.9 ha of mixture of spruce and Scotch pine, and
127.3 ha of mixture of Mongolian Scotch pine and elm. It is expected that the project would produce
800,326 tCO e of GHG removals in 60 years, with an average annual GHG removals of 13,339 tCO e, 2 2
starting in 2020. All species are native. No invasive alien species or genetically modified organisms are
involved. All lands within the project boundary are state-owned.
The project proponents and participants hold a view that the project, through the above-mentioned
activities, would contribute to environment improvement (biodiversity conservation and soil erosion
control), thus contribute to sustainable development, specifically,
- Sequester GHGs and mitigate climate change and enhance climate adaptation;
- control soil and water erosion and land degradation/desertification in the selected project areas;
- enhance biodiversity conservation by increasing forest cover and nature habitat connectivity;
- generate income for the project participants and local community.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project activity is the establishment of forests on degraded/degrading lands that were previously
logged and/or converted (to croplands/settlements) since 1950s. Therefore, it corresponds to VCS

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
Based on the provided context, the methodology of this project involves several steps:

1. Calculation of factor F: The project calculates the factor F, which represents the share of similar projects (penetration diff all rate of the measure/technology) using a measure/technology similar to the measure/technology used in the proposed project activity that deliver the same output or capacity as the proposed project activity. The formula to calculate F is F = 1 - N / N, where N is the number of similar projects.

2. Evaluation of factor F: The project compares the calculated value of F with a threshold value of 0.2. If F is greater than 0.2, it indicates that the proposed project activity is a common practice within the sector in the applicable geographical area.

3. Evaluation of N - N: The project evaluates the difference between N and N (N - N). If N - N is greater than 3, it also indicates that the proposed project activity is a common practice within the sector in the applicable geographical area.

4. Determination of common practice: Based on the evaluations of F and N - N, the project determines whether the proposed project activity is a common practice within the sector in the applicable geographical area.

5. Methodology deviations: The project states that no methodology deviation is applied in the project.

6. Estimation of baseline emissions: The project calculates the baseline emissions in accordance with ACM0001 "Flaring or Use of Landfill Gas" Version 19.0. The baseline emissions include methane emissions from Solid Waste Disposal Sites (SWDS) and electricity generation using fossil fuels or supplied by the grid.

It is important to note that the methodology described above is specific to the provided context and may not be applicable to other projects or situations.

B) Electricity generation using fossil fuels or supplied by the grid in the absence of
project activity;
C) Heat generation using fossil fuels in the absence of project activity; and
D) Natural gas used from the natural gas network in the absence of the project activity.
Since there are no heat generations or natural gas usage in the baseline scenario, only baseline

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
SECTION A. General description of project activity
A.1. Title of the project activity:
Inner Mongolia Chifeng Gaofeng Wind Power Project
Version: 5.0
Date: 19/09/ 2010
A.2. Description of the project activity:
Inner Mongolia Chifeng Gaofeng Wind Power Project (hereafter referred to as the proposed project) is a
grid connected renewable energy project developed by Chifeng Xinsheng Wind Power Co. Ltd. The
proposed project located in Songshan District, Chifeng City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China.
The proposed project involves the installation of 25 wind turbines (Vestas V80-2000kW of Denmark),
each of which has the capacity of 2000kW, for a total installed capacity of 50MW. The purpose of the
proposed project is to generate electricity using wind power resources in the project region and to sell into
and replace the same amount of power generation in Northeast Power Grid (NEPG) which is dominated
by the fossil fuel fired power plants, as identified both the baseline scenario and the scenario existing
prior to the start of the implementation of the proposed project activity which is that electricity delivered
to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected
power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as reflected in the combined margin (CM)
calculations described in the “Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system”.
It is estimated that the electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity will be 131,700MWh, and as
a result, 150,915 tonnes of CO2 emission reductions will be generated annually.
The contributions of the proposed project to sustainable development goal are summarized as follows:
 Being located in a power grid dominated by fossil fuel fired power plants, development of the
proposed project will not only reduce GHG emissions but also mitigate local environmental
pollution caused by air emissions from fossil fuel fired power plants;
 New jobs will be generated during the operation periods;
 Development of the proposed project could contribute to meeting local electricity demand and
increase employment opportunities, then boost the economy in the local region.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Prior to the project initiation, economic conditions in the project area are not very good and
the level of education is relatively low8, so farmers lacked advanced irrigation technologies,
such as the intermittent flooded water regime. However, intermittent flooded water regime
requires that irrigation and drainage can be controlled according to the growth needs of
rice during its cultivation. Whereas, the low economic level leads to the low income of
farmers, which means that farmers have no additional economic capacity to afford the
construction of the branch ditches which can practice controllable irrigation and drainage.
To improve the infrastructure conditions of agricultural production, increase food
production, and promote sustainable agriculture, the project was implemented. Therefore,
the project was not implemented to generate GHG emissions for the purpose of their
subsequent reduction, removal, or destruction.
Since the conditions existing prior to the project initiation is the same as baseline scenario,
please refer to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario) to see the detail information. Besides, this
project does not affect the environmental conditions, including climate, hydrology,
topography, soils, relevant historical conditions, type of vegetation, ecosystems, etc., so,
the present and prior environmental conditions of this project are the same, which are
listed as follows.

The Project Activity Instance is in the department of Meta, Colombia, in the municipality of
Cabuyaro at coordinates 4°23'24"N 72°51'26"W, approximately 90 km east of Villavicencio, the

2.1.5.2 Basic Physical Parameters
Soils
According to the soil map (IGAC, 2022), the soils that predominate in the project area are:
• Typic Hapludox: they are deep, well drained, and extremely acidic soils with low fertility.
• Association of Oxic Dystropepts and Plinthic Tropaquepts: deep to shallow soils, well to
poorly drained, extremely acidic and of low fertility.
To a lesser extent, there are also Typic Trópofluvents, Typic Tropaquepts, Oxyaquic Dystropepts,
Typic Tropofluvents and Tropic Fluvaquents, which are poorly drained surface soils with high
acidity.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Sustainable Agroforestry Cacao Meta, Colombia', 'project_summary': 'Located in the department of Meta, Cabuyaro is a municipality whose surface equals to 832 kilometers square, with a population of 5,432 inhabitants, and an altitude of 151 meters above the sea level (DANE, Censo Nacional de Poblacion y Vivienda, 2018). The project is located in Guayabal, a small town in Cabuyaro composed of 204 inhabitants who mainly work the land, growing a variety of crops such as plantain, cassava, papaya, passion fruit, corn, soy, and cacao which are mainly sold in the local market of Villavicencio.\r\nThis is a grouped project, the first area to be verified, consists of a total of 2,258 hectares composed of degraded pastures in majority and conservation areas, at the baseline. Of which 1,764 hectares will be established in an agroforestry system, with cacao being the perennial crop planted with other trees for shading purposes (Gliricidia sepium) and boundary purposes (windbreakers -Cariniana pyriformis). This agroforestry system has the goal of increase the soil organic carbon, as well as the aboveground and below ground biomass, and will recover the soil health and fertility through time. Other relevant agricultural practices that will be implemented are proper residue management as crop/tree materials that are periodically pruned are left in the soil for decomposition to build organic matter, processing of the cacao husks to produce organic fertilizer to be applied back in the field, as well as planting cover crops in bare soil areas, irrigation,  and planting boundary trees to prevent erosion and reduce wind damage to the cacao.\r\nThe rest of the project area, 491 hectares, corresponds to other uses such as drainage channels, internal roads, and conservation areas which included native forest species, called morichales, riparian zones, and secondary forests. The total project area is divided into two properties, Espejuelos (1,258 hectares) and Primavera (1,000 hectares).', 'project_state_province': 'Meta', 'project_country': 'Colombia', 'project_latitude': 4.41, 'project_longitude': -72.85}

SECTION D. Monitoring plan
D.1. Description of monitoring plan chosen:
>>
Dependent on the emission reduction targeted different methodologies and monitoring plans will be applied.
The two monitoring plans are :
AMS-III.D Methane Recovery
The simplified monitoring methodologies are going to be applied to determine and record the methane emissions
caused by the manure that will be captured and destroyed by the project activity and otherwise would have been
released into the atmosphere.
The amount of methane used as fuel for combustion or flared is going to be monitored, using a flow meter
respectively an hour counter and analysing the methane content of the burned gases. Not only the amount of manure,
but also the amounts and quality of co-ferments is monitored. The share of methane gas production resulting from
fermentation of the manure and from the co-ferments derived from wastes can thus be determined from 2 ways. It is
either calculated from the amount of manure and waste co-ferments used, or calculated from the total produced
amount of biogas minus the calculated theoretical methane production from the other co-ferments.
In operation year 1 the flow meter is only measuring the volume flow, but not calibrated to standard conditions. Thus
for the first year of operation the amount of biogas burned cannot be exactly measured, but will have to be re-

MONITORING REPORT : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Implementation Status of the Project
The International Small Group and Tree Planting Program (TIST) empowers Small Groups of
subsistence farmers in Kenya, Uganda, India and Tanzania to combat the devastating effects of
deforestation, poverty and drought. Combining sustainable development with carbon
sequestration, TIST supports the reforestation and biodiversity efforts of about 87,000
subsistence farmers. Carbon credit sales generate participant income and provide project
funding to address agricultural, HIV/AIDS, nutritional and fuel challenges. As TIST expands to
more groups and more areas, it ensures more trees, more biodiversity, more climate change
benefit and more income for more people.
Since its inception in 1999, TIST participants organized into over 12,000 TIST Small Groups have
planted over 18 million trees on their own and community lands. GhG sequestration is creating a
long-term income stream and developing sustainable environments and livelihoods. TIST in
Uganda began in 2003 and has grown to about 14,500 TIST participants in about 2,200 Small
Groups.
UG PD-VCS-001 is a grouped AFOLU project, eligible under the Afforestation, Reforestation and
Revegetation (ARR) category. It is a subset of the TIST project in Uganda and initially applied to
291 of the Small Groups, 1,662 members, 1,000 project areas and 777 ha. The PD was
validated and first verified on 20 March 2012 by Environmental Services, Inc. (ESI).
UG-VCS-001 was verified a second time 27 October 2014 by JACO CDM. The verification period
was 07 October 11 to 31 December 2013. The monitoring report demonstrated 799 project
areas, 700 ha and 833,038 trees.
This is the third verification of UG-VCS-001 and was conducted by EPIC Sustainability. The
verification period was 01 January 2014 to 17 April 2019. The monitoring demonstrated 463
project areas, 546 ha and 465,654 trees.
The following is the verification history, including the total GHG removals generated in this
monitoring period
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is registered under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS 3.7) as an Afforestation,
Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) project and has been developed in compliance with the
VCS Guidance for Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use Projects (VCS Version 3.6). It is a
grouped project.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.6 Project Crediting Period
The project has a fixed crediting period of 10 years from 17 November 2010 to 16 November
2020.
1.7 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
The estimated total emission reductions (ERs) over 10 year crediting period are 288,290 tCO . 2e
1.8 Description of the Project Activity
Technologies Implemented
The project involves installation and operation of a rice husk based boiler employing a new
technology based on the moving chain conveyor concept. The technology comprises a natural
circulation steam boiler with 5% continuous rate of blow-down. The treated water is heated to
reach its saturated temperature of 105°C in an economizer utilizing the return condensate and
hot flue gases (at about 160°C).
Inside the combustion chamber in the boiler, the rice husks are mixed with air at an inlet
temperature of 170°C. The rice husks are kept in suspension using circulating fluidized bed
mechanism by use of blowers at the bottom and induction fans at the top of the boiler. This
feeding system increases the overall boiler efficiency compared to normal feeding system which
is a fuel efficient feature in this technology. In order to control the quality of the rice husk ash,
temperature inside the boilers need to be maintained at 450°C-650°C. This is achieved through
the design of internal inclined reciprocating grate which allows the ash to cool down prior to
entering the ash collection system at the bottom of the boiler. Figure 1 summarises the
conceptual configuration of the overall system.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
This project will protect the Bolivian Amazon forest from planned deforestation, initially protecting
235 has of tropical rain forest. The methodology implemented is:
• VM0007 REDD Methodology Framework but limited to the planned deforestation
activities (module VMD0006 (BL-PL) as well as other modules listed in section 2.1
below)
Protection of the project areas under this methodology will prevent the emissions from
deforestation and conversion to pastures and allow the forest to reclaim its status as a primary
forest.
The project is a grouped project and the instances must be located in the only geographic area
defined by the union of the Departments of Pando or Beni in Bolivia. The instances must be
under threat of planned deforestation for conversion to agricultural activities as defined under
VM0007 at the time the project proponent took ownership of the project area.
The project starts with only one instance but this number is expected to grow with time. The
instance is located in the department of Beni, 150 km south of Riberalta and forms part of the
Bolivian Amazon Forest. The project area is home to species listed in the red book as vulnerable
and endangered such as Cedrela Odorata: Bertholletia excelsa, Amburana cearencis. The project
are has suffered in the past to some degree or other from selective logging, deforestation for
agricultural purposes and deforestation resulting from human induced fires.
In protecting the forest, the project will pay special attention to endangered and vulnerable tree
species native to the region while ensuring that the communities surrounding the project areas do
not suffer the full impact of job losses associated with forest preservation. In addition to
protecting the forests in the project areas, the project will enrich the project areas with
endangered and vulnerable tree species. The prevention of deforestation will lead to the loss of
employment opportunities. This will be partly mitigated by the project’s area enrichment with
endangered and vulnerable tree species that will generate employment throughout the duration of
the project.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The purpose of this grouped project activity is to electrify about 170,000 rural inhabitants and
neighbouring SMEs around Alaotra lake, through the installation and operation of run-off river mini-
hydropower plants in Madagascar.
The installation of 700 kW in Maheriara and 1,600 kW in Androkabe, in the Aloatra-Mangoro region, will
generate an average of 10,5 GWh per year. Their combined operations will reduce greenhouse gas
emissions by 12,748 tCO /yr, a result of the substitution of fossil-fuel based power generation by clean 2
and renewable energy. The technology to be employed is hydraulic & electromechanical equipment
including mini-hydroelectricity turbines and generators, as well as transformers feeding in to medium and
low tension grids. The project activity instances will benefit over 6,500 households, schools, public
services and approximately 1,600 entrepreneurs.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The type of the project is Abatement and the field is Energy industries (renewable sources). Sectoral
scope 1. The project is a VCS grouped project.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the provided information, the project sector described is Forestry and Land Use. The project involves the restoration and reforestation of degraded mangrove areas, which falls under the Agriculture, Forestry, and Other Land Use (AFOLU) category.
inputs.context:
industry and agricultural purposes (primarily cattle ranching and now palm oil), Aquaculture (shrimp
farming), and local infrastructure development, such as road and bridge construction.
BlueMX is working with private landowners, local ejido communities and government agencies to
secure mangrove ecosystems through legal contractual relationships with the legal possessors of
the land. In return for entering into contractual relationships, BlueMX, at its own expense, will
restore degraded mangrove areas through hydrological and sedimentological restoration activities
and then reforest restored areas with various native mangrove species via direct planting and via
nurseries. In addition to restoring and reforesting degraded mangrove areas at no cost to the
landowner, BlueMX will share in the carbon finance with the landowner.
BlueMX has also secured the conservation of significant areas of mangrove forest ecosystems near
restoration project areas where BlueMX will conduct conservation activities. These conservation
projects and activities will be registered with Verra separately as individual REDD+ projects.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is an Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) project under the Afforestation,
Reforestation and Revegetation project category (Sectoral Scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry, Land
use). The project is a grouped project and will utilize VM0033 Methodology for Tidal Wetland and
Seagrass Restoration and applicable modules.
Soil organic carbon is an important part of the total amount of the carbon sequestrated by this
project and as required by section 3.2.8 of the VCS Standard (Version 4.0) will comply with both
ARR requirements and WRC requirements. However, the project does not consider any GHG
emissions reductions and therefore does not fall under the description of WRC project in the
section 4.2.19 of the AFOLU Requirements (Version 3.6).
1.3 Project Eligibility
This is a grouped project and is eligible as it follows the WRC requirementsthe following VCS
eligibility criteria will be met by all project instances:
1. The project activity complies with national laws and regulations in Mexico.
2. The mangrove forest area qualifies as a forest under the VCS.
3. The project activities of restoration and reforestation fall under the ARR category.
4. The baseline scenario is degraded mangroves.
5. It is a project activity that reduces emission by restoring wetlands.
6. All land rights and land titles are in place and clearly defined.
7. The project proponent has experience developing VCS projects.
5

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology of this project is described in the VCS Version 3. It falls under the category of "Renewable electricity generation for a grid" and is in accordance with the approved small scale methodology AMS I.D. The project involves the construction and operation of a new renewable run-off river small hydro power plant with a capacity of 12 MW. The methodology outlines the applicability criteria for the project, including the installation of a Greenfield plant, capacity addition in existing plants, retrofit or rehabilitation of existing plants, and replacement of existing plants. It also specifies eligibility criteria for hydro power plants with reservoirs. The methodology includes a tool to calculate the emission factor for the project's electricity system, which can be applied to estimate the operational, build, and/or capital maintenance emissions. The project boundary includes the power plant, connected power plants, and the Indian grid.

The Indian grid is included in the project boundary.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.3
The areas within the Project Area boundaries which are eligible for carbon crediting, and which are
not eligible for carbon reduction activities, are described in the table below.
Table 1-7 Areas that are eligible and ineligible for carbon activities
There are some areas within the Project Area boundaries, but which are ineligible for carbon
crediting. There are described in the table below.
Table 1-8 Breakdown of areas outside project boundaries but within Marudi LPF/0008
1.14 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The conditions of the Project Area prior to the start of the project can be described as a natural
forest ranging from degraded to heavily degraded in condition. The Marudi, Marau, Tasong blocks
are predominantly peatlands and would have been converted to forest plantations under the Tree
Planting Plan before the decision to implement carbon project. The condition of the project site was
not a result of actions by the project or related parties to purposely create GHG emission potential
for subsequent reduction.
We demonstrate that the project has not been implemented to generate GHG emissions for the
purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction in Section 3.1.4 and the project’s
baseline scenario and additionality is justified by using “VT0001 – T-ADD - Tool for the
demonstration and assessment of additionality in VCS Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU) project activities”.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
The scope of the VCS Program excludes projects that can reasonably be assumed to have
generated GHG emissions primarily for the purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or
destruction. The VCS Program also excludes the following project activities under the circumstances
indicated in Table 1 in page 2-3 of the VCS Standard (Ver 4.4).
For the project activity, the GHG involved in the project activity is CO , one of the six Kyoto Protocol 2
greenhouse gases, and the project activities supported by a methodology (VCS methodology,
VM0010) approved under a VCS approved GHG program, and the project activity is not listed in the
exclusion table, therefore, it is eligible for the scope of the VCS Program.
The project site had been carrying out timber harvesting in accordance with the harvesting plan
approved by the local government within two years prior to the project start date, which is
representative of other forestlands harvested in the country within the past two years. And the project
site has transport networks, and Lizhou District also has wood processing plants. Evidences such
as the government-approved timber management plan for harvesting will be provided to the VVB for
check at Validation.
1.4 Project Design
The project has been designed to include multiple locations, but is not being developed as a grouped
project, which is IFM project activity converting the once logged forest to conservation with no other
activities included.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project involves the application of a monitoring methodology called "Metering the Electricity Generated by the Renewable Technology," which is defined by the baseline methodology AMS I.D. This methodology is applicable to the small-scale project activity of generating electricity using hydropower and exporting it to an electricity distribution system that would have been supplied by fossil fuel or non-renewable biomass fired generation units. 

The project has a fixed crediting period starting from 01/06/2006 and lasting for 10 years. During this crediting period, several data points are to be monitored, including the total net electricity of units 3 & 4 (measured monthly), total net electricity of units 1 & 2 (measured monthly), gross electricity of unit 1 (continuous measurement), gross electricity of unit 2 (continuous measurement), gross electricity of unit 3 (continuous measurement), gross electricity of unit 4 (continuous measurement), electricity consumption of Pamir 1 power plant (continuous measurement), net electricity fed into the grid with line 1 (continuous measurement), and net electricity fed into the grid with line 2 (continuous measurement).

The data for monitoring will be recorded electronically and on paper, and it will be archived for the crediting period plus 2 years. The archived data will be used for calculations related to the project activity.

For this project activity a fixed crediting period is applied.

SECTION D. Application of a monitoring methodology and plan:
D.1. Name and reference of approved monitoring methodology applied to the small-scale
project activity:
The monitoring shall consist of “Metering the Electricity Generated by the Renewable
Technology”, as defined by the used baseline methodology AMS I.D. in Appendix B of the simplified
modalities and procedures for small-scale CDM project activities.
D.2. Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it is applicable to the small-scale
project activity:
The project activity is the generation of electricity using hydropower potential and exporting the electricity
to an electricity distribution system (grid) that is or would have been supplied by at least one fossil fuel or
non-renewable biomass fired generation unit. Since the project activity is based on hydro as renewable
energy source and comprises no co-fired generation unit, only the electricity produced by the generating
unit must be monitored according to the methodology AMS I.D.

inputs.question: What are the start and end dates of the crediting period for this project?
inputs.answer: The start date of the project is August 8, 2005, which is the date on which the project began reducing or removing GHG emissions. The crediting period for the project is 10 years.
inputs.context:
VCS Project Description Template
1.3 Estimated amount of emission reductions over the crediting
period including project size:
The project is expected to reduce about 69921 tonnes of CO 2
equivalents per year i.e. over the crediting period of 10
years the estimated amount of emission reductions will be
699210 tonnes of CO equivalent. 2
The above project with 69921 tonnes of CO equivalent 2
emission reduction per year falls midway between Mega
Projects greater than 1,000,000 tCO e/year and Micro Projects 2
with less than 5,000 tCO e/year emission reduction. 2
1.4 A brief description of the project:
ITC (Paper and Speciality Paper Division) PSPD, Coimbatore
Unit (herein refer to as ITC), a part of the ITC Limited
group, have installed a co-generation plant and is utilizing
agro residues (waste biomass) co-fired with fossil fuel for
the generation of steam and electricity. The main objective
of the project is to meet the parent paper mill’s total
energy (both thermal and electrical) requirement in an
efficient manner utilizing renewable agro residues abundantly
available in the region and avoid the usage of fossil fuel to
the extent agro residue becomes available. The installed
power generating capacity of the project is 8MW . electrical
Utilization of waste biomass not only reduces GHG emission by
displacing fossil fuel but also helps control indiscriminate
open air burning and decomposition in fields under anaerobic
condition. Open air burning of biomass leads to N O emission 2
and decomposition of biomasses on the fields results in
methane emission and obnoxious odour problems. Both N O and 2
CH have higher global warming potential (GWP) than CO . 4 2
Further, projects of this kind would marginally provide
solutions to the problem of space constraint for the disposal
and decomposition of agro residues, a common agricultural
waste management problem, in all agriculture based nations
including in India.
The biomass residues fired in the project boiler are mainly
De-oiled Rice Bran (DOB), and Saw Dust, and Wood
Chips/Chipped Saw Dust in small amount. ITC carried out a
survey of the surplus availability of the biomass residues
like De-oiled Rice Bran (DOB), Saw Dust, Wood chips/Chipped
Saw Dust in the region within a radius of 200 km from the
project site. The survey was conducted by the Department of
Agricultural Economics Centre for Agricultural and Rural
Development Studies, Tamil Nadu Agricultural University. The
survey report reveals that DOB, Saw Dust and Wood
Chips/Chipped Saw Dust have a surplus availability of 62.49%,
2


VCS Project Description Template
reduction is limited to the actual amount of fossil fuel
replaced by biomass.
1.5 Project location including geographic and physical
information allowing the unique identification and
delineation of the specific extent of the project:
The ITC-PSPD, Coimbatore Paper Works, is located in
Thekkampatty village, Coimbatore District, Tamil Nadu State
(76.97ºE, 11.01ºN). The proposed co-generation system will be
located along the eastern periphery of the existing paper
mill facility within the same premises. The indicative layout
of the station building, steam generator, auxiliary buildings,
cooling tower, chimney, fuel handling area and other services
are shown in Annex– 1 “Plot Plan”.
Location Map
COIMBATORE
1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
• Project Start Date:
• The start date of the project is the date on which
the project began reducing or removing GHG emissions
i.e. Project Commissioning date 8th August 2005, start
of charging electricity to the system
.
