VCS Project Description Template
The date the first monitoring period commences: 8th
August 2005
• VCS Project crediting period:
10 years
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
The Paperboard facility at Kovai, Coimbatore was acquired by
ITC Limited from BILT Industrial Packaging Company in March,
2004. The commercial production under ITC management began on
29th March, 2004. The Mill earlier had a single board machine
with a capacity of 65000 TPA. With the increase in the
competitiveness of the Unit it has further potential to make
90000 TPA1 of Recycled Boards for Indian and export markets.
Prior to project initiation, the Unit used to meet its need
of process steam through in-house steam generation utilising
predominantly lignite as a fossil fuel and a negligible
proportion of biomass residues such as DOB and Saw Dust (1.5%
in terms of energy). The biomass residues as a practice were
used exclusively for boiler start up. During December 2003
and January 2004 biomass residues were fired as a trial run
prior to the implementation of the project activity. However,
during the baseline period of 2002 to 2004, proportion of
firing of biomass residues was as negligible as 1.5% of the
total energy input. To meet the electrical energy
requirements of the plant the Unit was dependent exclusively
on the electricity imported from grid.
With regard to the agro based residues, the earlier practice
involved partial disposal of the major proportion of the agro
residues in the fields or are fired in the open. This
resulted in decaying of biomass in anaerobic condition
leading to methane emissions and where the biomass is burnt
in the fields, N O was emitted. 2
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG emission
reductions and/or removal enhancements:
The project utilized biomass residues (agro residue mix of
primarily saw dust, de-oiled rice bran and also some amount
of chipped saw dust) available in the region of its operation
as primary fuels. In the absence of the project, the ITC
would have run the co-generation plant based on 100% lignite.
Thus, by using biomass residues as fuel, the project actually
displaces fossil fuel (lignite) and thus reduces GHG Emission
1 Source: http://www.itcpspd.com/aboutus/aboutus.html. Addition of power block and de-inking facility (removal of
ink from waste paper) will increase the competitiveness of the Unit, with potential to make 200000 TPA of Recycled
Boards for Indian and export markets.
5

1.5 Project Proponent
Xuwen Xinpenggang Building Materials Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as Xuwen
Xinpenggang) is a private entity and its core business involves agricultural scientific research
and experimental development, intelligent agricultural management, technology extension,
etc.
1.6 Other Entities Involved in the Project
There is no other entity involved in this project.
1.7 Ownership
The ownership of the rice paddies of the agricultural land management project belongs to
the farmers, which has been confirmed by the local government and agricultural and rural
bureau. Since these rice paddies are all legal agricultural fields, and the ownership is clear,
there is no dispute over land ownership in the project site.
And the farmers involved in the projects own the carbon credits generated by the project and
have authorized Xuwen Xinpenggang Building Materials Co., Ltd. (hereafter referred to as
Xuwen Xinpenggang) as the sole carbon project owner which is fully responsible for carbon
project development and trading 4 . Xuwen Xinpenggang has overall control and
responsibility for the carbon project as the project proponent without violating farmers’ rights.
Xuwen Xinpenggang, as the developer of rice emission reduction project, is responsible for
the development and management of the carbon project, including compiling the monitoring
plan, organizing the training, etc.

Xinpenggang.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: Based on the given information, the methodology of the project involves retrofitting an existing coal-fired boiler to a biomass boiler for renewable energy generation. The project aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by replacing the use of coal with biomass fuels. The project development timeline includes key events such as obtaining approvals, stakeholder meetings, and the start of project operation. The project is deemed feasible with the revenue generated from the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS), which helps overcome barriers to implementation. There are no deviations from the methodology specified in the project description. The quantification of greenhouse gas emissions reductions and removals will be based on the baseline emissions for different scenarios, including electricity production, heat production, power and heat production, co-fired systems, new renewable energy units, and retrofit project activities. The biomass fuels used in the project will be transported from nearby areas.

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer: The methodology used for this project is the VCS approved CDM methodology: ACM0002 Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources (Version 21.0). This methodology is applicable for the project, which is a solar power project with a total installed capacity of 21 MWac. The project involves the installation of a solar PV power plant at a project site where no renewable power plant was operated prior to the implementation of the project activity (Greenfield Power Plant). The methodology also refers to the latest approved versions of the "Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality" (version 07.0.0), "Investment analysis" (version 11.0), and "Common Practice Analysis" (version 3.1) tools. Additionally, a grievance mechanism has been implemented under the Environmental and Social Management Plan to address any issues raised by local stakeholders throughout the lifetime of the project. The project will also be listed on the VERRA website for public comments, and all comments received will be considered appropriately.

2.4 Public Comments

issues can register their issue for resolution at any point of time throughout the lifetime of the project.

PP will consider all the comments appropriately.

● “Investment analysis” (version 11.0)
● “Common Practice Analysis” (version 3.1)

sources” ACM0002(Version 21) is applicable for this project. The project activity is installation of a
solar PV power plant at project site where no renewable power plant was operated prior to the
implementation of the project activity (Greenfield Power Plant). The applicability of the methodology

inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The project is a CMM (Coal Mine Methane) power plant located in Xiaochong Village, Pan County, Liupanshui City, Guizhou Province, People's Republic of China. It involves the extraction and utilization of coal bed methane to generate electricity. The project started construction on September 18, 2019, and the first generator started operation on January 19, 2020. The remaining generators started operation on different dates thereafter.

Province: Guizhou Province

Country: People's Republic of China

Latitude: 25°39'05.74"N

Longitude: 104°30'15.88"E

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
The Project is located in Xiaochong Village, Pan County, Liupanshui City, Guizhou Province,
People’s Republic of China. The geographical coordinates of the project site are E 104°30′15.88″,
N 25°39′05.74″. Figure 1.2 shows its location.
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Prior to the project initiation, Area Jiayi of Jinjia coal mine was equipped with CMM extraction
facilities and all extracted CMM was directly vented into the atmosphere; the electricity
consumed at coal mine was imported from China Southern Power Grid (CSPG), and the heat was
provided by waste coal boilers.
The baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the project initiation; please
refer to Section 2.4 for the description of the baseline scenario.
1.14 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks

The project will introduce new anaerobic waste water treatment system (Two anaerobic

The project uses digesters to treat waste water, collect and utilized the generated biogas to avoid methane emissions. CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2.1.14 Project Start Date
The project’s start date is February 1st, 2015. TIST Uganda is a constantly growing program that seeks to
verify subsections of the program whenever possible. Data for this project was pulled from the database
on February 1st, 2020. The program is claiming a February 15th, 2015 start date for this project to include
the maximum allowable amount of activity.
Evidence of the project’s start date can be found in the ages of the trees included in this project. Trees
are planted virtually every day in TIST Uganda. The oldest trees in the project were 5 years old at the
time data was pulled. As such, the best possible estimation for the project start date is February 1st,
2015.20
TIST quantifiers are trained to assess the age and species of trees. The program sets an internal goal to
quantify trees every 18 months. More frequent quantifications than the required 5-year interval allow TIST
to accurately measure the age of individual trees. These ages are incorporated into our database when
trees are young (and easier to ascertain the age of the tree). Through the individual counting and
monitoring of trees, the program is able to establish the minimum and maximum age of trees in individual
groves. This monitoring takes place in conjunction with consultation of farmers who can speak to the age
of their seedlings.
The TIST database automatically rolls forward tree ages. As such, a data set run on February 01, 2020
will include trees planted 5 years (but no more) previously. Thus, the program can assess a February 01,
2015 start date of the activities that led to the generation of GHG emission reductions.
2.1.15 Benefits Assessment and Crediting Period (G1.9)
February 1st, 2015 – February 1st, 2075
2.1.16 Differences in Assessment/Project Crediting Periods (G1.9)
Accounting periods will be the same between GHG and CCB impacts.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Qijiang Water Management with Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project is to change from continuously flooded water regimes to intermittently flooded water regimes during rice cultivation in Qijiang County, Chongqing City, China, with a total acreage of 18,965 ha of single-cropping rice. A total of 8,425 households (36,059 farmers) were involved in the project. Without the project, local villagers would not have access to intermittently flooded technology and intact facilities to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to water efficiency, improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.\r\nThe implementation activities of the project include promoting intermittently flooded technology, technical training for the farmers, facility repair and replacement, etc. According to the needs of rice growth, farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in the rainy season.\r\nThe project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by 416,395 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,485 tCO2e. The project aims to reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.', 'project_state_province': 'Chongqing', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 28.47, 'project_longitude': 106.4}

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of the project is outlined in the provided project description. The project involves the installation of a new grid-connected zero-emission renewable power generation activity from a wind source. The chosen methodology for this project is ACM0002 version 10, which is a baseline methodology that assesses the applicability of renewable energy projects. The methodology is applicable to the proposed project based on the following criteria:

1. The proposed project does not involve switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources at the project site.
2. The geographic and system boundaries of the relevant electricity grid, specifically the Northeast Power Grid, can be clearly identified and information on its characteristics is available.

The project boundary includes the Inner Mongolia Chifeng Gaofeng Wind Power Project and all power plants physically connected to the Northeast Power Grid, which is defined as the project electricity system. The Northeast Power Grid consists of independent province-level electricity systems including Liaoning, Jilin, and Heilongjiang provinces. The connected electricity system is the North China Power Grid, which is connected to the project electricity system through transmission lines. The Northeast Power Grid has a net electricity export to the North China Power Grid.

For more detailed information on the methodology and tools used in the project, as well as their consideration by the Executive Board, you can refer to the provided link: http://cdm.unfccc.int/goto/MPappmeth.
inputs.context:

For more information regarding the methodology and the tools as well as their consideration by the
Executive Board please refer to http://cdm.unfccc.int/goto/MPappmeth.
B.2. Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it is applicable to the project activity:
The proposed project can meet the applicability criteria of the baseline methodology (ACM0002
version10); therefore, the methodology is applicable to the proposed project.
 The proposed project is the installation of a new grid-connected zero-emission renewable power
generation activity from wind source;
 The proposed project is not an activity that involves switching from fossil fuels to renewable
energy sources at the site of the project activity;
 The geographic and system boundaries for the relevant electricity grid (Northeast Power Grid)
can be clearly identified and information on the characteristics of the grid is available.
B.3. Description of how the sources and gases included in the project boundary:
The spatial extent of the project boundary includes Inner Mongolia Chifeng Gaofeng Wind Power Project
and all power plants connected physically to the Northeast Power Grid that the CDM project power plant
is connected to. Northeast Power Grid is defined as the project electricity system, which consists of
independent province-level electricity systems including Liaoning, Jilin and Heilongjiang province that
can be dispatched without significant transmission constraints. The connected electricity system is North
China Power Grid, which is connected by transmission lines to the project electricity system. Northeast
Power Grid has the net electricity export to North China Power Grid. The flow diagram of the project
boundary is as in figure 2.

1 Project Details
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
This project leverages carbon finance to avoid mosaic conversion of tropical forests and therefore
reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The project employs a Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and
Degradation (REDD) project methodology to determine the magnitude of these emissions reductions.
Through a combination of forest protection and sustainable development activities, this project is
estimated to avoid the emission of 2.5 Million metric tonnes of CO e over the project lifetime that 2
would have resulted from deforestation of
approximately 50% of the project area
over the next thirty years.
The Chocó-Darién Conservation Corridor is
located in the Darién region of northwest
Colombia within the administrative
jurisdictions of the Department of Chocó
and the Municipality of Acandí. The
Colombian Darién is part of the Chocó
biogeographic region, recognized as one of
the most biodiverse regions in the world
for its strategic geographic location and
high levels of species endemism.
The project is additional because the
project activities would not have been
possible without carbon financing. The
project baseline is an extension of actual
deforestation that was occurring
aggressively in the reference area adjacent
to the project area.

2.0.
This is not a grouped project.

Selabam Hydropower Extension Project (hereafter referred to as “the project”) is developed by
EDL-Generation Public Company in Champasak province (or called as Champasak). It is a

conforms to the present situation, but also can adapt to future changes in the electricity market.

supplied from the power grid. By displacing part of the power generated by thermal power plants,

first crediting period with average annual emission reduction of 10,509 tCO e per year. 2

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Hydroelectric Project El Edén (hereafter, the project activity or project) is implemented by Central
Hidroeléctrica El Edén S.A.S E.S.P (hereafter, the project proponent).
The project activity is a hydroelectric power plant that utilizes water from the Río La Miel (“La Miel river”),
located in the river basin “La Miel” in the east of the Department of Caldas, Colombia (hereafter, the Host
Country), about 125 kilometres from the City of Cali close to the municipalities of Pensilvania, Marquetalia
and Manzanares.
Before the implementation of the project activity, no power plant is installed at the project site. The energy
that will be generated by the project is currently dispatched by other power plants that are connected to
the national grid, and that include fossil fuel power plants. Hence, the baseline scenario and the scenario
prior to project implementation are the same and the project will help to reduce thermal power generation
in the National Interconnected System (SIN1) by providing renewable energy to the grid.
The project activity is a run-of-river hydroelectric plant that includes the construction and installation of a
concrete weir and intake, a desander, channel, forebay/settling tank, high-pressure penstock,
powerhouse and discharge channel. Two Pelton turbines with 10.115 MW and two synchronous
generators with 11,174 kVA each2 will be installed. Each generator will be connected to a transformer to
increase the voltage from 6.6 kV to 35 kV at the project site. The installed capacity of the plant at the
interconnection point will be around 19.5 MW (this is based on the design and can vary slightly at real
conditions).
The electricity generated by the project is expected to be around 104.5 GWh per year, which will be
delivered to the SIN. It will help to reduce thermal power generation in the SIN by providing renewable
energy to the grid. Thus, it will contribute to sustainability by increasing the share of renewable energy
and reducing GHG emissions. The expected average annual emission reductions are 32,102 tCO during 2
a renewable 10-years crediting period.
Moreover, the project activity will facilitate the achievement of electricity demand required for the social
and economic development of the country based on a renewable energy source. The project will
contribute to the region’s sustainable development in the following ways:
The project will decrease emissions of sulphur oxides (SO ), nitrogen oxides (NO ), carbon x x
monoxide, particulate matter, other pollutants, as well as carbon dioxide associated with the
combustion of fossil fuels.
The project will reduce the dependence on fossil fuels, which are non-renewable and limited in
supply.
During construction, the project will provide employment opportunities. To the extent practical,
these jobs will be filled by local residents. Besides, employment will also be generated for
operation and maintenance activities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Scope 1 - Energy (renewable/non-renewable)
1 In Spanish: Sistema Interconectado Nacional

inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.answer:
Project Summary: The Rio Manito Grouped REDD Project is a conservation project aimed at preventing unplanned deforestation in the project area. It involves implementing measures such as surveillance, mapping deforestation patterns, partnering with educational and research institutions, and providing benefits to surrounding communities. The project also uses the SOCIALCARBON® Methodology to measure its contribution to sustainable development. It promotes forest conservation, biodiversity conservation, and the development of the local economy while reducing GHG emissions.

Province: The project is located in the municipality of Marcelândia, which belongs to the State of Mato Grosso, Brazil.

Country: The project is located in Brazil.

Latitude and Longitude: The geodetic coordinates of the project location have been submitted separately as a KML file.
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1.11 Description of the Project Activity
- The Rio Manito Grouped REDD Project is a grouped project that consists in the
implementation of conservation measures for avoiding unplanned deforestation within the
Project Area.
- Instances adopt forest conservation measures such as recruitment and management of
surveillance teams to monitor on-site suspicious and/or illegal activities and control of
invasions within the project area. Other mitigation actions proposed by the Project in order
to avoid unplanned deforestation will be carried out by strengthening surveillance in the
area, mapping the local deforestation patterns, setting partnerships with educational and
research institutions, and through providing benefits to surrounding communities, aiming to
minimize invasions and illegal deforestation, offering alternative income, education and
professional training.
- Therefore, besides forest conservation, the present project aims to improve and quantify its
social and environmental activities that benefit the local communities, through application
of the SOCIALCARBON® Methodology. This methodology measures the contribution of
carbon projects towards sustainable development. The SOCIALCARBON® Methodology is
based on six main indicators: Biodiversity; Natural; Financial; Human; Social and Carbon
Resources and aims to deliver high-integrity benefits in each in order to improve social and
environmental conditions in the project region.
- The implementation of REDD + SOCIALCARBON mechanisms promotes sustainable
development through forest conservation resulting in the permanence of carbon stocks,
while reducing pressure for timber from other forest areas. In this way, biodiversity
conservation and development of the local economy can be achieved simultaneously.
- All the aforementioned measures are expected to result in net GHG emission reductions by
preventing illegal deforestation agents to advance with their activities, as well as by
retrieving their practices and, therefore, protecting and even restoring the carbon pools.
- It is important to highlight that this project is not located within a jurisdiction covered by a
jurisdictional REDD+ program.
1.12 Project Location
The first seven instances are located in the municipality of Marcelândia, a municipality which
belongs in the State of Mato Grosso. The region is also known as Southeastern Amazon within
the Brazilian Arc of Deforestation. The overall area of the seven initial instances correspond to
16,044.51 ha. This area corresponds to the properties areas, not project areas.
22

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
In accordance with VCS requirements, stipulated in Approved VCS Methodology VM0015, version
1.1, the project area may only include areas composed of “forest”10 for a minimum of ten years
prior to the project start date. In addition, some non-forest areas were also excluded, such as
rivers, rocks, and non-forest vegetation.
The size of the areas that are considered “forest” (i.e. per Brazilian definition which is accordance
to FAO’s) within the project area was 13,616.45 ha.
Geodetic coordinates of the project location have been submitted separately as a KML file, as
the Figure below presents the properties’ location.
Figure 1. Project Location
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The Rio Manito Grouped REDD Project makes an important contribution to the conservation of
Southern Amazonia’s biodiversity as well as to climate regulation in Brazil and South America.
In addition to contributing to the long-term conservation of the region, this project also functions
to establish a barrier against the advancement of the Brazilian Arc of Deforestation, creating a
Northeast Amazon biodiversity corridor in a vulnerable region.
The present project activity has not been implemented to generate GHG emissions for the
purpose of their subsequent reduction, removal or destruction. On the other hand, the project
aims to promote forest conservation combined with alternative income generation for local
communities, associated with a greater surveillance against deforestation agents.
The general characteristics of the project area and reference region are described below.
Climate
10 Brazil adopts FAO forest definition: “Land with tree crown cover (or equivalent stocking level) of more than 10 percent
and area of more than 0.5 hectares (ha). The trees should be able to reach a minimum height of 5 meters (m) at
maturity in situ.” Available at: < http://www.fao.org/3/x6896e/x6896e0e.htm >. Last visit on: August 06th, 2021.
23

The present REDD project is expected to avoid predicted 4,915 ha of deforestation equating to 3,083,553 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, with an annual average of 102,785 tCO2e.\r\n\r\nIn addition to the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, aiming at the propagation of environmental awareness, generation of alternative sources of income and environmental education actions.', 'project_state_province': 'Mato Grosso', 'project_country': 'Brazil', 'project_latitude': -10.48, 'project_longitude': -54.24}

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Prior to the initiation of the project, several conditions exist that are unsustainable and
contribute to the emission of greenhouse gases. A significant one is crop burning. Crop burning
is a common practice in sugarcane farming in the area. This is typically done to remove the
excess leaves and stems after the harvesting of the sugarcane. This process results in the
release ofsignificant amountsofGHGsanddepletessoilfertility.
Secondly there are inefficient farming practices such as overuse of fertilizers, pesticides, and
irrigation, which can also contribute to GHG emissions. Overuse of fertilizers leads to the
release ofnitrousoxide, whileinefficient irrigationpracticescanlead tothewasteofenergy.
All this is connected to a lack of awareness among farmers about the harmful effects of crop
burning andother inefficient farmingpractices.
The project has not been implemented to generate GHG emissions for the purpose of their
subsequent reduction, removal or destruction. Instead, the project aims to reduce GHG
emissions by addressing the conditions mentioned above. And to demonstrate this, the project
will promote sustainable farming practices, and conduct awareness campaigns to inform
farmers about the harmful effects of crop burning and the importance of sustainable farming
practices. The project will establish a monitoring and reporting system to track the project's
impact on reducing GHG emissions. Overall, byimplementing these strategies, the project aims
to address the underlying conditions that contribute to GHG emissions in the sugarcane
farmingindustry.

within the previous two years.”

iii. Environmental Law9: This law came into force in 1983, it considers the environment as a single

management of land and natural resources in an integrated manner. According to its basic
principles, and as also stated in the Constitution, citizens as well as the State bear responsibility
for the environment protection. Furthermore, this law states that in all economic activities, every
measure should be taken to minimize pollution.10

to generate electricity for the electricity market11.

using a renewable resource, hydroelectric power, in a sufficient, low-cost and environmentally-
friendly manner, using the latest technology available in the market. Morover, as an Environmental

Eligibility Criteria
This is not a grouped project activity. Thus, this section is not applicable for this project.
Leakage Management
Not applicable to the project activity.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Sustainable Development
As a renewable energy project, it will actively bring about both environmental and economic
benefits to the local society and contribute to the local sustainable development. The proposed
project activity’s contributions to sustainable development are:
• Reducing the dependence on exhaustible fossil fuels for power generation;
• Providing clean electricity to a nation in need of power;
• Reducing air pollution by replacing coal and other fossil fuel fired power plants with clean,
renewable power;
• Paving the way for further usage of the country’s renewable natural resources by
importing technology and creating local capacity;
• Contributing to local economic development through employment creation directly or
indirectly.
• Providing additional local income through the taxes that the project proponent will pay to
the Local Government Units (LGU). This additional income can be used by the LGU to
fund more locally beneficial projects.

inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Negros Island Solar Power Inc.', 'project_summary': 'The Negros Island Solar Power Inc. Project (hereafter referred as project activity involves the installation of 32MW La Carlota Solar Power PV Plant and 48MW Manapla Solar Power Plant. The total installed capacity of the project is 80MW. The Plants are greenfield, stand-alone power plants with a gross peak generation capacity of 32MWp and 48 MWp DC intended to provide daytime power to the grid throughout the entire year. The design concept is for approximately 124,000 modules and 179,000 modules respectively. They have been designed to ensure optimum energy efficiency. The power generated is replacing anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases estimated to be approximately 66,039 tCO2e per year (annual average), thereon displacing 119,312 MWh/year amount of electricity from the generation-mix of power plants connected to the Philippine electricity grid, which is mainly dominated by thermal/ fossil fuel based power plant.  This project was open for public comment from 10 January - 09 February 2018. Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
2 SAFEGUARDS
2.1 No Net Harm
There is no potential negative environmental or socio-economic impact due to the project.
2.2 Local Stakeholder Consultation
Questionnaires were distributed by the project proponent to the residents who lives in the community
and closely related to the project. The questions aimed to find out their concerns and opinions about
the project. The questionnaires covered areas of economic, social benefit and environmental effect
etc. The content of the questionnaire includes the following information：
1. The purpose of the questionnaire
2. Basic information of the participants
3. Questions
1) Do you know the proposed project?
2) What do you think the proposed project will bring to you?
3) Do you support the implementation of the proposed project?
4) What is your concern about the proposed project?
5) What is your opinion and suggestion regarding the proposed project?
The Survey was conducted through distributing and collecting responses to a questionnaire in Dec
2015. Totally 50 questionnaires returned out of 50 with 100% response. The following is a summary
of the key findings based on returned questionnaires.
1. Attitude towards the proposed project
All of them support the implementation of the project, they think the protection of forest instead of
cutting is good the environment, and will benefit the sustainable development.
2. The concern about the proposed project
The participants particularly hoping that the proposed project can improve local environmental
situation and increase employment opportunities at the same time.
3. Conclusion
The survey shows that the proposed project is 100% supported by local people. It is because they
believe the implementation of the project will bring multiple benefits.
14

The area of the project activity is 4,719.98 ha, including 525 subcompartments spreading over Dongshengchong Town,Laotougou Town, Sanhe Town, Zhixin Town,Dexin Township, Baijin Township of Jinlin Longjing. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned or collective-owned, and have the legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project are Oak tree, Pinus sylvestris and Broadleaf Tree.

Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 494,335 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 24,717
 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 415,241 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 20,762 tCO2e. 
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.", 'project_state_province': 'Jilin Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 42.21, 'project_longitude': 128.54}

The project is located in Ledong County, Hainan Province, China. The geographical coordinates

China Hainan Province
Figure 1-3 The Project Areas in the Project Zone
1.13 Conditions Before Project Initiation
Before the project, the economic development of the project area was relatively poor, and the
local farmers lacked advanced irrigation technologies such as intermittent flood irrigation. The
intermittent irrigation method requires that in the process of rice cultivation, irrigation and
drainage can be controlled by ditches and valves according to the growing needs of rice. The low
economic level leads to the low income of farmers, which means that farmers do not have the
additional financial capacity to afford the construction of cement ditches that can implement
controlled irrigation and drainage. Therefore, the project has not yet been implemented to
generate greenhouse gas emissions for subsequent reduction, removal, or destruction.
11
inputs.ground_truth: {'project_name': 'Letung Water Management with Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project carried out changes from a continuously flooded regime to an intermittently flooded regime during rice cultivation in Ledong Li Autonomous County (hereinafter ‘Ledong County’), Hainan Province, China, with a total acreage of 12,687 ha of double-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches, pumps, valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded conditions can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water, increasing rice yield, and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.', 'project_state_province': 'Hainan', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 18.7, 'project_longitude': 109.08}

inputs.question: What are the methodologies of this project?
inputs.answer:
The methodology of this project is based on the approved CDM (Clean Development Mechanism) methodology AR-AMS0007: Afforestation and Reforestation Project Activities Implemented on Land Other Than Wetlands - Version 3.1. This methodology is applicable to the proposed project activities due to various reasons:

1. The project uses the VCS (Verified Carbon Standard) containing the use of accepted CDM methodology.
2. The project activities do not take place on any land classified as wetlands.
3. Project activities are not implemented on organic soils, no soil drainage occurs, and no more than 10% of the total area of the project is disturbed due to the preparation of the soil for planting plants.
4. All waste will remain in place.

However, the proposer of the project has chosen to exclude five optional carbon pools related to estimation of non-CO2 GHG emissions, carbon stocks, and variation in dead wood, waste, trees, shrubs, and soil organic carbon stocks.

The project boundary includes thousands of individual discrete project areas spread over thousands of square kilometers. The baseline scenario of the project is the continuation of pre-project land uses, including Bamboo plantations, fallow, and pasture for a minimum period of 32 years.

Overall, the project methodology focuses on afforestation and reforestation activities implemented on land other than wetlands, with specific considerations for carbon stocks, GHG emissions, and land use practices.

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
strengthening of the community-based forest enterprises and other sustainable income
generating options that operate within the active concessions. This is achieved by either
maintaining or augmenting existing activities, or by developing new activities that promote forest
protection and community development.
The Guatecarbon project utilizes the Climate, Community, and Biodiversity Standards (CCB) to
ensure social and environmental safeguards and net-positive benefits. Therefore, the project
activities are categorized using the terminology in the CCB Standards and the examples of
activity categories are described briefly below.
Climate Objective: To reduce emissions from unplanned deforestation
1. To support forest protection and monitoring activities performed both by the communities and
by the state.
2. Assist and improve the implementation of local land-use zoning plans within the concessions
3. Support institutional and legal tools to improve overall forest governance
Community Objective: To reduce emissions from unplanned deforestation by enhancing
community well-being and developing economic resiliency through environmentally sustainable
enterprises.
1. Improve the operational and administrative capacities and efficiencies of community forest
enterprises
2. Broaden opportunities for income generation via non-timber forest products, eco-tourism and
other environmentally sustainable options
3. Promote the improvement of basic community services (health posts, schools, sanitation,
etc).
Biodiversity Objective: To maintain and enhance the connectivity of native ecosystems, and to
limiting illegal plant and wildlife trade.
1. Advance and complement forest protection activities by both the communities and the state
2. Reclaim and restore illegally deforested areas within the MUZ
3. Ensure the continued maintenance of high conservation value forests via FSC certification
4. Support and increase efforts to monitor and deter illegal plant and animal trade
5. Provide targeted monitoring of, and assistance to, populations of vulnerable species
By advancing the proposed activities the project is estimated to reduce 41,579,159 tCO e of net 2
anthropogenic GHG emissions through avoided deforestation over the project lifetime, which
translates to an ex-ante estimate of 36,939,263 VCUs over the same time period after the
estimated risk buffer deductions. The average yearly reductions are estimated at 1,231,975
tCO e yr-1. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral scope: Agriculture, Forestry, and other Land Uses
Project Category: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and degradation (REDD)
Activity type: Avoided unplanned deforestation (AUD)
Grouped project: No

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Leakage Management
Not applicable to the project activity.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Sustainable Development
The National CDM Authority (NCDMA), which is the Designated National Authority (DNA) for the
Government of India (GOI) under the Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF), has mentioned four
indicators for the sustainable development in the interim approval guidelines for Clean Development
Mechanism (CDM) projects from India. Thus, the project’s contribution towards sustainable development
has been addressed based on the following sustainable development aspects:
Social Well-being: Project activity instances of this grouped project are reducing specific fossil fuel
consumption per unit of output generation by adopting energy efficiency measures in existing steam
turbines. Hence, helps in reserving the fossil fuel resource and reducing the dependency up to a certain
extent. Project activity instances will boost country’s energy security by contributing in efficient way. Also,
helps in reducing GHG emission associated with the operation of fossil fuel fired captive power plant.
Economic Well-being: The project activity will also create business opportunities for contractors,
technology consultants and suppliers in terms of retrofit/modification and supply of existing turbine. Thus,
project activity would bring economic benefits for the local community and would lead to sustainable
economic and industrial growth in the region and country.
Environmental Well-being: The project activity instances are reducing fossil fuel consumption per unit of
baseline output generation thus reducing the GHG emission associated with the generation through
energy efficiency measures, thus help in reduction in further exploitation and depletion of fossil fuels. The
electricity generated from the project activity would help to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and other
associated pollutants from fossil fuel based thermal power plant; equivalent of which would have been
emitted in absence of the project activity.
Technological Well-being: The project activity employs the energy efficiency measures by retrofitting in
existing steam turbines which reduces the specific fuel consumption in fossil fuel fired captive power
plant. Thus, encouraging the captive power generating industrial units for adopting such measures which
will enhance energy efficiency in the industry and helps nation to grow in sustainable manner.
Further Information
The initial project instance is coming in First-of its-kind WEG facility.
2 APPLICATION OF METHODOLOGY
2.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
The project activity instances as part of the proposed grouped project activity will be small scale “Supply
side energy efficiency improvements – generation” project activity instances. This category comprises
technologies or measures to improve the efficiency of fossil fuel generating units that supply an electricity
or thermal system by reducing energy or fuel consumption by up to the equivalent of 60 GWh per year is e
equivalent to maximal saving of 180 GWh in the fuel input to the generation unit. th

inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.answer: Based on the information provided, the project sector mentioned in the document is Renewable Energy. The alternative scenarios discussed include the construction of a power plant using other sources of renewable energy with equivalent electricity generation. Although a wind farm or biomass power plant is mentioned as a possible alternative, they are not considered feasible due to factors such as costly capital investment and uncertainty regarding their availability in the area. Therefore, the project focuses on renewable energy generation.

This section will demonstrate the additionality of the project in accordance with the “Tool for the

Step 1. Identification of Alternative to the project  activity consistent with current laws and regulations  
 
Sub-step 1a. Define alternatives to the project activity 
 
According to the status of China Power Grid, four alternative scenarios were c onsidered for the proposed 
project: 
Alternative Scenario (a), The proposed project ac tivity undertaken without being registered as a CDM 
project activity; 
Alternative Scenario (b), Construction of a fuel-fi red power plant with equivalent amount of annual 
electricity generation; 
Alternative Scenario (c), Construction of a power plant using other sources of renewable energy with 
equivalent amount of annual electricity generation; and 
Alternative Scenario (d), Continuation of the current s ituation. Electricity will con tinue to be generated by 
the existing generation mix operating in the grid. 
 Alternative scenario (c), power plant using other sour ces of renewable energy with equivalent amount of 
annual electricity generation could be a wind farm  or a biomass power plant in current technology 
conditions. A wind farm is not commercially viable due  to costly capital investment. There are some wind 
farms in the same area, however, some wind farms had been registered as CDM projects
2 and some wind 
farms are in the processes of registering as CDM project3. And it is not know there is a biomass power 
plant in the same area. So the altern ative scenario (c) is not considered as a feasible alternative scenario to 
the proposed project.  
Outcome of sub-step 1a : The realistic and credible alternative scenarios are scenario (a), (b) and (d).
